description:
This is one of my favorite non-ayce Korean restaurants in SF! The food is solid, and the dinner set menus are perfect for group gatherings.

The variety of Korean dishes are all done quite well. The meats are cooked well and there are a solid variety of side dishes. There are good options for individual order items as well. I enjoy their bibimbab, soft tofu stew, and the braised beef short ribs.

It's a great choice for lunch specials as well - fairly reasonable portions at a solid price. Great for a filling bibimbab order.

Service is super fast, but not always the friendliest perhaps unless you speak Korean. I would definitely plan on returning fairly regularly for a good Korean food fix.
author: Michael L.

description:
This is definitely one of my go-to places for Korean food in SF. I have been here multiple times for lunch and also for dinner. They are very reasonably priced and have delicious side dishes/banchan. I love that they have steamed egg sometimes that they give on the house and definitely love the sweet rice drink (sikhye) at the end of our meal. Lunch specials are great and also good portion! One of my favorites is the hot pot bibimbap. 

Parking is not too bad compared to the busier streets like Clement/5th or Geary/15th, but it is still street/residential parking. I have not had any bad experience with service. Also, every once in a while, you'll see Korean/Asian tour buses swing by with a group of tourists.
author: Sara T.

description:
I've been here many times and taste is consistent , service is ok, they're always pretty busy.

I have to say the radish Kim Chee and Kim chee and other ban chans are done right here.

The kalbi is always consistent here. 
I had the BBQ chicken here but I'd just stick with the beef.

I've been eating Korean BBQ in the Richmond for the last 10 years and this place definetly beats out brothers and kukje.

Some servers are nicer than others when asking for more ban chan and water.
author: Jenn C.

description:
For lunch I rate this place a 6 out of 5. OMG ... this restaurant is great for lunch! Really authentic and delicious Korean food at very fair prices.

7 wonderful side dishes are included with your main meal. Not only that but also free delicious tofu soup, tea and even a rice drink at the end of your meal.

I'm a fairly big eater and yet couldn't come close to finishing  my meal (#9 Haesanmul Dolsot Bibibap - chopped and sauteed shrimp, squid, octopus which comes to your table served in a super hot cast iron pot with rice and an egg on top). 

Price for all of it? $13! Amazing.

My wife also really enjoyed her meal (#11).

I highly recommend giving this great restaurant a try.
author: Vic M.

description:
This place was recommended by a couple of friends of mine. They said their bim bim bap is delicious! Tourists come from all over to taste it here!

 S E R V I C E:
Decent. Nothing special. The waitress was able to get all our dishes correctly with our allergies in mind, so that was great!

F O O D:
I ordered their bim bim bap in those crazy bowls that keep it hot forever haha. Instead of beef I asked for chicken, which was cooked very well. I felt like it was lacking some veggies, maybe more spinach. The egg was perfect and adding some of the kimchi and hot sauce to the mix was fabulousss! They also gave some tofu soup on the house that I wasn't able to try since I was so full! 

O V E R A L L:
Great place, I wouldn't mind coming back here!
author: Jaclyn M.

description:
MAKEE RESERVATIONS peeps! At least a day in advance since they don't do same day reservations. Was craving some Korean bbq and remembered my cousin recommended me this place cause she said it was the best she's had in the bay. Little did we know how BUSY good they are. My group of 6 arrived at 6:30 as a walk-in to put our name down and we immediately regretted it. The wait was about 1.5 hours + for the grill. We put our names down and just waited outside. After 45 mins passed, we checked  back in to find out that the wait for a grill was STILL 45-60 mins. Turns out the empty big tables with grills that we were all staring at for the longest time were taken by reservations. 

After an hour wait and still 7-9 parties away, we changed to table ordering with no grill. Within 10 minutes, we were seated. Thankkkk the lord! 

After being seated, we went beast mode and ordered wayyy more than our starved and shrunken bellies can handle. 
- jap chae 
- spicy bulgogi 
- non spicy Bulgogi 
- spicy short ribs 
- non spicy short ribs 
- steamed egg
- galbi soup 
- pan fried dumplings 

Needless to say, we had plenty of leftovers to take home! Everything was delicious and the banchan was yummy (my fav are the fish cake, kimchi, soybean sprouts, and radish) My favorite dishes were the jap chae, bulgogi, spicy short ribs, steamed egg, fried dumplings, and tofu soup! Almost everything was bomb:) I didn't really care for the non spicy bulgogi, it was a bit bland. This is also the first place I've been to that gives you a FREEE tofu soup! Didn't notice that until after that every table gets one. Woo hoo!! service was good despite how busy they were. They're quick and attentive.
author: Anissa D.

description:
This is one of my favorite Korean restaurants in SF. I came here on a recommendation from a friend and it did not disappoint. 

We got there relatively early and parked a couple of blocks away. We put our name down and it was a short wait. You can actually select on the reservations lists whether you want to grill your own meat or not. We did not and were happy to be seated in the corner near the window where we wouldn't get too stinky from other people's grills.

Their banchan is one of the best I've had - they gave big portions and they were happy to refill. 

There were only two of us and we were so hungry we overordered! 

Gyeran Jim (Steamed Egg): This came in a bibimbap pot and was temperature hot when served which was fine by me. I love anything with eggs and it went well with my rice. 

Dak Gul (BBQ chicken): You can never go wrong with a plate of BBQ chicken...it was tender and sweet from the marinade. 

Haemul Pajeon (Seafood pancake): I always like seafood pancake and I loved how perfectly fried this was. Crispy edges and soft on the inside with chunks of scallions and squid.

Bibim Naengmyeon (Cold spicy noodles): I've never had this before and was pleasantly surprised. There was sliced Sliced cucumber and sliced pork on top of the noodles. I mixed them all together and it was nice to have chewy spicy noodles with crunchy cucumber. 

They also gave us a small order of tofu soup for free which we loved as well.

Service was very efficient and the servers were good to check in on us to see if we needed anything else. 

I've since been back several times and will always be up for going here whenever I have a Korean food craving (which is quite often!).
author: Nette T.

description:
Favorite Korean place in the city!
(Long line every time...)
The food looks heavy taste but actually quite light (lighter than other Korean restaurants) 
The free side dishes are really good.
We ordered the beef rice and kimchi soup.
We think the Beef rice taste the same with or without hot plate. And I love the kimchi soup! Super good with rice and the side dishes!
author: Yantong Z.

description:
I love the kbbq here, particularly the kalbi. The ban-chan is great and allows me to order less food and save money :) 

The lines can be long but I always come earlier in the evening to avoid it (i.e., before 6pm). Parking in the Richmond is always tough but sometimes you just suck it up and drop someone off to put your name down while you search for parking.
author: Sophia L.

description:
This isn't the best korean I've ever had (could use more spice/flavor if you can believe it) but it's probably one of the best in SF, and our go-to when we've got a hankering for korean. There may be a wait and a to find parking, but once you sit down and order, you get a SERIOUS ban chan spread, which includes soon do bu!!

I always get the kimchi bokkeum with another dish of someone else's choosing (galbi, pajeon, naengmyeon). 2 dishes are usually good for 3 people since there's so much ban chan and the dishes are so generous.

Service is fast and friendly but you may have to wave down the waitresses for refills etc. because they're always running around!
author: Vivian H.

description:
This place did not disappoint! Food and service was great! Similar to all the other reviews, their selection of panchans/side dishes have a great yummy variety ranging from fish cake, bean sprouts, cucumbers, kimchee, squid kimchee, radish kimchee, takguan kimchee, seaweed salad, and more! I love a Korean restaurant that gives the good stuff!

TIP: make a reservation ahead of time! There are always a ton of people waiting in line, so make a rezy if you are able to! We got seated right away during our reservation time. 

TIP: you have to order two meat entrees to bbq at your table. They have set tables for bbq-ing and other tables don't have a grill. 

If you love Kalbi, I would recommend 2 orders of it instead of ordering another meat. Their kabli marinade is delicious! I know 2 orders sounds like a lot, but we definitely did not get sick of it and it was perfect! We were very full and satisfied with the 2 orders. 

I don't think you could go wrong ordering any of heir jigaes/soups. We got the simple kimchee soup and it was delish. The soup included plenty of pork in it too!
author: Janice C.

description: Upon my approach, I knew it was going to be good, with a waiting group of people and a full house.  Parking is few and far between, so I ended up parking two blocks away; not bad for San Francisco.  My party was already seated, so I needed to do is order, which is not as easy as I thought.  So much to choose from and so much Ban Chan, that I thought I would not be hungry after the appetizers.  No way though, after I ordered the seafood mix of rice and all types of ocean dwellers cut into bite size pieces.  It was both hot and spicy, just the way I like my food and everything else that matters in life.  The others went for the Bulgogi and Chop Chae which was developed during the Korean war. Long tables are shared with smaller groups, and everyone just joins in.  While the waiter was taking our picture, we were photo-bombed by the other group at our table; so fun when in groups!  Well, if you're looking for tasty Korean food in San Francisco, try this place, which is in a rather nicer area of San Francisco!
author: Stevo O.

description:
Please forgive me for being a rookie when it comes to Korean BBQ ! This is only my second time having Korean BBQ. With that being said the food was really good I had the short ribs and marinated beef along with rice and a ton of sides (if you like spicy food). Waitress were very nice. My co worker absolutely loved it and stated this is one of the best Korean BBQ spots in San Francisco. 

The first place I went too was on clement street in SF and was very popular on yelp but overall this place was better to me !
author: Mike H.

description:
Ok we love the food but the service was not great! We watched 5 tables seated after us receive banchan first and had to flag down a waitress to get ours. We had to ask a waitress where our food was after waiting hella long, but it turns out that our first order wasn't sent to the kitchen in the first place. So we had to order again! We asked for water 3 times, 3 separate occasions. Never got them! Honestly, the servers have good attitudes but I guess we caught them on a bad day.

We got spicy tofu soup and bibimbap. Portions were filling and tasty and were given gyeran-jjim on the house. We wish there were more options for tofu soup, there was only one : (. At the end, they served sweet fermented rice drinks. 

All in all we would totally return! Lines aren't too long for dinner (table of two) and worth it for good food and a friendly atmosphere!
author: Ben And Conna ..

description:
You know its a solid Korean joint when you see a Korean tour bus parked right outside. Han Il Kwan has some of the best Korean food I've eaten in SF to date.

The line can get long, but apparently they take reservations. We waited around 15-20 min to seat a party of four. There was plenty of space in the back but only some of the tables offer BBQ. The place can get busy so service can get a bit slow - I'm assuming this was mostly because we were seated at the back.

We loved the banchan, they offer mung bean jelly and the portions for entrees are quite large. The banchan is enough to start filling you up already! 

I had the Haesangmul Dolsot-Bibimbap which comes with sauteed shrimp, squid and octopus and it was very delicious! Probably the best bibimbap I've ever had so far. We also got steamed egg which was good. I tried some of the Bibim-naengmyeon and Japchae which I remember being quite memorable as well.
author: Chelsea W.

description:
Han II is alwaysss my favorite spot for some quality Korean foood! I LOVE everything on their menu except their dok bok kee which doesn't have fish cake in it.  I always go for their seafood pancake and Bulgoki! Very worth for the price.  

I will keeeep coming back for their complimentary tofu soup and side dishes
author: Shuyi L.

description:
Sigh...I really wanted to give this place 4 stars instead of 3, but the experience here was just not that great for me. We came with a large group of people, so we called ahead and reserved tables for table top bbq. Well I guess there was a confusion on their end and they just gave us a normal table and we just order food. MAKE SURE TO SPECIFY THAT YOU WANT TABLE TOP BBQ LIKE EXPLICITLY. 

There is a lot of people who would come here, most of them seems like from tour buses. They probably have a deal of some sort for them. I see tour buses come and go real quick. 

The food here was delicious. We ordered their set meals, and it was plenty of food. I would think most of the high rate reviews are for food only.

Service wise, I want to hope that it's because we're at the back the service wasn't as bad. We would often be forgotten. Water refills was slow. Tea hot water refill was none existent.
author: Drew R.

description:
This place never fails to impress. 
Consistently great flavor of good quality meats. 
Reasonable prices and a clean eating area. 
I've always had lunch here as it is much cheaper than dinner. 

Lots of great  yummy Banchan. 

Barley tea adds a nice touch. 

For anyone who loves Korean food this is a must eat at!

Tour buses full of Korean tourists stop here daily (except Wednesday when they're closed). 

Add a large Hite beee for the perfect lunch!
author: brian k.

description: The food are really really nice, and the waitress are super kind and nice, we ordered a lots of food, and ending up with To-go, I will come back for sure!!!!!
author: Jeff L.

description: Lunch special deals are super worth it. They were pretty busy so we waited for a while for our order to be taken, but it was alright. Banchan was good; my favorite is the fishcake. When our orders came, the waitress placed down a tofu soup and we just thought she was just putting it down for a second, but then she left. We were confused so we called over another waitress and she told us it was on the house! We're not sure for the reason, but it's was a nice gesture. Food was great; very filling, but I was able to finish all of it. For dessert, they gave us sikhye, a sweet rice drink, which I love. Shoutout @megs for giving me hers too :)
author: Elizabeth C.

description:
Only been here once but i already love it. Didnt get the the kbbq. Instead just for normal dishes. Got rhe galbi jjim, haemul pajeon and mandu. Everything was very good, especially the galbi jjim. Meat was plentiful and super tender. I highly recommend if you come here. The pancake was good but really thick. Mandu was seared to a crisp and very flavorful. Your meal also comes with a complimentary soondubu which is ok.

Service is good too. They pretty much leave you alone to eat, drink and chat.

Place gets super busy so i recommend coming early or late. Otherwise brace for the wait.
author: edward k.

description:
What the .... 
Guys. Remember to always keep your receipts and check your bank account !! 
This happened twice!!
They overcharge you and put in the another number than what you want your total to be (inclduding tips). This isn't the first time !! 
Seriously, I hope you guys get sued . Even though this is a good restaurant for lunch.. their integrity of putting a higher amount than what your actual total is is extremely cheating to customers !! 
Holy shit . Good thing I checked my bank account or else they are over charging me $15.00 !!
author: Anney T.

description:
We really enjoyed our lunch there.
They do have better deals during the weekday lunch deals 11-4 pm , their prices are higher otherwise

Their bibimbap (I probably butchered the name) are what I would recommend. yUM ! The beef and the seafood are the best two 

Their grills are great too, as you can cook at your table, if you ask for a grill booth/table 

Friendly staff and easy to walk-in! Very very hard parking
author: Jad A.

description:
The bonchon and quality of everything here is fuego but that comes with a price.  

The tofu soup is more expensive compared to other places but the broth is soo good.  Also the portions are definitely big enough to fill you up.  The only complaint of the seafood tofu soup was the crab.  The flesh stuck to the shell and wasn't fresh so it was difficult to pick the meat out of it.  Aside from that, I was surprised to see the vast arrangement of seafood (crab, scallops, octopus, shrimp) inside was more than just a couple pieces of cuttlefish.  

I love my veggies and the bonchon sizes are very generous!  There's a steamed egg that comes on the house too, score!  I also ordered the bulgogi and it was perfectly marinaded and tender.  It's a bit on the pricey end though ($28) but you get what you pay for.

Easily one of the best korean restaurants around SF.
author: Derek L.

description:
The morning was overcast and chilly. Starting the day off with hot, spicy stew sounded like an excellent idea. Soondobu (Korean Soft Tofu Soup) came to mind and Han II Kwan has been on my radar for some time and endorsed by Yelp. Located in a quiet residential neighborhood in Outer Richmond, parking can be daunting. You may need lots of karma like I did when a car pulled out just in time in front of a busload of Korean tourists. Boy! Did I luck out finding a space and a heads up that Han was jammed with Koreans!
 
The meal started off with the traditional array of banchan. Han surpassed most others in variety, all 9 of them, which were mostly flavorful. I've had better kimchi, but the savory anchovies and scrumptious fish cakes were fantastic! The sesame oil marinated bean sprouts and the spicy pickled daikon weren't too shabby either. (4/5) The lunch came with a complimentary bowl of homemade Steamed Eggs (3/5) just like mom's although hers was not the Korean version! Very hearty with rice!

The main event was Soondobu ($12), which fell a little short. It seemed like the soup needed to cook a little longer for optimum flavor. While a tad bland, (maybe sans MSG), it did hit the spot and warmed me up! Soondobu was a soft silken tofu stew cooked with other vegs (or seafood if you prefer), served in a small cauldron, that infused deep, robust flavors. It was missing a cracked egg where the yolk gave it a bubbling volcanic effect while enhancing the overall flavor. (3/5)

The next dish was both good and interesting but I was somewhat intrigued by the difficult to pronounce name. Daeji Bulgogi ($23) was a hot plate of thinly sliced pork loin that was blended with soy and gochujang (a well-known, well-loved Korean chili paste) and pan cooked. It was served with a side of lettuce, which was used to wrap the cooked meat. The pork was well marinated, tender, slightly sweet and garlicky. The lettuce added a crunchy texture to the meat and helped tone down its saltiness and spiciness. I thought this was just simply finger licking good! (4/5)
 
We finished the meal with something chewy, sweet and slightly slippery! No, nothing from the ocean! It is one of Korea's best-loved dishes.....Japchae noodles ($12)! The noodles were made from sweet potato starch and stir-fried in multi color veggies. It also emanated terrific wok hay, had an addictive sesame oil flavor with just the right amount of garlic. The Japchae noodles had a lovely springy texture and chewy strips of beef.  Who says Koreans are not into noodles like the Chinese? Maybe only just not as much! (4/5)

We encountered a team of super helpful and cheerful servers.  I would single out Jin as the lady with the sweet, perpetual smiley face.  She was very patient to answer our questions and describe any banchan dishes we were not familiar. The interior was simple and no frills and devoid of any kitschy artifacts. It was old school and designed like an open-air courtyard with pretty blue tiles.  And for the Korean tourists, the food would cure any homesickness and pep them up for the next leg of their tour.
author: Geoff G.

description:
If Asian tourist buses are dropping loads of people here to eat, it just has to be good. Seriously SF, touring tourists to restaurants now?!

SF doesn't have the best kbbq but this one is probably the best in the City. And the best "Asian" food is always in outer Richmond district, NOT Chinatown or Japantown. 

1. Always crowded and long lines
2. if possible, make reservations 
3. Marinated short ribs - a MUST

Deprived from crappy food in SD its nice to be back in SF eating really good food, decided to set up a dinner session with a small set of friends. Called couple days in advance to make reservations for 14 people - they accommodated. PARKING SUCKS like everywhere else in the city. We were seated on time to one of the large tables in the back which don't have grills. The food came out quick and we didn't smell like kbbq as we head out to the bars afterwards. 

We ordered ALOT of food - family style. For the six dishes we ordered it was enough to feed the entire table. Hot soup, marinated short ribs, bugolgi, pork belly, japchae, octopus salad, plus the bunchons dishes and our rice. Everything was average except the MARINATED SHORT RIBS! It was probably the best dish the put out. Good smokey flavor and tender with juices from the bone-in. The free bunchons were good, a lot of variety small plates. We also ordered two rounds of peach soju. Soju is a creeper!!! Overall good experience. HIGHLY RECOMMEND

Until the next review...
author: Jane A.

description: Good food and service. Really like this place because of the quality of meat. It's a bit pricey but if the service justifies it, I am on board with that. Recommend!
author: Kuan H.

description:
My friends and I, on a short getaway from LIFE to SF. After a hike, we just wanted FOOD! We were so hungry, but we also wanted to try KBBQ in SF. 
This is not an AYCE joint just so you are all aware. 
Menu - so many choices to choose from.  There's large family size dishes that is cooked in their kitchen and option to grill yourself as well. 
Guess what...for jus 5, we just ordered all the things. 

Our menu that day for lunch:
1. Marinated Beef Short Ribs OR Marinated Beef Rib Eye (sorry, forgot which one) - GRILL
2. Seasoned Prawns with vegetables - GRILL (I didn't eat it. I was trying to be good and not eat something I am only slightly allergic to. I didn't have my zyrtec with me that day)
NOTE: ordering grill food you get Steamed Eggs In A Hot Pot  as well. THAT SHIT WAS HUGE! also, the best I ever had as well. If it didn't come with it, we were going to order this anyways. 
3. Long-Boiled Beef Short Ribs with potatoes and carrots - from the KITCHEN (this is my favorite meal from this place. I ate this with rice and it is really good.  A bit sweet if eating alone but with rice, it is a great combination)
4. Kim-Chee Pancake - from the KITCHEN
5. Cold Noodle In Light Beef Broth with pickled radish, cucumber, and egg - from the KITCHEN

I feel like I am missing something but not quite sure.  We also got Soju and beer. Nothing new with that.

looks like i never posted the photo...dumbo me. shall post those soon!
author: Cindy CiCi L.

description:
This is probably a better kbbq place in the city. However, I won't wait in line for 2 hours to get it. 

I came to this place on Sunday at around 4 pm and there was no line. My boyfriend and I ordered spicy marinated galbi and marinated Boneless Chuck Flap. The galbi was pretty tasty but the meat was on the chewy side. I like eating it with lettuce and dipped in the bean sauce. We didn't like the Boneless Chuck Flap much. It was like spicy pork but with beef and the dish did not have much flavor.

I like the sides Han Il Kwan provided. There were around 10 small sides and I liked most of them. 

If I visit again, I probably will order kbbq that has been cooked by the restaurant. 

If you really like kbbq, I recommend to check out South Bay. So far, my favorite has been Jang Su Jang.
author: Clare L.

description:
We left here smelling like smoky BBQ, but no regrets. The food here is awesome and 100% worth the 40 min average wait time. It's probably the best korean BBQ I've had in SF and I was a little bummed I just found this place now. 

Also one of the highlights of this place is that they legit give you a small tofu stew in a stone pot for every table and has like 9 little small ban Chan dishes right before your meal. What's also great is that every single one of the little dishes is something EVERYONE likes and will finish (you know how you go to some places and they give you shitty ban chan things that nobody wants to eat? Yea not here!)

Man this place smells so good it'll have your mouth watering by the time you get to the table. The meat tastes great and the bulgogi seasoning is to die for. This place is a must go to while you're in SF!
author: Sophie P.

description:
Authentic enough that I'd come back to get a full Korean craving satisfaction!  Came here for linner (late dinner) on New Years Day and waited 30 min until we could sit down at 4pm.

Venue / service: restaurant is a bit on the smaller side given how crowded it was that day, with around an equal number of bbq vs. regular tables.  They do have more tables in a more private room, but they didn't use them too much when we came.  It was a bit annoying when they would sit people rather inefficiently (i.e. one person taking up a whole table meant for 4-6); wish they would have used table dividers like they do at some other restaurants.  Service was a bit on the slower side, but I can forgive them since there were fewer servers that day and they were going at a pretty good pace for so few workers on a busy day.

Food: smelled authentic when I came in, tasted pretty good to me!  Meal comes with banchan that you can ask for refills on when you finish them.
-- Tteok-guk (rice cake soup)($13) - ordered this in honor of the New Year.  Unfortunately, it was a slight disappointment, since the broth itself was quite flavorless.  Everything was cooked well; it just needed a LOT of salt or more anchovy / beef broth flavor.  Weakest dish of the meal.

-- Galbi-jjim (braised short ribs with potatoes and carrots)($27) - super flavorful to somewhat make up for the tteok-guk!  Sauce was rich in flavor and thankfully not too thick, and the galbi was very tender; enough to come off the bone but without being mushy.  Potatoes and carrots were very tender and had soaked up all the juices- I highly recommend dumping the sauce on your rice and eating it!  This one takes a bit longer so you should order other dishes while you wait for it.

-- Bindaetteok (mung bean pancake)($11) - one of my favorite dishes of all time and they didn't disappoint!  My date had it for the first time and simple as it looks, it turned out to be his favorite!  Chewy but still has texture and great mung bean flavor!  These patties are quite big and they give you 6-8 to definitely worth sharing.  

-- Steamed Egg custard (free with meal) - you have a choice between this or sundubu jjigae as a free side.  Very tasty and not overcooked- as simple as it gets.

With makgeolli ($15), the meal came out to little over $30 / person, which I'm happy with given the size of the dishes and how tasty they were!  This is at the top of favorite traditional Korean restaurants in SF; pity it's a bit far out to get to. T.T
author: Audrey H.

description:
Han II Kwan has very good korean food. Myself and four other friends ordered the dinner A set menu and we had a grand feast for dinner.

The dinner included:
- Marinated beef rib eye
- Marinated spicy pork
- Sauteed seafood with vegetables
- Jot stone pot bibimbap
- Battered and pan - fried shrimp, pollack and zucchini
- Japchae
- Broiled fish
- Tofu Soup
- Steamed Egg

My favorite items would be the marinated beef rib eye (bulgogi), marinated spicy pork and bibimbap. The marinated meats were very tasty and the bibimbap is absolutely wonderful when served in a hot stone pot. However, the broiled fish and battered/pan-fried items were not very good. They were extremely salty and were soggy when served to us.
author: Henry W.

description:
Meh. The meat was good but definitely did not make my top 5 list from my fair share of kbbq. This place gets packed though so i guess it works for those in the neighborhood. The ban-chan was okay, a lot of kimchi based things. They didnt have rice paper and didnt serve individual bean paste with oil. 

They didnt ask if we wanted to cook ourselves or have them cook it for us. I'd prefer to have a kbbq experience all about cooking it yourself so i was slightly disappointed. The meat was good though. Very tasty, tender, and seasoned well. The seafood pancake was also very good. The spicy tofu soup was good but the bowls they had were very shallow. 

Although we were stuffed by the end of the night, they should have an AYCE option in their menu. I dont recall any kbbq place that doesnt offer that.
author: Jenna T.

description: The ratings do not match the quality of this food. Nothing taste fresh. I'll let the pictures speak for themselves. This is how the food looked when it was first delivered. Seafood tastes very fishy and the bbq had no flavor and didn't come with any saugse
author: Christine A.

description:
This place gets packed and after dining here I can see why! The food is delicious. We ordered the mungbean pancake , pork stew, barbeque galbi, spicy rice cake. 

We enjoyed the galbi and spicy rice cake the most. We were not a fan of the port stew and would probably not order it again. The food came with an array of small dishes which were all good and a steamed egg dish that was perfect size for a party of 4. 

The service was on-point and the servers were attentive.
author: Hong L.

description:
You know this place is legit because all the Korean tour busses stop here. You can find Han il Kwan at the top of all the Bay Area KBBQ power rankings, and for good reason. The quality of meat is incredible and the banchan is fantastic. If it's not too busy, the waitresses will also cook your meat for you!

This place often has over 1-hour waits during peak dinner times, so come early to secure your spot. You won't find a more authentic Korean barbecue spot in the Bay!
author: Richie Z.

description: One of the better Korean Restaurant in the area. The marinated Gal-bi is juicy, tender and flavorful, and the pancake is tasty albeit much too oily, the complimentary steamed egg with rice was good too. The Japchae Korean noodles was a bit hit or miss.
author: William D.

description: One of my neighborhood favorites. However I would suggest going at lunch as you can avoid the long dinner time wait and get a break on their prices-which aren't cheap. Love the Galbi and the hot pot is a must try.
author: Matthew S.

description:
I've been to a couple Korean BBQ spots here in SF (there aren't a lot in SF for some odd reason) and I must say this is my favorite one.

The food and atmosphere here is probably the best of the Korean BBQ places I've been to. During dinner hours, this place can get chaotic and really busy, so I suggest getting here as early as possible or making reservations. The menu is standard for a Korean BBQ place. There's bibimbap (vegetarian options included), bulgogi, kim-chi fried rice, soju choices, soups, noddles, seafood pancakes, and dolsots of course. The food quality in general was really good and fresh. Prices range from $11-$30, so it's moderately priced. For a group of four we ended up spending about $120. 

I must say that one major thing is that their service was terrible! I mean horrible service is pretty standard for most places in SF, so it doesn't really bother me. Just remember do not expect them to cater to your every need. We ran into an issue where the guy calling out the names on the wait list skipped over our name and we had to wait 25 more minutes on top of the hour we already waited on. In addition, one lady should be given an Oscar for her acting performance of passing out just to get a table ahead of everyone else. So be as patient as possible, it is worth it afterwards.

All in all, food quality is what matters! And this Korean Spot is definitely one of the best and tastiest ones in SF.

Tip 1: Only street parking is available, so the parking is bad here! Just uber or carpool with someone else. We took about 25 minutes just to find parking. 

Tip 2: This place is awesome for groups of 3 or more. The atmosphere, the price, and for the amount of food you're getting, the experience is better shared with a group of people.
author: Oliver B.

description:
This is definitely one of the better Korean restaurants in SF - their taste is pretty authentic, and their banchans are AMAZING. The banchans were probably my most favorite part of the meal.

The portion sizes are also quite generous. I got the tofu stew, and my friend got dolsot bibimbap, and basically both of us boxed half our meal because there was just so much.

A lot of reviewers say there tends to be a long line, but when my friend and I went on a Sunday at 12:30pm, we were seated pretty quickly and didn't have to wait at all. Maybe we just got lucky!
author: Deborah L.

description:
I really wanted to like this place. I really did.

The banchan assortment was really nice. Everything you'd expect - kimchi, cucumber, seaweed, all the fixings. Opted for the soft tofu soup instead of the steamed egg. Be forewarned - it's not spicy!

The short ribs were sweet, in a good way. Marinated really well. Steep price at $32, but at least it was really good.

I'm just disappointed with the seafood pancake. Super doughy, it almost felt like it was undercooked. I like that they have octopus in there, though!

The barley tea was amaaaaazing. Very flavorful without being overpowering. I really liked the tea.

Service was subpar. At first we thought the waitress was annoyed because we only ordered two dishes between the two of us? Then I read other reviews and other people shared similar sentiments.
author: Vee B.

description:
Great korean food! 

Make sure you get their early our you will have to wait 45 min like I did with my friends for a Saturday night at 5pm. 

The side dish were probably the best I have ever had. 
Order: 
Seafood bibimbap ( really good, usually eat the beef but this had the right portion to seafood and rice which is rare) 
The oxtail soup ( takes awhile so order it when you get their if you really want it, super yummy worth the price) 

Service is not attentive especially when it is busy. Had to flag down the waiter multiples time just for water it more sides. 

Parking, 
Side streets since it's in sf.
author: Sochietta K.

description: Like this place for their Kalbi Jim! Really good in a fair price. Been to this place for so many times. One thing I don't really like it is a lot of Tour group come here for dinner makes the line a bit long. But still good with all their food.
author: Kay H.

description:
My new fave korean bbq spot in the city! Although they don't offer AYCE options, they do take pride on their family style and ala carte menus.

I would say it's more worth it for a 3+ group as the items on their menu are cheaper as a whole than what you would spend at an AYCE place, and may even be the same or more than what you will consume. Thumbs up for take out! If you're a party of 2 and would like more of a variety, I suggest an AYCE spot might be more suitable.

Our crowd faves would have to be the galbi, beef bulgogi, and beef brisket. Japchae was subpar and their tofu soup comes in many different spice levels. They do have an array of banchan and offer lettuce for your lettuce wraps! If they're not busy they also come by your table to cook the meat for you! Call in ahead of time to see if they can accommodate you for bigger groups! Overall, can't wait to return to this kbbq spot!
author: Jana V.

description: Came in on Tuesday around 5:45 and it wasn't very busy but by 6:30 there was a waiting list, so super thankful for coming before the rush! The staff were very sweet and kind! The portions were great AND free steamed egg or tofu soup!? AMAZING! All the food tasted great, I really recommend the fried dumplings and try their steamed egg! I would love to come again and try the cook your own bbq and their seafood pancake! Plus at the end of the meal they give you the sweet drink with rice on the bottom, not completely sure what it is called, but nonetheless it was so yummy and great to end the meal!
author: Linda N.

description:
While visiting SF in December, we made a last minute change to our dinner plans to come here, and I'm so glad we did! We went during their busy dinner time, so we had to wait for almost an hour. It was definitely worth the wait. 

I ordered the mixed vegetable bi bim bap with beef and loved it! The flavors of the vegetables, rice, and beef all blended so well together. My boyfriend ordered the raw, minced beef, and I'll be honest, I was a little hesitant to try it, but I was pleasantly surprised. The sauce and crunchy vegetables of the dish complemented the raw beef so nicely. If you're looking for a great Korean restaurant, give this place a try!
author: Edith Q.

description:
Service was so great-very kind. I was seated with my boyfriend very quickly.
Clean atmosphere.
I really loved the small dishes-they refilled quickly and there were so many. Delicious.
They gave us a complimentary soup too with beef  thank you
author: Gloria Z.

description: It's weird I don't think I've ever been to a Korean place that I've felt like was just meh but there's a first time for everything I suppose? I'll commend the service first because our waiter was pretty efficient and checked in on us frequently (questionable friendliness but not so much that it bothered anyone). However, the food was just ok..and for the price, I expect it to be outstanding. The bulgolgi ($27 for a normal size dish!!!) lacked in flavor and was extra oily. The tofu hot pot didn't come with the freshly cracked egg that most places do and again, lacked in flavor. The seafood bibibap ($17 I believe) wasn't awful, but was, again, on the oiler side, and felt like it was missing flavor. The one plus was that it was pretty loaded with seafood so I didn't feel too jipped there. The bonchon (side dishes) are not bad, pretty standard (although they don't include japchae!), favorite was the marinated bean curd slices. They're good about giving refills as well. Also, like other ppl have said, the complimentary tea (barley and corn) is unique and tasty. All in all however, I think I'd pass on coming here again. The dishes we tried weren't impressive enough to convince me.
author: Tammy Y.

description:
Not AYCE, but great meat at a fair price. For a group of 4, ordering 3 plates of meat was enough, and way cheaper than forging ourselves at other, lesser-quality AYCE joints. 

I'd recommend the marinated galbi, it is delicious here. Don't forget to ask for the soft tofu stew or steamed egg, it is complimentary with the meat! 

We came in for lunch on Saturday. It was fairly quiet and there were plenty of bbq tables open, so there was no wait. However, it is street parking only, and parking on the streets in this neighborhood is always a hit or miss for me. 

I'll be back! Great quality food and quick service.
author: RachEl L.

description:
My brother and his wife brought us to this restaurant because when they tried this place they really loved the food here.  We choose to visit on a weekday around 6pm hoping that there would be less of a wait because on the weekends sometimes the wait can be upwards of an hour.  We didn't have to wait at all, and were able to be seat immediately.

Once we ordered we received the (banchan) small plates fairly quickly and started snacking on them, each place was delicious.  We tried several different dishes and each was better than the next.  We had an Oxtail marinated stew, bulgogi, Tofu soup, bibimbap and seafood pancake.  I really enjoyed the tofu soup with the white rice, I normally don't eat white rice but with the tofu mixed with the rice it was like a porridge and mixing in some bonchan bean paste it had the right amount of spicy and salty. 

My brother wanted to order the oxtail stew right away because it can take about 20-30 minutes to make so he place the order right away. So we were able to get the ox tail at the same time with everything else.  Everything was very delicious.  We had plenty of food left over for the next day and it was just as good the next day.

Parking can be a bit tricky, because you'd have to try to find a spot in the nearby neighborhoods and walk to the restaurant. I would love to come back and visit again the next time I visit SF.
author: Karen C.

description:
This is a very good Korean restaurant. I came here by myself and ordered a short ribs plate on the BBQ section. It comes with rice and a soup. In addition, it will serve you many small dishes. Here, you will be treated as a king and eat like a pig. I mean, eat a lot of good stuff. 

I was thinking to order a fish, but just the short ribs got me very full. Sorry, I left a few plates and the soup haft full. It was just too much food and I usually eat a lot. 

The price is great for the amount of food and the service.
author: Alberto W.

description:
I came here on a weeknight for dinner with a friend. I heard about this place for quite some time now and I finally got the chance to try this place out!

Food - We wanted a light dinner so we ordered a bibimbap and the cold noodle in light beef broth with cucumbers, beef slices, radish and egg. 

*Bibimbap - We ordered the one on a clay pot and I am happy this dish was good! 
*Cold noodle dish - I didn't like this dish at all. The broth had ice and flavorless. It came with half an hard boiled egg, a few pieces of beef slices, cucumber and radish. It was hard for us to finish this dish so we barely touched it at all.
*Complimentary banchan - I do like their banchans! There are 9 different types total and my favorite was was the tiny fish! 

Service - The waitresses were really friendly. When I was mixing my bibimbap together, a waitress walked by and asked to do it for me which I thought was nice.

Ambiance - There is the main dining room and a private room. I saw a tour bus full of people going in. If you come on a weekend night, there is probably a wait since the restaurant itself is not too big.

Overall, I wouldn't mind coming back but I would preferably try other korean places if I am in the area. I didn't like the cold noodle dish we ordered but I am still willing to try their other dishes since I probably ordered the wrong dish and I don't want that to ruin my experience here. I do want to try their bbq dishes, however it looked pretty expensive since I can get really good kbbq elsewhere. Overall, so it is a 50/50 experience for me.
author: Allie Y.

description:
Food: Their food is amazing! The meat is cut to the perfect thickness for their grills - everything came out so tender and juicy! They have a delicious and great selection of sides (banchan). Have also tried their tofu soup, and it was perfect.

Service: Went twice last fall, and the service was ok because it was difficult to get their attention for ordering and refillls. Both times, their waitresses looked stressed - I got the impression they were having particularly busy or lousy days.

Atmosphere/Location: Very clean for BBQ, grills are great, and there is street parking.

During peak hours (like Friday nights), the wait can be very long (easily 30-45 minutes).
author: Michelle B.

description: Service is too bad and needs improvement，Pork belly is too dry, poor produce！I came here with friends at noon yesterday to try this Korean food. My friend introduced the food here very well but when I tried to feel that the food was generally poor service, there was an old waitress who ordered my seat food but did not repeat Confirming my order, I will leave when the food comes up. The order is wrong. When I asked for a replacement, the woman gave me a face that felt like I was wrong. I don't know if it's her English or what caused me. I don't understand why. Such a person can serve as a service agency. I don't want to go back to this place.
author: Billy L.

description: I went to many Korean restaurants in China, South Korea and US. Han II Kwan is the first one also offer free soup. Both the food and service are so good here!
author: Eavan Z.

description:
I really like this place! The food choices and flavor of their meat and marinade were so good! 

It gets busy, so you'd have to wait a little but that's a testament to how worth it their food is. Love their banchan offerings too! We did the self bbq option with their rib eye, seasoned vegetable with prawns and tofu soup. we had a lot of left overs cause their were just 2 of us. 

Service was also great - they were on top with changing our grill and topping of our beverages. 

Nothing but a great experience and left very full!
author: Sol P.

description:
Not the greatest kbbq joint in the bay area by far but the best one in the city!!

1. They take reservations. Don't make the mistake of just showing up assuming you won't have to wait. They get really busy plus they constantly have giant tour busses of Koreans coming to visit. It's that popular. 

2. Closed every Wednesday. 

3. If you do kbbq must order a minimum of 2 meats.  It is not AYCE. 

4. Meal comes with a bowl of soondubu. Menu says it offers a choice of either soondubu or steamed egg but I've never gotten the option of the steamed egg in all the years I've been coming here. I've also never asked.

5. You come here for the food not the service. 

6. Only joint in the bay I've found that gives the sweet rice dessert drink. Yay! 

7. Good selection of banchan. A lot of joints only bring like 4-6 sides. They definitely bring at least 10. 

8. Come hungry.
author: Mandi W.

description:
Visited this restaurant today based on IG recommendations.  Here's my take.
Fish cake was a treat, If you know Korean food you know that encountering a Korean restaurant with authentic Fishcake is always a treat, they only offer it when they have it. Difficult to find! (4/5)

Japchae was my favorite dish of all the dishes. Flavorful not too many onions, love the variety and balance of vegetables (4/5)

Spicy Bulgogi, disappointing.  Not spicy at all!  I was hoping for the occasional pop of spicy from a jalapeño, but the spiciness was very underwhelming! I've had better, and overall bland (2/5)

Ban Chan was great, traditional and included fish cake so that was a + (4/5)

Kimchee Jjigae 3/5 

Our stove kept turning off and the server had to keep coming back to relight.  Customer service, I don't know what it is about Korean restaurants, but I've yet to encounter one with great customer service.  They all seem to be bothered when asked a question (1/5)
author: Ricco D.

description:
Very difficult to find parking nearby. Prices are fairly high, $16 for dolsot bibimbap. And it's very busy. But the food is delicious. Decently varied selection of banchan, including kimchi, bean sprouts (kongnamul), diced radish kimchi (kkakdugi), stir-fried anchovies (myulchi bokkeum), seaweed salad (miyeok muchim), fish cakes (eomuk bokkeum), and choice of a big pot of steamed egg (gyeran-jjim) or a small tofu soup (soon dubu). 

They take reservations over the phone, allowing you to skip the line in-person.
author: Julia C.

description:
This is probably one of the best and most authentic Korean restaurants in San Francisco! Been coming here ever since we discovered it upon moving back to SF in 2016.  Previously back in the day, my place was always one of the Brothers restaurants but when we moved back I found that the quality of the food is no longer as good as it once was.  After a few more times, we decided it was time to find somewhere new.

Han Il Kwan is off the beaten path in a quiet residential part of the outer(ish) Richmond.  There is often a wait but during the week, you can usually find a table with a short wait time, maybes 5-15 minutes.  God help you on the weekends.  We've waited an hr before.  There are no decent bars nearby.  Not even good dive bars so waiting around here sucks.  The restaurant gives you the option of both cooking at the table and having them cook it for you in the kitchen.  But if you aren't familiar with K-food, give cooking at the table a try.  They'll help you too.  Note the funny receipt when you cook yourself: "Cook at table.............$0".  Lots of LOLZ for this. 

The ladies who work here are great.  From the older waitresses, just the right amount of "sternness" you would deserve from the Korean aunties you never had (or do have!).  They don't have time to wait around for you to go the through the menu asking questions.  Peruse, then ask.  Korean BBQ dining is not for chatting or having a laugh with the waitresses unless they know you or you are a regular.    I have found the younger waitresses are more patient, "nicer" and speak clearer English (for those of you who have trouble with accents).  Not to say that the aunties are not nice, just stern.  Maybe you need to be past your mid-forties to graduate to a finger-wagging aunty. That said, the aunty waitresses are super efficient and will basically just take over if they see you cooking incorrectly or if you appear to be out of your depth.  One time I took my Dad and he prematurely tried to turn over some Kalbi before it was ready and the waitress [lovingly] smacked his hand with a stern "not yet". LOVE THIS PLACE.

I have read that they can accommodate people with allergies which is great, but I would heed my previous advice and try to be as prepared with your questions as possible.  I personally feel that people with self-diagnosed restrictions such as "gluten-intolerance" should just expect gluten to appear in most places like this- unless of course they have celiac disease.....or something else that's REAL. I feel most good Asian restaurants in general, unless they are new wave, fusion, trendy or expensive, will not be gluten free or accommodate allergies. So that this place WILL is a wonderful! I've got a friend who self diagnoses herself as gluten intolerant, has to go over each item on the menu WITH the waiter, is particularly picky about "cross-contamination" and has to have tamari soy sauce, not normal soy sauce.  I won't be taking her here. 

The food here is excellent.  Admittedly I am no longer adventurous with Korean BBQ bc I KNOWS WHAT I LIKES. I'm just a creature of habit.  The banchan (small side dishes) are just great here and I tend to "graze" on those all night long.  They don't give you as many options as some other Korean restaurants, but the kimchi and other various pickles here are legit. Plus they are generous on the refills! They also give you a choice of steamed egg custard "Gyeran jjim" or a spicy tofu "Jjigae" stew.  You can specify, so if you have a pref, ask.

We always get a Pajeon "seafood pancake" but if you don't eat seafood they have other versions.  I personally love Kimchi Jeon too! I also find it compulsory to order Jap Chae, a "low calorie" noodle dish, most aptly compared to eating heaven.  It is not questioned when Jap Chae is order at our table.  

Most importantly, meat-wise: if you are not adventurous or are set-in-your-ways like me, I would recommend the beef kalbi, the daeji bulgogi and perhaps the pork belly if you are particularly hungry.  These 3 choices of meat combined with the other dishes I mentioned is more than enough for 4 hungry people, especially if they are drinking Beer or Soju with dinner.  

Last time we ordered this "basic", there were 4 of us and we went home with lots of leftovers.  Keep in mind, we destroy the banchan, ask for refills and wrap out meat in the provided lettuce leafs.   This best way about eating like this is that you get the gristly richness of the meat,  the fresh crunchiness of the lettuce and pickles and the simple steamed rice, which makes for a very balanced combination of flavors.  Of course you have the other dishes as well which gives you some excellent additional varieties of flavours and textures!

Happy eating, you won't be disappointed with this place!
author: Adrian C.

description:
The most conspicuous thing about Han Il Kwan is not the cloud of bulgogi-scented smoke surging from its outdoor vents. Nor is it the puzzling enigma that is their name (is it Han 2 Kwan or Han 'ill' Kwan?). No, the most conspicuous thing about Han Il Kwan is the gigantic tour bus that is always waiting by its door.

Princess Carewee and I walk by Han Il Kwan quite often, and witnessing a hoard of tourists being ushered into the restaurant has become quite a regular sight. As #blessed as I have made my life look on the gram, I have actually had some unfortunate experiences in traveling with a tour group. And from these pitiful experiences, I know very well for a fact that these tour groups bring you to the crappiest restaurants in town. Thus, that humongous tour bus always appeared to me as a "DO NOT COME HERE" sign. So I just never went to Han Il Kwan.

That was until one afternoon, when my homie Colin M. invited me to lunch.

"How about Han Il Kwan?"

"Oh you mean Han 2 Kwan?"

"Yeah, maybe, that one Korean place at the corner? With that tour bus parked outside?"

"Oh yeah I know that one. Uhhhh you sure you want that place?"

"Yeah man let's go."

We arrived inside Han Il Kwan a little bit after 12. There were no tourists today, but the restaurant was still filled with a healthy number of other patrons. That was my first time inside, and the Korean style décor already had me impressed. When we were seated by the booth, we were given the option of having cooked dishes, or doing KBBQ.

"KBBQ!" I blurted. 

Mama ain't raised no fool. There's not a lot for the restaurant to mess up on if the meats are uncooked. The quality may be shotty, but at least I can somewhat control the flavors.

Within 10 minutes of the Korean small dishes, the meats arrived. The chicken looked tender and soft. And the pork belly, well, that was a marbled-marvel. Colin M. must have saw the surprised look in my eye, so he grabbed my attention.

"Looks good, huh? Give me 2 to 3 minutes to fix you something amazing."

Colin placed 2 pieces of the pork belly on to the grill. It sizzled at the touch. The fat oozed out bubbles of oil, releasing an aroma that made my mouth water. After a brief period, he turned it over with the tongs, revealing a side of perfectly charcoaled belly fat. It was a sight to behold.

When the meat was finished, Colin placed it on a green leaf of lettuce. He sprinkled some rice, added a dab of kimchi, and wrapped it all up. He handed it to me, along with a shot of Soju.

"Here. Eat this in one bite. The pork belly carries very heavy flavors, so the Soju serves as a perfect complement to the after taste. I call this, The Lettuce Shot."

I put the Lettuce Shot into my mouth. The flavors from the pork belly exploded through the lettuce. The rice blended with the flavor, but offered itself as another texture in the experience. The kimchi splashed in a taste of pickled spice, completing the package. I threw down the Soju shot immediately after. The subtle flavors in Soju is accentuated amidst the saltiness of the Pork Belly after taste, leaving a pleasant sweet sensation. The burn of the alcohol all but disappeared from all the oil of that one bite. It was awesome. The Lettuce Shot was awesome.

So Colin M. and I spent that afternoon doing Lettuce Shots in Han Il Kwan. It was one of the more enjoyable lunches in recent memory. After the meal, the waitress served us this small cup of sweet soup, which was an ideal ending to such a heavy lunch. I was wrong, so wrong. Han Il Kwan (definitely "ill") was great.

I learned an important lesson that day. In addition to never judging a book by its cover (which I do), you should also never judge a restaurant by the giant tour bus parked outside (which I don't anymore).
author: Ringo M.

description:
Went here on Saturday, January 27th around lunch time 12 ish. Made it just on time before it got really crowded! 

We ordered: 
*seafood pancake 5/5
*spicy rice cakes 3/5 
*2 bibimbaps 4/5 

I really loved how the restaurant looked inside! 
Staff was a little bit slow but it was crazy busy! But they checked up on us a good amount of time.

The side dishes are so yummy, 5/5. Never been to a Korean restaurant with that many side dishes. 
Only sad downside is that they don't do the lunch specials / beef plates on weekends:( but Ima definitely come back for that! Or maybe even try the BBQ, which looked good too. 
A good place to bring your family or a big group!
author: Cindy T.

description:
Han Il Kwan offers authentic Korean BBQ or family style food for a reasonable price. 

I had the family style meal here. It was $150 for a veritable mountain of food. We got spicy pork, bulgogi, some bibimbap, japchae, and some more stuff. It was all pretty delicious and incredibly filling. I could barely walk afterwards because I couldn't help stuffing my face. My only complain was that the service was mediocre and that the banchan (sides) were quite lacking

If you do the family style meal, definitely take 6-7 people. My group of 5 could not finish the whole meal.
author: Neivin M.

description: Came here around 6:45, waited about 20~mins. There were a lot of empty tables but they were reserve for korean tours. That's you know a restaurant is good the bonchons were great and it came with free tofu soup! The tofu soup was a little flavorless but it was free, can't complain about that! We also got the galbi but it was on the pricey. But everything was yummy, especially the spicy cold noodles! Will definitely be coming soon!
author: Emily H.

description: We had a party of 8 and was seated fairly quickly. I think only because most people came in parties of 2-4. Hot roasted rice tea was already waiting for us when we were seated. We ordered the Dinner B which was good for 8 people and was perfect for our group. The side dishes came out fast. Almost as soon as we finished the side dishes, our main course started rolling in. Staff were busy but courteous. We had a great time. Packed two boxes of left overs back to the hotel. Food was great. Our biggest issue was parking. We had to park three blocks away. That's SF for you though. Still 5 stars.
author: Mike C.

description:
SF is in dire need of more good Korean food. Han Il Kwan is a great step in making that more of a reality!

Right now I'd consider Han Il Kwan to be the best KBBQ in the city.

1) They can get busy, so come early or be prepared for a wait.
2) Great price! Sign me up!
3) The food is delicious! I can still remember how happy my taste buds were with the brisket
4) The staff is very friendly, albeit also very busy and may forget some of your orders... (be patient and don't be afraid to remind them)
5) It's smokeless vacuum grill! This means the smoke gets sucks down which means less of a kbbq smell and no vent in your face when you're eating.

I'd recommend this place for anyone who wants to eat KBBQ in the city.
author: Randy L.

description:
You know this place has legit Korean food if a tour bus of Koreans from Korea are eating here. I literally said "Horray!" when I saw this. 

It was a 35-45 minute wait on a week night (around 6pm) for a party of 3. Thankfully my sister and I occupied ourselves with some beer as the turnover at each table felt excruciatingly slow. The space here is relatively large for SF with a back room to accommodate larger parties. Even such, our tummies rumbled and we just kept sipping on more beer until dinner time.

Here's what we ordered:

Seafood bibimbap: pretty standard but the flavors were robust. The combo of crispy stone burned rice, sweet and hot red sauce, egg, and bits of seafood always wins.

Dok boki: simple and ideal as comfort food. The rice cakes were shaped like tubes (as opposed to flattened slices) and incredibly moist and chewy. The sauce was also sweet and spicy, but a thicker consistency to dress the rice cakes.

Seolleongtang: I get bamboozled every time I get this. What looks to be a clear, and perhaps "lighter" soup is a flavorful bone broth with large beef chunks, complete w bones. The meat itself could use a longer cooking time as it wasn't quite "fall off the bone" just yet, but the taste was there.

Banchan: The darn spread was beautiful. Little offerings that appeared fresh and in their prime. I really felt like the actual composition of dishes was less important as everything just tasted delicious.

I'll be back, but just not at 6pm.
author: Cici T.

description:
I'd give this place like a 3.5. High-quality Korean barbecue at a reasonable price is a tough find in SF but this place is one of the few that manages to provide some decent quality meats with lots of banchan (side dishes). Tofu soup that came with the meat was bleh but whatever.

Reasons why I didn't dig this restaurant as much despite decent meat quality:
-The parking here is absolutely atrocious because the restaurant is just plopped in the corner of an entirely residential area. We drove around for like 15 minutes trying to look for a spot in the surrounding neighborhood.
-Seating patrons took an unbelievably long time. There were at least 6 tables that were empty and waiting to be used but the host in charge of seating people was taking his sweet jolly time making his rounds picking up random cups from different tables instead of actually getting people seated. ?????? 

Anyway food was fine.
author: David Y.

description:
Came back again!  A korean restaurant located on Balboa.  Got seated right away & the customer service was excellent. A lil pricey to have kbbq but def worth it!! + you get free tofu soup & all the yummy side dishes! 
Ordered: gal-bi ($32), bulgogi ($26), seafood pancake w/out shrimp ($17)
author: Mikayla M.

description:
Han Il Kwan is a great option if you want delicious authentic Korean in the city. It's on the pricey side. I've eaten here multiple times, but had good experiences so far.
Most recently came here on a Friday night. My friends and I called and made a reservation two weeks in advanced for a party of 7 ppl total at 7pm. They seated us on time even when our party was not completely here! We ordered Set B menu for large groups - $180 (w/ tax or tip). 
First impressions: HOLY MOLY this is a LOT of food. Portions were definitely big enough for our group and we still had leftovers. And EVERYTHING was good quality. 
Highlights: BANCHAN is delicious. Large variety (about 10 dishes) and I love, love, love the cucumbers and kimchi banchan. Meats were marinated well...so delicious. Tofu soup had soft and silky tofu and enough spice to the point where I could enjoy it without crying. Bibimbap was also good!! Sizzling seafood plate was also delicious and loved the scallops that tasted like small marshmellows or mochi melting in my mouth. The sikhye, rice beverage, comes at the end as a dessert free of charge. It's very sweet and was a good way to end the meal.

Downside? PARKING. Omg. Parking in the neighborhood really sucks but you can find something along Fulton or closer towards 15th ave. Service was fast, attentive, and efficient, but not always friendly.
author: Debby N.

description:
This place is awesome but can get packed quick. We usually go with the Vermicelli and a bi bim bab. With beer and all the ban chan (did I spell that right?) it's the best place in the neighborhood. 

Haven't done bbq here because the tables are always packed. Probably the best sign of how good it is.
author: Nick H.

description:
Boy, what can I say about Han Il Kwan.. except that it was absolutely delicious and fulfilling. First time I've been here and one of my new favorites. A few big positives of more (I call them the 4 pillars of Han Il Kwan): 1) Great service, quick, kind (got a dish on the house!), and very easy-going. 2) You will never leave here hungry - ban chan madness in this restaurant. I distinctly recall 10 different plates. 3) delicious ingredients - I really enjoyed the house bibimbap and the spicy beef bulgogi. Everything tasted fresh authentic. 4) alluring smell as soon as you walk in. Like a sirens song, you are drawn into Han Il Kwan from 100 ft down the road. 

This place was totally worth a try. Will be back again.
author: Chris O.

description:
Although on the pricey side the food here never disappoints and this is why I'm giving this place 5 stars. Brought my friend here for his bday and he even said one of the best kbbq he's had in SF.

For the food must tries: 
-marinated short ribs!!!!!- last time I ordered 3 orders of this. very flavorful and tender!Wasn't burnt or under or over cooked. Just the perfect amount of cooked.
-Pork belly: super yummy and chewy. Went well with the rice and japchae we ordered 
-Japchae: noodz/ meat /veggies were all delicious making my full self want more even though I wasn't capable of eating more. 
-steam egg is always good!!
- bon Chan is BOMB so much different variety from rice paper with lettuce to little dried fishes to kimchi to fish cakes. All very delicious and you can ask the waitresses for more if you run out! 
-disclaimer although the food is delicious it does come with a price which is around 30 dollars a plate. It's a lot of food but just you do have to pay for the amount and the quality 
-in the end good service good food and also good soju that went down smoothly so definitely will be coming back for more of a big event or celebration since it is quality food but a bit expensive!
author: Leslie F.

description:
This restaurant looks like a Korean palace on the outside, and the motif continues on the inside decor. Makes a you feel fancy! 

We came at 7PM on Saturday, and waited less than 30 minutes, so it wasn't that bad. The food also came out pretty quickly as well. The staff was definitely pretty busy given how lit this restaurant was, so it took a bit of extra work to flag them down for service. They will cut the meat and get the process started for you (if you do self cook). 

We really, really enjoyed the meat, which was the highlight (and the most expensive!) part of the meal. The kalbi marinade was absolutely on point, and the spicy pork was thin and delicious. They gave alot of fresh, yummy small plates with lots of variety. The seafood pancake was also another favorite: it's much thicker than alot of other Korean pancakes I've had (and not charred at all!). I think the sundubu soup (listed under hotpot!) was pretty small, and the meaty flavor really came through, but maybe it lacked some kimchi? It wasn't the best.  We also got a naengmyeon (cold noodle), but we all thought it was pretty bland, which might just be the nature of Korean cold noodles. 

Overall, I'd say the meat was definitely worth it, 100%. Given how much food we got, the bill wasn't outrageous either, especially for Korean BBQ, which tends to run pretty pricey. I had a great experience, looking forward to coming back.
author: Ke C.

description:
This is probably my favorite Korean restaurant in the city! Parking can be quite a nightmare so you just have to keep driving around until you see something. Just don't be one of those people blocking someone's driveway.

There is a super long wait here during peak hours, so be prepared to wait. But if you do bare the wait, it is a delicious place for Korean food. The service here is nice and friendly. You have an option to either grill food yourself or have them grill for you and bring to your table. The location itself is a good size. They have a back room for larger parties.

We get the usual Korean picks like grilled chicken, ribs, bibimbap, seafood tofu soup, and braised beef. They also give plenty of side dishes. Get the complementary steamed egg! My favorite is the braised beef. It is cooked perfectly and it's such comfort food. At the end of the meal, they give you a sweet rice drink for dessert.
author: Michael T.

description:
Second time here. Brought my mom here for Mother's Day Pre-Dinner. The wait was long as we didn't realize this was a popular place and reservations would be needed. First time I came, we were seated right away! 

The food was amazingly delicious, very generous with the food portions, the appetizers have so many different flavors and textures, incredible service staff who were very attentive to our needs and requests. The seafood pancake was so good! The place was so busy, we closed out the restaurant as we were the last ones to leave. 

Nothing but good things to say about this place! We love korean food as a family, so it's nice to enjoy authentic food! Thank you!
author: Ruthie M.

description:
I know why the hoards of tourist buses stop here on their way through San Francisco now. The food is not just great, but probably the best Korean option in the Bay Area. 

The menu is a la carte but the quality is much better. And if you have a large party, ordering here gets you just as full for about the same amount of money as the AYCE places. Han Il Kwan gets their ban chan right. There are so many different little dishes that you can fill up on these alone. And they're all good! My favorite has to be the kimchi with squid, scallions and raw onions. It's drenched in pepper paste so I used it to flavor my ssam creations.  

But let's rewind and begin with the appetizers. Spicy rice cake good. Seafood pancake good. Japchae good because they added beef and it came out pretty hot still! Usually other places give you the cold version which feels like they bought it at the local market.  Now for the mains! Galbi good. Spicy pork bulgogi good. Pork belly good. Chicken good. Even the chicken was good and I normally refuse to eat chicken at Korean BBQ places out of my sheer pride to only eat beasts with four legs. 

They do let you cook if you have a large party and are ordering a good amount; otherwise they will cook in the kitchen and bring to you on a cast iron skillet. To be honest, I regretted being the designated cook for our party because I couldn't eat as much since I had to pay attention to the meats. Luckily, the nice wait staff came by and recognized my distress and offered to help us cook the rest of our meal. She's the real MVP.
author: Quoc N.

description: Expect to be waiting long. Came in on a Saturday afternoon after 4:30ish and it was a mistake. DO NOT...I REPEAT DO NOT COME late because there are loads and loads of tour bus groups and you will have to wait, but definitely well worth the wait. Food was good...it was my family and I's first time so next time we go we know to come earlier and we would know to order 1 meat dish and 1 noodle or soup dish, because food although seems like a small portion it was enough to feed a family of 4. The banchan are apart of the meal and everyone is given a bow of rice. We got a complimentary bowl of steamed egg courtesy of the staff due to having to wait long. Other than the wait this place is a must try. I will come back again next time.
author: Tina L.

description: Service was amazing and the portions were big. We ordered non-marinated beef and sullongtang for two, but couldn't finish it - we ended up taking left overs to-go and these will be our lunch for tmrw :) Finding parking out here is awful, so make sure to Lyft! I love the refreshments at the end! Come to Han Il Kwon if you want to try some good sf kbbq.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Hailing from the land of Southern California (for my formative years, at least), KBBQ was a solid staple in my diet. While I can't say I was thrilled by the concept of AYCE meat, the ice cream offered afterwards at places like Flower Pig or Cham Sut Gol kept KBBQ as a meal of comfortable, delicious comfort.

Operating on a protein-based diet these days, KBBQ made sense for a recent weekend dinner. I called in reservations a few days in advance for a Saturday night with no issue, and conveniently arrived right after a large busload of Korean tourists were taken away. Choice of seats, hurray! 

Aim for one of the covered tables with a grill, and you'll be set.

THE OVERVIEW.
+ Fast service, even when they get slammed. Also, quality service - not a single server forgot any request we had (we made the mistake of asking 3 different servers for more banchan, and received 3 additional sets - yum!)
~ It's a bit pricey, but the quality of the meat is delicious. It's not AYCE, but who wants the meat sweats anyways?
+ Good selection of soju and other drinks

Delicious dinner, best if enjoyed in a group or 3 or more. Also, at 8 pm on a Saturday there was a line out the door, so come early or make reservations!
author: Claire S.

description:
I am pretty pleasantly surprised by my visit here. As a Korean, my standards for Korean restaurants are pretty high. Typically when I visit a Korean BBQ place, I'm disappointed with at least one thing. I enjoyed everything here (besides the slight rudeness of the woman who called you for your table). 

We ordered bulgogi and chadol for our meats. The meal comes with an assortment of banchan and either soondubu or steamed egg (we opted for the soup). We also ordered the bibimnyangmyun (spicy, cold buckwheat noodles). Pretty amazed that I didn't find any of the food items to be a let down. At the end of the meal, they give you shikhae (traditional Korean sweet rice dessert drink). Typically you'll only find this at an authentic Korean joint. 

Overall, I'm pretty impressed with this place and I'll definitely be back when I'm in SF. (P.S. The service becomes all of a sudden more attentive and nice when you start speaking in Korean).
author: Joanne Y.

description:
This is probably the best korean bbq spot in San Francisco. I don't know why but there are not that many (great) korean restaurants in SF!

Meat quality here is great but service is terrible... like most things in San Francisco :)

No length review needed here. Pro-tip: go with someone that speaks Korean, make reservations or come early to beat the tour buses!
author: Stephanie B.

description:
Food was average, service was super slow, the wait was awfully long. However I'm giving this place four-stars because all of side dishes, Ban Chan, were very tasty and refillable which is always a plus. Portions were generous as well. I would go back again.
Oh did I mention their Sik-he, Korean rice beverage, that they give as dessert? It is a must-try.
author: Jina C.

description:
Ever since I've been little, I've always passed by this restaurant and noticed how packed it was. I never got around to trying it out until just last week. I'm honestly surprised at how late I got around to trying it, as Korean food is one of my favorites. 

My friend and I got to the restaurant around 6pm on Thursday and there were a lot of open tables, however within 30 minutes there was a line waiting outside, which definitely says a lot about a place. We were given the choice to either be seated at a table with a grill or a regular table. We decided to sit a regular table because we weren't in the mood to make our own food and we just wanted to order straight from the menu. 

We ordered the following items:

1. Bulgogi ---Hands down some of the most tender and juicy bulgogi that I've had in my life. The flavor definitely did not disappoint, but I do have to say, for the portion that's given, it's not worth the $24.00. 
2. Soft Tofu Soup (Not spicy) --- We asked to have the soup non spicy which turned out great. The tofu was super soft and every sip was truly enjoyable. 
3. Hot Stone Pot Bi-Bim Bab --- The bi-bim bap was also superb. The stone pot kept the rice and veggies hot for about an hour and continued cooking the rice to crispness at the bottom. It formed the most delicious golden crust and made the dish even more tasty.
4. Pan Fried Tofu--- I would totally recommend this dish to those who love spicy tofu because the entire top is covered with spicy sauce and spices. The tofu itself was low on flavorful and not really what I wanted, but this may have been because I'm a harsh tofu critic. 

In addition to all the items that we ordered, each table gets little plates called Banchan. These little side plates are all different and fun to try because they're very different than your typical American side dishes. Not all of these mini plates were my favorite, but some of them, such as the Kimchi and marinated cucumbers were AMAZING! The restaurant was also kind enough to bring us the steamed egg dish on the house, which was very nice of them. 

I would've given this restaurant a full five stars, however, after we finished our meal and put down both of our credit cards, we received the credit card receipts back for signing purposes and realized that the restaurant had charged each of us the full price... From my perspective this was quite a silly mistake to make, but it felt as if they were testing my friend and I to see if we would just let it slide. Little did they know that we check the bill prior to leaving. 

Overall, the food was very good, the service was on point, but that last part (wrong charge on our cards) just threw me off and made me feel somewhat uncomfortable. I really do hope that this isn't something they try with each of their guests, so take an extra minute to check your bill before paying!!
author: Julia K.

description:
My Korean friend tried to order in Korean but the server kept trying to change it to English. Haha. Great service and the food came out pretty fast. We  had to ask to change the grill 3x. 
We got pork belly, galbi, spicy cold noodle no broth, and tofu soup. All was great
author: Emily P.

description: I came here with friends at noon yesterday to try this Korean food. My friend introduced the food here very well but when I tried to feel that the food was generally poor service, there was an old waitress who ordered my seat food but did not repeat Confirming my order, I will leave when the food comes up. The order is wrong. When I asked for a replacement, the woman gave me a face that felt like I was wrong. I don't know if it's her English or what caused me. I don't understand why. Such a person can serve as a service agency. I don't want to go back to this place.
author: Tommy L.

description:
