As a girl born in Korea and raised in SoCal, I had pretty much given up on being able to find any authentic Korean food in the Bay that I'd enjoy nearly as much as what I'm used to. Han Il Kwan was such a great surprise when I went in for lunch on a Sunday.

The banchan was in larger quantity and higher quality than any other Korean restaurant I've been to in SF or East Bay. And the kimchi was on point: Definitely a good sign.

For main dishes, my boyfriend and I ordered naengmyun, crab stew, and japchae.
- The naengmyun broth was sweeter than I expected, but it wasn't anything that the vinegar and mustard they provided on the side couldn't fix. I was too full to finish all the noodles, but I definitely drank up all the liquid.
- The crab jjigae was spicy, super flavorful, and so unexpectedly authentic-tasting. Only wished there was more leftover to take home! 
- The japchae that we ordered at my boyfriend's request was a pleasant surprise as well. It's a simple dish that you can get at most if not all Korean restaurants, but honestly not a lot of other places in SF get it to be as good or as flavorful as it's meant to be. Also appreciated that it had a ton of vegetables.

Of course, the price point is higher here than around LA, but that's expected. Worth it for some rare, great Korean food in SF.
author: Sara L.

description:
One of my Korean friends invited me to this spot to try authentic Korean food -- and DEAR LORD -- the food here is amazing.  The beef short ribs are phenomenal, and they are the main reason I will make a trip back.  

This spot is casual, nothing fancy, and the wait staff isn't the friendliest, but hot damn the food is delicious.  It gets pretty packed but we didn't wait longer than 15 minutes for a table.  The food came out quickly and let me tell you -- the beef short ribs were cooked PERFECTLY -- super soft and tender.  

The other thing that really surprised me was the "rice punch."  O-M-G, that was delicious.  I drank one small cup of it, but my friend drank 3, so you're allowed to ask for more if you want.  Rice punch is like a sweet dessert drink (non-alcoholic).  

I live downtown and this is way out of my way, but it is worth the Lyft ride because it's that good -- I will definitely be back!!
author: Michelle S.

description: I love Han I'll Kwan! Best time to eat might be lunch. They have so many side dishes and always serve you a complimentary tofu soup to share with your table. All the dishes I've had with them are yummy and can't complain. Their beef stew is bomb! It's a big restaurant but at night time it gets busy and you can wait up to 20-30 minutes at a time but it's worth the wait. The ladies working there are nice as well. You can also bbq your meat if you'd like but i usually like it cooked already.
author: Yenni H.

description: Very authentic Korean restaurant! We were expecting a long line, but surprisingly it was only a 10 minute wait. If you want to come here during noon, be sure to find a parking spot beforehand. They provided banchan and the free steamed egg, so you won't be too hungry while waiting. I recommend the BBQ galbi and bulgogi -- super juicy and tender! The sundubu was okay, as well as the cold noodle. Definitely will revisit this place!
author: Renee W.

description: My first Korean restaurant in the SF area and I not overly impressed, especially having been to the Koreatown in LA and South Korea. Service was good but we had to asked several times to get water. Banchan was just ok.
author: Michael W.

description:
Food is really good but  they take Tour bus people over writing down your names. 
Lots of side dishes, you'll come out smelling like BBQ
author: Jared A.

description: Really great galbi that was well seasoned. The seafood was not bad too. We had more than enough to eat for three people sharing two bbq orders! I've had better banchan but that's because I'm spoiled back home. We had to wait about 30 minutes to be seated even though we came in around 8pm.
author: Jamie L.

description: Decent Korean bbq with an ample portion of side dishes and fairly friendly stuff. Best kbbq is still in LA, but this place can help hold down the cravings until the next trip to SoCal. The lower rating is based on cleanliness as they seem to take a bit more time to clean up dirty dishes from tables after patrons have left.
author: Kimberly H.

description: One of the worst experience I have ever gotten from a restaurant. We got there around 5 pm, the restaurant was half empty. After we indicated we wanted to be seated for two. The host who was a tall Korean shushed us to the side, so he can welcome the group of people behind us. I was stunned by how rude he was and did not know how to react. He then told me there will be a 30 minutes wait, he then just ignore us completely and start to bowing to the group that came after us. Never had I seen such servant syndrome and condensate behavior well mix. At this point I left the restaurant and almost feeling embarrassed about being an Asian.
author: Jared M.

description:
DAY:
 - Saturday dinner for 4.  We got here around 5:30PM and was not seated till about 6:30PM.  There seemed to be a longer wait since there were tour groups that were coming and going.
* Recommendation: make a reservation, unless you are planning to get there early.  But there is a list to put your name down if you did not make reservations.

LOCATION/INTERIOR:
 - the restaurant is located at the corner of Balboa St and 19th Ave.
 - the space inside is moderate but some of the table have the grill for the BBQ and some do not.
 - there is only one restroom and it is located new the kitchen entrance/exit which is very busy.  Also please note, not very clean.

ORDER & TASTE:
* We did not order Korean BBQ.
 - Gal-bi-jjim (#27 for $28): I was honestly not super impressed by this hot pot.  The oxtail was super sweet and was a little too much for my taste.
 - Japchae (#61 for $16): This was good but not sure if it's worth the price though.
 - Haesangmui Dolsot-Bibimbap (#32 for $14.95): Bibimbap was okay as well. I have definitely had better flavoring.

CUSTOMER SERVICE:
 - I though service was alright.  Had to ask for water refill multiple times and also for bonchon refills.  It was hard to get an attention of the servers.
author: Kei M.

description:
What a great way to spend dinner with friends!

Coming in as a party of six for dinner on a Monday night wasn't too long of a wait. The main room was packed and fully seated, but luckily they opened up the next room for us to use. So, yes... we were seated instantly! Woohoo, no wait.

Upon sitting down, our server instantly greeted us and brought us some delicious tea. I don't know what it was about the tea, but everyone enjoyed it. We had to keep asking for refills because it was very nice. 

I recently came back from Korea after studying abroad for four months, and being surrounded with Korean food once again brought back great memories. The servers all spoke Korean and English which was a plus because I was able to describe how I wanted my dish cooked with no problem. Our server was very joyful and friendly. She made sure we were comfortable with the menu and introduced some of my friends who are fairly new to Korean food to some of her favorite dishes/popular dishes amongst the guests.

We decided to order the bulgogi which was very flavorful (serving is enough for two to share). My friend ordered the Seolleongtang which is an ox bone soup. We ordered two Soondoobu (soft tofu soup), one non-spicy, or "white", due to my request and the other being normal. My other friend ordered their bibimbap which he throughly enjoyed. Portions were very generous.

Their side dishes here known has "banchan" comes in a variety, varying from kimchi, kkadugi (cubed radish kimchi), myulchi bokkeum (stir-fried dried anchovies), sukjunamul (marinated mung bean sprouts), gaeranjim (steamed egg), etc...  Sangchu(lettuce) was also available. This made the experience the most exciting because not many Korean restaurants serve these type of side dishes. Usually it would just be the simple kimchi and marinated bean sprouts. It brought back the whole Korea feel once again.
author: Marc C.

description:
Wow, who knew this place was so popping on a wknight? Came here on a Thursday night around 7pm, and had to circle around nearly 10 times to find parking. Insider tip, grew up in this area, parking is shittyyyy. Head towards Geary for more parking options since more ppl will be coming in and out!

Waited about 30mins(?) for a table of 2. Gotta appreciate their hustle. There's about two main ladies working the front on rotation to get ppl seated as quickly as possible. I didn't particularly mind waiting this time bc I wasn't so hungry, but be prepared to wait if you don't have reservations. 

Was craving the soondubu, but theirs has beef broth in it. And no seafood option. So FYI for that. Instead, went with the octopus veggie stir fry, steamed egg, and seafood pancake to share. Their bonchans are SUPER legit here. They come a plenty! 

Food was great! Steamed egg dish was massive. Twice as big as I was expecting, and well made. The octopus veggie stir fry was also flavorful and fresh. The veggies were lacking though, but that's korean veggies for you. And the seafood pancake was humongous. Couldn't even get through a third of it! Thicker than most korean pancakes, but again, great flavors - and didn't get soggy in the middle. 

Staff came by time and time again to check in. As busy as they were, they always filled up the waters and refilled the bonchans. So why 4 stars? I really wanted that soondubu...and I didn't get it. :/ plus the parking is crappyyyy. 

Would I come back? Absolutely! With different food and parking expectations.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
The most authentic Korean restaurant that I can find in SF. 

I had quite and interesting experience when I came. This place must have an agreement with a touring company because there was an entire tour bus that unloaded, filled 7/8 of the restaurant, ate, and left. This also meant that I had to wait because they had so many tables reserved for their touring event.

When I was seated, I ordered the seafood pancake, beef cold noodles, and bibimbap. There were also nine different banchan to pick at while I waited for my food. 

The seafood pancake was so good! I enjoyed it a lot. It wasn't too oily which is a common issue that I find in most other places. It was really thick but still cooked thoroughly and packed with seafood. It was a lovely sharing items for the table. 

The cold noodles were SO good! I was really happy with my order. It was such a hot day that it was completely called for. They put ice cubes in it as well to keep it cool. The noodles were nice and chewy and the broth was light. They serve it with vinegar and mustard. I only liked the vinegar in it. 

I would definitely come again. Parking is tough but if I'm already in the neighborhood, why not!
author: Tina Y.

description: Solid korean food with plenty of delicious banchan. My to go dish is the galbi jim, very flavorful and hearty! Their seafood pancake is also crunchy and thick, but not soggy which is great! Although the price is a little higher than other places, the food never disappoints
author: Sui N.

description:
Solid 4 stars

Good banchan, 7 dishes I think. Fishcake was a little soft though. I like it a bit chewier.

Lunch specials until 4 pm on weekdays!

I had the bulgogi lunch special, I came out to about $14 after tax. It was tasty and came with rice, banchan of course and a soft tofu soup. I think they'd probably give you 1 soup for the whole table, but it was still a good deal for everything. 

Tofu soup was really bland, and didn't come with an egg, but I ate it over the rice and it was good enough. 

I'd come back to try the bbq.

So far it's my favorite place in the area, but jong ga in Oakland on grand ave is still by far my favorite. They give you 3 times the banchan, it's all great, and everything they have is super tasty and makes all of the Richmond Korean places pale in comparison.
author: L Z.

description:
I keep coming back because of the raving reviews but I think I have finally come to the conclusion about this place - I don't like it. 

The tofu soup comes with way too much onion. As I was drinking my soup I thought to myself, "Did I order an onion soup or a beef tofu soup because there's about one whole onion in here and about 5 pieces of beef that's less than 1/2 inch big." 

They brought out the table BBQ meat one entree at a time. What if I want to eat both meat at the same time? It felt taboo to want to mix the brisket with the spicy pork belly on one grill. 

Everything here is either just okay or bad. There's not much to rave about and nothing stands out.
author: Michelle T.

description: If I could give this place negative reviews I would. Wouldn't sell me water because they didn't take card for water only. And they were "closed" because it turned closing time while I was standing there pleading with them. Cool.
author: Kacton D.

description:
Went to Han II Kwan last week with a friend on a weekday. It wasn't too busy which was nice. Parking was easy to find on the streets. According to many of the yelp reviews I've read, during the lunch hours are the best times to go but I went during the night lol. The prices for dinner was a bit higher I think when I compared the prices to the lunch menu I saw. My friend and I waited maybe 5 minutes or so before we got seated. We sat the table with grill and ordered the marinated gal bi and the pork belly! Both was delicious. Everything was marinated and they also give you tons of side dishes also! It's nice that the waitresses also grill the meat for you or you can grill them yourself. (For me, I'm lazy so I was glad they were there to grill the meat for me). All the food you order comes with the side dishes so you don't gotta worry about having to order those. We also ordered the Japchae (clear noodles) with veggies and beef. The japchae was alright, nothing special. I've ate japchae before at many Korean places but this place is A-ok when it comes to this dish. Our food came pretty quick. Service is quick and the servers are nice. The price is a bit too high in my opinion. You can eat AYCE korean bbq somewhere else and pay less than individual meats that they Han II Kwan has.  

Next time, I'll try coming during the lunch hours. Oh, I forgot to mention, this place is known to have tour buses bring the tourists here so you may run into a big crowd of people. According to my friend, she said that they take up almost half the room so you may want to get to the restaurant early before the tourists goes and fills the restaurant up.
author: Monica W.

description: Food (bibimbap) was bland. Save your $ & go to a better Korean restaurant. This was the only place open nearby during lunch so it was only resort.
author: Kiara A.

description: The food was not what the review say! Coming from a Culinary background the food was bland,  and the sea food was not fresh. Over rated.
author: Jenn G.

description: I came here for my cousin's birthday. Being Korean and having lived in LA, I find the Korean scene here not the greatest in terms of food. But if you want some decent comfort Korean food, I would say here's not a bad place to go. Although the price is a bit steep. I ordered their mae-eun-tang, which is Sciaenoid Fish Soup with Vegetables. It was $28! Not cheap is all I'm going to say. Overall, it was good. But have tasted better at LA and more importantly, nothing beats home cooked Korean food. We also shared their galbi and sauteed squid with vegetables. They were both pretty good as well. Will be dropping by prob during lunch hours since it'll  be a more reasonable cost when I'm craving Korean food :)
author: Jackie C.

description: Loved this place! Amazing bibimbap served with all the traditional accouterments. Great service. They even gave me an unexpectedly wonderful tofu soup on the house!
author: Zach C.

description:
I wanted to try a new kbbq place. After looking at the kbbq places around San Francisco, I saw this place had the most reviews and a good amount of stars compared to the other kbbq places. I've been coming here every Monday for three weeks straight. The first two times I came here, the wait was around 15-20 minutes. The outer booths are for kbbq and most of the middle seating is for ordering cooked dishes. Their grill is the best compared to the other kbbq places I tried. Their side dishes weren't full of my favorites but they were fresh and the meat was perfect. Their kbbq meat is pretty pricey, and you have to order a minimum of two of their kbbq meats to self-cook. I ordered their marinated beef short ribs ($29.95) the first time I came but didn't like it. My favorite is their brisket and pork belly. I'm also in love with the sauce you dip the meat in; I believe it's sesame oil mixed with salt and pepper. It comes with rice and a complimentary spicy tofu soup (1) and tea. The kbbq meat also includes complimentary lettuce wraps and sauce. 
However, the third time my friend and I came here, we waited for 55 minutes to get a seat. It was my idea to keep coming back since I really enjoyed their food the first two times, so I didn't mind waiting. The waitress in charge of seating people didn't acknowledge us and let us know the wait time. I saw her go around to several other people waiting and talk to them about their possible wait time. When we were finally seated, some of their sides didn't look fresh but I was surprised they brought out my favorite fish cake sides; it didn't taste as good as I hoped. So I looked forward to eating their brisket and pork belly. But when it arrived, I noticed the amount and size of the meat decreased compared to what we got last time. 
The freshness of their side dishes can be a hit or miss. I also felt like it wasn't worth the money the third time we came here. Coming here every Monday for three weeks straight, it's too much sesame oil, salt, pepper and meat. But we'll be back someday.
author: Kristin H.

description:
Service: excellent
Atmosphere: nice and cozy
Food: good

For bbq:
We got marinated boneless ribeye 
And chicken
Both tasted pretty good

The vermicelli noodle with veggie and chicken was pretty good!!

Beer: Hite
Drink: ?
author: Mary N.

description: Great place to eat with a group of 5-6 people. Waited over 30 minutes for a table for six people, which I feel is usually time for popping kbbq places. But it was well worth because the amount of food they give is a TON and GOOD too! Our table was overflowed with food when it came out! We were able to replace one of the dishes for a seafood soup for some extra $$$. Side note is parking - was pretty hard to find. I recommend parking a bit further and just walking or your going to end up looking for a while.
author: William T.

description: This is such an amazing place for the price. Staff was friendly, helpful at giving recommendations- the food was fresh and there was so many complimentary side dishes and soup that came with it. The picture doesn't show all of it, but point is there was so much good food for under 30$. Enough to feed two people who hadn't eaten in 12 hours and enough to have left overs. The bulgogi was so tender and well sautéed. Totally worth the drive!
author: Marc H.

description: Very good food and great service! And despite half of our party being late and many people waiting, they seated us exactly at the time of our reservation. All, meats, bon chon, noodles, soups, etc. were large portions and tasty. Be back here soon!
author: Joseph M.

description: This is a great option. The place is always packed so I'd come expecting a bit of a wait. They can do big groups in the back. I've come with my family a few times so we're always in the back in a group of 11 or so.  They have a good variety of banchan, and a lot of stuff comes with like a free soup or a free delicious steamed egg thing.
author: Veronica L.

description:
They have slightly above average food here, with below average service. I recognize that my standards are probably higher because I live in SoCal now, with access to great Korean food relatively closeby. 

I ordered the hot stone bibimbap and shared the rice cake in spicy sauce with a friend. The bibimbap was good! The best part about it was how the hot stone made a layer of nice and crispy layer of rice for me to devour at the end. The rice cakes were very average. The rice cakes themselves were soft and chewy, but the spicy sauce didn't taste that good at all. 

The plus side about this place is the number of banchan they offer, which were all quite good. They also have complementary steamed egg, which I suggest you eat while it's still steaming hot. Overall, this place is a great option for Korean in SF.
author: Diane Z.

description: The freshness was key.  We dropped by on a Monday at 12:15 and was able to score a table before the charter bus came by.  I liked the beef better than the chicken.  The lettuce wrap was fresh too.
author: Kevin L.

description:
One of the better Korean places in the city. At least it's definitely authentic and feels like a real Korean restaurant. 

I usually test the quality of a Korean restaurant by their banchan. The kimchi was okay (just not the ripeness that I prefer) but the rest of the side dishes were great both in portion and taste!

The spicy pork and the kalbi were both really tender and yummy. They gave us soondubu (asian bachelorette, anyone?) on the house because we had a large group, which was on the watery side and not as thick as I usually like it. I've had better soondubu in the city but I'm not sure if it's because it was just an "on the house" quality one or if their actual soondubu is like that..

Their kimchi pancakes were thick and chewy and very big - not as much kimchi and spiciness in it as I'd like but still satisfying!

The ddukbokki was surprisingly good to me. When it first came out we thought it looked bland because there is nothing else in it besides the dduk (no fish cake, no veggies, etc). But the sauce was sooooo good and the ddukbokki was perfectly chewy and hot and soft. YUMMM yum.

Service was particularly rough - maybe it was a busy day? They were understaffed, a bit ruder than normal even for a Korean place. But for the food, I'd definitely come back. This is a real Korean restaurant!! we need more in SF.
author: Nicole L.

description: Sf's gold standard for KBBQ. Obviously uncompetitive when compared to stuff in LA for example but it is the best we have in town
author: Han L.

description:
The Korean food here is legit. We didn't do the BbQ but we had the galbi and spicy pork and it was prepared really well.  We can here here for Linner (around 3:00) and it was the perfect time.  No waiting in line!

We also had the spicy tofu soup which was really good as well as the fried dumplings.  Four a family of four the food was just the right amount.  We found the service to be great.  

The only downside is the parking.  It's always crazy trying to find parking in the area.  

If you're looking for good Korean food, definitely worth checking out.
author: James K.

description:
Han Il Kwan is a restaurant that is very worthy of its great ratings and talk of good Korean food. I enjoyed it immensely, and here are some key points that come into eating here.

Location: 5/5
The restaurant is located on 19th and Balboa, in a small corner shop of the street. The place looks quaint and small, but the inside has a large area with two huge cooking tables and other any tables surrounding it, plus a back area with more tables. When you go in, you sign into a paper to get seated and it goes quick. Me and my family came in quickly during the lunch rush hour and got seated within 5 minutes. Parking for cars may get a bit hard as the streets are very packed, so make sure to keep searching!

Food/Pricing: 5/5
Okay, okay. This food is incredible. They give you free banchan, rice, AND choice of tofu soup or steamed egg. I have never been to a place that gives out free tofu soup, but they gave our table two free soups and it was really good. I usually don't enjoy soup, but this one wasn't overly spicy, still flavorful, and the tofu was really soft. The star of the banchan was the kimchi. My god, the radishes were fresh and cold, really snapped in my mouth and were refreshing, while the cabbage had the sour taste that made your mouth reminisce of past kimchi experiences, but better in that it was stronger in taste and the cabbage was fresh. We also ordered dwaegi-bulgolgi (spicy pork), seafood pancake, and japchae (glass noodles). The spicy pork was really good, also not as spicy but tasty meat. The seafood pancake we got was huge, with 8 pieces filled with vegetables and squid that made me extremely satisfied. The japchae was the most normal out do the bunch, not too bad but also not that good. Everything else made up for it, however. They also give you a little bit of rice water at the end, to clear your mouth which was awesome. I had that done in a restaurant only once in the past. The pricing was typical of a Korean a-la-carte place, mid-range around $25 for meat and $15 for other food, but nothing that broke the bank too much.

Service: 4/5
The service here was quick paced and nice. The ladies that served us were rapid and to the point, but also courteous as they allowed us to order while we discussed what we should still order. It did, however, take us three times to get our drinks after receiving our food, and when we wanted to get to-go boxes, one lady looked past us TWICE and didn't come to our tables. Our main server, however, was nice and she made it up to us. 

In conclusion, if you're ever in the Richmond District or the Bay Area and want some good Korean food, this place is the best. It's amazing and I am glad that I was able to eat here.
author: Joshua L.

description: Great food great environment and I even got a free dish when I went. Pricing a little High, averaging around 16-18 dollars per dish. But overall 5/5!!
author: Jessica L.

description:
It was fine.  Came on a Sunday and did indeed have to wait while big tour buses full of people ate here.  

Good, basic Korean food.  Wouldn't go out of my way to eat here.
author: Kathryn C.

description:
This is honestly my favorite go to place for Korean food in the city!

I find that Han II Kwan is one of the few restaurants that are generous with their ban chan (side dishes) and you get tofu soup on house along with your meal. I usually get the seafood bibimbap lunch special and it's always great for leftovers as well. And at the end, they serve you this sweet rice drink that I find helps cleanse the palate after a heavy meal. 

As a whole, they seem a bit understaffed so I would avoid during peak lunch hours.
author: Terilyn C.

description: The banchan, various kimchi, the tofu soup were all excellent!!! We got the spicy pork bulgogi and it was exactly what we were looking for !!! Im giving this place four stars because they only have like 3 ppl working as servers/ counter and it took forever to order- but the food came quickly and the interior is nice! If there is a line, theres a sheet you put your name on and you can mark if you want a bbq table or any.
author: Catherine R.

description: Very good Korean place! It gets really busy and they don't take reservations so get there early.  Sundubu is included in your meal :)
author: Jenna C.

description: Solid. Hits the right spot on a cool, breezy day. Got the Kim chi hit stone soup and it warmed my belly and soul right up!
author: Alvin N.

description:
Awesome Korean food at decent prices, and best of all, they're not skimpy on the banchan (small side dishes that come with Korean meals). Most places around here give you 3-5, here you can count on 8-9 banchan dishes, a flavorful range of variety.

I've had several different dishes here, including stone pot bibimbap, tofu soup, and galbi tang (beef short rib soup). All were delicious, but the galbi tang sticks out due to the generous portions of soft and tender meat and the simple yet heartwarming broth.

If your group is big enough to split some appetizers, the seafood pancake and kimchi pancake are also fantastic, just the right balance of crispy on the outside, savory and chewy on the inside.

Staff are attentive and friendly, coming by to check on you several times throughout the meal. When I came with a large group they even threw in a few pots of steamed egg on the house!

At the end of the day, my measure for great Korean food is how many empty dishes you end up with at the end of the night (poor dishwasher!), Han Il Kwan definitely ranks somewhere up there!
author: Brittany C.

description: Tour buses are giving this place, with great food, one star. I have been going there often. Last two visits (Friday & Saturday) they've had tour buses holding the tables and preventing locals from getting seated. It's OK if that's their business model, but at least inform your local customers or simply just close it for private events. They are having ZERO respect for their real customers.
author: Fernando F.

description:
We liked this place so much that we came back the next day.

My wife and I were pleasantly surprised by how good the Korean BBQ here is. We were exploring the Lands End area and were delighted that there was a Korean BBQ option nearby. We first came here for lunch on a Monday and there was ample seating. You have the option of grilling the meat yourself or having them cook it for you in the kitchen.

The side dish game is spot on - standouts are the kimchi, bean sprouts and seaweed salad. For the meats, we ordered the marinated beef short ribs, marinated beef rib eye, and marinated chicken. We had them cook it in the kitchen - they cooked it perfectly and the wait time was short. The meat was delicious, fresh and flavorful, especially the marinated chicken - this was the first Korean BBQ place I've been to where the chicken was a standout (in my experience, the chicken at other places usually comes out dry and lacking in flavor). In addition, the japchae here was one of the best I've had - perfect proportion of noodle, vegetables and beef without too much grease. They also give you free soup!

We happened to be in the Golden Gate Bridge / Presidio area the next day and decided to come back here for dinner since it was so good. We opted for the self-grill this time and the meats came out great (but would recommend having them cook it in the kitchen for a much more laid-back carefree experience - leave it to the experts!). Service is friendly and attentive.

Recommend coming here for lunch as the lunch special prices are much more reasonable. Also recommend this restaurant for visitors who are exploring the neighboring Lands End / Golden Gate area!
author: Kevin S.

description:
My favorite Korean restaurant in SF!! Great banchan and the ladies here are so nice...though be prepared to wait if you don't have a reservation!

What to order:
- Kalbi - marinated beef short-rib. Even though beef is BAD FOR THE ENVIRONMENT, I still can't help drooling over kbbq kalbi. The meat is cooked and cut to the right proportions..so you know exactly why you're dishing out $30 for it. Nice and fatty - I'd take this over bulgogi any day!

- Kimchi Jigae - Kimchi Stew! This is comfort food for me! I can eat this all the time and for any occasion! Definitely do it right here :)

- Steamed Egg - It's like a savory egg soufflé.. really good texture and serve in a giant bowl for sharing!

- Japchae - Glass-noodle dish with veggies. I love it here cuz it's not too sweet and they add a lot of it..not just a bunch of noodles. Yum!

- Bibimbop - The stone pot bibimbop is all about the same here as it is elsewhere. Not too outstanding here, but sometimes you just crave it.

Anytime we're in the area, this is where we inevitably end up eating! Highly recommend!
author: Jennifer S.

description:
This is probably my favorite Korean BBQ restaurant in SF. The food is great and the service is good. Parking can be a pain in the ass here though so either Uber/Lyft or prepare to spend at least 30 mins circling around for parking. 

I'm really amazed at how they handle big crowds here. When we were there this past weekend, they had two big tour buses (it's a regular thing here) coming for dinner and they were able to serve them in and out within 1.5 hour. 

My favorite dish here is the Galbi Jjim. The portion is huge, enough for 2-3 people to share and the meat is marinated so well and tender. You also can't go wrong with the BBQ meats. 

Lastly, I love the extra dishes they give you for freeeee! We got the Soondubu Jjigae (tofu soup) the last two times we visited.
author: Vy M.

description:
I'm Korean and grew up eating Korean food. I cook Korean food all the time. This is okay Korean food. The day I went for lunch, the kalbi was tough and too fatty and the kimchi was just mediocre. Neng myun was bland and needed more meat, cucumber,and mul kimchi.  

However their Kimchi chigae is very good and tastes like Korean food.
author: Teresa R.

description:
Our friends recommended this place so we gave it a try. We had to wait 45 mins for a table while all of these tour buses stopped by and took up half the restaurant. We figured the wait would be worth it if the food was good. 
Unfortunately it wasn't good enough for the wait. I'm used to great service at Korean restaurants. It's one of the things I usually forward to but this was not the case here. The waitress ran around and didn't stop at our table until we flagged them down and when we asked to get a refill of some of the  side dishes they just rolled their eyes and was felt it was such a burden. I had to ask for a Coke twice. 
The tofu soup, marinated short ribs, bulgogi, and chicken was nothing special. The bulgogi was not tender like others I have had before. There was five of us and we all had to share the tofu soup. Yes it was free but they should have at least given us two of them for five people. 
The only good dish was the extra steamed egg I ordered.
author: Lin K.

description:
100% worth it to come here.

Came on a Tuesday night with a party of 3 and got seated after 5 minutes. 

Excellent service-- the bonchon by itself were already delicious and they gave enough to feed 5. We got bimbimbap, steam egg and japchae and the japchae especially was amazing.

We also got a large bottle of sake and a 40oz beer and the bill came out to just over $60 

Cannot wait to come again!
author: Nat E.

description:
Han II Kwan is a popular Korean BBQ so be prepared to wait if you're going to eat during prime times.

They're not the friendliest or speak English well but the food is good and fresh.  My favorite was the Tofu skin banchan (side dish) and barley tea.  The price was very reasonable and I could have spent 20% more money at another competitor.  I liked that the waitress changed the grill several times without us asking.

I didn't like it when the waitress used the same tongs for placing the raw meat on the grill to also pick up the cooked meat.  They also don't have any music or music videos on a television to keep you happily entertained while eating.

They are understaffed.  During our meal, we sometimes cooked our own food.

Having been to many Korean BBQ restaurants from San Francisco to New York, I can say that this is one of my least favorite Korean BBQs I've been to.  Come here for the authenticity of Korean BBQ and nothing else.
author: Jeremy D.

description:
For SF, this is probably the best Korean food in town (tied with Manna in the Sunset). That's not saying a lot, but *shrug*. 

The prices aren't great (think $16 for a bibimbap in the stone pot/dolsot), and the service isn't that good either. But as my friend joked last time - service doesn't even need to be good when you're the only decent Korean spot in town. 

I've ordered kimchi jjigae, dwenjjang jjigae, seafood pancake, ddukboki, and bibimbap here. I wouldn't recommend the jjigaes, but the pancake/pahjeon and bibimbap is solid. The ddukboki is lackluster as well. 

They give a free steamed egg or soondubu jjigae to each table, which is a nice reward for putting up with the cold service. 

Three stars seems too low considering I eat here on the regular, so begrudgingly a four star establishment. That being said, Manna has better service with similar prices. 

Usually busy - be prepared to wait. If you see tourbuses parked in front, don't even bother. Tours frequent this place and when they are there it's really crowded.
author: Lauren C.

description:
This place is one of the most popular Korean restaurants in the Bay. My boyfriend and I were craving Korean food and decided to give this place a try. We arrived around 2PM and had to wait a bit. They seem to always be busy and customers keep coming in.

We ordered:
Banchan: Very good, a lot of selection, who doesn't love appetitzers!
Galbi: Pretty good, meat was tender. What threw me off was it was quite pricey. It was $30 PLUS additional $13 just to cook in the kitchen. The waiter did not tell us that at all. It would be nice if someone said something. I'm sure we would of ordered it anyways, but really #13 just to cook in the kitchen?! Are you using magic or real gold grills or something? Unacceptable.
Cold Noodle Soup: Pretty good, very refreshing.
Seafood Casserole Stew: OK, not too crazy about it. Seafood was not fresh and soup was meh.

Overall, experience was OK, not the best I ever had. They do well probably cause the Bay doesn't have much selection. I rather go to South Bay and try Gen.
author: Natalie L.

description:
Definitely one of my top Korean spots in the bay! Haven't tried the kbbq here, mostly cause I'm lazy and their menu items are already so good. 

Kimchi pancake is nice and thick. I really love all the ban chan options, and especially the free tofu soup that comes as an appetizer. Dubbokki is just okkk unfortunately, but I still enjoyed it. 

Lots of street parking, and both times I've been here we've been seated right away since we were barbecuing. I think the prices are pretty good too, especially considering the big portions.
author: Steph D.

description:
Food = good. But some items were a miss.

Soon dubu = good but quite watery. (Choice of soon dubu or steamed egg for the table, with the entree.) 

Daeji bulgogi = spicy, flavorful and good cuts of pork. One of the best items. $23.00.

Bulgogi (beef ribeye) = grisly and full of stuff that one couldn't really chew. We were disappointed.  Bad cuts. Cutting makes a difference and they failed. $26.00.

Hamul pajeon = okay. It was very doughy and on the bland side. Disappointing. Especially at this price. $17.00.

Banchan = excellent.  Can't complain about it--great kimchi, anchovies, and nokdu-muk! 

Service = friendly and efficient. 

Prices = moderate.  Dinner for two came out to $71.61, with leftovers. 

We waited 45 minutes for a table while the usual tour groups came and went.

Finding a piece of stainless steel wool with our meal = aggravating, too. They acted like nothing was wrong when I mentioned it, at the end of the meal. One should make sure that the cleaning crew is careful--choking hazard, ripped out gums or dental damage.  Zero excuses.

Don't know if I'll make the effort to go here again.
author: Fannie S.

description:
The amount of food you get here is amazing!!
I came with a group of 7 and we got the Set Menu for 8 people + Soju + Beer. :) 
 It came with 2 types of meat, tofu soup, bibimbap, japchae, fish, egg, a bunch of side dishes, rice, etc! It was so much food it was almost overwhelming! But we finished it all and the food was really tasty. 

The service is also really good. The waitresses really work hard getting anything our table needed, and they helped to change out the grill when it got really burnt. We came on a Friday night so it was really busy, but despite the chaos the waitresses were super nice :) The only thing was that we wished the food would come out one by one, but it all came out at the same time and there was little space to put all the food on the table.
author: Brenda Jiwon L.

description:
BEWARE, my gluten sensitive brethren, before going here. Who would ever expect the tea to have gluten?? They set it on your table before the meal for all guests with no warning whatsoever for those of us who will be sick for days because we're not used to examining the complimentary tea. It's hard enough to examine every piece of food for it, especially when the waitress has no idea what you're talking about. Don't get any of the marinated meat either, because those have soy sauce and thus gluten. You'd think it would be standard procedure for servers to at least understand what gluten is before they inflict allergic reactions in their unsuspecting customers. 

Otherwise the food was good.
author: Kristina M.

description:
Granted the limited Korean food availability in SF, I'm glad this spot by my house is solid. 

Have been here a bunch of times many years ago but stopped going because of the insane crowds from the tour busses. Heard some buzz about this place from friends recently so decided to pay this place a visit again. 

Came here for lunch on a weekday and there was a wait! The place was full and I was pretty surprised. After a short wait, we were seated and decided on sharing Jap Chae and Galbi. Both are good, however, the Galbi was a little drier than I'd prefer. I appreciate how they cut the bone out for you though! Lunch included the large selection of ban chan and tofu soup. Pretty okay deal in my opinion. Came out to around $30 out the door. 

Staff is nice but they're understaffed. They're busy and are constantly running around. Asked for ice water three times to two different waitresses and never got my water lol. I accepted it and stuck to the tea at my table. But water would've been nice
author: Carissa G.

description:
Best Korean restaurant I've been to in SF so far. Parking is difficult to find in the area though.

Short ribs: marinated to perfection. Delicious and only a few pieces had bones, the meat is high quality, tender, and very juicy too.

Kimchi pancakes: very thick filled with kimchi. Not very spicy though (may be a good thing depending on your preference that day).

Tofu soup w/ beef: perfect amount of spice. They used spicy oil instead of spicy powder. Pro-Tip: add an egg.

Note: must order at least two BBQ meat dishes (~$30 ea) in order to sit at the self cook booth. Otherwise if you just order one you may sit at a normal table and they cook it in the back and bring it you (not a bad thing, saves your clothes from getting all smelly).
author: Tom P.

description: The food is great but they dont take same day reservation. So plan ahead and make reservation! Otherwise the wait is 30 min and more.
author: Amy L.

description: The food is good but the service is depended on the waitresses mood, usually bad!! Sometime, there are tours and here will be busy
author: Arutchaporn J.

description: This place was tasty and helped me with getting a receipt for company reimbursement after I left. Thank you guys!
author: Bill B.

description:
I've eaten at over 20 Korean Restaurants in San Francisco and this one gets my vote as BEST KOREAN RESTAURANT.

Large portions, big on flavor, you can't go wrong here.  Prices seem to be about a dollar or two more than Korean restaurants on Geary, but that's a couple dollars well spent.  Reservations necessary on weekends I hear.

Everything we ate here was outstanding.
author: Joe S.

description:
UGH. This place was so good. 

We got the galbi, the pork belly, the seafood pancake and the dolsot bibimbap. For four people, this was honestly way too much food. 

Something that is so important to me is the bonchon, and Han Il Kwan's small dishes were excellent. The kimchi was the right amount of salty and sour with a good crunch. The kkakdugi was also crunchy and satisfying. 

The staff helped us cook our meet and were very friendly. The galbi was the perfect texture with some caramelization from the bbq process and tenderness of the meat itself. Was also a huge fan of the pork belly when eaten with the lettuce leaves and the dipping sauces they had.
author: Jon L.

description:
My go to Korean restaurant in San Francisco. I've been coming here for years but after living in Seoul for a year, I sometimes have intense cravings for the real deal abroad. Han Il Kwan does a great job of fulfilling that!

The menu is more on the pricier end of the spectrum. There aren't as many options unlike Los Angeles which keeps its fare low due to the healthy competition of offerings available in and around Korea Town.

KALBI JJIM
This is the beef stew, similar to Cantonese ow laam. The kalbi just melts in your mouth and the stewed flavors is a nice medley of savory and sweet. The Kalbi Jjim comes with a generous heaping of potatoes and carrots and even the stew alone is delish served with rice. If I'm only allowed a single dish, this would be my pick.

NAENG MYEON
This is a cold, buckwheat noodle in a icy broth served with cucumber shavings, half a hard boiled egg, and slices of pork. This is the standard meal for sweaty hot days but since San Francisco doesn't really have those, I guess a nice sunny day can calls for naeng myeon too. It's not too special but for the sake of nostalgia, I got this. I was dining with my family and they weren't a big fan but I'd still suggest people to try it.

SEAFOOD PANCAKE
Their seafood pancake is loaded with lots of various seafood. I recall generous portions of shrimp, leek, and squid. You really can't go wrong with this.

TTEOKBOKKI
The tteok are the long cylinder rice cakes and they are the perfect amount of chewy drenched in a spicy chili sauce. I am not a big fan of spicy food, in fact I am a total wimp that cannot even handle Sirarcha but the tteokbokki is to die for. I would continue eating it despite the burning pain and tearing up. It's that good.
author: Anna F.

description:
This was my first time at a local Korean bbq joint dice I move here so I was really excited to finally have some bbq.  When we got there one person was running late and they won't seat you until the whole party is there. Kind of annoying when restaurants have that rule.  

We finally got seated and I noticed the seats were all ripped up from wear and tear.  A bit surprised that they didn't fix that.  

This place is all you can eat.  There's the $19 side snd the $24 side.  Obviously the more expensive side has more meat offerings.. Specifically bulgogi so we all agreed the 5 extra bucks was worth it.  The sides were a bit depressing... There were maybe 5 sides and at a normal restaurant there's at least double that.

They have these cool big "pitchers" of Hite beer that are $15 and we all shared that.  Ended up getting two for 4 people.

When ordering meat there's a limit of 3 per order to avoid wasting food which was fair.  The best thing we got was the miso pork belly.  The sauces they provided weren't great.  Lacked flavors.  They didn't have kalbi which is my fave when getting bbq.  

The staff were attentive and changed the grill pretty often for us.  It was pretty busy which I mean for $19 all you can eat Korean bbq is decent.  I think there's one in LA for $10 all you can eat and more sides, but that's irrelevant lol. 

Tbh I wouldn't come back but the whole cooking food in a grill and having a good laugh and chat with your friends is priceless.
author: Nyla K.

description: Not impressed. Maybe it was an off day. Service was good and wait staff were friendly. But the food was just mediocre at best.
author: Amanda C.

description:
The banchan was so good and the restaurant is very generous. Servers are continuously walking by and topping off waters and asking if everything is alright if they see a need. Really appreciate the genuine customer service and delicious food. 

Spicy tofu soup blows BCD out of the water with bits of beef, tofu, and zucchini. It's a good mix of sweet and spicy.
author: Jenny Q.

description:
This is probably one of the better Korean restaurants I've been to so far in San Francisco.

We came here at around 2pm on a Saturday and had to wait around 10 minutes to be seated. We didn't eat KBBQ, but we got the kimchi-jeongol ($22) and seafood and scallion pancake ($17). 

The kimchi-jeongol was alright, but since they provide either steamed egg or tofu soup for complimentary per table, I really didn't see the need to separately order a soup. I ended up eating the steamed egg more than the actual kimchi-jeongol. Unless you really want a specific type of soup, I wouldn't recommend separately ordering one as their steamed egg was really good (I didn't get the tofu so I don't know, but I'm sure it's good).

The seafood and scallion pancakes were amazing. They were big in portion and tasted great. Each piece was thick and filled with so much food, I really enjoyed eating them. Highly recommend this!

I wouldn't necessarily come back here again unless I'm in the area, but I can see how this place is a good Korean restaurant. If I come back, I would definitely get KBBQ or get a type of meat. It is a bit pricey, but I think you really do get what you pay for in terms of food quality and service.

This place wasn't anything spectacular (honestly a 3 star), but it was good enough for 4 stars given that I've been to so many worse Korean restaurants nearby.
author: Jen S.

description:
I just had experienced this place on a new light. I used to work around outer Richmond and used to go here for lunch. The best deal at this place is lunch time; A meat with all the fix-ins (Ban-chans). My go to lunch item is the Kalbi/Galbi/Beef Short ribs a perfect and hearty lunch.

Yesterday, I went with a group of 5 people... This place was PACKED! I'm so not used to that. Go here for lunch, without the Korean tour bus, and this place is dead.

We went for the Family Meal A meal $160.00 good for 6 people. And the food just kept on coming.

You get to chose if you would like; Short Ribs or Rib Eye, and choose Chicken or Pork Belly for the second meat. The meal comes with the essential banchans - anchovies, fishcake and the daikon are my favorites. It came also with...

Tempura platter
Tofu Soup
Stonepot soft egg
2 meat entrees
mackerel
sizzling seafood plate
and a bimbimbap

ALOT!
author: Jan R.

description: Please note that this is NOT an all-you-can-eat Korean BBQ. The menu prices are for 1 plate of beef, chicken or pork to BBQ. The food was fine but for the same price per plate, I am sure you can find an all-you-can eat BBQ in SF. Also, do NOT come here between 5PM-7PM as multiple tour buses will arrive and the staff will forget about you.
author: Jean D.

description:
They have great lunch specials but it can get crazy packed in here. So be prepared to wait. 

Most items here are really good. If you like to do your own BBQ get a booth if not any table will do. Cant go wrong with the house cooking for you. They are consistent. 

My favorite things to order are the marinated short ribs and chicken. Spicy pork is good as well

Service is a little lacking. I don't think they are adequately staffed. Doesn't mean they don't work hard. 

Parking is also a pain, with these few negatives I still come here.
author: Lyman C.

description:
This is hands down one of my most favorite Korean food places! My sister and I usually get a plate of beef bugolgi, jap chae, dukbokki (spicy rice cakes). This is enough because there is a variety of side dishes which is also very filling. 

I have also tried KBBQ here before and though it tastes good, it is very pricey when it comes to KBBQ. TheyI would recommend going to an AYCE place for that to get your money's worth. 

Overall, this is a great place to grab a bite to eat at lunch time! The people are really friendly and the food also tastes delicious.
author: Jeanette Q.

description: I used to come here weekly when I lived in the area and it was a solid 5 star korean joint but I went there recently and ordered the galbi and black cod.  I was very disappointed with both.  The fish was very bland like they hurried the cooking even though the place was empty and the galbi just was not as good as I remember.  I'll stick with the places in Duluth next time.
author: Rich K.

description:
This isn't LA KBBQ. No AYCE and it's not cheap...BUT it's got some great quality meat. And in my opinion, this is the best KBBQ place in the city. (You would think there would be more KBBQ places in SF by now...)

Meat quality is fantastic and their portions are pretty big. But what I actually love most is that they have some authentic Korean dishes on their menu. Ranging from noodles to soups - they've got a pretty impressive menu. Usually you'll just get meats from a KBBQ place, but not here. Which is awesome if you aren't feeling the meat. And to top if off, you have the option of sitting at a table where you can cook your own meat or get it served. We always choose the former because who doesn't like to cook their own kbbq?! Plus, the waiters/waitresses are so attentive that they end up helping cook most of it.

I miss the Korean food in SoCal, but this place is as close as it gets. It might not be the cheapest and there's almost always a wait, but it's worth it if you want some Korean food done right. I took a star off because it's really just so pricey. Other than that, I highly recommend this place.
author: Steph S.

description:
Excellent spot - tour buses seem to drop off loads of tourists here regularly. 

Would recommend the bbq pork or beef dishes, seafood wasn't my favorite
author: Eric S.

description: If you can, come here for lunch during the week. You can order your own dish of meat with rice instead of ordering the more expensive cook-your-own meats. They also give you a lot of the little bon chon dishes and the soup, which makes up for having to cook your own meat if you choose to. I like coming here because their food is really good. I always get the bulgogi. That's my go to meat at Korean restaurants.
author: Allyson L.

description: I have been trying to go here for a while now but the line is always so long so we got smart and did take out instead. It is about time that I found another place in the city with delicious korean food. We got the seafood pancake, ox tail soup, and gal bi jjim. There is only a small % of korean places that make the gal bi jjim and this place did not dissapoint. I was really surprised by the amount of food too when i went to pick it up. They pack up all the side bon chons for you and even tossed in a free soon duboo. i will def be back
author: Tao Tao W.

description: So, be prepared to wait, longer wait times if you want to grill your own food.  When I went I needed to wait just over an hour.  The wait was worth it though.  Everything they brought out was delicious.  The kimchee pancake was not super spicy and the meats were all seasoned perfectly.
author: Erica A.

description: HANDS DOWN BEST KBBQ EVER! Gen KBQQ doesn't hold a candle to this place. Everything was absolutely delicious. I came here around 5pm on a Sunday (come early to beat the insane rush!) and was seated fairly quickly for a group of 7. A few of my favorites: seafood pancake, pork belly, and beef ribs. For drinks, we ordered the standard soju and Hite beer, but we also tried a rice-fermented drink called mak-gul-li. Tastes a lot better than it sounds/looks! By end of the night, cost was about $35/person. For the quality AND quantity of food/drinks, this was incomparable. Everyone at the table was highly satisfied and will definitely be back!
author: Jenny T.

description:
Everybody knows the good Korean food is in the East Bay and South Bay. 
With that being said, Han Il Kwan is about as good as Korean food gets in the the city. 
Side dishes: You get about 10, good variety, refilled upon request. + Complimentary tofu soup. 
Meat: Good quality, good marinade, they're Galbi is cut in a unique way and you get a big chunk of bone to take home to your dog. 
I really like their pan fried beef dumpling.
They give you fee rice drink after the meal. 
Prices are pretty good especially for lunch, you can get very full w/o breaking the bank (not AYCE).

Warning: Weekly Korean tour buses descend upon this restaurant, and when they do, it can get a little crowded. Workers can be are not the friendliest sometimes.
author: Antonio W.

description: Authentic Korean BBQ, very tasty! They give you lots of side dishes. Really enjoyed it on the New Year's Day of 2018.
author: Sarah S.

description:
Solid Korean food. I haven't been to many Korean restaurants in the Bay area, so it is hard for me to compare. They had a pretty good selection of small plates, and they didn't give us dirty looks when we asked for second and third helpings! 

I really liked the japchae (clear noodles), seaweed salad, cucumbers... They gave us a complimentary steamed egg dish, and finished with sweet rice water desserts. 

Pretty good overall! Would love to have tried the BBQ and the cold noodles, too.
author: Julianna K.

description:
Everything was so good!

It's very rare to find a good Korean restaurant in San Francisco or perhaps even the Bay Area, but I'm so glad to have found this place! Usually a lot of restaurants don't serve as much variety in Korean cuisine. The menu you here, although very pricey, lists an extensive number of choices. Came here with a few friends on a Friday night around 7pm, and the wait wasn't too long. Something to be aware of, the dinner was particularly special for us because we all studied abroad in Korea together and decided to meet up that night. The fact that we've experienced Korean cuisine from the motherland might be factored into my critique.

SERVICE: Great service! They came by very often to check in to see if we're ready to order and also to grill the meat for us. They even provided complimentary 1 bowl of tofu soup with our meal and sweet rice drinks afterwards.

FOOD:
Banchan: (5/5) 9 plates of kimchi, bean sprouts, radish, acorn jelly, dried anchovies, tofu skins, and a few others. All of it tasted good.

Chamisul Soju: Normally I don't feel the need to comment on soju, since it's all the same anyways. But no, they also gave us this vial of "Red Knights" to add a few drops to our soju shots, which is something none of us have ever heard of before. I tried looking it up, and it apparently it's some sort of hangover cocktail vinegar base. I guess it made the soju a bit smoother?

Galbi, Bulgogi, Spicy Pork, and Pork Belly: (5/5) Okay, so this restaurant was slightly different due to the service provided. The servers would actually come by every now and then to ensure our meat was cooked properly, which I really appreciated. We didn't have to do much grilling ourselves as we reminisced about the good ole days back in Seoul. As we went through each plate of meat, I thought everything tasted great. I have nothing bad to say about any of our selections except for the prices. They would also provide a small basket of lettuce for wraps as well.

Seafood Pancake: (5/5) What I loved about this dish is that they fill the thick pancake with whole pieces of scallop inside along with pieces of other seafood.

A very nice place for Korean food.
author: Kevin S.

description:
Yummmmm... I tried Han Il Kwan for the first time on a Saturday afternoon with a girlfriend. There was no wait, but only because it was 3 pm. Surprisingly, the restaurant had a good amount of people inside though!

We ordered the japchae ($15) and the bulgogi ($24) to share. The prices may seem a bit steep, but once you factor in the endless supply of delicious banchan (side dishes), the huge portions, and the free tofu soup or steamed egg (yes, FREE!!), the prices will look fair. The banchan came out first and they were all amazing--my favorites were the fish cake, the pickled daikon, the broccoli, the bean sprouts, the pickled cucumber, and the little dried fish. Also rather noteworthy is the tea, which is the traditional roasted barley tea! 

The entrees came out pretty fast afterwards. The japchae portion was huuuge, had a great texture and sauce, and had the perfect ratio of noodles, veggies, and meat! Not that we needed any more meat... Because the bulgogi portion was even bigger! Meat was cooked well and the marinade was very yummy! Between the two of us, we probably only finished around 2/3 of each entree. We both took home takeout boxes full of japchae, bulgogi, and side dishes.

At the end, they will give you a super sweet rice drink. It sort of just tastes like rice water with little bits of rice at the bottom haha. Interesting!

For the total we both paid around $25 each. Not bad for a full tummy and a bunch of leftovers! I would definitely love to come back with a bigger party to try out more items!
author: Tara A.

description:
This is my go to place for Korean food in SF. Many places in the city cut corners by cutting down on the selection/quantity/quality of ban-chan (the free little side dishes you get at most Korean restaurants), or not spending the time to cook their broth for dishes like sunndubu or yukgaejang. You won't find any of that BS here. IMO, Han Il Kwan serves the most authentic Korean food in SF at a very reasonable price range.

They also have Korean BBQ, which is awesome. The service is attentive, and often times they would throw in a dish or two on the house, which is nice.

I've been to Han Il Kwan multiple times and for several years. Their quality is very consistent. Def my favorite Korean restaurant in town.
author: Joseph L.

description:
So. Much. Food!

If you can manage the wait for a table, you'll score quite the bang for your buck here. All those bus loads of tourists rolling in and out of here know what's up.

We left with about 2 days worth of leftovers and smelling like we'd just left a Korean kitchen. I love smelling delicious!
author: Loli L.

description:
I wish I could really rate this place higher, however, due to the experience we received three stars are more than generous.  We came here pretty early so we didn't wait much to sit down.

We order two bibimbap, tofu soup and fermented beans soup. The food was great, it also came with lots of sides and a complimentary soup. On the flip side, the service we received here was really bad.  I don't think I've ever come across a waitress as rude as the one we had.  I know it's a Korean place and by no means I was looking for fine dining service, however, she was pushy and she rushed us throughout the whole meal.

It's a shame that a place with great potential has rude staff.  Hopefully they can fix this issue.
author: Josh Giosue D.

description:
I'm not claiming to be a Korean food expert BUT I ate it almost constantly, I cook it at home, I have 3 cookbooks, and I lived in Korea for 1 year. WITH THAT SAID! Here is my review.

I made reservations via the San Francisco Urban Adventure Club 2 weeks ago for 8 people and I'm glad I did. I got there 30 mins early (6:30pm) an there were a ton of tables open, as soon as it hit 6:45pm there were people waiting for a table and writing their names down looking to get seated.

Staff was so friendly without over doing it. Whenever my table (of 6, not 8) and I would ask for something there was no attitude, they just got whatever we needed. We didn't feel like we were bothering them BUT we also didn't bug them lol.

We ordered Dinner - A for 6 people.This dinner option was huge! It fed all 6 of us and we are all foodies who at the moment happen to be very hangry. This dinner option is great for tables who have both a meat eater and vegetarians. There was a ton of meats, a ton of seafood, a ton of vegetables. The quality of the food was really good and the service again was impeccable.The only item on the menu that didn't wow the group was the spicy tofu stew. I didn't have any but everyone else said it was just "ok" compared to everything else we had. But everything else was fantastic! They also didn't get cheap with the food, there was a lot.

The ambience was great too. Everything about this please felt authentic. They even had alcohol options that I haven't seen in most places.

I look forward to eating here again. If you can bring six people and have dinner a then you will save a lot of money. Also, this menu option comes with bibimbap and small bowls of rice. If you don't want so much rice just tell them you dont want a small bowl.
author: Rani C.

description: Loved it not mind blowing but good experience I'd recommend this place. Could be slightly better if it was on the level of LA's Korea Town but happy to have discovered this place. Good attentive service too.
author: John N.

description:
food is consistently fantastic! service is consistently rude. this is a very busy environment and they will shoulder check you if you're in their way. i don't mind too much since it means they come out with food in a timely fashion. would give another star if service was that much better. 

don't come here for service. come here for fantastic Korean food, eat, and leave so the next crowd of people can eat and leave.
author: June K.

description: Easily one of the best (if not THE BEST) Korean food in SF! They have the best side dishes and a great lunch special if you want an earlier meal for a fraction of the dinner price.
author: Phi P.

description:
For whatever reason I haven't tried this place out, I finally came on a Monday late afternoon around 4PM. Luckily, we were the first seating group and got seated immediately. My grandparents live a couple blocks away so I have always seen Korean tour buses double parked in front of the restaurant and thought it was a tourist trap. Boy was I wrong! 

All table orders either come with the tofu soup with beef or the steamed egg. We got the tofu soup and it seemed like they added a little bit too much chili flakes in it but wasn't too spicy overall. I ordered the bimbambap in the stone pot and it was delicious. My only wish was that my stone pot was a little bit hotter as my friend got the seafood stone pot and hers was way hotter than mine. The flavors blended nicely and the vegetables tasted pretty fresh. 

Get here early so you don't have to wait over an hour to get a table because I think those tour groups reserve a lot of the restaurant when they are in town!
author: Jordan W.

description:
More than half of what we ordered was not good. Compared to the incredible Korean BBQ in L.A., I've got to give this place a one star rating. On top of there being no parking nearby, the quality of the meat is just not good. I was slightly hopeful when the price of the meats were a little bit higher ($25-$30) but nope, they were just overpriced. 

We opted for a table for where we wouldn't cook it ourselves. At legit Korean BBQs, the servers come to the table and cook it for you anyway, so to save ourselves time on the wait list, we decided to get seated at whatever table opened up first. 

The Non-marinated Beef Short Ribs came out way overcooked as did the Marinated Beef Rib Eye. Normally at Korean BBQ, I'll make sure that all the meat is eaten so it doesn't go to waste. Here, I just couldn't bring myself to finish all this dry and burnt meat. What a shame. 

The banchan was a letdown as well. You have to choose between the tofu soup and the steamed egg. You can't have both unless you pay more. You also can't get seconds on these items either. (I'll give props to the tofu soup. If they allowed free seconds on it, I'd maybe consider raising this review to two stars.)

I've had better Korean BBQ at food courts at a fraction of the price. Save yourself the disappointment and fulfill your Korean BBQ needs when you're in L.A. It'll cost more but it'll be so worth it.
author: Charles L.

description: The wait was sooooo long, and we didn't get a grill (not the restaurant 's fault) since we opted for whichever one as available first. There's no waiting area, so the hungry souls and gawking at you as you try to enjoy your food. The food was okay, I've had better. For me the wait, and thus the poor service was enough to decide not to come back.
author: Joanna C.

description:
If you want to enjoy cooking yourself, this Korean BBQ joint is one of the best in the city. Lots of options to eat from and the meat quality is good. The price point is going to be $22-28 per head (minus the drinks & tips). So not that cheap.

I recommend this.
author: Saad Z.

description: Delicious Korean food, easy parking, great sides, and perfect portions for the price. This will definitely be my new go to Korean restaurant in Sf.
author: Lauren H.

description: This is my favorite Korean restaurant that is not a buffet. They have a great lunch deal. The entrees are all under $15 and you get lots of accompanying side dishes. The service is always prompt and attentive here. I don't usually come here for dinner because it is pricey to the point where buffet is a better value.  Also tour groups can frazzle the workers to the detriment of service at times for dinner. I would give 5 stars for lunch and 4 for dinner.
author: Wallace C.

description: This Korean bbq place has a long history in SF. A nice size restaurant With delicious food especially those small side dishes are in good quality. Free steam egg is complimentary with entree. The service may not be the best, but that could be their traditional Korean culture. You are in the neighborhood, give it a try. You won't be disappointed.
author: Raymond L.

description:
Super good just like the food I ate when I was studying abroad in Korea. Definitely go during lunch special time. The tteobokki was spicy and the bibimbap was super cripsy from the pot. I love the banchan as well and it's refillable just like how it should be.
It is a bit pricy we got galbi for $30 so definitely go during lunch special time!
author: Grace Z.

description:
Highly recommend his place. I am a Korean. And i used to had LA korean food. I havent had this high quality korean food in Bay area naver. This is soooooo great, no MSG as I feel, no too much sugar. (Basically, korean food in USA, there are too much sugar.) I could feed the side dished to my baby xause it is so fresh. In addition, the servers are soooo nice and kind. They always smile and hello to my baby. My baby is picky, but she loves them a lot. My family decided to go there this weekend. We live in Walnut Creek, yes it is far and Oakland and solano has korean restuarants but we will be Hanilkwan again for cold noodle and yukejang. 
"Thanks for the mom's cook taste."
I recommended this place to my co workers this week. Haha
author: Seoung-joo Y.

description:
I was in SF not too long ago with my family and we took an Uber just to go to this place 
because this place is out of the main tourist area in SF.
I was pretty confident about my choice looking at the good reviews and rating but I do not recommend this plce 
                      
Maybe for people who doesnt have that much experience with korean food might think 
this place is good but all my family were not happy with our food and compared to the quality of the food the food is OVERPRICED
                              AND PLEASE READ THIS PART 
Another reason is as one of the side dish they serve kkakddugi which is kimchi with radish 
had a piece where the cut look like an arch that looked like a bite which could mean THEY RE-USE THE LEFT OVER SIDE DISHES. It did not have the mark of actually bite with teeth mark but. FYI usually the shape suppose to be square cut or triangle (end part) but never like a BITE MARK. It was my dad who found it and our family knew how angry my dad could get so we were saying i'm sure they don't re use the left over again to calm him down. 

I REALLY REALLY WISH I TOOK A PICTURE OF THE PIECE but I was too busy try to make sure my dad does not get super mad. 

Believe or not since i do not have an actual proof that they re-use their side dishes but just to 
let you guys know
author: Jenna L.

description:
We came here for my boyfriend's birthday and that food was great. Although the waiting can be slow (over 1hr on weekends), it becomes worthwhile after you order.

I highly recommend sitting on a grill table and cooking your own meat to get the full experience. Definitely coming back!
author: Veronica E.

description:
Excellent Korean food in the city! 

Very difficult to get a table  because of the tour buses, luckily we had a friend who speaks Korean to make a reservation for us, and they could barely accommodate us. We were a group of 10 and ordered the the set dinner for 8 people, and it was still more than enough food! 

Because of our table without a stove, we did not have the option to grill our own meat, but I actually like that better because it is less work for us and we won't smell like Korean bbq. Staff were very attentive, always asking if we are doing ok, refilling the banchan and giving us more water. The dishes were served one after the other very efficiently, we were overwhelmed with the many plates of delicious food all at once and had a hard time choosing which one to taste first!

They gave us plenty of banchan, all are delicious! Their Kalbi and spciy pork are all nicely marinated with plenty of flavor. The beef was juicy and tender, especially since it was grilled for us, we probably won't be able to get such a perfect grill ourselves. I also like the grilled fish a lot, although slightly dry, the meat is slightly salty and seasoned evenly through out with a perfect grill. The tofu soup is so good and flavorful! it is spicy, boiling hot, with very silky tofu inside. The tofu soup on its own already beats many other Korean restaurant in the area. I also love the steam egg and spicy squid. 

Han Il Kwan gave us plenty of food, and they are not stingy on the meat. The sweet rice drink at the end is also special. Although they serve big groups from tour buses, everything we had were great quality! I absolutely love every single dish we had and will definitely come back again and again!
author: Karen C.

description:
Long wait even during off hours. We came at 8 pm on a weekday and it was still a half hour wait. Just put your name down at the counter and wait for your name to be called.

The service was really friendly and attentive. They give you a ton of good banchan and it came with FREE tofu soup which was actually really delicious.

We got the kimchi pancake ($15) to share. It is a large serving size enough for a meal on its own. The pancake was perfectly fried and savory. We ordered the bulgogi ($24) which was super tender but a little on the dry side for me. The short ribs that a lot of people were ordering looked better. 

I got the hot stone bibimbap ($14). That was my favorite part of the meal. The rice gets so crispy and it's packed with tasty vegetables. 

Overall great Korean food but not necessarily worth a long wait.
author: Linda X.

description:
This place is a top hit! From the service to the menu, and the price? Unbelievably pocket friendly. 
I'll recommend and visit this place again and again!
author: Emmanuel A.

description: Not ask good as before, they don't offer rice punch or the pancake after meal anymore on lunch. But compare to other Korean restaurant in the city this is still the top ones.
author: Qing L.

description: First off, the food was AMAZING! I ordered the dolsot bibimbap along with the green onion pancake. It came with a variety of side dishes that covered half of the table! Very generous :) HOWEVER, the parking was insane. I had to drive around blocks and blocks and all of the parking spaces were barely accessible. Unless you're willing to spend most of your time looking for a parking space, I recommend parking on a street elsewhere, then walk to the restaurant itself.
author: Jasmine L.

description:
At first, they gave me 11 appetizers (Oh my got), then they surprised me with complimentary warm soup, then I destroyed my makarel and rice, after all they presented rice juice and tea! 
I've got my stomach ripped..
And this is for $16 only! And this is not McDonalds with their dump burgers and coffee for the same price
author: Ruslanio B.

description:
There's a lot of rubbish Korean food in SF, so I was stoked to discover a delicious, authentic meal at Han Il Kwan. My friends came here Sunday late in the afternoon so there wasn't any wait. You can either sit at a table/booth with grills or one without. None of us wanted BBQ, but the meat looked awesome.

The restaurant served amazing banchan...so many different plates, and they kept coming. I hate when Korean restaurant serve crappy banchan. They also offered complimentary things like barley tea, your choice of egg custard or tofu soup, and sweet rice tea at the end. 

My kimchi jigae was on point and it packed a lot of heat. Zero complaints. My friends enjoyed their tofu soup and bibimbap. Even the brusque service made the place feel more authentic.

I would come back in a heartbeat!
author: Valerie L.

description:
I'd been milking my birthday celebration for weeks. Seriously. It's one of those years where you are still in the earlier decade of something and this is possibly the last year before you become the middle of something of a decade. I was having second thoughts of coming here for food, because I called and they said the wait was 45 minutes. Time passed by quickly as we went to do some shopping nearby.

As many would tell you, Korean food in San Francisco is nowhere near as good as Los Angeles. I would venture to say Orange County Koren food is even better than the bay area. And Atlanta for that matter. Having said that, Han II Kwan is very good. It's popular because, I think, this is one of the only ethnic restaurants around the neighborhood, plus the Korean tour buses stop there. Their banchans are good and plenty. They have decent selection. One time they gave us tofu pot, pancakes AND steamed egg. This time we only got the usual plus the steamed egg. I grew up on that steamed egg dish. It's my go to comfort food. Did I mention that I'm 9% Korean? Ah, it's in my blood to appreciate the banchans. I asked for seconds. They bring them out immediately. 

I think the soup is very good. I tend to get the fish roe soup here. The beef short ribs seems to be a huge portion for one person. A lot more than what you'd get in other Korean places. They have cold Korean beer. It's a lager and very light, it reminds of me of the beer I consumed as a young girl in northeastern China. 

The best part about this restaurant is its location. A bit quieter than the Inner Richmond area's Korean restaurants on Geary. I recall being much younger and going to Brother's BBQ on Geary every Thursday with some young male consultant types, the gathering was more about drinking and dating fest than eating Korean food. It was the scene back then, and it was that memory that dominated my impression of Korean food in the avenues. It's about time then, to find something else to replace that memory with. Something homey, pleasant, tasty, and non controversial. I think I found that something else here.
author: Victoria E.

description:
My party of 3 came in for an early weeknight dinner as we happened to be in the neighborhood (and the restaurant we wanted to go to was closed for MLK). We were seated right away as there was only two other parties at the time. 

We opted for ala carte instead of grill ourselves and had the bulgogi (rib eye), seafood pancake, kimchi tofu stew, and dol-sot bibimbap (the one in the stone bowl).
