The waitstaff was super nice and brought a pot of steamed egg with our banchans. Everything was super delicious! The meat was tender and flavorful, the tofu stew was hearty, the bibimbap was the perfect consistency with a great ratio of rice/veggies/meat, the seafood pancake was crispy with ample critters and the steamed egg was fluffy and satisfying. I also loved the variety of the banchans, though there is no fried yellow croaker if you're wondering.

Service was quick, the waitresses were nice, and we left super stuffed for less than $30 pp. I can see now why this is a Richmond institution for Korean fare. I'd come back in a hurry if I'm craving Korean food in the area.
author: Angela L.

description: Came here for the first time, waiting time is 45mins. But the food is very ordinary. I don't feel the 45min waiting is justified. The service isn't great either.
author: Emmy P.

description: I went there on Sunday afternoon. It was full. We ordered Korean bbq but ventilation hood wasn't working well. It was very difficult to sit there with all the smoke. Food was good but I don't think I'll go there again.
author: Simbel G.

description:
I came here at 6:30 on a Friday night: prime dinner time. Our group of 4 waited 25 minutes, but when we sat down a big crowd came so I guess we were pretty lucky!

I got the Soft Tofu Soup with vegetable & beef broth. It was good, nothing super special. I didn't realize the table came with a complimentary Tofu Soup or a Steamed Egg dish. Since we already ordered the Tofu Soup, we got the steamed egg. For someone who doesn't like egg much, I actually thought it was pretty good! My friend ordered a beef bibimbap and it was HUGE, definitely enough for leftovers. The side dishes were all delicious, no complaints here!

This place was a little pricey, but you can expect that from many Korean restaurants. Service-wise, they weren't the most attentive... it was pretty hard asking them for a bill, and they didn't bother refilling our sides when we finished them early on. But I'm not really picky with service, so I don't mind that they ignored us most of the night. Busy restaurant, totally understand.
 No particular wow-factor, but I may come back if I happen to be in the area.
author: Jenny C.

description: Ate here for the second time in the past year.  There was a wait when we arrived at 7pm on a Tuesday but it moved fast.  Banchans were a higher quality than some other Korean restaurants, but they were never refilled even though we asked and they nodded that they would be provided.  The food was good and the prices moderate.  We had  Kalbi for 2 last time and it was high quality but expensive at over $30/serving. Would come again but try for a less busy time for better service.
author: Seong M.

description:
Yummy KBBQ. :)

After my bf found out about how kbbq is my fave food, he started taking us to kbbq alot. One night few months ago, we came to Han II Kwan for dinner, and it definitely did not disappoint. Bf really liked their tea (barley/corn tea) so much that he had a phase where he kept on drinking that tea at home. Haha.. 

Pretty okay selections of banchans, but they don't have my bf's fave which is the pickled radishes/carrots. Of all the banchans there, I like the fishcake and potato. The meat is very delish. We usually get the kalbi and bulgogi. Service is usually pretty attentive.

The only complaint we have about this place is that it's catered to tour buses. There's even a spot/signage for tour bus parking right in front of the restaurant. When there is a tour bus, you're basically f'ed cause you'll end up waiting for awhile for a table.
author: Amy C.

description:
I guess i was really cold last night looking for parking that I didn't notice the tour bus sign that everyone's complaining about. However I must say that it's not surprising that Asians would do that. They give no shits about customer service and want to serve as many people as possible. 

I didn't have to wait long but the menu is slightly confusing. They have the usual Korean short ribs but they only list it under raw food. I had to ask if they serve dishes cook because I need to cook for myself that. They serve the usual side dishes but I was very disappointed that they add jalapeños to their Fishcake. The seaweed was a lot more sour than I'm used to. 

The dishes cool down quick! When my kalbi cooled down, it was really chewy. I save my leftovers to have breakfast the next morning and so far over half the pieces are chewy.

I will not be returning because the quality is not worth two entrees for $70.
author: Danae L.

description:
Came back here to try the BBQ area and it was AMAZING!

My table ordered the pork belly and marinated beef short ribs, and it was delicious! We couldn't finish eating the side dishes because we were all focused on eating the pork belly and the ribs. Yumm! Everybody left with a smile on their faces! :)
author: Patrick T.

description:
Good solid Korean BBQ but poor service! I get that it's busy and there's a lot of tables to attend to but they 1) forgot an item we ordered, 2) never refilled our water 3) took at least 3 attempts to flag the waitress down to refill our tea and 4) took forever just to have them collect our credit card to pay for the bill.

Food wise, good quality meats, good portion and I love that they will refill your vegetables! They also have the grapefruit soju here!

The mixed review is mainly due to service. I wouldn't say that their food is good enough for me to want to wait in line to eat it. I think that I'll be back only if it's on an off day where there's no wait. Otherwise, there are a few other kbbq places I still want to try!
author: Shelly W.

description: Galbi here is soo good.  Definitely high-quality meat, fresh, beautifully cooked.  The kimchee pancake is solid--nice, fluffy, flavorful, and crispy.  All the servers are middle-aged Korean women that really hustle.  While we were being seated, a whole tour bus of Korean tourists came to dine at the same time.  To our surprise, we didn't notice any interruption of service and food came out well prepared as always.  A sign of good management.  Really enjoy this Korean BBQ spot, will definitely be back.
author: Matt B.

description:
The fucking wait! But the food is good. Been here plenty of times. They always fail to bring my egg side and give it to others instead (but they do remember all other banchan) so I always have to ask for it again. 

Very good portion size. Great flavors. If you see a huge tour bus parked outside with Korean letters on it, try another day ;)
author: Anees L.

description: The place was very packed and the service was okay because of how busy it was but that's okay and understandable. The kimchi stew had a very authentic flavor but didn't have any pork in it. The complimentary soft tofu stew was good but not the best I've tried. The ox-bone stew was also very hearty. Overall the food was great, and I would come back again.
author: Qingbo Z.

description:
I'm one of those angsty control-freak people who likes to plan out my day in detail and make use of every minute. You think I'd explode from a 1-hour wait for dinner, but for Han Il Kwan there is no arguing that every bite was worth every minute.

The deliciousness begins with the colorful variety of banchan, consisting mostly of pickled veggies so you don't feel quite so guilty with all the carnivorous entrees to come. And they do not skimp--no odd non-Korean side dishes (I've seen mayo fruit salad and canned corn at other places). They even serve the small dried fish which is a rare banchan nowadays (probably due to its considerably higher cost in comparison to alternatives like canned corn).

I usually don't care much for beef short ribs, but the kalbi jjim is heavenly. While most kalbi seems dry and a bit tough in texture (not to mention the extra time and efforts needed to dissect out the bones), the kalbi jjim is more like beef stew, with surprisingly moist and tender chunks of beef that melt in your mouth like slow-cooked pork--props to pro cooking technique rather than relying on extra fattiness for that melty goodness that is on par with pork belly. Just a hint of spice is added, placing the emphasis on the rich beef flavors. The vegetable condiments are good as well, but unfortunately there is no space in my stomach for potatoes when it comes to dinner at Han Il Kwan.

The memorable kalbi jjim was definitely the highlight, especially because it's a dish you can't get at most Korean places. We also got the beef bulgogi and spicy pork for kBBQ, bean paste soup, and japchae, all of which were good as well. I especially liked the japchae, which wasn't too greasy and had a lot of veggies and beef. The only potential problem is that the spicy pork was marinated in orange-red sauce, so it was hard to be sure that it was cooked.

The meal finished off with a sweet rice drink. Although it's listed as a recommended item on Yelp, I found it interesting but thought it was too sweet. (Maybe I'm too used to 30% sugar from all my boba orders)

The damage was $20/person total--not bad for all the amazing Korean specialties and endless kBBQ. Worth it despite the 1-hour wait and my extra work volunteering as tribute to do the kBBQ cooking.

Side note: They have better ventilation than YakiniQ, so you actually don't come home smelling like you sat in a sauna of kBBQ smoke.
author: Edna C.

description: This place was referred by a friend who lives in the neighborhood. It was our first real Korean meal and it was fantastic. We chose the marinated beef ribeye and the vermicelli noodle dish.  Both were delicious. It was also very affordable and the sake was great!
author: Matthew L.

description:
I've been here twice and I must say , I am really impressed with this restaurant. My girlfriend introduced me to this place and now it's so really starting to become one of our go to places for korean food! 

A couple reasons why i like this restaurant:
Very good portions, both times i've gone, I've left the building too full to walk.
Priced very well, not expensive and definitely worth the price.
They are generous with the small plates, everyone loves korean food for their appetizer small plates! some places are stingy but this restaurant is definitely not!
Servers are very polite and nice! Service is important in order to enjoy your food!
They give a free soup, usually steamed tofu for free!

A couple reasons it might suck:
Parking is really hard to find in this neighborhood. For us it has been sort of a hit or miss in terms of parking but be prepared to spend some time looking around(or just find parking a couple blocks out)
author: Jack Z.

description: Great Bi Bim Bap! The pickled starters even included octopus. They used good quality ingredients and it was prepared correctly. Worth coming out to the Avenues.
author: Rob W.

description: The place was so great! My friend and I are from Los Angeles so we have had so much great Korean food back there! We both felt there were relatively few Korean restaurants around SF. This one was really a great one! First of all, the owner offered a large amount of side dishes, six or seven. Most importantly, they were so delicious and the quality was not lowered because it was free. The food we ordered were so great! Love it! Definitely recommend people go!!
author: Ziyi W.

description:
The Korean tour groups that stop here know what's up! The seafood pancake, kalbi, spicy rice cakes and cold noodles were all scrumptious. Hell, even the complimentary banchan dishes were good. I was really digging the steamed egg served in a sizzling stone pot. 

We walked in hoping for one good meal, and left the restaurant with leftovers for days. I can't think of anything better than smelling like kimchi all week.
author: Suany W.

description:
Oh my god - easily the best Korean BBQ I've had in the city (although I've never tried Brothers, who appear to be its closest competitor). 

All my favorite Korean BBQ places used to be in South Bay, but Han II Kwan is easily better - both in price and in flavor.

+spicy bulgogi - best I've ever hand
+pork belly
+banchan - the marinated cucumbers are the best. I think I ate 3 dishes of these

pro tips: 
1. BBQ tables are fun, but add significantly to the wait. While I love the do it yourself BBQ, the next time I go, I would consider getting the normal table just so I can get started on the noshing sooner
2. a simple, spicy tofu soup comes with the meal, so don't bother ordering another one
3. dessert is a sweet rice drink. it's delicious.
author: Patricia K.

description: This place was crazy busy, and the wait was pretty long when our party came here on a weekend night. But the food was bomb! We actually ordered a lot (too much...): seafood pancake, bulgogi, spicy pork, and the tofu soup. Along with the banchan, it was a really filling meal. We all agreed that the bulgogi tasted better than the spicy pork in taste, and the seafood pancake was not those wimpy ones -- this one is DENSE. Great place to eat and enjoy with friends/family, but I personally didn't enjoy being surrounded by waiting parties while we were enjoying our meal. This place was just too popular.... Be careful of wait times and an overall sardine-packed vibe going here.
author: Vicky N.

description:
Foods:
We did not order the barbecue and mostly ordered soupy dishes.
* Overall, I think the dishes were comfort food. This is a place you can visit when you don't want to cook. Compared to Boston area Korean restaurants, this place is pretty much similar, imho (contrary to my expectation that Bay area would exceed Boston). 

Service:
* The service was a bit slow during our visit even though there were several servers.
author: Rafael W.

description:
If you see a big tour bus parked outside, go elsewhere. They will be too busy and too focused on said tour group than you and yours. For example our last adventure here (spoiler: we starve) they sit us down, take our order then an hour later we flag down our waitress to ask for some side dishes cause yknow we hungry (kinda why we here right?). We have not gotten our food or the drinks we ordered. Also why are we asking for side dishes? Shouldn't they just bring us some ... Like every other table here? 

After another half hour or so goes by and now with empty side dishes that we've cleaned and scrapped for every drop of sustenance we can manage since we are seriously hangry by now, we ask them "where is our food?"

You guessed it, they forgot our order. Nice. They non-chalantly ask us what we ordered.. seriously it's been so long even I forgot. I respond by asking for a menu cause that would kinda help. 

After our food finally arrives, I ask again... Seriously where are my drinks? They promise yet again to bring it. Keep in mind it's literally right behind me in a windowed fridge. It's a rhetorical question. I know where it is. What I'm actually asking is why do you hate me and want me to die alone, starving and parched?

We finish our food and nope the drinks never come but you know what did? A bill with the drinks on it. Lovely. Apparently they want me to die alone, starving , parched AND penniless. Thanks but no thanks.
author: Peter W.

description: It's a busy restaurant long wait but the food was good. Nice friendly staff. I'll go back soon.
author: Lili L.

description: I've been here once in the past and didn't do the KBBQ option. Second time around I was determined and had planned all day for KBBQ. So we were looking forward to this meal all day. Came here on a Friday around the time they had just open. I already anticipated a wait which I didn't mind at all. Added ourselves on the wait list for two people and waited. The lady approached us a couple of times to check if we still wanted the BBQ option and we said yes. 30 minutes pass by, then 45 minutes pass by and we are watching all these groups getting seated. She finally came up to us again and realized that she had totally skipped us on the list. We were close to the top of the first page and she had crossed out all the names before and after and had seated a bunch of people on the second page already. Those who were seated when we got there were already leaving. She apologized quietly with her face turned away and told us that we will get the next BBQ table. Great, we waited this long, might as well stick through it (even though we were getting hella hungry and irritated already). Soon after, we saw a table leave and figured YES, FINALLY. However, the lady went ahead and seated this other couple who were standing in front of us. At this point I was so pissed. I wanted to go up to her and say something but instead we decided not to make a commotion and just walked out. This was way past an hour (probably 1.5 hours) of standing around waiting. Completely disappointed at the service here!
author: Tina C.

description:
I've tried enough Korean restaurants in the Bay Area to know that I need to keep my expectations low. Han Il Kwan seemed like one of the more promising options, however. On Labor Day, we stopped by at 1:15pm for lunch and had to wait about 20 minutes before we were seated.

The decor is cute with some booths and Korean style roofs inside. When we were finally seated, we both ordered the dolsot bibimbap lunch special. Dolsot bibimbap is one of my favorite Korean dishes and this version was average at best. I did like that the rice got a great crisp. I didn't like that the egg was cracked unevenly so half of it was scrambled and half of it was uncooked sunny-side up. I also do not appreciate cheap chewy bulgogi in my bibimbap; I'd prefer to pay more for galbi.

The banchan were alright but since japchae is sold as an entree, it did not come as part of the banchan spread. The meal ended with a sweet rice drink. For $10 + tax/tip, it's a pretty good value for SF. Quality-wise though, Han Il Kwan is 3 stars even on the Bay Area curve.
author: Yi Z.

description:
The line is long.  The wait is worth it.  Korean BBQ how I've missed you.

Tucked into a quiet location on sleepy Balboa street, Han Il Kwan is a clean, tight and efficiently run Korean BBQ that is worth a visit.  We waited about forty minutes to be seated at a BBQ table (it went quickly. Chatting with a friend, the time flew by) and once seated ordered one bulgogi bbq ($24) and one mixed seafood ($23). The dinner set-up that comes with the BBQ includes all the beautiful Korean side dishes to nosh on: rice, seaweed salad, pickled daikon, pickled potato, kimchi, sesame mung beans, pickled cucumbers, spicy tofu soup, warm tea, the whole nine yards. This is the perfect meal for the constant grazer, and I fit the bill. As far as Korean BBQ goes, a very solid stop.  

The BBQ table set up here is clean to a fault. They even changed the cooking element mid meal to ensure we had the best grilling experience, after we charred a few bits.  The warm sake ($6 for a large) is a nice complement to the meal, especially on a very foggy and windy summer night in San Francisco.
author: Rachel H.

description: Food is decent to solid. One of the best korean bbq spots in SF, but still nothing to write home about. Their seafood and kimchee pancakes are pretty good. Lines are insane due to a regular rotation of tour buses packed with tourists. They get ushered into some large rooms in the back, but still take up a lot of seating and kitchen/serving staff capacity.
author: Denise H.

description: I've been here a couple of times and it's pretty good and consistent every time. Remember to always make a reservation, there's always a crowd of people waiting to eat. We had 8 people so instead of everyone deciding what to get, we got the set menu for 8 people. We didn't know if there would be enough food but there was plenty...we had bulgogi, spicy pork, mackerel, japchae, tofu soup, squid, steamed egg, fried things...lots of things which I can't remember. It was all good! I'd come back, oh wait, I already have...
author: Kylie L.

description: This place is on the tour schedule of several Korean tour buses. They show up at 4:30 and 5:30 on Saturdays. Book a table in advance if you don't want to wait in line and done go when the tour buses show up! I called 2 weeks in advance and got one of the tables with the BBQ in the middle so we were able to cook our Bulgogi and Chicken. The Bulgogi is so flavorful and delicious. The chicken was nothing special. We did the group menu that comes with several dishes to share and it was fabulous. Noodles, fish, meat, soup, baked egg, BeeBimBop and more condiments than you have seen in your life. We had a fabulous time. The staff is not very friendly or super attentive but you get what you need. Really great food.
author: Nettie A.

description: Excellent value during lunch. $15 Kalbi lunch gave plenty of meat, complimentary tofu soup to share and Bancha. Service is normal, and a complimentary sweet drink at the end. You won't find deals like this anywhere.
author: Jorge T.

description:
We decided to come here because the reviews were really good for this place. It was super busy and we waited a little over an hour for a BBQ table. When they finally called my party, the waitress tells me that my party should just do regular Korean food instead of BBQ because the wait would be too long. Even though we wanted BBQ since that's the reason we signed up for it, we decided to just do regular Korean food since we had been waiting for awhile and we were all really hungry. But when we sat down, a BBQ table had just opened up. We were going to say something and to try to get that table but since we had already decided what we wanted, we decided not to. 

I ordered a seafood bibimbap and it came with a lot of seafood! I love eating the crunchy rice on the bottom of the stone pots and this crunchy rice came out perfectly but left a pool of oil on the bottom of the pot. 

My friend ordered the braised beef short rib which took awhile but it was not bad! Definitely enough to feed two people. 

Some of the pictures says that they give a complimentary sweet rice drink at the end of the meal and although I did see some tables get it, mine did not. 

The food was only mediocre to me. I didn't think it was amazing nor did I really think it was worth the wait.
author: Melissa L.

description:
The Korean Food is real good.

Popular location

Note Their is Korean Tour Bus that stops by and fills the most of the seating.

However, the Korean Tufu Soup is Comp.

Yahoooo
author: Ralph Y.

description: The crab in the soup isn't fresh enough. The side dishes are not sour but just too sweet. The meat is fine. However, overall is 3 stars, can't give a better review.
author: Vanessa Z.

description:
ANOTHER ONE (DJ KHALAD VOICE). This place would be a go to Korean Restaruant for me, if it wasn't all the way in San Francisco. It's coo though, I'm sure I will be back. As we put our name of a list for 2, the wait had to have been at least 25+minutes. This Korean house is the home of the asian community who seem to be visiting SF and party buses are coming every 10-15mins dropping a group off to eat at HAN!

FOOD:
The food is very delicious and very inexpensive, I have to recommend this place to all of my yelp pals in the SF area who simply loves asian dishes. The Kimchi Pancakes is a must try delicious dish!

SERVICE:
Besides that very long wait because of all the party groups, the service is quick, fast, and organized. Making sure customers are where they need to be, moving quickly to try and get people seated as fast as possible although they have so much going on already. That's just from what I can tell about the service. 

The owner is doing a great job down here making sure his customers are leaving satisfied and that his/ hers employees are being treated with respect while making sure everyone they are serving is happy. All in all I RECOMMEND MUST TRY
author: Andre L.

description: All of the staff is very nice to customers, but Younghee is our favorite waitress, she is very friendly and she is a very nice person.  It makes me feel at home and she is a wonderful person. Don't give me wrong, but I wish every waitress could be like her. The food and the service is very good.
author: Os G.

description:
Went to lunch at 12 pm on Friday (12/11/2015), and there was a booth free, which was great since we didn't have to wait at all to get seated.  However, when we were done eating, which was around 12:45 or so, there was a small line of people (probably 4 small groups) waiting to get seated.

Food:
Lunch Special - Galbi ($13.95) - This is my go-to lunch order whenever I decide to eat lunch here.  They give you quite a bit of meat, unlike some other places.  The only bad thing about this dish is they always give you one piece with a big bone in it, which is pretty hard to eat, especially if the dish gets a little cool so I highly recommend trying to eat the meat off of this bone first or you probably won't be able to get any meat off of it later on.

Banchans - they give around 8 or so banchans each time I'm here for lunch with a small order of fried fish cake? which I think is the best.  For the rest of the banchans, you can always request multiple free refills (except for the fish cake) so if you like something, you can always ask for me, which is great.

Soup - They also give you a free bowl of tofu soup, so yay for that.

Service:
There's usually only like 2 waitresses during lunch so it might take a bit of flagging down to get something if they are busy, but I don't really have any complaints, especially since they'll keep getting us more free banchans. :)

Overall:
Food is good and service is decent so I'll continue coming back here for lunch.
author: Gilda W.

description: We came here on a Sunday night around 7 and waited around 30 minutes which wasn't too bad for a weekend. I love all the banchan they bring out and that they give you a complimentary tofu soup. We all ordered the bibimbap, which is a huge serving and two people could definitely share this entree. Everything was tasty and delicious, and the customer service was great! Would come back to try their kbbq side.
author: Cheyne T.

description:
Food:  This is my go to Korean Place!

-Kalbi Chim (Short Rib Stew)- Want a hearty meal that you have for 2 days!??!?!?!?  Order this.  You will get a big pot of short ribs, carrots, and potatoes.  Given the amount of side dishes you get...I rarely am able to finish this on my own so I end up having this on the second day...and yes it's just as delicious.
-Rice Cake Dumpling Soup - I am a fan of carbs so this hits the spot.  You get the chewy rice cakes and dumplings in a very rich and hearty broth.  
-Dukk Bokki (Sauteed Rice Cakes) - Rice Cakes in a spicy sauce.  What can I say...I like my rice cakes.

Service: The staff are fairly friendly and attentive.

Ambiance:  Like all Korean BBQ joints...you will walk out smelling like beef!  Not so much a bad thing.  It tends to be packed and can get a little bit loud.

Overall:  Well this is my go to so I keep on going back when I want some good ole korean food!
author: Spencer Q.

description:
This place is great - I've been looking for decent Korean food in SF since I moved and they did not disappoint. Disclaimer: I haven't actually had their KBBQ, but we tried their soft tofu soup, yukgaejang (spicy beef soup), seafood pancake and bibimbap both times that we went. It's definitely crowded on Friday nights and you'll have to wait anywhere from 30 min to an hour during peak times, but if you're looking for a legit Korean restaurant in the city it's a great option. Another plus, they give you a steamed egg on the house and have great side dishes, that they'll come over and replenish as you get low. 

I've seen people come in with reservations on Friday nights and weekends (just call ahead) and not have to wait as long, so if you're planning on coming (especially if you have a group), definitely go that route.
author: Ada C.

description:
This is my go to Korean restaurant in the city. My fave meat is Kalbi and Pork Belly - so yum!!! All their stews are really good especially Kimchi Jigae and Dong Tae Jigae. 

Seafood pancakes have lots of filling and not too much batter which is great and their steamed egg is the cherry on top!!! LOVE!
author: CY C.

description: I came here around 12pm and the wait was around 15 minutes. Sometimes they will have a big bus full of tourists coming here on a weekend so the wait will be longer. The first time I came here on a weekday there was no line. The kimichi here is fresh and the fish cakes are tasty. Also, I really liked the seafood pancake since it was crispy and steamed egg is given with a bibimbap I ordered. I would highly recommend trying this restaurant.
author: Joanna C.

description:
Finally, a solid KBBQ spot in SF! Why are they so hard to find here?

After a 1.5-hour wait for a barbecue table on a Saturday night, you can imagine how hangry we were. Also, our tummies deceived us as we ordered more than we could order. But because you have to order two BBQ meats when sitting at a BBQ table, we doubled up on kalbi, and that was the right choice! Now, I have kalbi leftovers to eat for lunch today, whaddup!

The banchan was off the chain as it included steam egg (hell yes)! Definitely had some meat sweats last night!
author: Nitar L.

description:
As good as it gets for Korean food in San Francisco. To be honest, that's not saying...very much, but Han Il Kwan is definitely respectable, if a bit pricey. Having grown up in Seoul and Orange County, it's hard to beat SoCal for Korean food, especially Korean BBQ, but Han Il Kwan has high-quality meat and authentic Korean dishes ranging from kimchi-jeon, the cold buckwheat noodles (nangmyeon), and good banchan (side dishes). 

The menu is comprehensive, and you have the option of grilling your own (KBBQ-style), to getting a regular table (where you can still order kalbi and other meats). They have a pretty big space, but expect the wait to be quite long, especially on the weekends. The prices are a bit high, but it's Korean-owned and operated, so you know you're getting the authentic experience. 

I'm quite fond of the kalbi, all the "pancakes," and their egg custard jjim (savory). It's a bit far away in the middle of Richmond, but if you're craving real Korean food, it's worth the trip.
author: Kate M.

description:
So. Much. Food. Complimentary steamed egg dish that my entire family really seemed to enjoy. The spicy levels are legit here. Definitely be ready to handle your spices. But for non-spicy eaters there are a ton of options too. My cousin really enjoyed his kalbi for example.

Banchan side dishes have many vegan options. There is also a sweet rice drink at the end for dessert that is really fun to try. You can ask for jap chae without meat if you are vegan like me. Lots of options and good for groups!
author: Evonne L.

description: I haven't eaten anything better than this in a long time. This is my first time eating Korean Barbecue and I must say it does not disappoint in the least. With any KBBQ they bring you all the sidestep put on the meats and they are all unique and interesting in their own right. The two of us devoured the chicken and beef but it was probably suited for a meal for two. Paired with an ice cold, refreshing Hite beer, this is a meal you are sure to remember.
author: Michael A.

description:
Good authentic Korean food in SF. They had a good selection of banchan (side dishes) with your choice of free steamed egg or spicy tofu stew. Plenty of food to stuff yourself.

Tried the following:
1. Kimchi pancakes
2. Octopus with vegetables
3. Tofu dolsot bibimbap

Saw another table's japchae and it looked very good. I'd totally come back again to try that next time I'm craving Korean.
author: Diana C.

description: Probably my favorite place to go for a comprehensive Korean meal.   They have a set meal deal where you play $140 or so for a "dinner for six."  I usually get this when I come here but share it amongst our group of four.  The amount of food is perfect if everyone is hungry, and comes with a wide variety of dishes including Korean BBQ.  Super yummy!  Yeah!
author: Mason W.

description:
Probably the best Korean food I've had in the city!! It is true tho - loooooong waits, probably due to huge Korean tour buses that unload into the restaurant at an alarming frequency. There's a new group every hour!! They really hustle those groups. But they tend to block off all the back room tables for them, so at least you don't have to eat in the middle of them. It just means a lot fewer tables for the rest of us :( and there a lot of us non-tour-group people. My group of 8 got pretty lucky. We arrived around 5:30pm on a Sunday night and I put our name down (maybe 8th in line). I heard a group of 4 complaining that they had arrived at 4:30 and were still waiting!! That. Sucks. Anyhow, we actually managed to be seated around 6, not too long after that group of 4. We must have come at the end of the first wave of the dinner crowd so they all finished eating around the same time and a bunch of tables opened up at once. Whew! I'm glad we didn't have to wait too long because we probably would have gone elsewhere and missed out on the AMAZING FOOD!!

Also, bring a Korean friend with you. The servers were definitely ignoring me blatantly when I was trying to get an estimate on the wait time -.- I've also just noticed that they tend to be a lot nicer and attentive on waiting your table when there are Koreans haha ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

Onto the food! We got the set dinner for 8ppl ($180) and it was plenty of food with leftovers! It came with a ton of entrees and a large bibimbap bowl and tofu soup. The bibimbap was reaaaaally good, I definitely want to come back and just order one of them as my meal. The japchae was also delicious as well as the pork bulgogi and kalbi that we ordered (you get to choose two meats from a selection). The meat came with lettuce wraps and fermented bean paste which was yummy. Everyone gets a bowl of rice as well - overall a very well-rounded meal with tons of variety! I would def recommend the set menu if you have a group of 6 or larger. 

Other pluses were the delicious hot barley tea and also the sweet for rice drink they bring at the end of your meal!

Oh almost forgot... pro-tip: they take reservations but NOT same-day res (we tried that first) so make a reservation at least a day in advance to hopefully skip out on the long lines!!
author: Grace D.

description:
Growing up, I've always passed this place while on the bus going home.  I thought no one ate there except tourists who were bused in.  My friend took me here because I had a hankering for a bi bim bap dol sot.  Yes I like the crunchy rice underneath the dish - don't judge.

I ordered a beef bi bim bap dol sot.  It was ok.  It did come with a lot of mushrooms which I did not like and I had to pick out.  The crunchy rice wasn't as crunchy as I would have liked.

They also serve you a bunch of small plates - on the house.  At the end of the meal you get what I assume is cane juice - which I did not partake.

Service is efficient.  They leave you alone.  Prices are ok.  Street parking if you are so lucky to land one here.  It's very difficult to park in this area.
author: Wendy H.

description:
Best Korean bbq i've had in town. Highly recommended by a few of my Korean friends. Truly exceptional food and very authentic. 

If you could not make a reservation for a bigger group, the wait is a little too much. But worth it!!!
author: Helen L.

description: The food is great but the staff lacks of friendliness. I felt like everything was being rushed. Not a smile, not a thank you. Please improve your service and be a little more corteous with customers
author: Leesly V.

description:
My boyfriend and I always come here for lunch and only once for dinner. It's our go-to Korean. Why? Because the food is sooooo good. And the price is great too. $30 for two at lunch for two dishes. The service is okay since it does get pretty crowded but the ladies are always very nice.
Items we really like:
Bulgogi (lunch special)
Galbi (lunch special)
Kalbi
Japchae (we usually ask for it spicy, it's amazing)
Bibimbap stone pot

We've never had to make reservations and have never had to wait too long for a table. But I do recommend making reservations since they often have Korean tour buses coming in (in response to those who don't understand why they couldn't be seated immediately even with all the empty tables) 

Parking is a pain in the ass lol we live 4-5 blocks away and even parking near our house is sometimes hard.
author: Chi N.

description: Honestly the best Korean restaurant in SF. They have such fresh kimchi and just quality food. It's a little pricey but honestly it's worth it for superb Korean food.
author: Alexa R.

description: It's crowded. It's good. Very nice wait staff. Cooking at the table is a helpful first time experience. Time two, the kitch will do just fine. Everything but the steamed egg dish got my attention. Go there.
author: Hay S.

description: Definitely a good Korean restaurant. They have the best kimchi pancake. My husband and I never finish the kimchi pancake but it is so good here that we actually ate it all. Staff are courteous and very hard working. We had to take all of our food home because we were so full from the banchan and kimchi pancake. The Korean restaurants in my area do not offer rice cakes so when I saw it here we had to order it. Would return if in the area!
author: Erica R.

description: Wow this place is wonderful! Very accommodating staff and friendly service. We were moved to a quiet back room after a table of drunk guys too shout-y. Nice big portions and a diverse menu! The banchan is to die for. Best I've had on the west coast. Get the galbi or the kimchi pancakes you won't regret it!
author: Hel D.

description: Every time my partner and I come down to the bay we always make sure to come here before we leave. It's so comforting -- from the decor to the staff that reminds me so much of my family to the top notch assortment of korean food I always leave happy and with leftovers enough for second dinner :') I have a big soy allergy (which suuuucks because I'm Korean) but I still come here and get whatever I want because, as my partner says, sometimes food for the spirit outdoes the pain your body might feel. I may break out into hives tomorrow but at least my little korean heart is happy
author: Jin M.

description: One of the best Korean restaurants I've had! I love that they give a free tofu soup (or steamed egg) to each table. We ordered the seafood bibimbap, sauteed squid, beef short rib hotpot, and the seafood pancake. Everything had large portions, great flavor, and plenty of seafood in it. Our favorite dish was the seafood bibimbap but it was all delicious. Would definitely go back and recommend to anyone who loves Korean food!
author: Angela C.

description: Such a great, interactive experience for date night or a night out with the family. You are traditionally served many different side dishes with your main course including tea, soup, a variety of salads + more. I highly recommend Han II Kwan for both the tasty food and experience!!
author: Racquel T.

description:
Went for lunch with my hubby and parents a couple days ago. Enjoyed their dol sot bibimbap, haemul pajeon, soon dubu jigae, kimchi jigae, sullungtang, and all the banchan. The dishes were delicious, some banchan a little on the sweet side for our taste, but overall very good. The food came out quickly despite a full dining room.

They were quite busy, so the service was adequate, but not exceptional. I'd go back.
author: Sharon Y.

description: Hands down, best Korean BBQ I've ever had. The marinated beef short rib and marinated beef ribeye are my favorites. They give complimentary spicy tofu soup for small groups and steamed egg for larger groups. It's ALWAYS crowded at dinner time, so go for an early dinner at around 4-5 pm. The service is good, too. They check up regularly and help you cook meat if you're doing BBQ at the table. Closed on Wednesdays.
author: Bob J.

description:
HOLY COW THE FOOD IS DELICIOUS! Oh my goodness. I have never had Korean food like this before! Let me tell you, parking is a nightmare, but it was well worth it that I can't even dock a star. We got the Bulgogi, Brisket and I believe Pork Belly and as I was eating, all I could think about was MORE MORE MORE. So delicious! Even all the sides they give you was amazing. I like EVERY SINGLE ONE OF THEM. I usually don't like a few, but all of these I tried, and loved. They also gave us so free soup which was very nice and also very good.

I can't wait to go back. I'm so hungry for more just thinking about it.
author: Kristina S.

description: This place is yummm. It's a hidden gem here in the bay where they do Korean food the right way. Swing on by and pick up some kimchi and grill yourself some great meat. Delicious rice and veggies. Don't forget to stop by and yummm in up here they have great pork n veggies. Soup and wontons/dumplings. Food is amazingly fresh and service is exquisite. If you find yourself in SF make the trip to enjoy some great food. And cool waitresses and cooks. The atmosphere is nice and the variety of people makes it more comfortable too in my opinion. Don't hesitate to stop by and satiate your appetite  at Han il Kwan where they do Korean food Right!
author: Zelix L.

description: This place is awesome, be prepared to wait (like for any other good place to eat in SF).
author: Sam R.

description:
This place is wonderful if you want some good Korean BBQ. Parking is relatively easy to find, and the wait time is not too long. Their sides are delicious, and their tea is amazing.

The BBQ is especially tasty, as the meat has a good fat to meat ratio, and it gives off a nice aroma. Downside is that when you run out of tea, rice, and sides, you can feel the fat and oil coat your mouth, which I dislike.

Service could be a bit faster, but it's fine. I wish  there were more seats to sit on when waiting, but that's also fine. The view through the windows are nice, but there could be ventilation to help clear up the heavy smell of fat and oil. The restroom is not the absolute best, but it is very well maintained and doesn't smell like a dumpster.

Overall, this restaurant is pretty decent with delicious food but could use some improvements. This place is a hidden gem, and I would definitely come back again sometime.
author: Justin L.

description: $26 for mediocre spicy bulgogi! Are you kidding me! I thought it was joke... turns out the joke was on me! Not recommended!
author: Ryan C.

description:
Food here is pretty good. You have an option to grill it yourself (2+ orders of meat required) or have them grill it for you in the kitchen. This is not an all you can eat kinda place but portions are fairly generous. For around $20 you get the meat, all the side dishes, tofu soup or steamed egg, rice and sweet rice drink at the end.

Do expect a wait. We came close to 9pm on a weekday night and had to wait about 30 mins. 

You will smell like grilled food so make sure you wear something you don't mind washing afterwards.

Service was pretty good overall, someone was always around to check on us and to help with the grill. The only thing I didn't appreciate was when they saw me cut the raw chicken with the scissor and later when the chicken was cooked they came and got the same pair of scissors to help us cut the meat. 

I would come again but would be mindful of cross contamination.
author: Andy W.

description:
Good galbi, bad sides and weird vibes lol

Good korean food for sf, but for really good korean gotta go down to the south bay or LA
author: Mason L.

description:
we have been here so many times that we have lost count....

quantity n quality is continuous here....

check out my spread....
author: Leslie Y.

description: Waitress was nice but basically very little English in this korean place.  Our family kept asking for advice and we kept ordering.  I asked her directly: is this too much food.  She said: it's good.  We ordered 2 korean barbecue meats.  I asked if portions were enough to share.. she said.. .NO ONE PER PERSON.  OK so we proceeded to order accordingly. When food arrived it was like a buffet for 10 people. We were 4. I also ordered after discussing with waitress what I thought was korean beer that turned out to be a large green bottle with a high alcohol sake like concoction. Not suitable as a meal drink.  FOOD REVIEW; Not impressed.  Meats:  spicy pork was ok but mushy,  and flavors not balanced.. marinated beef was bland.  These meats were chopped and seemed to be boiled .as they were on the wet side and no grill marks.. so much for korean bbq. Portions were large but at almost $30 each,  ..we could have ordered 1 meat.  The bimbap bowls similar story.. wer ordered two.. again.. way too much food. The seafood bimbap was yukio, overly fishy flavor,  octopus was tough as a rock.. the other one was regular bimbap with white rice, egg,  protein etc.. waitress had recommended as one of favorites.  It was just OK, Low on flavor.  There's a Cuban restaurant in Miami, FINKA, that that does a much better bimbap. Anyhow.. overall disappointed.. the general theme here was that waitress cannot communicate and is guiding food amount choices incorrectly. We hoped for great experience.. but sadly we didn't get it.
author: Abe C.

description: Food tasted good, came with a lot of sides and tea that's a plus. But one of the ladies seemed rude but everyone else was really nice and friendly.
author: Cristine R.

description:
Seeing as this place is highly rated, I had to check out the hype for myself. My mom and I came in around 3:30 on a Saturday afternoon and waited approximately 40 minutes to be seated. Make sure you put your name down when you walk in. 

The short ribs are super yummy, as well as the fish and their side dishes. Honestly, food deserves 4 stars but I docked a star due to the following:

1. Service was terrible. They forgot our order and was NOT apologetic whatsoever. Also, it takes an eternity to wave someone down for anything. They also rush to herd you out. 

2. Price is steep for what they serve compared to other spots in the city. 

Parking is decent in the area. Honestly, I probably wouldn't come back due to the horrible service received. What a turn-off!
author: Kristi T.

description:
One of the better Korean restaurants in San Francisco. Food was decent, while service was forgettable. They cook for you during lunch time.
There are many better Korean spots in the Santa Clara - Oakland area.  Value is excellent at lunch.
 Picks:
Banchan was fairly limited to 8 pretty standard items plus a Tofu Soup.

Lunch Galbi ($15) Marinated Short Ribs was reasonably priced. Dinner portion costs $32.  Good flavors and a reasonable amount of meat.

Lunch Dwaji-bulgogi ($11) Marinated Spicy Pork was pretty good. Larger portion than the galbi.  Not too spicy.

Just OK:
None

Would not reorder:
None

Overall - Good
Food - Very Good
Decor - Good
Service - Fair
Value - Good

Would we come back - Yes
author: Ellen H.

description:
Place was busy on a saturday night. When we walked in, no one bothered to greet us, though, and there was no obvious place to write our name on a guest list. After about 5 minutes of being ignored, I walked toward the cashier and noticed the guest list. Cool, guess I should write our group down.

Anyway, we got seated, ordered, and waiting quite a while for the food. We ordered two things, the spicy pork bbq and the seafood soft tofu soup. The spicy pork came out kinda just warm... we're used to other restaurants taking it out sizzling. Then we waited another 10 minutes for the seafood soft tofu soup to come out warm, which was kinda irritating, since it should be coming out bubbling and semi-cooking. They didn't serve it with eggs.

We liked the side dishes--they serve a lot of them, but didn't offer to refill any of the ones we had finished. 

Kind of had to wave down the servers for any help, and they were impersonal at best. 
Meh... not gonna come back.
author: Danielle S.

description: It was really good to come here today on Thanksgiving Day. I really like how they served free steamed egg. I especially like their cold buckwheat noodle and it was so good.
author: Cindy K.

description:
You know this place is good when tour buses full of Korean people stop here for a meal.  There's even designated tour bus parking in front of the restaurant! I've never seen that before for any restaurant in San Francisco!

We visited here because my mom's hairdresser had recommended this place to her. I didnt even get a chance to check yelp reviews to see if her hairdresser was on point. I'm so glad we came!

The restaurant has a bunch of booth table seats (also window seats) but those are only reserved for those that want to self-grill.  We didnt want to grill our own food but we did want to eat some grilled meat. Their menu was a bit confusing for the meats because it looked like you could only order the meat if you planned to self-grill.  But thankfully we could order the meats and have someone else in the kitchen grill it for us (at no extra cost).

We ordered the spicy pork (my favorite), bulgogi, chap chae and a grilled fish dish.  We got a ton of little side dishes (complimentary) which included tofu soup and a sweet rice drink for dessert.  The bill between the three of us was a little over $90 (includes tip).  A bit expensive for asian food but I felt it was still worth it. Service was also really good and they speak English here.  A definite plus! Will definitely be back!
author: Janet E.

description: Went for lunch and although the food was good the service was so slow and the servers were not friendly. We didn't get water until we were halfway done with our meal and we waited around 25 minutes to get our check. Tried making eye contact and flagging down the server but it seemed like 3 people were working and we weren't able to get their attention. I've been to better places and probably won't be back here.
author: Dominique V.

description:
Service: Fairly friendly and attentive. Attentive: when it's not busy. 
Bathroom: 9/10, would of been 10/10 bit it's only a single stall. 

Came here for lunch because I was craving for some Korean BBQ. The lunch was a great deal$ ordered three items; spicy pork, beef, and the spicy squid and it came with at least 8 side dishes (banchans) and a tofu kimchee soup. I had my fair share of banchan but this place was on point with it. It was  so worth it, the beef was so tender, spicy pork was spicy and thick and the squid was just delicious. At the end there was left overs so prepared to either eat or take some home. Came out to 40$ included tax and tips for three people. 

Parking: triple thumbs down: I recommend parking at Fulton which is 2 blocks towards golden gate park. 


Enjoy !
author: Sam T.

description:
DELICIOUS. As someone who spent the last couple years in Southern California in which we had concentrated Korean ethnic enclaves (LA's Koreatown and the city of Buena Park) with legit food, I wasn't sure I would find something as good back in SF. This restaurant definitely exceeded my expectations. 

Came around 3 pm on a weekday for lunch with a family member and there was plenty of space, no wait. Lunch specials go until 4 pm. I got bulgogi which was flavorful. It came with rice and spicy tofu soup. My brother got the spit pork. But what really merits the five stars is that I was really impressed with the plentiful amount of side-dishes and the portions were pretty big! We also split a seafood pancake and they were generous with the seafood! We were stuffed and still had leftovers to take home. 

Overall, would definitely come back.
author: Wendy L.

description:
I was craving Galbi and Kim Chee, but have not had much success finding good Galbi.  Since it was Saturday, and my schedule was free, I decided to head into the city and consult with Yelp for a good Korean restaurant.  Han II Kwan appeared with four stars and over 1000 reviews, so (relying on my fellow yelpers) I trekked in for a late lunch (3:30'ish).  Given the hour, I expected the place to be somewhat empty.  While the place was not very crowded, it was far from empty.  I took this to be a good sign.

I ordered the Galbi and a side of rice.  Hubby ordered Bi Bim Bap in a hot pot.  The banchan consisted of approximately 8-10 little dishes; the Kim Chee was good!  The serving of Galbi was very generous - I had tons left over for dinner, even though hubby picked at some of it.  Hubby's Bi Bim Bap was also quite good, but remained very hot (due to the hot pot) throughout dinner.  He would order it without the hot pot next time.

The prices were good; our bill came out to $50.00.  You can find free off street parking.  The neighborhood feels safe.  We will definitely return.
author: Theresa C.

description:
This place is a little tucked off the main drag of Clement street, but you can smell the deliciousness from the street. They've got great options for booth (4-6 people) or giant tables (we had 8 people). 

Big plates of food (we ordered way too much) and fast service. No veggie options, which was kind of hard for our friend who wasn't into red meat as much, but delicious all around. 

Went on a Tuesday night, didn't need to wait for a table at all!
author: Lai-Nin W.

description:
My heart weeps if this place is considered one of the best Korean restaurants in the city.  Very mediocre Korean food overall.  

It also doesn't help that this place herds Korean tour groups in and out of the restaurant like cattle.  Service was so focused on having quick turnaround for these groups, they forgot about their regular customers.
author: David C.

description: The most delicious Korean fare at extremely reasonable prices. Freebies and complimentary extra dishes enhance the experience, although are not necessarily given every visit. To judge from the banchang, this place is more delicious than some places twice the price.
author: Michael J S.

description: My favorite place for dolsot bibimbap. I usually get seafood bibimbap and it never disappoint me. They give a lot of seafood in it! Apart from bibimbap, Gal-bi jjim is also the bomb! 4 out of 5 times they will usually get us tofu soup.
author: Rosita O.

description:
Really good food and excellent service

Only disappointment is they didn't have ukae.
author: Donna B.

description:
FOOD WAS PERFECT! I am very surprised! The marinated chicken was AMAZING and the marinated short ribs were GOOD! My friend and I also ordered the seafood pancake and the japchae. Both our favorites were the japchae and the marinated chicken! The seafood pancake ACTUALLY has seafood in it!! I believe everything we ordered was WORTH THE PRICE! 

SERVICE... It's whatever but I still give it 5 stars because of the food.

PRICING... A little expensive but worth it. I would advise to go Monday to Friday for the lunch special. Prices are about half the original price! 

PARKING... Correct me if I am wrong but While driving around I saw a lot of houses actually painted the Curbs in front of their house red. If it does not have any letters on it like dpt it's probably a fake red curb.

I am definitely going back to eat at Han ll Kwan. I recommend all to go :)
author: Darlene T.

description:
Galbi stew - our favorite - the sauce was really nice and the meat was fall off the bone tender. It would have been even tastier if they added turnip to the dish. 

Ox tail stew - the meat was tender; the sauce is the same as the galbi stew, so next time I would recommend to order one or the other. 

Galbi -  a little on the fatty side, however flavor and tenderness was good. 

Bulgogi - this was good, pretty comparable to other Korean places.

Pork - this was just okay as it lacked a certain sweetness that usually accompanies the spicy pork.

Seafood pancake - good amount of seafood, nice crispy texture on the outside and soft with a bite of chewiness on the inside. 

Out of the abundant amount of side dishes we enjoyed the anchovies and kimchi.
author: Jay G.

description:
If you have a big enough group, I would recommend getting dinner B. We added #25, the stew, to it, too. It was all really delicious. My favorite was probably the galbi; it was thick but still super tender and flavorful. We had 10 people and had a lot of leftovers. 

Wish we could have sat in the front room so we could have grilled our own meat, but at least we didn't have to wait long for a table. Service was excellent. Would return. 

Note: there's only street parking, so unless you have a tiny, I would recommend public transit to get here. We had to circle around for quite a while before finding a spot on Geary.
author: Angela T.

description: Asked the front desk a question about a particular food on the menu. Received a sarcastic response followed with attitude. When I persisted and continued to ask questions about the menu and the food I will be ordering, the front desk person gave further attitude as if I was an idiot. Sorry, I do not eat Korean food often. I decided to order takeout anyways, the order took over 30 mins and when I received the food and took a look, I was very disappointed for the front desk woman described the food as "Sizzling chicken" turned out to be soup.
author: Howard T.

description: Food was fantastic, service was TERRIBLE!! We simply asked for water or the tofu soup they were SUPPOSED to bring automatically with the meal, but when we asked for anything they gave us a dirty look like we were bothering them!! Terrific food Han Il Kwan, but you gotta work on your servers.
author: Madison S.

description:
Han il kwan is quite possibly my favorite Korean restaurant in SF. They've consistently served delicious Korean food time and time again. Back in January 2013, the roommate and I stopped by for dinner.

*Banchan (9): My favs were the fish cake, little anchovies and bean sprouts!
*Complimentary pancake
*Complimentary steamed egg

1. Kal-bi: Marinated beef short ribs ($22.95)
15. Soft tofu soup with chopped vegetables in beef broth ($9.95)
44. Chap-chae: Stir-fried vermicelli with vegetables and beef ($13.95)
68. Whole king fish ($14.95)

You can bbq here too, but I typically have the restaurant prepare the meats. I love kalbi, so I always order that. Han il kwan's version is flavorful and has a great sear. I love my soondubu spicy and they make it just right here. The tofu is silky and the broth delicious! The japchae has a nice chew and a good amount of veggies and beef. And the fish is nicely grilled.

The roommate and I have been exploring other places lately for Korean bbq cuz I've been on a new restaurant kick. But we always come back to Han il kwan. The only drawback to the place is parking can be a little difficult at times. Good thing the roommate has a motorcycle for occasions like these. Easy parking with that. Leftovers however, can be challenging. But we've managed to make it work. That's how much we love Han il kwan!
author: Elena N.

description:
Been meaning to come here..heard good things from friends and other things (i forgot where)

Its right at the corner of a quiet neighborhood but quite spacious inside.

Menu is decent priced, not a lot of options but good enough.

We opted for the 
Spicy Bulgogi
Daboki
Jap-chae

THE MOST AMAZING BEST FAVORITE THING HERE for me...
is the amount of ban chans and sides!!  It's more than most Korean places in the City and its pretty darn good!  They also offer tofu soup and mini egg pancakes as part of the sides...if i can do the emoji face with the heart as eyes...it is exactly how i feel about this place and the ban chan....SIGHHHHH 

The spicy bulgogi was very sweet, more sweet than I would like, but it wasn't bad.  We wanted to do it ourselves, but maybe they were closing soon so it came cooked (no biggies, we didnt wanna smell like BBQ)  Portion size is alright, good enough for 2

Daboki...very saucy!! i love it!! i wish they add just some garnish to it - it was just sauce and rice cake.  Eventually the gluten got into the sauce...making it thick.  This too was a bit too sweet

Japchae - it was loaded!  had a lot of veggies - i feel like theres more veggies than there was noodles and hardly any meat =(...it wasnt bad but maybe the taste of bell peppers kinda ruined it for me.

Also...free dessert drink...*drools*

For 2 people....we TOTALLY over ordered...but I will for sure come again
author: Laurie W.

description:
Best Korean BBQ I've found in SF. Which surprisingly has few options. 

Im used to LA style Kbbq. This place falls a little short of what Im used too, but it's still the best in SF. 

Better options are available in the East Bay.
author: Luther M.

description: GREAT SERVICE! There was a lot of people during dinner time but they serve the food pretty fast. The food wasn't bad but I expected the Japchae to be better but the other foods were good!! It is pretty pricey for Korean food but it was worth going to try it for sure!
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Their lunch special is awesome!! 

An exceptional sized personal plate of kalbi, tofu soup, and panchan all for a good price of only $13.95!! The amount of kalbi they give you is good enough for two people. 

They also have other good food items, one of my absolute favorites is their seafood or kimchi pancake. OMG DELCICIOUS!!!!! 

They get pretty packed during lunch special hours from 12-3, sometimes a large tour bus of people come to eat here during lunch hours. So make sure to come in a little early to get a seat and find parking! The service can be hit or miss. But the food here is exceptional Korean food and I would definitely recommend it!
author: Amanda R.

description: Ok quality meat, overly priced ($32/kalbi) i guess because it is located in SF. Wouldnt visit again. Waiters were friendly and attentive but they were always busy with group tourists from korea so it seems like everything was in rush. Not very impressed.
author: Soo C.

description:
This place caters to tour busses and LOTS OF THEM while everyone else is neglected. Dont expect the truth if you call in advance to inquire about their table availability. I have waited 45 minutes and longer even after calling first all the while empty tables just sat there.
.
I had loved ban-chan here, if I could ever sit down at a table. When an order comes out incorrectly, too bad. It is so very unfortunate that I dont beleive these guys understand anything about customer service. 
.
As a man who lived in Korea for more than three years I am gravely disappointed by this business and its operation here.
author: Caesar A.

description: This place seems really good because of the reviews but honestly it was not that good. The service was so bad, not once did they come to check on us at the table. I had to go up to them to ask for more water and again for the check. The food was presented beautifully but the meat quality was not that good for the price. Very expensive, I think you could get a better meal for cheaper. Not that well seasoned maybe needs more salt. But the ambience is nice but I feel it is overpriced for the quality of food and service
author: Alimira S.

description:
My siblings and I were craving Korean food so we wanted to try this place out since it was near their apartment! 

When we entered the restaurant, I saw that they had regular tables as well as tables with grills (depending whether you want to eat ayce or not). We came in at the right time because the wait only took about 5-10 mins even though the place was pretty crowded. They had a wide selection of food but the meat selection was pretty pricey! 

Although their food was expensive, they serve big portions since it's family style. I enjoyed their side dishes (kimchi, pickled cucumber, fish cake, etc), steamed egg and seafood pancake (dense yet fluffy with seafood and green onions). We ordered more but those dishes were my favorite.
author: Jackie T.

description: I always get lunch take out from here and I love the side dishes and the complimentary beef tofu soup even for Togo orders! Portions are generous and their lunch special quality is great with reasonable price! Highly recommended! Parking might be a challenge though.
author: Mandy T.

description:
I came here for one of my girlfriend's bday dinners. It is a wide, ventilated space comfortable space so you don't walk smelling like BBQ. They have standard prices for Korean food. Not a place to  choose if your looking for cheap, all you can eat BBQ.
It is pretty nice that they let you be seated even though your whole party does not completely arrive all at once. The hot tea and little appetizers were good. I had the $12 tofu soup. I was hoping for a bigger stone pot. It wasn't bad but wasn't that good. I like how they gave one free side of white rice per dish each person orders. The service was decently  prompt and the waitresses were patient and polite. Overall, this place is definitely worth trying.
author: Carleen C.

description: The best time to enter the restaurant is before 6:30 to avoid the massive wait for the BBQ/Any. The food portion is big, and the quality is good. One example of that is the seafood pancake. It's very thick and divides into ten piece, each the size of a candy bar filled with squids. We ordered a soup, a pancake and bibimbab for four people. The restaurant gave us an extra tofu soup on top of our order. We are very satisfied with the taste and portion. The bill comes out to be only 45$. Fantastic deal for a Korean restaurant that you can not get elsewhere for four people meal. Of course, the BBQ dishes are a bit more expensive if you have a table of meat lovers, but you do get a big portion as well. The servers do not cram the place even if there are plenty of customers waiting. That gives the restaurant a very nice, spacious, quite environment to enjoy the meal and the eight types of kimchi.
author: Vincent Manjin L.

description: At 4 pm on Sunday in the empty restaurant refused to seat 1 person. Told me they are booked.... I say bullshit. Not a good place for walk in. They would prefer to serve larger groups but that's not a business model I like.
author: Alexei L.

description:
The side dishes will fill you up before the main dish comes! The side dishes are fresh and it also comes with tofu soup or steamed egg per table. 
I ordered a bi bim bap and the beef was juicy and tender comparing to many dry ones I had in other Korean restaurants!
author: Jennifer F.

description:
4.5 stars. I came here with some friends to satisfy our Korean food cravings. This was not our top choice restaurant at first, but I'm so glad we ended up here! Though the service was mediocre, the meat and ban chan were both on-point. We ate several rounds of pork belly and spicy beef ribeye. Delicious. The ban chan had a ton of variety, and our waitress was pretty proactive about refills on those dishes.

Keeping this place bookmarked for the future! Definitely would recommend.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
I'm giving this place 5 stars because the food is good and I did not have to wait.

After reading yelp reviews that the wait is hours long and even if you have a reservation, you're still forced to wait...I was worried. I hadn't made a reservation and I called at 11AM on the Tuesday I planned to visit to make a reservation for 5 at 7PM. Expecting there to be no reservation slots left, they said it was totally fine. My group arrived slightly early around 6:50 PM. We were seated immediately. I also saw two tables that were empty. For 7PM, I was expecting a large crowd and was pleasantly surprised not to find any.

We got a booth with a grill in the middle. We ordered spicy bulgogi and spicy pork to share. Each table comes with either gyeran or soondooboo. We opted for the soondooboo. The kimchi was super fresh and tasted slightly spicier than your average kimchi. The banchan was very plentiful and included kongnamul, gamja jorim, myulchi, and fishcake jorim. The bulgogi and spicy pork tasted better than other places I've been to (hint: yakiniq) because the meat was not super fatty. We also ordered pajeon and it was some of the thickest pajeon I've seen. Some places make it very thin and flat but this one was stuffed with lots of veggies. I also loved the oksu cha. Some restaurants use tea bags. This restaurant made it from scratch with the actual kernels. The tea was full of flavor and not diluted or weak like some tea that is served at other restaurants. 

At the end of the meal, the waitress gave everyone complimentary sikhye. That is really nice service. I've never been to a Korean restaurant with free sikhye at the end. 

All in all it was a very pleasant experience. I ended up paying less than I typically do at AYCE KBBQ places and I left the restaurant feeling completely satiated.
author: Amanda S.

description:
Word of advice, come early. This place gets packed fast and parking is a pain. 

However, this review is really for the food. I've been here twice and the food was pretty consistent. Galbi is my favourite, being extremely tender. Their bulgogi wasn't bad, although I like it usually cooked longer with a glaze. Their pork belly was a disappointment, tasting pretty dry and tough. My favourite is always their japchae though! Haven't found another place in the city that makes it better.

Overall this is a solid spot to come with friends or family with good Korean food in the city. Be prepared to wait, and if you like grilling your own meat, this is the place for you.
author: Ryan C.

description:
3-3.5stars

We got a eight people dinner combo. All the food had good quality and they are delicious. However, they are within the expectations of what I would get out of any korean restaurant. One real highlight of all the dishes is japchae(clear noodles). I paid 26.5 dollars for this meal.

Tl;dr. I came here with a big group of people and we ordered two eight people dinners. The food we got can definitely feed more than 16 people. The service is very good. The eight people combo didn't come with real barbecue( meaning like the ones that you have to cook yourself) I might come back again for some real barbecue.
author: Tianyi L.

description: Super crowded the few times I've even there. We ordered the fix dinner on our last visit Super good deal and tons of food. We BBQ our meats, which was incredible. The Egg Flower soup was light and delicious. Be patient, it's worth the wait. Parking is tough in the neighborhood. Great place for small groups.
author: Leon L.

description:
One of my favorite things about Korean food is the ban chan!! Han Il Kwan does it right - they give a large variety of ban chan, and it's all absolutely amazing.

The food and service at Han Il Kwan is good too. 4 of us ordered the kalbi, the spicy pork bulgogi, the kimchi stew, and of course, the seafood pancake! Everything was amazing, and the portions were BIG. The seafood pancake and the kalbi were my favorite. The seafood pancake had little dough, and a ton of seafood goodies - my kinda pancake.

If you order more than 2 portions of meat, you can choose to cook your own meat, which is awesome. My group opted out, but the groups at the surrounding tables were enjoying themselves.

Super authentic Korean restaurant - one of the best ones in the city!
author: Michelle L.

description: Came over for some classic Korean dishes.  None of the entrees will knock your socks off but you'll satisfy any Korean food cravings you have.  The place can get quite packed so expect to wait a bit.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
I have been coming to this place for years (I would say at least 7-8 years) and the food hasn't changed a bit. 
My all time favorite:
1. Kal Bi BBQ ( I love to put some bean paste on the lettuce and one slice of Jalapeños then two pieces of Kal Bi and some ban chae....wrap it up and put everything in my mouth. Yummy!) 
2. Mixed Seafood ( very big portion, enough for 2-3 people)
3. Pork Belly (okay portion)
4. Steamed egg (hit and miss; sometimes they forget to put salt in it) 
5. Sautéed squid (delicious)
 Service was alright! Sometimes the staffs are really nice and other times they are not. It just seems like after all these years, they are strangers to me!
author: Elaine Y.

description:
need to get some new wait staff, I have been going to this restaurant for years.  food is good but the wait staff is terrible.  most of the waitress do not want to work here and it shows.

to the owners, your business will not last forever, look at what happen to Brother's restaurant, you need to improve on your wait staff
author: Mason C.

description:
Great KBBQ in San Francisco!

My friends and I wanted to eat here a few Fridays ago, but apparently it's a popular stop for the tour buses so it was all packed and the wait time was ~45 min. So this time we decided to call TO MAKE A RESERVATION, which was a great idea, because by the time we got there, they were ready to welcome our empty stomachs.

There was 6 of us so we decided to go with the 6-person combo, which was ~$120 before tax+tips. IT WAS SO MUCH FOOD. Not including side dishes (which they gave a plentiful amount - see pictures!) we had: 1) two plates of pork, 2) two plates of spicy pork, 3) bimbimbap, 4) grilled fish, 5) kimchi/tofu/beef soup/stew, 5) gamja guksu, 6) spicy octopus/seafood, 7) mini seafood pancakes, 8) deep fried seafood and veggies. Hope I didn't leave anything out. But yeah. It was so much food....definitely enough for 10 of us! 

So I am from LA and have been spoiled with the all-you-can-eat KBBQ. I have a pretty high standard for Korean BBQ, and I would say this one can be on the same playing field as the ones in SoCal. The meat was well marinated, especially the spicy pork. The gamja was also very tasty. The service was very nice and the waitress/waiters helped us (occasionally) to cook the meat. Since it was Halloween, they also gave us chocolates (how sweet!!!).

But yeah. Definitely come with an empty stomach and clothes that you don't mind getting greasy smells in! Also grab a friend who speaks Korean so they can help do the ordering and cooking ;) (Just kidding!)
author: Wendy F.

description: Very good weekday lunch special. Servings are very generous and everything we tried was delicious. Friendly staff too
author: Mark M.

description:
Eaten here a few times, food is great and lots of delicious side dishes, probably one of my favorite restaurant for Korean food in SF.

Customer service is inconsistent, but I think if you're nice and polite, and if it's not so busy, you'll have better service.
author: Khanh N.

description: they wouldn't let me do BBQ...cuz I'm by myself...I'm having a shitty day and feeling very upset already...now I literally wanna cry and jump off the bridge after the dinner. But I won't cuz I wanna have BBQ before I jump off the bridge, which is not happening tonight cuz I'm dining by myself. This is not fair l. I stood  in line, waited for a table just like everybody else.  The bibimbap is good though comes with side soup too.
author: Porscha Y.

description:
Yum! Had the kimchi chigae and it tasted as good as one in Korea. Being from New York, the flavors and freshness were better than the best Korean restaurants in Queens. The banchan were also fresh, and come with a free oven baked egg. The free sweet rice drink were a nice touch--be sure to get every bit of sweetened rice. 

Tour buses come in pretty regularly (3 came in the span of an hour). The group eats quickly - 20-30 minutes start to finish - but can take up numerous tables. Coming at off times could help avoid a wait.
author: Kim M.

description:
I don't know what's with the three-star reviews. 4 I can kind of see due to the service and okay if you're coming from LA, but you don't really go to any Asian joint and expect great service unless it's a fancy one, which this is not, and this is not LA.

We had the barbecue because that's what my dad likes. The banchan was almost as good as my aunt's, and the little anchovies were just as good as my aunt's. The banchan was plentiful and very high quality and really good.

The galbi was really good and the spicy pork was some of the best I've ever had.

I do hesitate to go to Korean restaurants in the Bay Area but this one deserves its great reputation. It's jammed with Koreans and for good reason.

I think it's a super great value considering the high quality of the meat and the banchan. I could have used more lettuce but my dad didn't use any so it was okay.

Oh, the samjang wasn't that great, it was pretty much just danjang. I guess it would have been off the hook if they would have given you the raw garlic and peppers to BBQ 2 but they did not. But I'm not complaining at all.
author: Cynthia C.

description: Although customer service wasn't the best from one of the waiters, the food was wonderful. I went to eat here on a Sunday afternoon at around 3 PM and there wasn't too long of a wait. We did not get a BBQ table, so that may have sped up our brief wait time. I was thankful they were able to accommodate food requests. I wanted pork instead of beef with my bimbimbap and they did that for me for no extra charge with no questions. Every table gets a complimentary steamed egg or soondubu. My table decided to get the steamed egg, and I must say that I was impressed! We also ordered a soondubu, and that was really good. One of the more flavorful soondubus that I have had here in San Francisco. I will be coming back again whenever I am craving soondubu.
author: Lynn T.

description:
Despite the great food, the staff here are rude and will prioritize Koreans over you for seating.

Been waiting for 1.5 hrs and Koreans who came way after us were continuously given priority seating.
author: Tod L.

description:
Ate here yesterday evening.  The interior vibe's fun, social, with a authentic Korean Restaurant vibe.  Had the seafood bi bambap.  It was good.  The BBQ beef and chicken were excellent as were the supporting banchan.

Would come here again.
author: Tony U.

description: I've been here three times already and this restaurant is hands down the best Korean restaurant in SF(but it is definitely not cheap)! The last time I went here, my table ordered the marinated Galbi, Japchae, the seafood pancake, and the Sundubu-jjigae. The quality of the meats at this restaurant is always superb! They also give you a generous amount of side dishes. The waiters/waitresses are attentive but that can vary with which day you come in.
author: Chantal D.

description:
the place has the is the best korean food in the bay area!!!!! great to come to on a warm night, forewarning tho: parking is hard to come by, and expect a 30 min wait at least. 

+ braised beef short ribs: 5/5 i love this dish! the potatoes are so good too and the beef ribs are very tender. i like the soup too. 
+ seafood and scallion pancake: 5/5 i thought the seafood here was so plentiful. they give you A LOT, like 12 pieces. really good for group sharing 
+ spicy beef soup: 4/5 really good spices, beef was tender. still VERY good, but was not blown away (in comparison to first dish). really good for a cold SF night tho

portions are huge! and easy to share.
author: Cathy Y.

description:
When craving kbbq for lunch, it was a struggle when my usual go-to spots didn't open til around 4 or 5 pm. So it came down to either My Tofu House or Han Il Kwan, which were both open by 11am.
