My issue with this place is the service. Service is really bad here. I came here with my parents and my kids which is a party of 6 and they would not seat us during lunch in a table for 8 which was unoccupied. The lady told us to wait because the table with 4 people are almost done. 

So I had a WTF moment and gave her the WTF are you doing look and asked her is this table reserved and she said no, so I said why can't we sit here since we are a party of 6 just remove 2 chairs. After she reluctantly acquiesced we had an average lunch.

If you want shitty service and decent Korean food come here but for us no thanks!
author: Michael C.

description: Best Korean restaurant in San Francisco. To me, what separates them from the rest are the side dishes-- super fresh with a lot of variety.
author: Sihoon Y.

description:
This area is fairly difficult to find street parking as it's mostly residential. Unfortunately I came when there was three tour buses of Korean visitors passing through but before the normal dinner crowd. Our wait was about  30min. What I thought was interesting was the guy that was coordinating all the seating spoke both Korean and Mandarin. Props to him for that, but he was a very harsh person and not pleasant to talk to. Since we didn't want to wait any longer, we opted for any table. Of course the first table that opened up wasn't a BBQ table.

Our order:
Steamed Short Rib: ($23.95) Long-boiled beef short ribs with potatoes and carrots
Seafood Pancake ($15.50)
Spicy Rice Cake ($10.95)
Small Hite Beer ($3)

We ordered way too much food because they give you so much banchan! It even includes two small scallion pancakes and tofu soup. All the banchan were really good but we were unable to finish everything. =( 

The Steamed Short Rib came out in a stone pot and came out bubbling hot. Before the waitress left, she cut the meat off of most of the bones for us. How nice! :) The potatoes were soft while the carrots weren't nearly as soft. The meat was very tender as well. Heads up: This dish's sauce is on the sweet sauce so I'd eat it with the rice.

The Seafood Pancake was crispy and had really long scallion pieces so it made eating a little more of a hassle. The cut the pancake into large pieces for you though, so that does help the eating process. The pancake also had a good mix of seafood in it so they weren't stingy on the ingredients.

The Spicy Rice Cake was good, but for someone who could barely handle Sriracha, it was too spicy for me (it was a medium spicy as well). I could only eat a few pieces. =(

At the end of your meal you also get a sweet rice dessert drink. Quite tasty :)

Next time I would like to get a BBQ table to try the items that you can cook at the table yourself. Those are always so much fun to do :)
author: Kitty K.

description: My friend said this place was the best korean place around, we came here and there were tour bus and tour bus of people. I've never quite understood, because from my knowledge of traveling and understanding tour busses, they usually go to cheap and mediocre or subpar locations. Regardless, we gave it a shot, it was about a 1 hour wait time before we got seated. We ended up ordering pre made food which was interesting. They do give you a lot of side dishes, but then again, who doesnt give you side dishes at a korean restaurant. When we got the side dishes, there was not fish cake. We had to ask at least 2 times before they brought it out. Service was definitely a 1/5. The food was so pricey. I got a bulgogi and paid about 25+ in that. They do give you free tofu soup at the end, but it's basically water and spicy sauce. I don't think I've been as dissapointed by a korean food before especially if you have to wait 1 hour for the food and it's below expectation. I would not come here again. There isn't much in the area at all either!
author: Amy Y.

description:
Three separate attempts to dine here were foiled by two bus loads of Korean tourists pouring into the restaurant. We almost gave up trying to have dinner here however we decided to give it one last shot. This time we arrived at a later time and dropped in just in time to see the tour bus packing up and leaving. 

With no wait at all we were seated immediately at a corner location. We ordered: kimchi pancakes, bibim nengmyun - cold spicy noodles, and steamed eggs. It didn't sound like much but this ended up being way too much food for two people. We'd each received a bowl of rice, the banchans (as expected), the stone pot of steamed eggs, and our freebie, a small stone pot of soondoobu. 

- Kimchi pancakes - way too thick in my opinion but would otherwise be a delicious flavored pancake
- bibim nengmyun - a bit too sweet and not spicy enough for me. But this was perfect for my non-Korean husband who accumulate beads of sweat on his face whenever he eats spicy food. 
- steamed eggs - very bland. Some spices (or salt, which I think they forgot) thrown on top would have a long way. Plus too much water is added making it too soft and smooth a texture. 
- soondoobu - Smooth textured tofu, perfect flavor.  

We did the best we could but we left a lot of leftovers. I hate wasting food but there was absolutely no way we were going to finish this. 

Service - The ahjummas and eemos are quick so that you are in and out quickly. We'd noticed a line was accumulating so we rushed up. 

I'd certainly go back. But here's a tip: You may be some serious competition for seats with a couple bus loads of tourists should you arrive before 6:30pm.
author: Esther A.

description: Some of the best Korean food I've had in SF. All the food was great and they have proper ventilation so you don't leave smelling like food which is a big plus for me.
author: Justin S.

description: This and Brother's Restaurant may be my top two contenders for Korean BBQ places. Whenever we have a good size party craving Korean BBQ (5 or 6 people), we love taking them to Han Il Kwan. The food here is delicious and the meats are well marinated. They definitely supply a large number of banchan, which is my favorite part of a Korean meal. Tofu soup or steamed egg comes complementary too. I would highly recommend this place, though keep in mind, parking my be hard in the area. Korean Tour buses also stop here a lot, so the line might be longer than expected. Their hot pots are also delicious, and some may take longer, but it's worth the wait!
author: Denise D.

description:
So far the best Korean food I had in town. Every single dish I got there was super yummy. The place is huge so perfect for big parties.

Don't miss their seafood pancake, it's really good. Their bibimbap was also fantastic! Bear in mind though they let you use the little grill on the table if you have 2 people (I think min is 4 people).

Enjoy your food!
author: Nuno S.

description: Although the BBQ was delicious, the service was poor. We had to ask multiple times for kimchi and water. Not the friendliest service either.
author: Maia S.

description:
3.7 for dinner. but 4 stars including the wonderful service we received!

We parked it and ate here....for hours on end. 7 of us... we had our game on. Flooded with dishes once they started coming, and absolutely no room to place another plate!

big big thumbs up for the complimentary pindaeduk and hot tofu soup. Those were beloved, savory pieces of food...I loved them both..  sesame soy dipping sauce are to also be used for pajeon and kimchi pancake.

We ate until our sides hurt.... lots of things tried. 2 dol sots of various kinds, lots of octopus. Curious thing: weakest thing on our table was the lack of grill flavor of the bulgogi. Presented on an iron platter, the meat was not caramelized, and the onions remained raw-looking. did they forget to heat the iron platter? strange.

Banchan was fresh. Not the best or most flavorful that I've tried, but appreciated just how fresh. The selection and number they give here is bit less than say....Jong Ga on other side of the bay. Seafood pajeon: too thick. needed to be bit more crispy, and the coarse cut of the ingredients.. didn't care for.

Lucky for us, we made reservations for a large table, and the Friday night was not crazy, affording us the ability to non-yell our conversations. Fun times. 

Glad that I can finally try my aging bookmark!
author: Jana C.

description: This place looked super good when I looked at the pictures and read great reviews, so my boyfriend and I were so excited so try it. Right when we walk in the lady asked for how many and I said 2 and she said she couldn't seat us because there were people coming... I looked over and there were 5+ tables open like wtf?! She said the wait was going to be 30-1 hour like f*ck that! We're hungry! So we left. Not welcoming at all. Plus, so many flies and the back looked so messy and unsanitary!
author: Lauren P.

description: Most Korean places have pretty good service. This was just disappointing. From the guy who was actively ignoring me while I tried to put my name down to wait, to the waitress who I requested the steamed egg as part of my banchan and forgot and gave me the tofu soup instead and when I told her I ordered the steamed egg she basically was like tough luck, next time kid. But I have to admit, the kalbi here is pretty good. Sigh. It's got a lovely marinade and is beautifully charred and that charcoal flavor is the only thing that would bring me back. The dokbokgi is the simplest I've ever seen served, just the rice cakes and sauce for $10which is not worth it to me. Again, the kalbi was the only thing I'd come back for. It's a pretty big portion too.
author: Nina S.

description:
Family and I got lucky and came here when there was no line. The place looks a little small. They have an extra private room which probably seats 15 more people. The staff were pretty nice. We were seated, ordered taken, and beverages served pretty quickly. 

We ordered the tteobokki, braised beef stew, spicy seafood soup, japchae, seafood pancake, and spicy pork. I think the star dishes were the braised beef stew and japchae. Don't order the spicy seafood soup with noodles. It was really bland. But the japchae was surprisingly flavorful, and beef stew was very juicy. Would go back for these two dishes, but if there's a long line, I don't think it's worth the wait.
author: Brenda V.

description: Love this place!! Food is so good and portions are huge.  The wait can be long but definitely worth the time
author: Kennedy T.

description:
I've had a soft spot in my heart for Han Il Kwan ever since they used to support fundraisers for the Korean Immersion Program at Claire Lillenthal School. Finally made back for the first time in five years and it was as good as I remembered, but busier.

Our party of three had the BBQ selections with bulkogi, spicy pork and mixed seafood, cooked at our table. First score, the base price is several dollars cheaper than some other places and includes decent sundubujjigae (tofu soup) for the table and a sweet rice drink dessert in addition to the usual panchan. They serve you lettuce leaves if you want them to eat your BBQ along with a rather small portion of gochugang (but I'm sure I could have got more if I'd asked).

The seafood I wouldn't order again; it was about 80% vegetables and 20% seafood. Other than that, really no complaints. Well, one maybe: the lighting sure is bright. But we got used to it, and it helped we were seated at one of the booths next to the windows.

Tip: parking is amazingly hard to find in this residential neighborhood. Allow time for a few spins around the block until you get lucky.
author: Otis M.

description:
We were only the third in line when we got there.  We were never greeted when we went in and we just automatically lines up at the front door after others.  Soon all the tables in the large outside room were all cleared.    Astonishing enough we watched people walked in and just started to sit at the table and dig in.  All the empty tables were taken!  Not until then we realized there were tourists from the tour bus that had reserved the tables.  Then some guy came and took our names down without giving us any heads up of the waiting time.  This process went on for 3 rounds of tour bus tourists and we were going nuts!

Eventually after a hour's wait we were seated!  

The food was good but not worth the wait, absolutely!
author: Rebecca L.

description:
I've been here a few times in the past. The place can be busy at dinner but lunch seems to be alright. I ordered the Jap Chae and it tasted great, not much to complain on the quality. The portions were big enough to my filling but pricey. Banchans were set on the tables. There's lunch specials as well. I also enjoyed the complementary sweet drink that we get to drink towards the end of the meal. 

Although service can be slow sometimes even though they might not be busy in the day. My friend had to flag the waitress down a couple of times to get water and napkins.
author: Tony C.

description:
Was honestly a little disappointed after eating here because I was hoping for a good experience after reading all of the reviews. 

For the price that it was (way too expensive), I don't think it was worth it to get Korean bbq. It's not all you can eat and the meat is very pricey.

They give you an 'okay' portion of the meat but in my opinion it wasn't seasoned that well and they didn't offer many sauce options to make it any better. 

This place offered other entree options so I would come back to see what else they have to offer.
author: Kelly C.

description:
*  Welcome Experience
-  Ordinary

There were going to be six in our party but we showed up with four.  We were seated right away regardless.  I like that.  For some reason I hate it when a restaurant tells me I have to wait until my entire party is present before we are seated.  

The restaurant was *empty* at 6 when we arrived.  When we left close to 8 it was packed without a free table.  A TOUR BUS dropped off lots of people and things got REAL up in there.  

*  Establishment
-  Encouraging

Cool looking place.  Seems very clean.  Interesting decor.  Felt very nice.   

*  Service
-  Discouraging (kinda)

The guy who seated us and took our order was a joy.  He seemed very nice and led us through some questions gladly.  Then he was off to do other things while the food was brought by a very no-nonsense lady in a ponytail.  

I keep getting told that there's some "cultural" reason why the service is tense and sparse.  Like that just acceptable elsewhere in the world.  (I ain't never been nowheres else so maybe that's true) but I don't get it.  

An establishment like this could look at "stopping at a patrons table" like an unnecessary nuisance.  It felt like this place did look at it that way.  I get that stopping to ask of anyone needs anything - well - gets people telling you what they need - and that means you have to do more stuff.  I can see why people hate doing more stuff.  Like, I would have loved another single-serve bowl of rice.  No way.  

But there's also a few upsides to the establishment, no?  For much of the meal myself and others wanted a soda.  If this was a more accessible thing, we could have got what we needed, and the establishment would recognize a bit of profit too, no?  Six canned sodas at $2 each adds up.  Then there's the "higher tip for good service" benefit to the establishment too.  

This place wanted neither the reputation, better tip or profitable ring.  They just wanted to never do more stuff my going near our table.  I call that bad service, but for some reason, it seems to be expected here.  

So - lower your expectations - like I was told to - and enjoy the food. 

*  Food Quantity / Quality / Presentation
-  Outstanding 

The food was spectacular.  Bright, fresh, vibrant and flavorful.  My sister ordered for the table, and I have NO CLUE what I was eating, but it was dynamite.  

I do remember the kimchee pancakes (incredible) and the pork (wow!)

The rest of the food was indeed memorable but I wouldn't have a clue what to call it.  

*  What I'll remember

Dat pork!  And kimchee pancakes!  Wow!

*  What I can't wait to forget

Wondering if they were mad at us because of their scowls and avoidance of eye contact or table maintenance.
author: Peter L.

description:
Hands down one of the best Korean restaurants I've been too. Food is great. Service is crazy awesome!!

My friends and I ordered the BBQ short ribs which were all already cut into pieces for you (which means no bones nor mess). They marinated pretty well.

We also ordered a kimchi pancake which looked really neat when we got it. It was interesting and differently cut than other restaurants. It was a little too spicy for us but still pretty bomb.

Lastly, we got the bibimbap which I thought was only ok. I felt like it was missing some flavor to it even when have put the sweet chili sauce in there.

On top of everything, they give a complimentary soup to begin with. :D

What's great about this place are their side dishes. They give a lot and willing to refill a whole lot for you. Also, the owners see that your dishes are put awkwardly, they come to your table to help fix it by putting the big plates in the middle and side dishes around. Pretty thoughtful of them. I love them! :)
author: Annie H.

description:
This place isn't open as long as friends and I would like for it to be, but a meal here is totally worth juggling our schedules to eat before closing time. We're not the only ones who think this - a couple sitting behind us was from Europe, and the sizable round table beside us was having a birthday party.

I sang along a little bit during the cake song, but I don't remember if I clapped after the candle blowout. I was honestly too consumed by the food to focus on much else. I was taken from the get-go when muk came out among our banchan. I didn't have to ask for it or anything - it's standard, as further evidenced by its photo in the menu with a factoid bubble explaining what banchan is.

On top of that, pajeon was one of the other banchan. My friend pointed out that, where applicable, the side dishes were generously chunky. Namely, the fish cake, spicy radish, and marinated cucumber were cut a little bigger than at other places. It was like way back when Campbell's introduced their "Chunky" range, enlarging everything about the soups I'd always eaten before.

The theme of bigger pieces carried over to my entree as well. The al (roe) clusters in my aljjigae were mostly heftier than in other renditions I've had. It's been so long since I've seen hot oxtail soup that I can't say how the cuts in my friend's bowl compared to those at other places.

Other goodies were on the menu, such as intestine, crab soup, beef bone soup, and pork belly, at least one of which will doubtlessly be on our table during a future visit.

The beverage selection included items not at other restaurants, such as Daepo, Maechuisun, and what might've been the pomegranate wine I've seen at some Korean groceries. This third one I don't know for certain because we didn't get it - I just briefly saw it through the refrigerated glass case and thought I recognized the bottle shape.

I'd say the only hiccup in our service was that, by the time we'd received everything else and made headway into eating our food, our appetizer was still absent. We caught one of our three servers to ask about the modeudwigim we'd ordered.

Server: "What?"
Me: "Modeudwigim."
Server: "I'm sorry?"
Me: "Mo deu dwi gim?"

I wasn't succeeding, so I gestured for a menu so I could flip to the page.

Me: "Ah, modeumdwigim."
Server: "ModeumTWIgim."

Daaaaaanng, I can't get some slack around here? Truthfully speaking, I'm glad people are looking out for my pronunciation. (But was it that much of a stretch to infer what I wanted?)

Maybe it had been waiting; not but a minute or two afterward, the plate was at hand. The pieces of battered and fried vegetables + shrimp were oversized too, even more so than the banchan and entree. The zucchini(?) and potatoes were big blocks that nearly defied chopsticks, and even the shrimp surprised us.

Toward the end of the meal, we were one of three, then two, pairs in the restaurant still eating. Around then, our three servers sat down two tables away for their own dinner. Glancing in their direction, who did I see but a grandma strutting out of the kitchen. Breaking the attire guidelines of the other workers, she had on a bright sea green shirt and an orange multicolored apron. A second grandma appeared shortly with a more earthen but nonetheless hodgepodge look.

Maybe it's they who make the food. If so, you'd do well to invite them when you have your birthday here.
author: Dan B.

description: It was still packed around 8pm on a Sunday night so that's indication that this restaurant is really good. My roommates, who are Korean-Americans, were really impressed by the authenticity of the food here. The side dishes or "banchan" were plentiful and you also get to choose between tofu stew or steamed egg as a side dish. The stone bowl it's served in is about the same size as the regular entrée stone bowls. The Seafood and Scallion Pancake was huge and stuffed with fillings. We also got the Braised Beef Short Ribs, which they warned would take about 20 mins to cook. My roommates said this probably meant they're actually cooking it, instead of heating up precooked short ribs. All in all, this is probably the best Korean restaurant in SF. Definitely check it out.
author: Thao T.

description: Amazing spot for Korean BBQ. Always packed and hectic but servers are amazing at seating everyone as fast as they can and still being able to serve you well.
author: Yonguk K.

description:
I was surprised that coming on a Friday night around 9 PM, the wait was not that long. They have two options, either you chose to sit for bbq or regular table. I got the tofu soup with vegetables and beef. I was disappointed that they did not have a huge variety of tofu soup. I was surprised at how much sides they provided. They also gave us complimentary rice cakes and steamed egg. The sides were delicious. The soup was average. I wouldn't say it was the best soup I've had but it was good. 
Parking is terrible. It's street parking in the residential areas. I would recommend taking muni there.
author: Kelly O.

description:
Someone said this was the best Korean food in San Francisco so off we went to Han Il Kwan.

This place has a cute interior.  It's small but not stupidly small like some Asian restaurants.  There are some tables that have the exhaust hood so that you can make your own Korean Barbecue.

We ordered the pre-set menu that was suitable for 6 people.  It is a LOT of food and you end up paying like $30 per person which is not too bad.  The meats were all good (spicy pork, kalbi, etc.) The bi bim bap was good and surprisingly had some nice crunchy rice.  The jap chae dish was also solid.

I really liked the soon-du-bu tofu soup.  The broth was spicy and oily and just the way I like it!

We had a big problem with the smoke coming from the food.  We thought the hood was on but we weren't 100% sure.  It got to be like a small bonfire at some point.  The table next to us had similar issues.  I am kind of surprised that management didn't come over to assist us in putting out the smoke - it got to be quite charcoal-y at some point.

I would come back again - just bring a fan or a gas mask next time and we should be good.
author: Danielle C.

description: Best korean restaurant in San Francisco. The Kalbi stew is amazing.
author: Joe Z.

description:
The best Korean restaurant in the city. I'm Korean and very picky with my Korean food and I'll have to say of the 10 plus times I've been here, it's been consistent.

The service is iffy as sometimes you'll get great fast service and sometimes you'll have to wait for them to serve all the Korean fobs that come in from the tour buses.

What you get for your money is more than what you would get elsewhere. For instance if you order the bulgolgi, you will get a plate piled high full of it - unlike other places that have half of that.

The side dishes are great and there is a huge variety, more than many places.

I don't even bother going to other Korean restaurants in the city but if you must, Seoul Garden in Japantown is also very good but much pricier.
author: Julia P.

description:
we love love love this place!!

why? because they gave us 15 banchans!! that includes a freshly steamed egg and soup!
we obviously had trouble eating it all. 

we ordered the galbi tang and their dol sot bimibap. while galbi tang came in a HUGE bowl with steaming warm soup and noodles, the meat was on the rough and tough side. the dol sot was fairly normal and normal size - no complaints there. we had so much food leftover ... because they give so much for "free" and portions are large -- that one meal turned into 4 meals...(actually more like 6 meals for someone like me!!) 

well priced, fast, and very friendly service. very popular place with tour buses and large spaces. do come on an off peak time as wait can be long. we went around 2pm with no wait.. but crowds came soon after.

they also do korean bbq with bbq stations at each table. if you opt out, you can always get a booth w/o the que.
author: Mimi C.

description:
Food seems decent. Lots of families. 

Service really bad. Sat for an hour and they did not put in my order. So had to wait another hour before the galbi Jim came in. 

If you're not worried about bad service, then you should come here. 

Overall, could try out once if you're in the neighborhood.
author: Will Z.

description:
I never knew this place existed! It's out in a semi-residential area in the Richmond. I guess it's pretty popular with tour groups because there were a couple bus pick ups when I got here at 7pm on a Saturday. Reservations are recommended, especially if you want to bbq your own meat. We didn't know that, but only had to wait about 20 minutes for a regular table.

We ordered a pretty good variety of items seafood pancake, bibimbap, japchae, bulgogi and one other dish I can't remember. The food came out pretty quickly. Since we weren't able to cook at our table the bulgogi was cooked in the kitchen for us. The seafood pancake and bibimbap were the two winners for me. The pancakes were thick, fluffy and had a nice crust on the outside. The bibimbap was full of great flavors and the pot was super hot so we got the nice crunchy rice bits. 

The price was amazing. All 5 of us paid $20 each and that includes tax and tip!
author: Adelina W.

description:
Korean food here is always good, but service is very iffy depending on how busy it is. Keep in mind, there ARE Korean tour buses that take up the whole big room in the back so it lessens the amount of tables you can sit at so just beware of a wait during dinner.

I am a regular and am aware of this fact, so when we wanted to come here on a Sunday at 7:30, we made a reservation for 6. When we got there we ended up waiting 45 minutes, at least. WTF IS THE POINT OF A RESERVATION THEN? I know sometimes you can't expect what is to come.. but 45 mins for a table even with a reservation is pretty ridiculous. When we asked why we had to wait so long, there wasn't really an explanation. And I know EXACTLY which host Ron S is talking about (who said: Watch out for host he rolls his eyes at you and looks at you like your stupid). This is exactly what he did to us too. I didn't mind the waiting but it was how he treated us that was the bigger offense. Maybe he was having a bad day but don't exert it on your customers who made effort to come here specifically to eat at your restaurant..

That aside, the food here is great. The spicy pork here I've had is the best I've had anywhere in the city thus far. Come early to avoid the wait (and attitude, jeebus). Otherwise, the rest of the service is great and works through the craziness just fine.
author: Emily C.

description:
I've been here twice and I have to say that the food is great! Whenever I go they have a two piece pancake and a small tofu soup on the house!! So I really recommend getting their other dishes because there's no point in getting two tofu soups. They also have good kimchi.

The prices may look intimidating, BUT with the small plate starters, pancakes AND the tofu soup on the house it's totally worth it!! The waitresses that work there are very kind which is also a big plus. 

Go try it out!
author: Momoe K.

description:
I really wanted to give a good review - but the service and wait in intolerable! We waited 45 minutes - told it would be 5 . A tour bus then came  and the host told us another 5 minutes........... 8 times - it was ridiculous . 

They then gave away our table two times.( your table is right there- your next - wait another 5 minutes (as they sat another party) ) 


Then no server for another 20 mins. Food is pretty good, service is not bearable. 

Watch out for host he rolls his eyes at you and looks at you like your stupid.
author: Ron S.

description: This is one of the most classic Korean restaurants in San Francisco.  Delicious foods, good services.  I was there many times.
author: Adam I.

description: Great place for korean bbq, I would recommend making a reservation if you have more then 4 people. If you have a large group of more than 8+ people, they might not be able to accommodate self grilling because the tables with the grills are not large enough. The large group set menus are a good option if you are not sure what to order, there is a variety of options on the menu. Aside from the meat options, my other favorites are the stews and tofu soups.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Food 5  their food never disappointed me. alway good, consistent.
Ambience 4 the huge space is good for big groups!
Service 3 always busy, so we always have to wave hands.  
Price 5+  kind for my wallet
author: Tory T.

description:
Husband liked this restaurant so much that he wanted to return again when we were in the City. We took Mom for her first experience eating Korean food. Dad went with us again also. We ordered bulgogi again, but this time had to order for daughter on restricted diet the marinated spicy pork and the kimchi bibimbap. We like the marinated spicy pork even better than the bulgogi. Grandma who is also on a restricted diet enjoyed the mandu which were not too oily and the bean sprouts one of the side dishes.

There was no tour bus today, but the wait for a table was 30-45 minutes. They seem to be a little short staffed. The lady who seemed to have seniority was managing the front desk, trying to seat people, handling take out orders, running the credit cards for payment, and serving. We liked the server who she sent over to take our order. She said, "Thank you" to us as we left the restaurant. The third server did not talk much. She only dropped food off at tables.
author: Belinda L.

description:
When you see a huge Korean Tour bus parked in the front, you know this place is going to be good! 

Wait might be long but the food makes up for it. I usually call in to see how bad the wait is or I just make a reservation. 

They give you at least 9 side dishes and you can get free refills. You can also ask for the Spicy Tofu soup which is on the house.Free mini Korean pancakes and a sweet rice drink is given to you at the end of the meal.( I've been there only for dinner so no idea if that applies for lunch too).

The food and service at this place is good, a tiny bit pricey but there is a lot of food and the side dishes fill you up fast too! 

My go to Korean food restaurant regardless its family night, a big group of friends meeting up or just a date night!
author: Yas J.

description: Was there for a late lunch around 2:30pm.  Plenty of seats and the service was good.  We ordered BBQ Pork Belly and BBQ chicken, delicious! Plenty of food left over to take home.  Definitely will return again for lunch to avoid the dinner rush.
author: Marie H.

description:
This is my first Korean food experience in San Francisco.  So I can only compare to other Korean restaurants in Oregon.  I thought this place was good, but not great.

Food - 4, beef was a little tough, bibimbap was a little wetter than last time, and the spicy intestine/ tripe had great flavor, but the intestine/tripe ratio was way off.  It was 90/10.  I would prefer to see more tripe.  The banchan is what brought this to a 4 rating.  All of them were delicious.  I think we enjoyed the banchan more.  It would seem they have a consistency issue according to my relatives who have been there more than once.

Service - 3, food came out fast, but overall service was slow considering there were only 3 tables full.  But, I have never got excellent service at a Korean restaurant, so that might be normal.

Overall, 3.5 rating!
author: Ryan Y.

description:
I was searching for a good Korean restaurant in the Inner Richmond, and my fellow-Yelper Brian H. recommended Han Il Kwan.  I trust him because he's Korean and he seems to have very high standards for the Korean cuisine.  So I decided to pay Han Il Kwan a visit when I craved for some sizzling bibimbap.

Complementary pancakes:  Texture was a bit weird and it was very oily, but the cakes were free.

Ban chan:  Very solid.  Gave us a good amount, and the kimchi was very juicy and tasty.

#29:  Classic bibimbap, delicious!  It's easy for a bibimbap to taste bland, but this one had tons of flavor, and I especially loved the beef in it.

Tofu soup:  So this tasted good, but it was so much smaller than the bibimbap?!  When it came out, my boyfriend thought it was a complementary tofu soup rather than the one he ordered.  I didn't expect it to be so small!

All in all, Han Il Kwan is a solid Korean gem.  Love!
author: Christine A.

description:
I've been going here for HELLA YEARS..and it is tooo damn good to ever pass up. 

Even though I've been avoiding korean food bc I'm working hard to get in shape. Korean food once in a while is a must! Especially HAN II Kwan!

I personally believe this is the best korean restaurant in SAN FRANCISCO.

BAN CHANs usually fresh and sooo delicious! Every meal also comes with a complimentary STEAM EGG or SOFT TOFU SOUP. Most of the time they also give a SMALL PIECE OF KOREAN PANCAKE to each customer. 

Service is usually good, even though they tend to be very busy.

MUST GET: 
Spicy beef soup...thats what I get EVERYTIME!! 
Beef short rib .. tender meat! Marinated nicely!!

Parking can be hard since it is located on the corner of 19th and Balboa. But  definitely WORTH IT!
author: Tammy F.

description: It's a hit or miss at this place. Parking is horrible.  MSG used on the marinated meat. Most of the waitresses are nice but there's that one waitress who is nasty. They will over charge you so make sure to look at your bill carefully, had to go back and get almost $60 dollars refunded. I guess when there are limited number of Korean restaurant in the city, you can do whatever you want.
author: Christina C.

description:
Food is great but a bit pricey.

Although I think the 5 refill requests I made for the free 10 banchan dishes makes up for it.
author: Chris C.

description: Found this gem after going to the Legion of Honors.  The shrimp pancake & complementary tofu/ pork soup were delish!   Would definitely come back for more.
author: Stacey H.

description:
I cannot believe that I have not written a review for this place. I have been to Han II Kwan more times than I can remember. Whenever my family needs a break from Chinese food, we head here.

The banchan (side dishes), spicy tofu soup, mini pancakes, and sweet fermented rice dessert is a meal by themselves. We have tried almost every dish on the menu but always order the beef bulgogi, marinated chicken, spicy kalbi, bim bim bap, and chap chae. I enjoy every bite of korean bbq but my favorite part is the no-so-spicy hot saucy. It has the perfect flavor and right level of heat for the bbq. Everyone working there must know how great the sauce is because they always give us a bottle.

What I recommend: 

-- bim bim bap
-- beef bulgogi
-- refills of the banchan
author: Andrew W.

description:
One of my favorite Korean BBQ spots! I've been coming here since middle school and the service and quality has remained the same! 

You really can't go wrong with any dish on the menu and they alway hook you up with some sort of complimentary dish. My must have is the spicy soft tofu stew in beef broth. Be sure to ask for a raw egg to crack in the piping hot broth. Oh and mix it while it's hot! The soup becomes rich and so creamy. 

This place can accommodate large parties as well!
author: Sara W.

description: One of the best KBBQ spots around the area! A little pricey, but I think they're actually cheaper than others that serve the same type of food (and their portions are huge!).
author: Lisa N.

description:
HAN IL KWAN
This place was fantastic!!! One of the best Korean restaurants in San Francisco. How do I know, other than dining there personally? There are Korean tour buses parked outside all the time! That's how good it is! Come here for the steamed short ribs! They were outstanding! The seafood pancake was also another winner. Parking is nightmare, but it's well worth it. Awesome food here!
author: Stanley C.

description: Such an amazing place. Excellent service and delicious food at a good price. It'll be hard not to over order as all the food is that good. We ordered bulgogi with all the fixings, fried dumplings, and tofu soup. They even complimented us a free omelette.the food is fresh and not overly spicy, and would be a perfect place to go if you've never had Korean food before (or if you were raised on it!) 2 BBQ orders required if you want to self cook at the table.
author: Brad S.

description:
Came here with friend and fellow yelper Vikki K. We both decided to try out Han II Kwan because we've heard good things about this place and had to try it out for ourselves. A friend suggested that I'd go during lunch because their lunch prices were the best. We all know by now that Korean food doesn't come cheap, so we came here to check out the lunch specials. Sadly it only applies to weekdays and we came on a Saturday. We got lucky with parking because it's pretty hard to find parking in the Richmond district.

We ordered too much food as usual, our eyes were definitely bigger than our stomachs.. so we had a lot of left overs.

We had the spicy BBQ pork and cold clear noodles.. and it came with the usual ban chan, tofu soup and pancakes. 

I was surprised by how much food we had on our table with just the two of us.. it was overwhelming. 

Everything was tasty and the prices weren't too bad considering it was the normal pricing at the time.

I'd definitely come back for the lunch time specials soon.
author: Tiff C.

description: Worth the long wait that is almost always unavoidable. But completely worth it. We came in on a Friday night planning for a long wait and it actually went by quicker than expected. Great quality Korean BBQ and I love that the soon dobu soup automatically comes with your meal. I have to come here anytime I'm in the city.
author: Rosie I.

description: Best Korean BBQ in SF as far as I'm concerned. I live in the Inner Richmond so it's just a short trip on the 31 for me, but it's worth making the trek even if you live downtown or in the Sunset.
author: Evan Z.

description:
Seriously impressed with this place. They give you plenty of small dishes pre meal along with tofu soup. I don't think i've ever been to a korean place where they also provided a soup as part of the appetizer dishes. Despite all the small dishes there was no kimchi dish, waaaaahhhtt? 

I got the bibimbap, and fried prawns to share with my friend. Their portions are quite big so come hungry. I was hoping that the bibimbap came with more meat, but they never do so in this regard Han II Kwan is much like the other korean places i've been to. The fried prawns were delicious though, and i'd recommend it.

There's a good amount of seating inside, and in the inner room there's two long tables so this place should be pretty good for groups. If you are looking to grill though there's only a few tables that support it so you might have to wait a bit before you get seated.
author: David C.

description:
One of the best things about this place is that you get so. much. food! Nine banchans, a tofu soup or steamed egg, rice, and a sweet rice dessert drink at the end. 

I recommend: 
- Beef Rib Soup: generous portions of beef and delicious tendon. The broth is flavorful and not overly salty 
- Braised Ox Tail ($26): SO. GOOD. AND. TENDER. comes in a sweet-ish broth with carrots and potatoes. (Honestly not sure what broth it is, but it is dang good). Good portion to split between 2 people. This is my favorite thing here! 
- I personally haven't tried it yet, but the KBBQ ($25/pp) seems to be what the hype is all about :) 

Mehhh: 
- Oxtail Soup ($13): this is not to be confused with the braised ox tail! This comes in a white broth, which was honestly extremely bland. I had to add a good amount of salt & pepper. The oxtail was tender, but dish was overall disappointing. 

Expect to wait at least 25-30 min during the dinner rush. Parking is also quite terrible in the area.
author: Samantha C.

description: Han Il Kwan is probably the most authentic Korean restaurant within the city. I personally like Cheongdam better, but that's located in Santa Clara. This place is packed during lunch time and dinner time. Make sure you get there earlier than 12pm for lunch and 6pm for dinner. BBQ and hot stone bibimbap is amazing here. Seafood pancake was too doughy for me. I usually prefer crunchy and thin ones. Since i'm Korean, I try to judge quality of Korean restaurants based on their side dishes(banchan), and this place has side dishes (banchan) on fleek. My fav banchan is cucumber one..so gooooood.
author: Sm Y.

description: Han il korean is consistently solid Korean food! . A bit more on the speedy side; but what you pay fore is an authentic feel with a great dining experience. If trying to be more thrifty; consider coming for their lunch special deals during the weekdays. Be aware that they often cater to large groups of Korean tour busses so sometimes they seem extremely slammed; though with good company and endless banchons -- it's not a shabby shake down
author: Alexander T.

description: Han II Kwan has been my to-go place for korean food since last year. My favorite time to go is during their weekly special during weekdays. I usually enjoy eating the bibimbap ($9-$10), and I'll get a side of seafood pancake ($24?) with my friends. They also give complementary soup and small pancakes which is very delicious. At the end of the meal, after you pay, they also give a complementary sweet rice drink. Han II Kwan has a lot of "service", a term in korea which means "freebies". And that's why I enjoy going here so much.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
9pm on a Saturday night.

We walked in and all the workers were so friendly! We waited about 15 minutes to get seated. You have the choice of sitting at a table with a grill or not. We chose the table without the grill since it was faster seating.

The servers were attentive and checked up on us a good amount of times throughout the meal. We ordered the spicy bulgogi (#5) and the marinated short ribs (#1). The bonchon arrived shortly after. They had a great variety of different side dishes such as kimchee, pickled cucumbers, dried fish, lettuce, etc. I tried every one of them and they were all delicious! Definitely refreshing. For the main course...

DUN DUN DUN.

THE best Korean bbq I've had so far. The meat is so juicy and flavorful. They give you a huge amount of meat with a side of rice. I can't get over how flavorful it was! They also gave us some tofu soup on the house. Not sure what it's called... But it was good as well. The random food just kept coming and it was all included with the meat we ordered! Who DOESNT love free food?! 

After about 30 minutes of stuffing my face and unbuttoning my pants to make way for my new food baby, there was still more than enough to take home. and they also gave us a free sweet rice milk drink at the end to cleanse our palettes. Again... FREE FOOD PEOPLE!!

I love this place. I hope our relationship continues to grow. 

-1 star because it was a little on the pricey side.
author: Sami E.

description: Be prepared to wait but also know it's worth it! Rumor is they take reservations if you call head but this didn't work for us so we waited for 1.5 hours for a BBQ table. I was very skeptical but my friend swore tour buses full of Koreans regularly pull up to this place, which is a huge testament to the legitimacy. Once we got seated, we ordered two serving of meat, which come with all the yummy sides. They kept the yummy sides coming and were very attentive at getting the meat cooked properly. We inhaled a mass amount of food and beer over the next hour and the bill was still on $30 each. Totally worth it, can't wait to go back!
author: Larisa J.

description: Authentic Korean Food..... It tastes even better because it will take you a minute to park LMAO... Quick matter of fact service. Nice portions , fresh and really yummy flavors. It's in the Richmond District. You can do your own cook it yourself style or just order off the menu.
author: Cecilia D.

description:
Grilled beef perfume...ain't that sexy?!  My friends and I left with the smell of Korean BBQ on our clothes and in our hair but it was good no doubt!  My friend wanted to come here because she was craving kbbq and came here a while ago.  The restaurant location is totally random, right smack dab in the residential area of Balboa!  

Place was packed on a Saturday night & we had to wait about 45+ minutes for a table with a bbq.  We ordered the kalbi short ribs, marinated chicken, & the sliced rib eye.  So much meat!!  We enjoyed the tender short ribs and the perfectly marinated chicken.  The rib eye however was tough.  We were all over the daikon and bean sprout banchan dishes and loved the tofu soup with plenty of silky tofu.  Service at times was a little difficult to flag down but friendly nonetheless.  At the end of the meal they also gave us a sweet rice dessert beverage in little shot glasses, it kind of tastes like tea (which I don't drink at all), but my friends enjoyed it.  I always think that Korean food is so pricey, but were so stuffed with their big portions.  Pre tax & tip the bill came out to $60ish.  

3.5ish rounded up.  And yes as others mentioned....this place is crowded with frequent Korean tour buses stopping, but isn't that a good sign?
author: Cat C.

description: This is by far my favorite Korean restaurant! Always make a reservation as it's crowded all the time. I bring all my friends here if they want some decent Korean food. The dishes they serve is always on point. The speediness of service may be a bit slow, but it's because it's jammed packed! Go there with an empty stomach, and come out full and smelling like meat :)
author: Lo L.

description:
4.5 stars. I finally made it here with the suggestion of one of my korean friends. And it didn't disappoint as the best korean restaurant in San Francisco. We ordered some traditional korean fares (bulgulgi, seafood pancake). everything was delicious, as well as the little dishes in the beginning of the meal. The seafood pancake had the right proportion of seafood to starch without being too greasy. 

highly recommended. one tends to order more than one's stomach here, especially given the small free dishes in the beginning. so go light on ordering at first.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
Excellent kalbi ribs.  Great marinade sauce.  Price on par with other kbbq. ($30pp) 

Can select to bbq or not (we did).  Very solid selection of side dishes, including fishes! (Anchovies)

Came 6pm on a weekday, no line.

Parking can be difficult in this neighborhood.

Would come back.
author: Leland F.

description:
Wow wait was about 45 mins on aug29, Saturday around 7 with no reservations. Alot of people (mostly asians) and we just stand there basically for 45 mins and parking was crazy too!!

Now the food and service has pros and cons:

The good with the bad. 
-This joint DOES NOT seem to have a DRY MSG AFTER TASTE unlike many Chinese places that leaves your mouth dry with loads of MSG. 
-Free appetizers like the standard kimchee, ben sprouts, rice, etc...
-free tofu soup very flavorful and not that spicy with mushrooms. 
-Jap chae is not salty and taste just right but more sweet potatoe noodles would be nice agian it has mushrooms. 
-seafood pancake looks and taste good but is there any dipping sauce to take it to another level?
-beef short rib stew with carrots and potatoes was very brothy and flavorful and i even saved the broth for my left over free rice. 
-octopus with veggies was a little chewy but not like rubber and sauce was killer. Again it has mushrooms.  
-Bulgogi taste very beefy and had a nice not too dry texture to it but could use some better presentation with garnishing. 
-bibimbap was flat and had not taste to it. My least favorite dish for some reason. 
-rice sugary drink was perfect with some rice on the bottom. 
-service from the older korean ladies is fast and seems nice when compared to Chinese servers. 
Overall food, service, wait time and price i give it a four. Would come here again in the future but not on a weekend.
author: Organic T.

description:
I didn't eat here - so take this with grain of salt...
I called to ask if I could make a reservation for tonight.
They told me they only take reservations the day ahead and so I should just come in.
I drove over with my family and arrived about 20 minutes after I'd called.
When we go in, the hostess asked if I had reservations and I said no because the woman on the phone wouldn't make a reservation. She said all the tables were full and it would be at least a 45 minute wait.
I wish she would have said that on the phone because that's why I wanted to make a reservation. She could have at least told us that the restaurant was full and that we'd need to put our names on a list or whatever their system is so we could have made a more informed decision before driving over, looking for parking, and the whole shabang.
We left to go to another restaurant.
author: Siobhan B.

description:
Another one of my favorite Korean restaurants in the city!

They give sooooo much sides (even if it's just two people), including free tofu stew & vegetable pancake. 

I don't know the names of the dishes I ordered but they were both good. One was squid in the sweet/spicy sauce. And the other one was a fall-of-the-bone short ribs dish in a sweet sauce/broth, slow cooked in a hot pot with potatoes & carrots. 

The portions are HUGE. Two dishes were enough for 4 people!
author: Alysha K.

description:
Best Korean food in San Francisco. Trust me on this one. Also they have the ox bone soup which no other restaurants in the city carry. Banchan was fresh and delicious, great service as well. 

Beware on weekend nights as parking will be atrocious and the restaurant fills up with tour groups.
author: Mike S.

description: This is a very popular Korean restaurant that offers both grill and no grill style eating. Upon arriving, there were probably 20 people waiting and we ended up waiting for roughly 45 minutes to get a non grill table. The restaurant comes with side dishes (ban Chan) as a normal Korean restaurant does, however this place had by far, more side dishes than any other place I have gone to. They even give you an option of tofu soup or an egg side which could very well be an option on the actual menu. We ordered bulgogi and bibimbap, both of which came in large portions. Rice was served on the side with the bulgogi. Afterwards, they brought us a sweet rice drink which I had never been served before. Han Il Kwan was a pleasant restaurant with great interior design and awesome portions.
author: Tuvshin T.

description: Ordered oxtail soup and bibimbap for dinner, came with side dishes and a steamed egg dish on the house. Ox tail soup was refreshing, can be bland, so add in salt as you please as it is provided on the side. The atmosphere was very lively and the food was overall delicious.
author: Gigi H.

description:
Another cold, rainy, day, another body-warming sundubu joint. Dropping in with a friend from SoCal several weeks back, we ended up ordering: 

* Tofu Soup (Sundubu) - Okay, but too bland for my tastes. Manna, while having fewer items in the actual soup, serves up a far tastier tofu soup. We actually dumped in all our kimchi to spice things up a bit - when our waiter came by later and noticed this, he actually suggested that we get the kimchi variation of it the next time around.

* Steamed Egg - This was actually sent to our table, on the house. I actually wasn't aware Korean cuisine had a variation of what I only fondly know as chawanmushi. While less seafood-filled, it was warm, fluffy, and tasty. And free! (Friends have commented on how Korean restaurants realize that free things tend to bring people back - I can certainly see why)

* Braised Beef Short Ribs (galbijjim) - Easily the best part of the meal, the beef was super tender and tasty, albeit a bit sweet. Make sure to enjoy it with some rice to balance things out a bit.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - The interior of the restaurant is massive: tables are aplenty, and spread out quite far, so accessibility shouldn't be an issue.

Bathroom - Didn't check them out, so I can't comment.
author: Johnny W.

description: Just left this place without eating. Called ahead to see if any Korean tour buses would be there, I was told that one was coming at 6, so we booked over and got there by 5:15 (we live walking distance). When we arrived, there was a huge crowd of tourists outside the restaurant (they were leaving), and a line of non-tourist customers waiting to be seated. We put our name down on the wait list and were pumped that we beat the tourist rush. We waited for about 10 minutes for the wait staff to clear the tables. Next thing we know 2 HUGE tour buses roll up and droves of tourists walked in right past us, the line of non-tourists. They sat down and occupied the entire restaurant, which meant we would probably have to wait another 45 minutes before being seated. We like this place because it's one of the few options within walking distance but the food just isn't good enough to wait that long. But more importantly they give preferential treatment towards the tour agencies vs locals. I give this place 0 stars because we didn't even get to eat, but moreso because of their poor service.
author: Andrew M.

description: Incredible hot pot soup. Came in for lunch, left completely satisfied and bloated for just $15 of food. (Small dishes were complimentary and beautifully presented!)
author: Leo G.

description: Crowded at 5:30- took that as a good sign, and boy were we right! Spicy pork and  marinated beef spare ribs did not disappoint.  Clean and bright with snappy service - great experience
author: Aimee W.

description:
Service is slow and the rib eye is tasteless. Spicy pork is okay but more on the dry side. Keep in mind that our food was cooked in the kitchen because not all tables had the vent for cooking yourself. The side dishes are large but our food came in the wrong order. First the bbq beef, then spicy pork, then side dishes, then jap chae, then the soup. 

I would not revisit this restaurant simply because the experience is not worth paying for.
author: Allen T.

description: This place made us wait for an hour while telling us it is 20 minutes.  In the mean time, they are serving the tour bus one after another.  THEY DON'T WANT TO SERVE LOCALS!
author: Muoi W.

description:
Hands down best Korean restaurant in SF!!!

After growing up in Korea, Ive been on a mission to find an authentic korean restaurant in SF..its been so difficult, but Han Il Kwan answered my prayers...

Amazing service, food, and kimchi (ask for  more fermented kimchi if thats what youre into).

Meat is amazing quality, and the side dishes are plentiful. I'm in love
author: Cheri K.

description: Superb Korean food, not insanely crowded, and really delicious homemade banchan! We ordered the japchae noodles, bulgogi, and kimchi pancake. All outstanding! The tofu stew that comes with each main dish is really delicious too. They happily accommodated our request for vegetarian japchae noodles. SF has superb Korean food, but this place is a must!
author: Mick J.

description:
Korean is one of my favorite foods. I found this place on Facebook as one of my friends recently ate here. The lunch specials are a really good value. I'm use to spending hundreds at Korean restaurants but surprisingly, we got out of here for less than $50 at lunch time.

Parking is a huge problem around this area of San Francisco. Be prepared to circle the blocks. Plus I have a long car so it makes it harder to squeeze into the little spaces without blocking peoples driveway.

The service was friendly and with a smile. Usually Korean's are very curt. But the man here is very friendly.

I like onion beds under my meat. At this restaurant, you have to request it. Most Korean restaurants I go to put the onion bed there automatically.

I have posted photos of this restaurant. Please check them out and you can also see all the yummy dishes I ordered.

CIAO
author: Emily C.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here on a Friday night at around 7pm. First off, the parking sucks as it took us almost 30 minutes to find a spot. When we finally found parking 3 blocks away, we walked to Han Il Kwan and saw that there was a tour bus leaving, so we thought we came just in time however, the wait was about 30-45 minutes for a table (cooking and non-cooking.) When we were finally seated, our waiter, who I'm assuming is one of the owners, brought us water and our menus. We settled on the stone pot bibimbaps with beef. As they were bringing out the side dishes, they also brought out "on the house" vegetable pancakes and tofu/beef soup. 

Stone pot Bibimbap with beef - Piping hot, flavorful, and soooo delicious! I've never had bibimbap and my boyfriend suggested that I try the stone pot as opposed to the regular pot because the rice at the bottom gets crunchy. The vegetables were fresh, however I wish they put more beef in the bibimbap!

Overall I had a pleasant experience at Han Il Kwan and I wouldn't hesitate to come back. The service was definitely on point, the waiters/owners were extremely friendly, and the food was so delicious for the price! I'll probably try the kalbi or any of the cook yourself meats when I have a larger group to dine with. Overall, it was under $30 for 2 people, which is not that bad for a Korean restaurant.
author: Joyce E.

description:
tl;dr

This is the best KBBQ north of I-380. 'nuff said. Really. Come during lunch for great deals!

----

Come on, you know a place is legit when there are hoards of Korean tourists eating dinner with you on a regular basis :)

I've been to Han Il Kwan (HIK for short thereafter) so many times (especially during the summer, when I interned at the SF VA) that the servers started recognizing me and not giving me a menu anymore.

I've been here for lunch probably around 15 times, and dinner about 4 or 5 times.

DINNER 

Dinner first - the KBBQ here is legit, and all of the grilled stuff we tried are quite excellent. Kalbi (both marinated and non) is succulent, with the right amount of fat and juiciness. The pork belly, although overwhelming at first sight, transform into delicate morsels of joy after a few minutes on the grill. The spicy pork, like people mentioned, is wonderfully flavored and even better after a night in the fridge.

Kalbi is one of HIK's strength's, so they make an equally excellent Kalbitang. It's one of the best renditions I've had, both in SF and elsewhere. If you want a thicker, sweet soy-saucy flavor, go for the Kalbi-jjim. I like their jap chae too (again, one of the best in SF), but the only thing that's lacking I've found is their bibimbap. It isn't really much to write home about.

So yeah, if you're looking for a nice KBBQ night out with your friends, HIK is the place to go. It might be worth it to call in advance, as they will inevitably fill up (especially when those Korean tour groups come!) We were so stuffed with KBBQ once that I got on the Balboa bus shortly thereafter, and literally passed out cold until the bus was close to Embarcadero. 

Dinner is about $25-30 pp, depending on what you get. When you have a big enough of a group they won't make everyone get an entree. 

LUNCH

I actually think HIK is the best for lunch, because they have AMAZING lunch specials at a ridiculous price. For LESS THAN 10 DOLLARS (pre-tx/tip), you get all of their dinner KBBQ mainstays (kalbi, spicy pork, chicken) or bibimbap complete with:

-6 or 7 _generous_ portions of banchans (usually 7)
-a small slice of korean pancake (this is actually not much to write home about)
-your OWN soondobu soup
-rice
-a tea kettle full of hot steamy barley tea
-sweet rice drink aftewards

I actually eat a lot, but this is a lot of food even for me. The key is that HIK's banchan portions are huge, and they really fill you up. This, plus a bowl of rice, a bowl of soondobu soup, AND a good serving of grilled meat...tell me how you're still hungry. It's so much food that when I worked at the VA, I would come here only once a week because it was such a rich lunch...but I loved it nonetheless :)

A note about their banchan: my absolute favorite here is their marinated cucumbers. It really seems all they do is brine the cucumbers, then toss it in sesame oil, but it's incredibly tasty here. The cucumbers are always juicy and at the right level of sweetness, to a level that I haven't seen emulated by Korean restaurants elsewhere. Their radish kimchi is also quite excellent, and their fish cakes as well depending on the day.

I honestly think HIK is better than 90% of restaurants in NYC K-town, and I haven't really seen anything that compares in Manhattan proper without getting to Queens. I only hope to be living close to a place like this someday :)
author: Chris S.

description:
I think the best thing about this place is the side dishes. The reason I am giving it a 3 instead of a 4 is because I think the food was just okay. It's probably more of a 3.5. 

So we were seated quickly once we entered. We didn't sit at a table with a grill because we didn't feel like doing the BBQ.

So I ordered a tofu soup and my friend ordered the bibimbap. I think my tofu soup was okay, no egg came with it. I like the bibimbap overall. I think I prefer that over my soup. 

I came on a weekend night, so I felt like it was busy. They were quick with the service and served us in a timely manner. We asked for bunch of refills on the side dishes, I feel like I can eat it all day.

At the end of the meal, they gave us some dessert drink I didn't care for. My friend said it's suppose to help with the digestion. It's very sweet, and it looks like there's rice on the bottom of it. It comes in a very small cup.
author: Margaret L.

description:
Wow... Me n the wife just had n amazing meal here. It seriously just made it to one of the our top go-to Korean places in the city. 

We were surprised to find out how cheap our bill it was... Well by Korean BBQ standards anyway. We over ordered because we were so used to getting small ass servings from other places. The table of 6 next to us literally had the same order as us.
My god we were so full... I'm still full right now!! I'm actually on the toilet right now tying to let go of some of it go ... lol. Sorry... Ykno I'm actually thinking this will be the place I write most of my reviews from now on. Post meal dump review... The PMD review.. Kind of the best place to write up these reviews if you really think about it. Whatever. Lol. 

Anyway... Food was great. Portions are big.. Service was good. You should eat here.
author: Shaun A.

description: Very long wait, so get there early.  Banchan is excellent, some of the best I've had at a restaurant.  Seafood pancake is delicious.  As was bibimbap and vegetarian tofu soup.  BBQ pork was okay - it was already cooked b/c we didn't want to wait another hour for a bbq table.  I'd recommend getting a bbq table.  I like it crispier than it was served.
author: Sondra H.

description:
Been coming here since literally forever. It is my favorite Korean restaurant in the whole world.

LOVE their galbi and bibimbop. My boyfriend likes the bulgogi, but obviously he's a noob since galbi is where it's at! I like their ban chan as well. Their mackerel is good too. 

As little kids, my sisters and I used to fight over who got to drink our parent's rice dessert things. Why did I say as little kids? We still do that.

Their lunch specials are good for the money conscious (~$10). They serve it until 4PM, not on major holidays though. My mom gets me galbi lunch special to go sometimes, hehehe. My boyfriend and I will order the galbi and bulgogi lunch specials to share. We normally have leftovers too. The bill is $24.

Ugh, I love this place so much. You really have to come.
author: Bianca W.

description: Lots of banchan (even free spicy soft tofu soup) and generous portions. Staff were friendly even though they were really busy!
author: Alyssa H.

description:
One of the best Korean places in San Francisco! Went here for dinner and it did not disappoint. The portions were huge and they give plenty of side dishes that can be a meal in itself. This restaurant gives out "on the house" items - such as seafood pancake, japchae, or a bowl of eggs.

I got the short ribs, jap chae, pot stickers and rice. Doesn't sound like too much but it does when you stack on about 8-9 side dishes. No BBQ because it tastes better when they cook! It gets a little busy around dinner time and the meat plates can run up to $30 a dish. Although the price is a little steep, they do a good job offsetting it with a lot of food as their portions are quite large and can fill anyone up. I'm a guy with a large appetite and I ended up having to take the food home.

If you're ever in the Richmond district, I recommend giving this place a try. Service is great, food is good, parking wasn't too difficult.
author: Vincent C.

description:
This would have been my 11th check- in here if I wasn't so busy with their yummy dishes, good friends and conversation! Bar none this is the best Korean restaurant from SF to the Peninsula! Just come and try it for yourself! You can't go wrong!
My fave is the marinated beef, noodles (Japchae) and seafood bibimbap!!
author: PixieD D.

description: All I can say is wow everything from the short ribs to the stone bowl was amazing they even gave us a bowl of complementary tofu soup that was awesome I definitely plan on coming back here the service was excellent.
author: Michael D.

description: I wish I have come to SF more for food before! This place is absolutely comparable to those popular Korean restaurants in NYC! We had seafood pancake, marinated beef short ribs (my favorite) and seafood bibimbap. All were delicious!
author: Vicky L.

description:
A,very good friend invited to have dinner here. The wait wasn't so bad but parking is so hard. The server were great and very attentive. 
Food is so good and serving is good amount at least 2 per serving. Side dishes were hmmm yummm!!!

Will definitely cone back and tell my friends!!!
author: ML A.

description:
Must try!
Must try!
Must try!
I love the food!
Service is excellent!
Very quiet!
Parking is not that bad
Cheap enough for lunch but get expensive for dinner!
Perfect for dinner date or even lunch date! I suggest to come for lunch!
Soup and side dishes would fill u up so be smart with orders if going in groups!
author: Lhyn G.

description: I give them five stars originally went here because they said rude service but awesome food so i knew it had to be legit.....food was awesome not an expert on korean but fresh spicy and drlicious i ate my whole bowl of beebop and normally i cant eat that much the condiments were delicious....u know its aurhentic when there's a lot of condiments :) service was not rude either....there were very busy and flexible with my change in reservations and patient when my cousins card got declined....food was a little on the pricy side 20$ for beebop
author: Emily B.

description: This place is amazing! Went after a round of disc golf and it was a good thing we went after. Left fat and happy! Amazing experience, must go
author: Robert H.

description:
Get the soft tofu soup. Don't care if you like tofu. Or if you eat meat. Get it, it's to die for.

The bi bim baps in stone bowls aren't bad either. Loved the small dishes that come with every meal. I know the green seaweed looks pretty icky if you're uninitiated, but it was my fave, so give it a shot.

Just don't say you want bbq and then change your mind. You'll have to do the walk of shame after a grumpy Korean waitress says "you-have-to-move" -- all one word, said as if she's said it too many times. The bbq happens at a table with a special hot plate, you see.. and if you aren't going to pay the $28 or so minimum to order TWO types of things to bbq, why, then you can't sit there.

That's fine. I'm not particularly fond of the long tables in the back room though. Reminded me of a middle school cafeteria.
author: Diane Y.

description: My party was able to get seated in a timely matter. They definitely deliver on the "freebies" (ban chan) and because they were so busy, they actually gave my table a free large pot of the steamed egg, which I thought was nice. The workers aren't as fast moving as the workers in other Korean joints that I've been to on the east coast but they're doing the best they can. Food tastes great and they have a lot of options. Definitely coming back!
author: Stephanie F.

description: I can only speak to the awful service and mediocre soup dishes. My wife and I ordered galbi tang and seo lung tang. Both dishes were bland and had very little "Gan". I don't know why Bay Area Korean cuisine is so mediocre in general but this spot lives up to that reputation. Took 20 min to catch anyone's attention for the check and a to-go box...the waitress' responded with an exasperated sigh, as if we were asking too much of her. We don't really expect the best service at a Korean restaurant but even by our low standards the waitresses were incredibly rude and neglectful. We will not be eating at this restaurant ever again.
author: Augi K.

description:
San Francisco is foodie paradise but not so much for Korean food. My family and I were extremely tired from moving in my brother all day and all we wanted was some comfort food. Han Il Kwan provided that for us and it might be the most authentic Korean restaurant in the city. There is a parking spot only for tour buses. That's how popular this restaurant is. When we got there, we had to wait a good 45 minutes also but once we got seated, the service was very good. Food took forever to come out though and totally out of order. 

Their banchan service is phenomenal. We never had to ask for refills because they constantly refilled it for us. We ordered short ribs stew, yukaejang (spicy beef soup), an order of galbi (marinated short ribs) and soontofu (tofu soup). Things came out one at a time which was very annoying but they were swamped beyond belief. I never order galbi at restaurants because they're too sweet but it was pretty good here. Tasty with some rice. I didn't care too much for their soontofu. It was good  but I've had better soontofu elsewhere. Their yukaejang was delicious. Filled with beef and vegetables and so delicious. The dish that we were most anticipating was their short ribs stew but this really took way too long to come out. We were ready to cancel and go when it came out. The restaurant gave us a free steamed egg to compensate for the time but by that time we were already full. The stew was loaded with perfectly cooked potatoes and vegetables. The only thing that was wrong with it was the sweet factor. Over the top sweet. They really need to cut back on the sugar there. 

Overall, for Korean food in the city, it really isn't bad. It doesn't compare to the food in LA, but I would be back if I was in the city. Everything came out piping hot and we walked out of the restaurant relatively happy and full. 4/5
author: Michelle L.

description: Best side dishes we've had in SF I dare say! Besides a full range of usuals, we even got to choose between having steam egg or soft tofu as a side! Reasonable prices for its soup dishes which I was craving for coming here. Good lunch deals for individuals. BBQ dinner or dinner in general would be more affordable for groups due to the packages on offer and minimum order requirements. But the ambience is excellent for groups and families. When you see tour buses of Korean tourists being bused in all the way here, you know you've found something pretty authentic. ;-)
author: Jan L.

description: One of the best Korean restaurants in San Francisco. This place is always packed with or without tour busses in front. If you see busses parked in front, then I would not even bother waiting for a table, since they book the entire restaurant. The wait was not too back when I went on a Friday night, and we were able to get a table with a grill. We got the Kalbi, Burgolgi, Seafood Pancake, Bibimbap, Seafood Tofu Soup, and the Beef Short Rib Stew. The Kalbi and Burgolgi was very tender and was well marinated, we were also able to grill it at the table on our own. The Beef Short Rib Stew was the best out of the entire meal, as it was very flavorful and tender. The Seafood Pancake had a bit too much green onions. The Seafood Tofu Soup and Bibimbap was standard. The service here was also very quick, as they brought out our orders very quick and our tea was also refilled frequently. They also helped us grill the first round of Kalbi and Burgolgi which was nice. It really feels like you are eating at someones house when the waiters serve you. The only downsides is the wait and the need to find parking in the residential area. Will return later on to try the other options on their menu.
author: Peter C.

description: So many people. Waited 30 or 40 mins for a table. the have rules to all you can eat bbq. Ended up getting soup and a bowl since my friend didn't want all you can eat BBQ. All good. Food was bomb!
author: Lin D.

description:
I really wanted to love this place because of all the good reviews from my Yelp friends, but I couldn't cause of the service I got :( 

I love Korean BBQ! ..but my bf isn't a huge fan of it. After eating AYCE on Wednesday, I still wanted more! He finally agreed to eat with me and we both wanted to try some place new! So, we stumbled upon Han il Kwan on Yelp. We arrived half an hour before closing and lets say they hated us the moment we walked in. 

Okay, I guess it was my bad for coming in half an hour before closing (with the restaurant already have 4-5 parties), but it doesn't mean you should treat us with an attitude. When we stepped in, the guy already told us that they were about to close, but we still agreed to stay. 

He sat us in the corner which is a kinda awkward seating location but kinda cool at the same time, because for parties of 2-5, there are booths available. In the corner behind the booths, there's only a table and 4 chairs - pretty secluded. For bigger parties, there are tables in the middle that you can be seated in, and they include a grill if you like to cook your own food! Before he gave us our menus, he asked us if we knew what we wanted. Since it was our first time here, obviously we didn't. When he did hand it to us, he stood by our table, kinda giving us this impression that we should hurry up and order what we want. Reading the menu was confusing cause I think they put the dishes into categories (i.e. Lunch, Grilling, etc. but when you look at the dinner menu, they don't have Bulgogi or Galbi on there because it's in the grilling section.. Ask your waiter if you're confused on how it works!) My bf and I ordered from the grilling section but it was cooked in the kitchen, cause we weren't seated with a grill. There was no 'cook in kitchen' surcharge for us, cause I think we came super late, so you should make sure if you don't want a surprise! 

After we placed our orders, our banchans came out and this consisted of bean sprouts, fish cakes, broccoli/carrots, and more (about 8-9 banchan - there's also tofu soup). The fish cake here was a little different as the color was lighter than usual, but it tasted about the same. During our meal, they gave us 2 mini pancakes but it wasn't all that great, and when one of the ladies working there gave us our tofu soup, she kinda spilled it and didn't even care or apologize. Yep, they definitely hated us. 

Food!
*Before I start, I will say that the two dishes my bf & I ordered were both DRY (overcooked), and lacked presentation to it. Looked as if it was just thrown on there. Canned soda beverages are $1.50. 

Beef Rib-Eye aka Bulgogi - $22
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/han-il-kwan-san-francisco?select=r7wzh4g-x7RowxRlF91UZg#KGBTo1_zbmEgaknBFr9p4Q
Though our dishes tasted dry, the good part to it was that it was marinated and definitely had flavor. The overcooked-ness didn't make the dish taste as good, but I'm hoping to try it again next time .. and hopefully it'll be better! 

Spicy Pork - $20 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/han-il-kwan-san-francisco?select=r7wzh4g-x7RowxRlF91UZg#oGX-nGMG35vw52_2NkhZkg
I love spicy pork! This dish was actually pretty spicy, and I couldn't finish it. Again, I think it would've been better if the dish wasn't overcooked and dry. I would recommend ordering this and Bulgogi! 

Even though we pretty much received crappy service just because we came in late, some of the waiters were a little nice and still checked in on us. I think part of the reason why they rushed us was because so they can start eating dinner at the restaurant. I think I will give this place another chance .. but probably not anytime soon, and make sure to come earlier. 

For what we had, our bill came out to be about $50 for two people, excluding tip.
author: Mandy G.

description: One of my favorite Korean restaurants in San Francisco. The food is pretty authentic and services are great!
author: Sonia P.

description: Food was authentic and good. Very big portions. The only reason for the 3 starts is due to customer service.  I was there at 3:30 pm by myself. Restaurant was not super busy. The staff seems to be either no sure how to handle a person eating by herself or just too busy to smile. I didn't feel welcomed there by myself.
author: E. K.

description:
Great place to have a big party--private room in the back.

Parking is a major pain in this area, esp on a Friday night. Luckily, our DD dropped us off and he went to look for parking. 

Came up on a Friday night for a bday celebration with over 20+ ppl.

We arrived a little late, but fortunately the host ordered food for everyone--family style; I guess we came just in time since food arrived once we were seated ;)

My favorite dish of the night was 'Kalbi' Bbq Short Ribs Marinated In House Special Sauce. MUST TRY!!! 

Good ban chan too!
author: Jen H.

description:
