My trusty partner-in-eating, Vicky L., and I headed over after work to find the place packed with a busload of Korean tourists. We were seated right away around 6 but another busload came in a few minutes later. They were in and out pretty quickly.

Banchan -  7 or 8 small dishes, PLUS Korean pancakes and steamed egg. I was almost full after this point...

We also ordered a side of Korean pancake (since we didn't know about the free one!) and I had bibimbap - my go to Korean favorite. The bibimbap is HUGE. I can usually eat the whole thing but I had lunch for the next day. It's surprisingly good re-heated. 

All for about $20 pp.
author: Sara P.

description:
Food: I have tried quite a few Korean restaurants in SF, this one Food is just the average level. Compared to the real Korean cuisine, the food in this restaurant is not that "Korean".

Parking: I went there at 2pm. easy to find parking spot.

Service: Horrible from the moment I stepped into this place. I'm not judging the waiter's pronunciation, but I did misunderstood once when he took our order, and then, when I asked about the detail, he repeated the same sentence in a louder voice and an angry tone, omg. They didn't cut noodle for us. I mean, they could have done better, but they didn't.
author: Pelou G.

description: Wasn't too impressed with the service or the food. It's a spacious and well-lit restaurant which is really nice, but during lunch hour on a weekday (it was pretty busy) there were 2 people waiting on all the tables so service was really slow and unattentive. That was fine, but then my table was given a smaller variety of ban chan than the table next to us, AND THEN!! --- my dol sot bibimbap was just so WRONG in that the rice did not get crispy at all. There are some good lunch deals here on weekdays and it seems like a good enough restaurant, but I just had such a mediocre experience.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Love this place and their awesome lunch specials! The staff tends to be a bit unattended but I'll forgive them for feeding me yummy Korean food! 

There are probably 10 things on the lunch special list you can choose from among other dishes on the regular menu. But the lunch specials are a really good deal, given that they come in smaller portions? Not sure about the smaller portions cause I can never finish my meal. I've tried their spicy pork and kalbi, and both are delicious! The meal also comes with pancakes, banchan, rice, and dessert rice drink. I love it when korean restaurants serve dessert rice drinks! Nice touch to end the meal after eating all that BBQ-ed and spicy food. 

Great place to go! There's always parking outside and never crowded during the weekdays. But the service is just a tad slow, so bear with them.
author: Michelle L.

description:
This place is pretty bomb. I went with a group of my friends and there was a lot of us LOL. So this place, I think, is great for groups! The meat was SO SO juicy and flavorful! Everyone LOVED it. The sides that they gave us was also great! It complimented the meal very well!
We were missing one order and we told the waitress, she corrected the order very quickly! Plus, she gave us 3 free seafood pancakes to show how sorry she was! (We weren't even mad at her!) So I would say my experience with the service was great :)
author: Jeca V.

description: Great selections of side dishes!! Spicy tofu house on the house! All those dishes can feed us full already. We ordered Bulgoge, seafood pancake, octopus with veggies and bimbimbob. Octopus is kinda chewy but the taste is good.  Seafood pancake is okay. Too much green onion and the taste is too blended. Bimbimbob is average, but I like the crunchy rice stick on the pot. They have the sweet drink for dessert too! Taste good! Their service is great! Will definitely come back soon!!!
author: Suki W.

description:
This place is great and ranks up there with restaurants I go back to again and again. I love Korean food and Han Ill Kwan does it well. I always see Korean tour buses full of Koreans eating here.
My go tos:
kalbi
Pork belly
Spicy pork
Bulgogi
Bi bim bop
Jap chae
You get about 9 banchans.
They also give free rice, Korean mini pancakes, tofu soup or egg, and the sweet rice dessert drink.
They also have great tea that is some kind of green and barley mixture.
The food makes up for the sometimes miss service. Since they are so popular sometimes the wait is just too long. They do being the food out pretty quickly. You also have the option of BBQ at your table or having them cook the meat. I'll often suggest this place to friends and family.
author: Annie P.

description: Good for big groups, though our party of 9 didn't get to use the self cook grills. Decent service considering we had a big group. Server was really sweet and thought we miscalculated the tip, came back to our table to double check. Well-lit, clean, reasonable parking.
author: Sophia N.

description:
Highlights: 
- I'm in LOVE with the included items that come with your meal here. Freebies 
make me happy! 
- Their Kalbi beef is the best. It comes with an option to grill your own meat at the grill tables or already grilled along with lettuce on the side. 
- Each meal comes with about 8 mini appetizer dishes (pickled carrots, kimchi, jelly, fish cake, bean sprouts, caramelized potatoes, mini pancakes), rice, along with a bowl of tofu soup. You also get a mini cup of a sweet rice drink for dessert.
- When Korean tour buses come to this restaurant, you KNOW it is good!

Improvements:
- Service is slow as there are only a few servers for the restaurant
- Pricey but flavor is great and you get so much food.

Tip: This restaurant is popular and can get busy, so come early or be prepared to wait especially on Friday nights and weekends.
author: Tracy T.

description: My favorite place to have Korean BBQ in the city hands down. Soooooooo good. The best Kalbi.  I wish they had chicken wings though.
author: Maria E.

description: I've never been in a restaurant where I pay them money to get yelled at by their waitress simply because I was clarifying what she was saying. I understand and appreciate accent. I, myself, has an accent. So when I was faced with this waitress and had to ask her what she was saying, this old Korean waitress yelled at me in front of my husband, mom and 9 month old daughter. You don't deserve my business and I don't care how good of a food you have, you simply do not disrespect your customer. I believe I'm not the only one who have commented on their rude service, so you be the judge. You guys don't deserve a penny from me and be sure that I'll be calling San Francisco health department for what I've seen as some questionable health code violations.
author: J C.

description: I love this place. The food is great and they will come by and assist you with cooking the food. Added service is always a plus in my eyes.
author: Kar Sui L.

description: omg! i drive by after a day in the park and i see a random korean restaurant on the street.  i jam my brake find parking and run in around 4pm.  theres already people sitting and eating.  about 20 minutes later there is a wait.  im like oooh yeah i beat the crowd.  got a seat to cook my own food.  ordered two different types of meat.  pork belly and spicy beef.  omg for 50 dollars you get sooo much food.  on top of the two meats they give you EVERYTHING YOU CAN DREAM OF.  kim chi, broccoli, sprouts, tofu soup, pancake, rice, potatoes, lettuce, etc.  they give you all the fixings.  omg its heaven.  i was soooo full! way more full than an all you can eat korean bbq for about the same price.  crayyyyyyy.  they really cater to you.  they help put the meat on the grill.  they help cut it.  such good service.  love it! i imagine during real food hours it can get super crowded.  so lucky i went such odd time.  good thing my eye spotted this place.
author: Matthew G.

description:
My mother is Korean and I've lived in Korea for the past 5 years. I've been back in SF for almost 2 months and homesickness hit hard. My friend and I decided to get Korean food today and we chose Han Il Kwan because our other friend frequents here. Yummy banchan and spicy tofu soup that are complimentary (Can't understand why any restaurant would charge for that!) and I found that they had one of my favorites: yook hwae bibimbap (raw beef). Food is pretty good and I like that the service was fast. Complimentary shik hye (sweet rice drink) at the end was nice as well.

I haven't to tried the other Korean spots in the area yet but this may be my go to Korean spot for when I'm homesick!
author: Yuri K.

description:
My fav Korean restaurant in the city! Service is slow but better than the rest.
Food is fresh and plenty side dishes.
They get really busy so come early or eat late!
author: Alison W.

description:
This place Han Il Kwan is an OK little place. I would have given it more stars but the service here is really crap. The wait staff are generally rude and preoccupied with God knows what. It may also be a Korean thing..I don't know. I'm not for certain if Korea culture is one that treats others in a rude manner..but that's what this place seems to do. 

The food at Han Il Kwan is decent. They give good portions and if you are fan of Korean food, I think it's pretty good. Not great, just good. I've been to a few other Korean places in the Bay Area and I found one in Oakland to be better. Only problem is it's in Oakland..and we all know what goes down in Oakland. Not a good idea folks. 

Han Il Kwan menu is quite extensive as most Korean places go, I like the short ribs and the chicken, I wouldn't do the sea food because quite honestly, I don't trust it. I've seen it, but I don't trust it. They also serve this wild and spicy tofu soup. It's good for a few sips but don't get too involved. 

The other day I sat next to an older white American man, looking about 65 years old with white hair and fat gut. He was complaining that they gave him too much food. Go figure huh? I would think a guy like that would be complaining of the opposite. In any case, the fat guy told the waitress to take his spicy tofu soup back into the kitchen because he didn't want it. The waitress waits a few minutes and brings out a spicy tofu soup to my table. I get the idea that she gave me the fat guy's soup. As a precaution I don't take any sips, I leave it on the table and don't touch it. It's really hard for me to trust Asian places when it comes to stuff like this. Honestly, I love Asian food, but these people aren't known for their hygienics. 

(I once saw a roach crawling around in a Vietnamese restaurant on Balboa Street..it was right next to my table---absolutely disgusting!!) 

Anyways, Han Il Kwan is a decent place. The food is good, the service is horrible. The wait staff could take a lesson in manners and learning how to tend to customers...but you know, I realized at these Asian places that they actually thrive on being rude. They love to yell and spit and give people dour faces. It may work to your advantage if you're rude and mean. Just be pushy and throw things around the table, act like you own the place and be very demanding. I'm assuming that's the Asian way. 

I think I'll try that..see how it goes. Just don't spit in my food.
author: Tiffany R.

description:
I'm beginning to wonder about the standard of Korean food in SF. I've heard Han Il Kwan was supposed to be really good, if not one of the best places in the city, but I really didn't think it was anything worthy of mention!

There were a combination of aggravating factors that led to my 2-star review.

1. Location. Sure, I get that good food is often a trek but this place was not worth it! Either you have to sit on a bus (or two) for over an hour, or drive and spend 15-20 minutes finding parking. Not fun.

2. Service. The wait staff were perfectly courteous but they were severely understaffed! It was hard to get their attention after our initial round of food came. We wanted to get more tea/water, order more banchan, and check on the status of the rest of our order. It took forever! Also, at most Korean places that let you bbq at your table, the wait staff usually takes care of the meat for us. Either it wasn't Han Il Kwan's protocol or they were too busy. Either way, I feel like the price of the food should include that part of the service, even if we were perfectly capable of cooking the meat ourselves. I also didn't like the fact that they didn't come to change our grill plate.

3. Banchan. Nothing to write home about. I've definitely had better quality and quantity at other places! We chose the soondoobu and it was not good. It wasn't even hot.

4. Meat. Quality was not good. Our kalbi was thin and the lean meat to fat ratio was lopsided and unevenly distributed. When it was grilled, it didn't turn an appetizing color (and that's my proxy for how  fresh the meat is). The portion was pretty small too. The bulgogi was okay. Spicy pork was definitely spicy, but the marinade wasn't evenly distributed. There were slices that didn't get much marinade at all.

5. Everything else. This is just me being nitpicky but as nothing else was that good, this only worsened the situation. The napkin was really thin and Korean food can get messy. The cups for tea and water were really small - you take two sips and your cup is empty! Gotta refill it... oh but wait, there's no tea in the teapot and they're not around to refill it. The door never seems to close so half of me was getting blasted by the cold outside air and the other half scalded by the heat from the grill.

I definitely wouldn't trek out to the Richmond for this place again. I'd rather pay 50% more for expensive but really good food in NY.
author: Sherry L.

description: Just been there again. Still amazing. Book a table for dinner. Lines can be long - even on a random week day.
author: Asmus O.

description:
Food:OK (65/100) 

Service: BAD 
(except for a busboy who was kind enough to bring us water after being ignored by waiters for more than 15 minutes)

Price: Overpriced

Overall Experience: OK 

I would rather go to Brothers.
author: Y T.

description: To be fair, I only tried one thing here and it was really good and a generous portion. I also took it to go, so I'm not sure about the dine-in experience, but the beef spare ribs over rice were really yummy. They seem to have a wide variety of seafood options. I don't eat seafood, but I do plan on coming back and exploring what else is on the menu.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
One of the best, if not best general purpose Korean restaurants in all if San Francisco. The quality is great and the price is silly cheap. 707 Sutter is a distant second.

DongBeak, CocoBang, My Tofu House and so many others can't hold a candle. Now for Wood Charcoal BBQ, there are better places, but if you're looking for a little Kimchi Jigea, or bibimap,  or soups, Han Il Kwan is the spot. They give you so much ban chan (the side dishes) that they are a meal in and of themselves. For $20 you're served 3-4 meals worth of food!
author: Art W.

description: Han Il Kwan is quite an experience. Came here on a Saturday around 5pm and waited for about 15 minutes. They bring out a lot of interesting appetizers with any entree you order. We had a chicken dish and the seafood bi bim bap. We didn't end up liking the chicken dish, but the bi bim bap was pretty good with calamari, shrimp, scallops and a fried egg. Not sure I will ever come back here, but it was good to try out.
author: Sarah K.

description:
This review is going to be from my (chinese) parents point of view (of which i agree with). 
So it was their first time ever having korean BBQ, but needless to say, they LOVED it.

- banchan=free stuff to a chinamen (2 huge thumbs up). i also have to add that they picked off the roots/ends of the bean sprouts (which takes alot of work btw!) and i really appreciate this because i won't eat bean sprouts unless those ends are picked off. 
- kal-bi stood out! It was really tender. amongst other things we ordered were: spicy bulgogi and tripe+intestines
- tofu soup = meh....we've had better
- bibimbap = mehhh.... i wanted more of the rice on the bottom to be crispy. it just wasn't getting there. Also it came with a sunny side egg on top. I prefer it to be a raw egg i crack on there myself
- japchae = delicious. melt in your mouth
- the complementary soft egg = again to a chinamen is great! For me, awesome because it's one of my favorite things to eat! 
- rice, which we didn't get charged for. YES. AWESOME

and then there's the bill: for 6 people, ~130 (+tax/tip). SO GOOOOOD!!! so cheap
author: Priscilla W.

description:
Jap chae (sweet potato noodles but wasnt sure how truly grain free so only had a little bit but it was very good)
kalbi short ribs yum
bibimbap (automatically served with rice on the side - so paleo i think!) i put just a little bit of the red sauce on it for more flavor.
side dishes all yum esp the mini dried fish
came with a bowl of tofu soup which we all shared which was yum too

all excellent food

but next time i will definitely just get take out - the back room where they put us was so smokey we all got a scratchy throat and felt suffocated. this was even with the door open. they need a fan or something back there. we were able to move to the table by the door under the overhead vent fans but could still feel a little smoke problems. if you have a sensitive upper respiratory system dont sit in the back for sure.
author: Win H.

description:
Love love love. I live really close to this place, and it's super convenient for when I don't know what to eat for dinner. 

Stone pot bi bim bap and the dumplings are amazing. They definitely don't skip out on the ban chan and although this place is always super busy, the staff are extremely friendly.
author: Denise Z.

description:
This is probably the only place I'll go to for Korean food in San Francisco.

Food: The dishes are good! Very flavorful. I love getting the soup here. My favorite meat dish are the short ribs. 

Parking: horrible. It always takes us a couple of rounds in the neighborhood before we find parking. 

Service: OK. They have 2 main waiters who takes your orders. So when it's busy, it's hard to get their attention.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
This place seems to have really good buisiness which explains the long wait for seats on a Friday night. I felt like they didn't pay attention to our table just because we're a bunch of high school kids. We didn't recieve the service that everyone else had. First, we had to wait more than an hour for seats. Then we were seated at a large round table considering that we only had 4 people. We practically had to scream across the table to talk to one another. There were 4 empty seats between us on both sides. Everything was a diaster and it was so awkward to sit at such a large table with only 4 people..

The side dishes didn't come until a good 15-20 minutes after we were seated. I was already starving. The bowl of steamed egg didn't come until the very end which was after we had our main dish. The price was a little above decent while the food was okay. I don't think I will be back anytime soon. I highly prefer My Tofu House a lot more.
author: Kelly H.

description:
I will preface with the fact that I am from Los Angeles, spoiled by the delicious, affordable fare of Koreatown. That said, San Francisco's Korean restaurant scene has been a very tough sell for me. 

I expected a lot because I heard that all the Korean tourists come here in buses. The fiance and I ordered bulgogi, bibimbap, and soon tofu. The bulgogi and bibimbap were okay. Not the best I ever had, but it did it's job. As for the soon tofu.. we found a fly in ours. :/ We informed the waiter, and he brought us out another bowl. Even still, their soon tofu was not my favorite. 

Thinking back, there were actually quite a bit of flies flying around. :/ We went during lunch and it was a particularly sunny day --maybe that was it? Pertaining to all Korean food in SF.. KBBQ is expensive here. Like close to $20 for a plate of bulgogi? In LA, you can get decent all you can eat bbq for like $10. 

Anyway, yea.. I've had better. Sorry Han Il Kwan.
author: Kristina R.

description:
Han II Kwan is located in the Richmond District. Parking is very hard to find as it is located in a residential area regardless of what time you decide to come here. It's definitely one of my favorite Korean restaurants in the City. Some tables come with grills and some don't. Depending on whether you want to cook the meat at the table or have them cook it for you.

I love how they give many banchan dishes. We also had received complimentary pancakes and steamed egg. Both were quite delicious. I have tried various dishes from soups to bbq dishes, stews, and bibimbap. Portions are big and quite delicious. Everything is well-seasoned and flavorful. We always end up with leftovers to bring home! I don't think there was anything I have not liked yet. At the end of your meal, they serve a sweet rice drink. Service is pretty good, helpful, and friendly.
author: Philana C.

description:
This place has the best Korean food I've had anywhere. I like in particular how the Kalbi comes already off the bone, and how soup is included with the table order.  But all the food is great here - I also like spicy pork and the jopchae (noodles with beef).

What makes this place 5 stars is the lunch special. Korean food is generally expensive due to portion sizes and the accompanying freebies. But during lunch here you get 50% off. My girlfriend and I get an amazing lunch for $17 or so a person.  You will be stuffed, satisfied, and coming back for more.

Service is great if you are in front room. If you are in back room, you may need to walk out to front room to ask for things as the servers check in far less frequently.
author: Charlie B.

description: What a long wait with hunger :-( and another long wait for food! At one point, I had to beg for side dishes served first because my son was too hungry and eating ice cubes! The soft tofu soup was just ok, we were so spoiled by the nice Korean tofu house in South Bay ;-) But the side dishes were yummy and of great amount, they also served big bowl of steamed egg. They really need to optimize their service, they seem too busy, hire more if needed. Angry customers are bad for the business ;-)
author: Cherry L.

description:
This is one of my favorite Korean restaurants in the city!

What I got: 
Seafood Pancake. Rating: 3.5/5
Bibimbop. Rating: 3.5/5
Side Dishes (Banchan. Rating: 4.5/5
Soft Tofu Soup. Rating: 4/5
Bulgogi. Rating: 4/5

Restaurant usually gives a sweet and tasty rice juice after for free. 

Con:  usually you'll have to walk far if you're trying to find parking.
author: Erin M.

description:
It took me a long time to write any review of this place as I really love their food. It's as authentic as they come. Their kimchi is simply delicious, marinated meat is amazing, the free spicy tofu and sometimes pancakes are icing on the cake.

That being said, their customer service is horrible. If it wasn't for their food, they get only 1 star! They almost never change out your grill (went there more than 10 times, only change it once), constantly need to flag them down for any refill and it will take them forever to get back to us. And if you flag them down often enough they learn to be blind around your table area. Last visit experience were in a group of 6 and even with reservation and outside of rush hours their customer service still sucks.

Doesn't matter how good your food is, when your customer service sucks, it embarrasses me to bring any friends over to try to tell them how good your food is.
author: Jennifer K.

description: This place is not good and expensive. Not all you can eat like most Korean bbq and was forcing us to order everything at once because they were too lazy to check on us.
author: Nicole D.

description:
so where can i get a bus ticket?

this is the restaurant famous for it's authenticity - so awesome that it's part of a korean bus tour. with that much street cred i knew i just had to try it.

first and foremost- parking is really hard to find so if it's possible drop of a scout to sign you up on the list while you circle around and around and around looking for parking...

there will probably still be a bit of a wait after but that's expected with kbbq. good friends and smart phone games make the time pass by and soon enough you will find yourself seated and ready to order. *if it's your first time here, check out the menu while you wait and figure out what you want so you can order as soon as you sit.

we had kbbq- which is one serving sort of a deal unlike other places that are all you can eat. so we got two different plates. the pork belly which when sliced thinly is pretty much bacon :) YUMMY BACON! we also got a plate of tripe and intestines. not on every menu but something i always look for- it all goes back to the first time in LA... anyways. it was on the spicy side but with just enough to get you to break into a sweat and wanting more. the ban chan spread was modest. it was a decent spread which surrounded the bbq in generous portions.

i loved the place and i enjoyed the food. i think it was just bad timing on my part to come after one of the buses. the wait was kinda long the service was really slow and they ran out of that wonderful sweet rice juice that ends the meal. but that doesn't mean i won't be back, because the place was delicious.

until next time

cheers!
author: Jerico P.

description:
This is one of my favorite Korean places in San Francisco. A quick ride down the 31 bus drops me right in front of this place. While the prices may be a bit expensive than other competing Korean restaurants. It is worth spending the money. You get a huge amount of tasty side dishes that cover the whole table as well as tea that is promptly filled if you go through the tea pot. Not to mention, every time I've gone, they've given us a free dish of egg or pancake. I usually get their bibimbap but their lunch specials are delicious and are a very good price.
The waiters are very nice and accommodating to groups. A friend warned me that tour buses come often so the place gets cramped. I didn't believe her until I came around 4 or 5 one day and the restaurant was mostly empty, only 3 other tables had people. Then 3 tour buses came one after another and the restaurant was filled within minutes. A group of 4 people, who came 10 minutes later then our group did, had to wait 45 minutes to get a table. Usually the restaurant has plenty of room but just be aware that sometimes it can get really full. 
Overall, Han il kwan is worth the price and the food is always fresh and tasty.
author: Summer B.

description: Great place but always a long wait especially dinner time during the weekends.  Plenty of good side dishes.  Better to have them cook the bbq than to do it yourself.
author: Tommy K.

description:
Han Il Kwan has the option for you to BBQ your own meat, or they can grill it in their kitchen for you. For our party, we got lazy and had them grill it for us.

The Meat:
Short ribs, ribeye steak (bulgogi), marinated chicken, and spicy pork were all full of flavors.

Side Dishes:
Complimentary like many Korean restaurants but this place gives you COMPLIMENTARY tofu soup!! Enough for everyone at your table. That's a plus!

Bi Bim Bap:
This was very delicious and full of flavor as well. Rice and other ingredients served on a hot stone pot. Go ahead and pour on that hot sauce and mix, mix, mix!

Alcohol:
Choice of beer, soju, or sake. 12 oz of beer for $3, and 20 oz of beer for $6. You know what to do here. ;)

Dessert:
Complimentary sweet rice water at the end to finish up your meal. 

My party and I all left very full... I think we ordered too much, but somehow we still finished it. Must have been THAT good!
author: Nancy N.

description: Legit Korean food! Hubby and I loved it!!! The spicy rice sticks (not sure what they are called in Korean) were so delicious. Definitely one of my favorites. The beef and spicy pork were outstanding. All the little Korean dishes they give you (my hubby told me Korean word for it but I can't remember!) were so delicious. Service is good and the place is very clean! It gets busy! Make a reservation and go early!
author: Kristen C.

description: After a long walk in GG park on a cold and cloudy SF day, this place was a wonderful nearby spot for lunch. Every dish was delicious and well-prepared. Portions are large and likely one main + all the included side dishes will be enough for two. Braised pork spicy dish (takes longer to prepare per menu) was indeed worth the wait - recommend asking them to bring side dishes out with this entree so you don't fill up on small plates before the main comes out (or just have good self control!). The broth was excellent with rice and all of the small plates. Pork a bit tough, but really absorbed the broth's nice flavor.
author: Jay B.

description:
Wow. Authentic Korean food.  I've been looking for such a restaurant since I moved here 4 years ago.  Back home in Hawaii, we can find great Korean food on the daily.  Here, not so much, but this place is a gem (and thankfully only 2 blocks from mi casa).  
The banchan is fresh and delicious and the meats are excellently seasoned.  It is a little pricy but you pay for the authenticity of the food.  I recommend!
author: Alex G.

description:
H ard to beat a place with parking reserved for Korean tour buses
A nd if the Korean nationals come here, it must be legit, right?
N o doubt -- this is my favorite Korean restaurant in SF

I t all starts with the Panchan (sides) -- plentiful and well made
L ove that it includes Tofu Soup and a delicious Mung Bean Pancake

K albi Chim (Korean braised short ribs) is a winner!
W onderfully tender and amazing flavors -- I highly recommend
A ll of their meats are delicious: Kalbi, Bulgogi and the Bi Bim Bab
N ice to finish the perfect meal with Sweet Rice Water -- refreshing!
author: Anthony N.

description:
Ate here with some friends and it was so crowded! Food was good though! All the meats were fresh and delicious! The panchan tasted good too! 

The reason for only 4 stars is because i wanted to take my family over and they told us to eat at either 4 or 7! Apparently a tour bus would be there all night.....bummer
author: Anny L.

description: Ok so let me start off with saying they're food is probably good and authentic, BUT that does not excuse them from being rude and unprofessional. The workers don't speak English well so I'm trying to communicate with them and ask where the waiting list is to sign my name in, but just told me "Wait" and I said "Ok.." Then while I waited, there's a group that knew where it was and immediately signed their names on it even though we came there before them. So that's one. Then as we waited nearly 45 mins (not exaggerating I swear) and we were next up, there's a tour bus that just parked outside and a sea of Koreans came in and they seated all of them before us. I asked the lady again because we're next on the list and we've been waiting, and I honestly just wanted to know the approximate time, and she told me "Look, you have to wait ok" and I'm like I've been waiting! So we literally just walked out and I'm not gonna be disrespected like that. A place like that doesn't deserve my business or anyone's if they're gonna treat us like that. On a side note, I felt a little discriminated by (I'm Filipino) them since I was so lost in translation and they kept ignoring me and putting the Koreans as a priority in communicating and seating. Thanks but no thanks.
author: Trisha B.

description:
I passed by this place while looking for a parking space and saw a long line of people so I decided to give it a shot.

They have pretty good service and the side dishes were just right, not too spectacular but they did everything right.
We ordered the meat that we could cook at our own table (kalbi and intestines). I honestly have had better kalbi before. The texture was insanely rough to the point that my tongue ended up getting a cut from a small string of meat that still held the two blobs together while one half of it got lodged in my throat and the other was still between my teeth. Pretty good marination though
Intestines was horrible
Don't get it
Ever
Don't even try it
I felt like I was eating rubber bands
I liked the shik hye at the end, made me forget about my near death choking experience. Which is why my review isn't 1 star or 2 stars
author: Brian L.

description: One of the best Korean places in town. The wait was worth it! You can choose between table seating or barbecue. This is one of the very few places where  you can cook your own food. It's not all you can eat, but the prices are pretty reasonable for SF. If you have to choose between Bulgolgi or Kalbi, choose Kalbi. It's delicious!
author: Tina S.

description:
Food: 2.5 stars (Mediocre)
Service: 0 stars (Beyond bad.....it's actually horrible and one of the worst I've experienced ever!)

Went there with a group of friends for dinner and had kalbi. From the start the service was bad. The place was half empty when a few of my group arrived. But the server would not seat us, only asking multiple tomes if we had reservation to which I said yes. After 10 minutes of waiting we were finally seated and that's when it went from bad to mug slinging ugly. The waiter had mad attitude issues!!! WTF... For example, he brought over the drink order and when I tried to order food he told me....wait, wait, wait (literally 3 times in a row in a not so friendly tone). Writing this review is making my blood boil so ill skip the rest of the horrible service examples.  Just know that the waiter made all of us feel as if we were supposed to accommodate him (and his "I don't want to be here serving you" attitude). 

In terms of the food, it's nothing special. The banchan selection was scarce and it wasn't as yummy as other places (Oh and the waiter wouldn't bring out the only banchan that tasted good) and the kalbi was on the too sweet side, more so that other bay area Korean restaurants which are usually sweet because they typically don't cater to Koreans.  Also, their grill set up is horrible for kalbi since it's not a mesh type of grill so the kalbi marinade burns much faster and have to constantly change the grill (which the waiter wasn't too trilled about!!)

In summary, I will never return to this establishment.
author: Chris S.

description: Good Korean food but hard to find parking. Was going to try to eat there again but could not find parking this time. There were two tour buses stopped in front to eat there.
author: Lisa M.

description:
this place is truly bomb.
my lady and i went yesterday.  got seated quickly, even though a tour bus was there just an hour before.
the banchan was bomb.  included tofu soup which was a brilliant bonus (sweet rice dessert at the end was a brilliant perk as well).

we had jap chae (solid).
bibimbap in stone bowl (solid).

and i need to add, which is the basis for writing the review, that the kalbi stew was divine.  really, one of the best dishes i've ever eaten.  the kalbi must have been prime grade beef.  so tender. and the stew was incredibly tasty.  i could eat a pot of rice with just the gravy it was that bomb.  

maybe the best korean food i've ever had.  beats BCD in socal.

highly recommend.
author: Brad U.

description: The food was awesome, however, the service was terrible and slow...We came in at noon on a Monday and the place wasnt even packed; there were several empty tables, however, we had to wait 10 minutes before we were seated...not even sure why...after getting seated, we waited another 10-15 minutes before our orders were taken and then another 15 minutes before our side dish came out...when our main dish came out, they forgot to bring the rice and my dish wasnt even what I ordered...I was too hungry to care so I just ate what was brought...nonetheless the food was delicious, however, that being  said, I don't think I'll be back, as the service sucks! If u like being ignored and have to wait an hr before u get ur food, this is the place to go...
author: Trang N.

description:
Probably my favorite korean bbq place
the price in my opinion is slightly cheaper compared to other korean bbq places
the portions are good
the meats are great, usually get spicy pork and the beef
the place is clean
usually gets packed because there's always a tour bus on the weekends and some week nights that eats at the back room
the spicy soup was bomb
they end your meal with this sweet rice drink, really refreshing after everything you eat
good amount of side dishes
sometimes they'll even give you complimentary soup or other plate. i personally have gotten something complimentary on 2 occasions
place doesnt get smoky at all

first on the list if im ever craving korean bbq
parking can be a hassle because it is in the middle of residential area
author: Andi I.

description:
I cannot believe I haven't written a review for this place yet! Everyone (meaning people who are interested and open to different foods) should come here and would love the food as well!

I love this place and would choose to come to this korean restaurant over others because:
- amazing food (banchans  and main dishes)
- open and comfortable setting
- great lighting
- big windows in front
- do not rush us during our meal (I recently went during the dinner rush)
- clean bathroom
- fast service

Food:
I am a pescetarian so that limits the things I can eat at the restaurant but that does not stop me from coming! I always order their hot stone kimchi bibimbap and mung bean pancakes. The crispy burnt rice from the hot stone plus the spicy and slightly sweet mixed rice with crunchy and chewy mung bean pancakes and side dishes. = DELICIOUS!! 

Cons:
- have better outtake air fans for the BBQ pits in the center of the restaurant. It got pretty smoky and thankfully I was not seated in the vicinity for my meal bc I would've smelled like meat afterwards (and I do not eat meat!).
- cannot make adjustments to the menu item you order. For example, cannot have something taken out of a dish.
author: Shirley M.

description:
One of my favorite Korean restraunts in SF. It's a little pricey, but they are generous with the portions. Meats (bbq beef, chicken, and kalbi) are perfectly marinated and tender.  They also threw in freebies with our dinner, tofu soup and some pancake thing. And you get all the little side dishes. You can cook at the table or have them cook for you in the kitchen. I was so stuffed at the end of the meal. To top it off, they give you the dessert rice drink which is always a must-have at the end of a Korean meal.

Good place for groups.

Service was not super attentive but you will not leave dissatified or hungry with the food.
author: Ali F.

description:
I visited Han II Kwan with my family for father's day. I absolutely love Korean food, and being one of San Francisco's best Korean BBQ restaurants, I decided to try it. There were large groups of Korean tourists coming out of buses, and this caused us to stand waiting for about 10 minutes. The whole restaurant was literally just Koreans, and my family were the only white people there. Now this is a GREAT sign. No white tourists = GREAT authentic cuisine. 

We were seated by a kind waitress with a BBQ table. I immediately ordered the Kalbi (my favorite). My parents ordered the Seafood BBQ plate. My little sister ordered the Bulgogi. 

When our food came, I was ready to dig in. The Kalbi was amazing, and same for the Bulgogi. The Seafood was average Seafood. The Banchan here was very tasty, and had a wide variety compared to other Korean BBQ places I have been to in San Francisco. 

After we were done eating, I noticed I had the BIGGEST food baby. I was absolutely stuffed. I love Han II Kwan. It was so delicious, clean, addictive, and full of wonderful Koreans everywhere. I totally recommend checking this place out.
author: Emmanuella Z.

description:
This is definitely one of the better Korean BBQ places in SF. We came here on a Saturday night and the place was packed. I liked how they put some thought into the design, making it look somewhat like a temple. Luckily our wait wasn't too long and we were seated by one of the booths.
To me, the banchan (side dishes) are just as important as the main dishes, and the banchan at Han II Kwan was excellent. It was fresh and they had a lot of variety. Also, this is the only restaurant I've been to where the tofu soup is on the house. We sampled most of the meat, including Kalbi, bulgogi, chicken and pork. The meat was marinated perfectly and tasted delicious, very similar to some of the meals I have had in the LA k-town. 
They have a parking spot for tour buses right outside the restaurant. During the middle of our meal, half the customers in the restaurant started leaving. We were a little confused until we realized they were all from the same Korean tour group. 
The bill was around $160 for a group of six people. We left the restaurant with our stomach full, our clothes and hair smelling like Korean BBQ, and some bones for my dogs to chew on. Overall, the bbq meat here is delicious and I would definitely come back again.
author: Helen Y.

description:
Lately my coworkers have been coming here often for group lunches.

I've only ever been here for lunch and I always get something from the lunch special menu. Prices are a bit high, but that's usually the case with most Korean restaurants. Meals start with plenty of banchan which you can refill. Tofu stew is provided too. However, if you're in a group, it usually isn't enough for everyone to get more than a few spoonfuls. When I have eaten here alone, they give you your own individual bowl which is a lot better.

I almost always get the kalbi. Most pieces are pretty good, but I usually have trouble with the single bone piece they include since the meat is difficult to chew. I've also tried the chicken once, which was really good, but it takes far too long to cook so I would rather just stick to other items. Stone pot bibimbap was really good here too.

They usually include enough miniature (bite-size) pancakes on the house for everyone near the end of the meal. I wasn't a big fan of these pancakes like I usually am at other Korean restaurants though, to be honest.

Another thing - parking is horrible around here, so you may have to walk a few blocks.

Overall, a pretty good place to get Korean food for lunch. Haven't tried coming here for barbecue though, so other people's experiences may be pretty different since it sounds like a lot of people don't appreciate the service.
author: Allen C.

description:
San Francisco is lacking in delicious Korean food. This is no secret.
Han Il Kwan? This is somewhat of a secret. Tucked away on Balboa, one wouldn't think you'd find the best variety of banchan out here. 
First of all, they serve cheongpomuk muchim!! (Mung bean jelly) The banchan also tastes fresh.. haven't heard any horror stories about recycled banchan (uhh Hodori in Ktown LA anybody?) and they give you a ton!! 
Ordered 2 dishes and dam.. It was too much food. Between all the banchan and the complimentary soodubu, I was already getting full.. But I do love me some spicy sauteed octopus! That was plenty enough for me FOR SURE.
author: Susy C.

description: I have been to a lot of Korean restaurants, but this one is so far my #1. Don't let the sign of the restaurant fool you into thinking that the place will be very old - the inside ambiance is  nice although finding parking can be difficult (my husband had to park 3 blocks away). Get  the barbecue table and experience cooking on the table (we had to wait 10 min. though given there was no line) - the Kalbi barbecue short ribs marinated in house special sauce was so good!!!! Not to mention the 'jap Chae' - delicious!  Oh, did I mention that the complimentary banchan dishes with the soft tofu soup was also very good! If you're craving Korean - this is a must try.
author: Mary Gay L.

description: Excellent hangout spot! The food is decent at good price. Last time we had kimchi fried rice, fried chicken wings (yum yum), and budae jigae (korean army stew). Peach soju is jackpot!
author: Thanh N.

description: Delicious flavor profiles- minus one star because I spent a really long time having to pick bones out of my fish. I initially dove into the dish, assuming it was deboned, and ended up choking on some bones. There was a delicious crust, but I had ended up having to take it off in order to get the bones out. Had it been deboned prior to cooking I could've enjoyed the absolutely delicious crust (not coated, just cooked in a delicious way). Next time I will probably order something else, and I bet it will be delish!
author: Megan M.

description:
I'm giving Han Il Kwan 5 stars because they always let me bring my bicycle inside (but I should add that I have gone during off hours - between 1:45 p.m. and 3:30 p.m. - so, if you go with a bike when it is busier, there may not be room inside). :) 

I also really love the side dishes, especially the bean jelly. Mmmmmmmm. And as others have indicated, the lunch specials are about $8.50 and the portions are quite generous. I must eat here more!
author: Eva G.

description: I waited for 30 minutes for a coca, but waiters just forgot about it. I ordered too much food but they are not that tasty. Guess I'll never come back.
author: Cheese C.

description:
The lunch specials are amazing bang for your buck!

With lunch they serve the regular banchan sides plus a tofu soup and a Korean pancake for the table. The lunch-sized bibimbap was very large and with all the sides, I had plenty leftover for the next day.

I liked that the bibimbap had lots of big pieces of mushrooms along with a wide array of veggies and beef. They give you a botthle of gochuchang, and a few good squirts add tons of flavor and a some spice to the dish.
author: Annaliese D.

description: Avoid on the weekends. Tour buses have the priority. They occupy about 75 percent of the place.  As soon as a tour group finish, they prepare the tables for the next bus. That's two tour buses at a time. They don't tell you this. The long line is for everyone else waiting for the tables against the walls, about 6 tables. That's it. Besides that, I think this place is one of the best Korean restaurants in SF.
author: Nilreb A.

description:
SUCK it Brothers!


This place is fucking amazing!!  

The service is super nice and prompt!

The food was great.

Had the mackeral, Spicy Chicken Soup, and Tofu soup.

The Ban chans were house made, delicious, and endless

We got free goodies too!  steamed eggs, korean pancakes, and rice 

We took home the left overs and the next day it tasted even better (cold!!)

All for ~$55 with tax and tip.  

Worth EVERY PENNY!
author: Spanky M.

description:
AMAZING AUTHENTIC KOREAN FOOD. Trust me. I'm a Korean who loves food and grew up with homemade Korean dishes by my mom. This place nails the flavors and the cuts of meat for the BBQ are awesome. Great portions, prices and service. There are always tour buses full of Korean tourists out in front - what does that tell you? I get my fix here since my mom no longer lives in the US.

Eat here and get the BBQ- my faves are the sam-gyup-sal (pork) and galbi. The soups are great too! Yum!
author: Kaliah C.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised to find this Korean gem hidden within the Richmond. The smell of Korean BBQ was obvious even a block away! 

I like how the restaurant gives you the option of BBQ-ing your own meat or getting it served to you already cooked. Since it was my friend's first time BBQing his own meat, we decided to choose that method. However, because it is so time consuming, I probably wouldn't do it again next time. I mean, there is something to be said about having someone else cook your meat for you, no? 

If you want to BBQ your own meat, there is a 2-plate minimum for each table. It was a bit too much food for the both of us, to be honest. We ordered the Kalbi and the Bulgogi (spicy). The Kalbi was really good - I would definitely order that again. The spicy bulgogi was ok... I've had better. It was a bit too spicy for me - perhaps next time I'll order the regular bulgogi. The tofu soup was watery and not too flavorful - my favorite is still the spicy tofu soup at Sahn Maru in Oakland. 

Service was ok. We had to flag down our server for rice and our tofu soup that was supposed to come with our meal. 

Overall, a good Korean BBQ place.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
I came here for a birthday party - Korean style. We sat in one of the back rooms reserved for special parties, so I didn't get your typical dining experience. The food was pretty damn good. The service was solid. I'd come back. 

I enjoyed the Prawns and Vegetables in Oyster Sauce and the Assorted Pan-fried, Oyster, Fish, Vegetable Dipped in Batter among all the other food that I shoved into my face. 

I ate so much I cried. Then I drank beer. I prefer to dilute my tears with alcohol. 

They serve Korean Hite beer. It's in the lager group of beers similar to Chang. I think I prefer Asahi or Sapporo but it's a light beer. Just drink it, yo!
author: Sethy Wethy ..

description:
this place fuckin said that you have to make a reservation 1 week ahead and I had 5-7 people that's it. a 40-1 hour fuckin wait oh hell no. so I called up My tofu house which isn't even that far away and they said I would
only have to wait 10 min and that's just for them to set up so aye go hit up my tofu house
author: Tiffany L.

description: This place is awesome! Complimentary soup, pancake and great pan chan:)
author: Chris G.

description: I was a tad disappointed by the Bi Bim Bap (was a bit dry), but everything else was delicious. The service was fast and friendly too.
author: Ed K.

description: Amazing food and friendly wait staff. In my opinion this place is probably one of the best in the city. Always a line but I believe in waiting for good food.
author: Sky C.

description:
I came here with a coworker after work last week. We arrived around 5:40 and were told we'd have to wait about 30 minutes for a table. My coworker had been here before and said it was worth the wait, so we sat down and made ourselves comfortable, reading the menu as we waited. I noticed there were several empty tables that looked like they were set for people to eat at, but nobody was there. Then, almost suddenly, a tour bus pulled in and about 50 Korean passengers piled out and marched into the restaurant. They sat down at these tables and began eating furiously. In about 15 more minutes, a second bus pulled in, and more people came flooding into the restaurant. The first group was done eating in about half an hour. I'd say that there were about 4 or 5 tour busses that dropped off passengers and picked them up during the time we waited for a table! We ended up waiting about 45 minutes for our table, but my coworker assured me it would be worth it.

We made our way to our table through the last of the Korean tour bus groups and sat down. We'd already been looking at the menu and were now REALLY hungry, since we'd waited for a long time. We had agreed to purposely order more than we knew we could eat, just so we could have more types of food. We ended up ordering the dol sot bi bim bap, kimchi pancake, seafood pancake, and kalbi.

The bi bim bap was SO GOOD. The rice was nice and crispy at the bottom and there was a really good ratio of vegetables/meat to the rice. In fact, we each only ate a little bit of it (since we ordered so much other food), and, by the time we were done eating about two hours later, the pot was still hot and everything was just as good!

Both the kimchi pancake and seafood pancake were absolutely scrumptious. I'm personally more a fan of the seafood pancake and didn't like the kimchi one quite as much, but both were delicious.

Now, the kalbi, oh man - this is not just the regular thinly sliced beef-rib-meat. It had the whole bone (I think it was actually the cut of meat that wraps around the bone at Korean barbecue places...not sure what it's called). They cooked it for us since we only ordered one meat, but the plate that came out was piled high with meat and the bones were included! This may have been my favorite part of the meal!

Let me just say that this place was certainly more than worth the wait. Sure, we ended up spending quite a bit of money, but this meal ended up lasting us at least 3-4 more meals! (I love to have leftovers, so that's always a good thing for me.) I'm sure we'll be back sometime soon - we'ver already been looking for another time to go!
author: Charissa L.

description: We've had some great meals here, but recently we ordered the pre-set menu and it was not totally up to par.   They were extremely accomodating and I still love that this place is around the corner from us, but I would have given them 5 stars if our last visit was't better.
author: Edgar C.

description:
So the first time I came here it was really really good but the second time it was okay.  

Obviously this place is legit since tons of Korean tourists chow down here daily, but this past time I went I wasn't as impressed.

The Kal-bi was a little tough but had a nice flavor.  The chop chae had a lot of veggies (mostly mushrooms) but hardly any noodles, which are the best part.  The sides are good and they give complementary tofu soup, which I love.  I think they may have just had an off night and I will definitely go again.

This place is comparable to Brothers on Geary, but wayyyyy larger and cheaper.
author: Marisa R.

description:
Very delicious! 7 ban chan plus tofu soup for 1. Flavorful food and quick service.

No wait at 12:30 on a Tuesday. The restaurant was not full the entire time I was there. I'm not sure where all the complaints of wait are coming from. I certainly didn't see that to be the case at all.

I will definitely return.
author: Zoe D.

description: Pretty much disappointed about their customer service ;( ...Maybe I just came in at the wrong time, but I believe that an establishment should be professional and provide good service at any time-
author: Maki J.

description:
I've eaten here several times and have only been disappointed once, which is my fault (Don't order street food at a restuarant!).  

Fantastic Banchan, marinated BBQ meats, jigae/stews, and soups, but stay away from the spicy rice cakes, not because it's spicy but it's just meh!  Otherwise everything I've tried on the menu is awesome, but definitely expensive more like $$$ instead of $$.  Oh and Your meal comes with a complementary spicy soft tofu soup, which is awesome!  Service is great...when it's not packed full of people and your seated in the back room, if you are good luck on waving down a waiter until it lets up a bit.
author: M W.

description:
They have good food.  But the service is so bad.   I don't think we will be back anytime soon.  
Went there for lunch. Ask for refill for side dish. Never got any.  Ask for more tea.   There server toke the tea pot did not return with any tea.   I runout of rice.  Then there spear to have customer waiting for table. So one of the server bring the sweet rice drink and ask how many book we need.  I point out we are still waiting for refill on side dish and our tea.   Only got the tea pot bought back to our table.  5 mins later she bought us the check.  The check is about $48.  We left $50 on the table.    One might get better services at MCD.
author: Peter W.

description:
Update:

Keep in mind that I've been going here for over 20 yrs! Whenever someone would ask me where the best korean rest in SF was at I would say this place. I would also say the quality compared to SJ isn't as good and def. not as good as in LA. This place is still pretty good though.

HOWEVER

We made a reservation for sat night at 7:45. I get there at 7:30 and tell him we are here. He says it'll be an extra 20 minute wait. I'm thinking, really?? I told him we had reservations and he said he can't do anything. Anyways, we get seated 30 minutes after our reservations.  

The waiter, bald head guy, made a snippy remark to my younger cousin about paying for a drink. That def. did not start the meal off on the right foot. But after I ordered a very simple dish called Dol Sot Bi Bim Bap (hot stone pot bi bim bap), I coudn't put my finger on WHY it wasn't tasting right. I added more chan geerum (sesame oil) and more gochujang (hot paste) and still it wasn't right. After about 20 minutes I figured it was the place did NOT add any beef AND no sheegum chee (cooked spinach in sesame oil and salt).  I'm like, how the heck do you not have sheegum chee?!?! I could go back there and make it. The texture and the taste completes bibim bap and I've never had Bi Bim Bap without sheegum chee EVER or ANYWHERE.

Honestly, I'm sick of korean places in the bay area. Way overpriced and par food at best. Def. never going to Wooden BBQ on Geary and will probably not frequent here as much anymore. I'd rather drive to SJ and have food around there versus eat at places like this.

Sad that it came down to this but the management were so worried about catering to the 40+ ppl on the korean tour bus vs their regular patrons.
author: Sean Y.

description: Best Korean I've had in a long time. So good. Excellent service. Felt like real people.
author: Alex M.

description:
Been here a few times and every time we leave over stuffed and satisfied.  Their dishes are a bit on the expensive side but very generous portions and also good number of side dishes. We always get free tofu soup or some sort of pancake when we go. The wait staff is always friendly and service is decent speed.  

Parking is a pain but we usually find parking after looping around the neighborhood in less than 10 mins.
author: Jeannie C.

description: The BBQ beef was delicious. though the spicy pork was also flavorful the mouthfeel of the food was not pleasant. The variety of appetizers was excellent and included a few dishes I hadn't seen before.  As per usual with Korean BBQ the servers insist on cooking the food for you, even though I signed up to BBQ for myself.
author: Mike S.

description:
Han Il Kwan....I don't know if I love it or just like it, but I don't know of many other places to get some decent Korean food other than Brothers on Geary. This place isn't too bad though. 

I don't think this requires a long extensive book, but after coming twice with my family, we definitely like the chicken, beef short ribs and their steamed egg from their lunch menu! The first time we came, we ordered the spicy pork, and the other beef dish that is slipping my memory right now off the lunch menu, and the jap chae. After our first time, we just ordered the three favorites. There is not much to say about the flavor, your typical bbq tasting Korean food, and the light and fluffy steamed egg. The sides you get are plenty tasty on their own as well, and if you want  a refill of anything, good luck. The workers always walk the opposite side of the room or are always on the phone, or doing something other than look at your direction (this is my experience, both times)! Other than the service though, the food is yummy and this place is definitely affordable at lunchtime (for groups, not sure if I would come alone...).

B+
author: Alex T.

description: Best Korean restaurant I ve ever had!!!  Very busy with tour buses full of Korean tourists.,.,
author: Frederic D.

description:
I came here for lunch today with some friends and had the marinated chicken lunch special. My meal came with rice, tofu soup and the usual small dishes. Also got to try the pancake (not sure of the name) but it was good.
Overall my chicken was tasty and moist. For $7.95 I sure got a lot of food!
Service was just okay I had to get up several times to get the waiter's attention-food came out fast but servers were not super friendly. 
I would return again to take advantage of the lunch specials (only M-Fri). Otherwise, not bad!
author: Miss H K.

description: Love this place! The food is good and the service is wonderful :) They have lunch specials every week day, except Wednesday they're closed, and it ends at 4pm.
author: Bonnie S.

description: Best Korean restaurant in SF. They have really good lunch deals M-F that ends at 4pm. I like their seafood pancake, bulgogi, kalbi, seafood bimbibap and all their side dishes are really good quality. Yum they have the best kimchee + egg soufflé.
author: Laura T.

description:
Delicious kimchi and Bulgogi! Many side dishes, pancake, tofu soup!
Difficult parking!
author: Martha N.

description: We came here for dinner and ordered the most common Korean dishes (short ribs, spicy pork, dumplings, and tofu soup).  The short ribs were tender and quite yummy. The dumpling was okay as well.  However, the spicy pork was too soft as if it was not BBQ because I can still taste the marination and the tofu soup was bland. We had reservation but still had to wait a bit due to everyone from the Korean tour bus. Overall, the food was average. The only thing nice was the sweet rice drink at the end.  We had better Korean in San Jose.
author: Vivian T.

description: The best Korean food place in SF. HANDS DOWN. The place is usually packed, and sometimes you'll see the tourist bus stopped at the place. Banchans are great, and they give you the tofu soup on the house. So much good food for what you're paying for.
author: Silin N.

description:
Good food and excellent portions. 

Love that the banchan comes with Tofu Soup and the Pancake. The other side dishes are what you normally would get. Wish they had the sweet yams though.

Ordered the Kalbi and Spicy Pork and Kimchi Pancake (only cause I didn't know they give you a free plain pancake with the banchan)

Portion size is very good. One order of meat will definately make 2 people very full. (sucks cause I like a little bit of each, they should really consider a mix meat plate)

Service was okay. And by okay I mean if they're already walking around the tables and see you looking for them, then they'll stop by. Otherwise good luck getting their attention from behind the bar.

A little pricey. But considering the portion size and all the extras they give you, I'll let it slide.

Watch out for the tour buses on weekends. Don't even bother waiting.
author: Annie C.

description: It has been awhile since I've paid this place a visit. The food is delicious. I don't doubt that. My favorites are probably the bulgogi and kalbi dish. The seafood bimbibab is pretty decent as well! They also have tables with grills if you prefer to cook your meat yourself. It is pretty pricey, but it is San Francisco.  They start you off with 6-7 side dishes! I was really sad they do not have fish cakes or seaweed. They also give you a free tofu soup on the house! Service, however, was terrible. My party and I had a hard time deciding what to get and the waitress came to our table every 5 minutes to ask if we were ready and she sounded quite impatient. But their food is good so I can care less. What was ridiculous was- they did not give us our change after we paid and took it. We sat there waiting for 20 minutes and saw no sign of the workers returning our tab so we had to go ask them for it. Did they really think we are giving 30% tip for such horrible services? If you're looking for great and attentive service, skip this place. If you don't really care much about service and only want good Korean food then this is your place to go. Definitely make sure you get your change back though!
author: Shanna C.

description: I NEVER Yelp but I had to for this restaurant. I went a couple nights ago with a group of 5 and we waited for about an hour and 15 minutes when a BBQ table finally became available for us. There was a group of 7 next on the waiting list (after us) and they gave them the table instead of us. We ended up just leaving but came back the next day when it wasn't so busy. We were seated right away but completely ignored for about 15-20 minutes. Every one who came in after us had their order taken first. It wasn't until another KOREAN MAN stopped a waitress to tell her we had been waiting, that she finally took our order. Not only that, but when she did come, she was very rude and aggressively set the table. They have absolutely NO personality, they don't really speak to you and they barely even make eye contact. Idk if it was because we were the only Hispanic/black group or they just lack customer service. Anyway, the food was okay. Nothing special.
author: Keilah N.

description: Surprised by this place as I live right down the street from here and always see bus loads of people here - ranks right up there with Brother's BBQ and is a nice place to experience quality Korean BBQ - food was super good, had it cooked in back versus doing it ourselves (you don't smell like BBQ after - that is bonus!!) - good variety of small plates to accompany the main dishes - went  with short rib, pork, and pot stickers - the pot stickers were outstanding as well as the short ribs, the pork was so-so...will go back!
author: Richard D.

description: The food is fresh and great, and the portions are substantial. We wanted to cook the  meet ourselves, but would have been better if they checked on us at least once to see if we needed refills on sides .
author: Monica R B.

description: First review ever and typically very easy going person. Awesome food here but terrible seating experience. Put my name on the list and others after me kept getting seated. Turned out the guy missed my name on the list. Be sure to double check with the front person because they're so busy.
author: Ken C.

description:
After days of eating bland meals, our tour bus boasted of good Korean food for dinner--FINALLY!

The banchan (side dishes) were all very flavorful and fresh tasting.  There was a large variety of side dishes and the ingredients looked cleaner and fresher than a lot of Korean restaurants I've been to. I especially liked the mook and yellow radish.  
The nakji bokeum (octopus in spicy sauce) and tofu stew were good.  The boolgogi (beef) was a bit on the dry side but still OK since I was craving Korean food like no other.
Having warm rice with these good side dishes were perfect on a chilly SF night!  If I lived in SF, I can see myself going here a lot.
author: Catherine K.

description:
Have seen this place pack it in over and over again by the busload for years since my bro-in-law only lives about a block away... 

We were up in the city recently for the 4 day weekend and met up with them for lunch and I was mildly surprised when they suggested this place. I mean it is convenient; we walked there from their house so parking was mitigated. We were lucky to get seating for 8 right before the next busload of tourists came in. Technically, since we've been out of the city for so long, that makes us tourist too I guess. Alot of the places that we used to remember in the Richmond are gone. This place has been here for awhile but I never came here until now. 

My bro-in-law ordered a bunch of stuff and we ate community style so I don't know exactly what everything was; it's not like I was very familiar with Korean cuisine to begin with, I usually defer to someone else to order anyway. I do like Kalbi ribs though and I've had some pretty good stuff in the past. So I was pretty disappointed with the paltry serving that came out... not only was there not enough to go around (we ordered two of everything..) the meat was chewy and so tough that you would have to spit it out to keep from choking, you couldn't chew through it. Everything else was kind of ordinary and uninspiring... I don't even remember anything really noteworthy. 

The service was quick, but emotionless, even rude.... they practically threw all the dishes down at us... Such a dine and dash mentality... What a bunch of clowns!.... 

Been there once to satisfy my curiosity, but now I probably wouldn't repeat unless I had a wingman to help me know what to order...
author: Lawrence L.

description:
This place is really cute! I wanted to grill my own meats but opted otherwise since I was on a date and didn't want to smell like food 

We ordered two plates, a BBQ beef one and bibimbap. I've tried bibimbap at other krn places and this one was well seasoned, the pot was super hot so my raw egg cooked and the bottom rice was crispy. The bbq beef was marinated well and came with a larger variety of refillable sides than I'm used to seeing! 

On top of the excellent service, they also hooked us up with a big free tofu soup. I WAS STUFFED by the end of the meal and I had enough leftovers for us to get stuffed again the next day! 

The prices are great for a krn restaurant. I left a fat tip and I'll be back for more!
author: Linda N.

description: So good! Get the beef short ribs with potatoes and carrots- you won't be disappointed! Enough for 2 to share!
author: Jennifer M.

description:
Delish!  Great value and great food!  Will go again.
Been there for lunch only, but looking forward to going for dinner. 
They are also concerned for the parking in the neighborhood.  They want to make sure their customers are not parked on the "street cleaning" blocks. Very considerate and service conscientious. 

Thanks for a great meal!!!
author: Reb K.

description: The best food and service I've had in SF! The portions are generous and the service is fantastic. Can't wait to come back here!
author: Christy M.

description: 9 different (and good!) panchans. Great food for the price. Service is a little on the slow side though.
author: Formo S.

description:
I didn't find this place to be all that good.  Maybe we ordered the wrong items. We ordered tofu soup, bibimbop, a spicy noodle in a broth (can't remember the name but I took a pic of it) and seafood pancake.  We received a mung bean pancake and steamed egg on the house. 

The tofu soup was bland.  I would not recommend it as it was one of the worst tofu soup I've ever had.  The seafood pancake was disappointing  They didn't bother cutting the green onions into smaller pieces.  It was hard to eat without trying to shove a whole piece of onion into your mouth with each bite. 

On to the good - I liked the bibimbop and the steamed egg; there was a good selection of banchan. 

Service was okay, but didn't think they were the friendliest people.
author: Lorraine G.

description:
Best Korean BBQ in SF and reasonably priced too- set dinner for 6 (which can easily feed 8) was $126 and came with tons of food. 

- Kalbi and Bulgogi- very flavorful and tender
- Green Onion Pancakes and Egg battered Shrimp and Zuchini- Delicious
- Soon Tofu- not the best i've had but pretty good nonetheless
- Fried Fish- we should have declined them; none of us actually ate it. What a waste!
- Jap Chae- yummy
- Mung Bean Cake- another dish that wasn't quite as popular with our group
- Steamed Egg in hot pot- light and fluffy

We also ordered a side of Seafood pancakes- it was a HUGE dish. We had quite a lot of leftovers. 

Good service; they came to change out our grill 3x.
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
Still just as good as my previous review. 5 star food! tho only 4 stars service on jam-packed nights but understandable. 

I will suggest that you don't cook it yourself because youll likely burn it; u can't really control the grill unless u are sitting on the exterior seat. So, I recommend that you just have them cook it. It's faster, and less carcinogenic (burnt foods). Bulgogi, pork, and chicken will often come out unscathed by the heat, however the short ribs and kalbi ribs will likely be at least somewhat burnt....do bite it off and spit it on a napkin for your health's sake. also, the short ribs are different from kalbi ribs in that kalbi ribs are marinated, whereas the short ribs are not.

Each plate averages around 20 bucks, more or less depending on the meat.

chicken ~17$
pork~20$
bulgogi~21$
short ribs~22$
Kalbi~23$

something like that.

-wifive
author: simon k.

description:
If wandering around the Inner Richmond district for somewhere to eat, you won't likely find Han Il Kwan because it's on Balboa St, not Clement or Geary. With that said, Han Il Kwan is truly a hidden gem in the residential part of Richmond district.

I came here yesterday with my dad and grandma, and we ordered the lunch specials beef bulgogi, bibimbap, and japchae. Overall food quality and quantity were amazing! Loved the banchan too, especially the radish, tofu, and kimchi! They give ~8 dishes, and they're not stingy with the portions either. Bulgogi was very tender, juicy, and flavorful. It first appears dry and boring, but most of the juices are all underneath the meat, at the bottom of the plate. I always love the presentation of bibimbap, and it came in a huge, sizzling stone pot with lots of fresh vegetables and a container of gochujang (Korean red pepper paste). Japchae was oily but had a heaping load of beef and vegetables (shredded carrot, onion, scallion, shiitake mushroom, and that common mushroom). Complimentary tofu soup had a little spiciness and lots of chunks of tofu, a few chunks of meat, and some scallions. And to top this feast off, your not-so-typical dessert, sikhye, a sweet rice water drink. I just wish they served more and in a larger cup!

The overall service was very friendly, but slow in the beginning. Clean little restaurant with cute outer and interior decor. Will definitely be back, especially for the weekday lunch specials! (Served Monday through Friday, until 4PM, except on major holidays, ie: New Years, Christmas, Thanksgiving.) Ten to choose from and each under/around $10. You have your main dish, lots of banchan, complimentary tofu soup (or steamed egg), AND complimentary dessert -- SO MUCH FOOD!! It's a such a great deal that I'll be back more often!
author: Priscilla W.

description: The boss in this restaurant is a racist, I recommend non-Korean Asian don't go there. Extremely bad attitude
author: 泽瀚

description:
From what I can remember:
Went with a friend to 'celebrate' our completion of summer school/college.
Really good Korean food from a restaurant tucked in a residential area. 
We were one of the only people dining in on a very seemingly quiet late afternoon.
Ordered: 
-Kimchi Casserole with seafood, vegetable, and noodles (couldn't finish)
-Kimchi Pancakes (Yum!)
-Stone pot Bi Bim Bap (Yummy too!)

Though it may seem we ordered very little food, the dishes above plus so many small side dishes and steamed eggs filled our stomachs enough to have leftovers (and some difficulties in walking). In other words, soooo much food!

As we were eating, the staff were busy setting up empty tables with utensils and banchans. We noticed about 1 to 2 charter buses filled with people came in to dine. Perhaps this restaurant caters to travelers from different cities?
author: Kim L.

description:
Definitely a gem in the Richmond district. Why are you hidden on Balboa street??? Who drives on Balboa? Everyone drives on Geary. Well, last week, me and my homegirl Christine were craving cheap Japanese, so we decided to go to Kitaro! I don't know why, but she decided to drive down Balboa to get there. And then right there at the corner on 19th ave was a restaurant. Hey what's that? What's it doing in this residential area? Let's go TRYYY !!

So we did. And I'm so glad we did! The food was derrrricccioussss! We went for lunch so the prices were very kind. Most of the things on their lunch menu were under $10. That includes the kalbi! But I got Bi Bim Bop in a stone pot. The tofu stew is good too. Order it! The side dishes were good. I love the fish cakes and when we ate all of it, we wanted to get more. The waiter said that they don't do refills, only dinnertime. Sad face. He went to refill our tea, and when he came back, he had a full small plate of fish cakes, smiled, and left us to enjoy the rest of our meal. So yes, 5 stars they deserve. I can't wait to go back!
author: Amy X.

description:
I've came here a few times and I realized there are better places out there if you want Korean bbq. 

I have ordered jap chae, bimbibap, and bbq beef on different occasions. Jap chae was alright, bimbibap is kinda pricy if you order the hot one and the rice gets burnt. As for the bbq beef, it's good at first but I realized I can get much more else where. I just felt the price wasn't worth it for some items such as $19-22 for the bbq meats. I can pay that same amount somewhere else and eat all I want! 

What I like about this is place is that they are generous with their side dishes, meaning if you ask them, they will refill for you. Also they give additional items such as the bean pancake, egg soup, or sweet rice drink. 

There is one man who always seems happy to assist us and he would smile a lot. That's a plus when it comes to service since you won't get many smiles or positive energy at a lot of Asian restaurants. 

Overall I probably won't return since I know places that are worth the money for portion and selections. Not to say this place is no good, it's just alright to my standards at this point. If you don't mind the prices then everything is good.
author: Victor Q.

description: Awesome Korean BBQ in the city. Lots of delicious ban chan, and the meats we bbqed were all yummy! Great attentive servers, and reasonably priced. In a quiet neighborhood, but no parking lot.
author: Lynners C.

description: Love this place. It is by far my favorite Korean BBQ place to come. It is a little pricy and can be hard to get into. It is a huge tourist spot so don't be shocked if you have to wait or can't get a table because their is a high probability that their will be a tour bus pulling up to fill The restaurant. Defiantly make a reservation and don't bother showing up early because they won't seat you any sooner or faster. Also be careful because parking is pretty tough me personally it is defiantly worth the bus ride over there. The BBQ chicken and BBQ pork are delicious!
author: Sarah G.

description: Great food and the ladies that work here are so nice! They told me that I was "special" and gave a me a free side dish. So adorable....
author: Abel S.

description:
This was the first time I was disappointed by a place that got 4 stars in yelp. Arrived at 4pm on a Saturday and the place had a lot of empty tables but half of them hadn't been cleared yet.  They seemed to have plenty of staff so I wasn't sure why we couldn't be seated right away nor why the service was so poor once we were seated. The food wasn't anything special from any other Korean place we've tried and it even seemed more expensive than others.  In fact I should've listened to the reviews that the oxtail soup was bland, but because I love oxtail I had to try it.

And yes there are tour buses that arrive between 5 and 7 and they seem to get all the attention/service.
author: WinnJess E.

description:
Living only 7 blocks away, I've been coming here for years. It still stands as one of my family's favorite Korean restaurants. It just makes it better that it's so close to home. 

I won't give any recommendations on what to order. I usually get bul go ki, chicken, and spicy pork (don't know how to say it in Korean). The food is good here. You can cook the meat at the table or they can cook it for you in the kitchen. Certain tables don't have grills however.
