Lunch time is cheaper than dinner time but it feels like they give you the same amount of sides regardless. It's always more than enough. 

If you have a large party, they have a private room that can be sectioned off depending on how large of a party you have. So yes, it's good for groups! 

Also, beware of the tour buses. This place services a lot of tours so sometimes you may have to wait a little longer. Otherwise, no complaints here.
author: Connie Y.

description: Made a reservation for a barbecue table @ 7pm for a party of two and got there 5 minutes til but they didn't have an open table ready for us... So we had to wait a total of 20 minutes and we were starving so it felt like a long time until they finally seated us. If you get a barbecue table to cook your own meat, you have to order a minimum of two plates of meat- so we got the galbi + bulgogi. Having read that this place was among the top kbbq places in the Bay Area (thrillest) I came here with big expectations. For $76.00 we got the two plates of meat, the 9 complementary side dishes, the kimchi stew, and an egg soufflé on the house. The meat was quality and delicious, the side dishes were average, the kimchi stew was bomb, and egg soufflé mediocre. I had kbbq at another top ten Bay Area kbbq joint called ohgane in San Jose last month and for a cheaper price we got more variety of meat there, more side dishes (higher in quality & quantity), egg soufflé on the house, and along with a stew on the side too!! The kimchi stew was about $15 here... Good but i consider it kinda pricey. Anyways- it was definitely tasty and super filling... But I'm not dying to come back here again anytime soon.
author: Caitlin L.

description: My mom has never had kbbq and with the reviews here I thought I should try it out even though it's pricer than another place I typically go to. My family and I go for lunch, it's five of us and we get seated right away (it's not busy). We get menus and tea right away but have to sit there for about 10 minutes before we finally got to order. We had to ask multiple times for water, tea and rice. I even had to go to the counter to ask for water. They had water jugs just on their shelves, but my party of 5 doesn't get one? But the party of four in front of us do. I know in LA they usually change out the grill but we just kept cooking because they hardly checked on us and it was very difficult to get their attention. They get an extra star because the food is delicious. We got bugogi beef, pork belly and seafood. My mother enjoyed the food. I just felt like the staff was very scatter-minded and disorganized which led to our poor experience.
author: Lisa Y.

description: I love their kalbi and chicken. Their side dishes are decent. I adore the jello treat. Good luck with having a table since there are constantly tour buses there! You would need to be a bit patient besides having a time limit eating at this place as well.
author: Gina Y.

description:
Owners weren't too happy with a big group of Chinese people for dinner, but the food here is worth it! They have hella good side dishes and their kimchi pancake is the best I've had (although it doesn't look appetizing). Sorry I can't remember other things we've ordered, but I would recommend this place. 

But seriously, service was rude and inattentive.
author: Adorable T.

description:
Probably the best Korean BBQ in SF.

The meats were nicely marinated, pretty spicy and not overly sweet like most places. No charcoal though, so Wooden Charcoal House has the upper hand in that regard.

Banchan was plentiful, with refills and they gave us free soondubu (needed more of a kick though). 

Even better was the price, quite a steal for the amount of food you get.
author: Derrick V.

description:
Whenever I get a chance to get a weekday off, I love to come here for lunch with my bf! 

their lunch specials are reasonably priced and love their banchan still. love love their short ribs  and fish cakeeeeee and bf likes their spicy pork. their sizzling seafood....veggie dish has great flavor and we shall order that more often too. love the free soup, just a good complimentary side dish, not the best soup but its free.

we recently did a to-go order so that we could eat at the park. they pack you loads of food! and super cute to go boxes. and banchan boxes for both of us! we were so full and barely even finished half our food! so we ate the rest for dinner yum.

we actually got to try the seafood hot stone pot by accident since the guy on the phone couldn't understand what i was describing (the seafood veggie dish). but it was yummy so we weren't mad.

even though I love going here to eat, I wouldn't mind to-going my food!
author: Christine M.

description: Rudely turned away. Place had patrons, no where near full, basically on a Saturday at 5:30. Never trying again.
author: Skinkton Z.

description:
I was so glad to find this place! I haven't done korean bbq in SF in about 4 years - mostly b/c I wasn't here- but going for good food and bad service has become harder to put up with (ie, the brothers). 

This place is awesome - great food, good service and they take reservations. Their variety of banchan was fantastic. They bring out a tasty spicy tofu soup that is complimentary mid way through the meal. And every time your grill starts to smoke, they're there to change it out in under a minute! 

As far as reservations are concerned, its like putting you at the front of the line. We got there at about 8 for an 8pm reservation and got seated about 8:20. Not bad for a Saturday night given how busy they were. 

I will definitely be back. NOTE_ parking sucks! so give yourself some time to look
author: Komal B.

description:
Had ordered the soft tofu soup, which was good, but nothing different from other places that I have had before. My friend commented that their meat in her bibim bop was really good, but I didn't try it so I can't rave about it like she did. 

The side dishes were pretty decent/good. Again, nothing to write home about. No issues with the service. It did get busy on a Wednesday evening, and there are a good amount of tables in the restaurant. They didn't rush us out. Friendly.

Felt the prices were a bit more than I'd expect, but I think the atmosphere may be what is driving up the cost. It isn't a hole-in-the-wall place. Saw families here for dinner. 

We didn't have parking difficulties, but we did also go around 530p (elderly people dinner time. sans early bird special. that's how we do.)
author: Vicki T.

description:
I've decided that unless you are a true Korean, you can't cook KBBQ without burning it. And that has always been my struggle with KBBQ. Anyways, back to the topic. Came here for a friends bday and definitely enjoyed the food and everything. Service was super good, and the owner let us open a bottle of wine without charging us a corkage fee. Sweet! The kbbq was not bad, and the sides were pretty good. The only thing that was eh was maybe the tofu soup, definitely more on the eh side. We also had a dish that had squid and onions and spicy sauce which was delicious like no other.

Definitely coming back here next chance I get.
author: Jessica H.

description: Would have liked to eat here but we couldn't get seated because of a continuous stream of tour buses.  There were a number of customers who had put their name on a waiting list but during the 40 minute plus minutes we were waiting, few of us were seated.  This restaurant should either close while serving tour buses or given equal attention to non tour customers.
author: Diana O.

description:
The side dishes here are EXCELLENT.  I loved every single item. 

We ordered 1 bi bim bap, 1 chap chae, 1 seafood tofu soup and 1 short rib casserole.

Everything tasted great except for the tofu soup which was super bland and boring.

Will come back again ...
author: sonya h.

description:
Went here last night. Parking wasn't fun, but got lucky.  We get in and see two groups ahead of us, yet the restaurant had all these empty tables that needed to be cleared.  That gave me a bad first impression (why not clean the tables and let the people sit).  No one came up to us to ask how many in our party or anything.  So I started getting skeptical.  Within 5 minutes of getting to the restaurant, a string of korean people come in... non-stop.  A korean tour bus had just come.  So then it made sense, all the workers were busy setting up the table for this large group.  Once the group got seated in the back room, I see all these workers cleaning tables and that's when someone came to greet us.  Yes, not the most friendly of greetings, but cordial and fine.  

The food was good (but my mom's is better).  I think the kimchi at 90% of korean restaurants suck, this one was good/pretty good.  We ordered (the prices are what I think it was, don't quote me):

galbi chim (beef rib stew, sort of) ~$24: large potatoes, large carrots, good sauce, tender. very yum.  You can't really go wrong with galbi chim, but this one was like home cooking, not typical restaurant style

Daenjangjigae (bean paste stew) ~$11: it was good.  tofu, jalapenos, not too strong smelling (I wanted my non-korean friend to try it)

Dukbokki (spicy rice cake) $~12 : this was really good.  It's not as spicy as most places (which is good and bad).  But still had enough heat at the end.  b/c it wasn't as spicy, you could taste more flavors. I brought some home to my mom, and she said it was pretty good dukbokki.

Kimchi jun (kimchi pancake) ~$14: I really liked this. It is pretty thick, but fully cooked.  Sometimes when juns are thick, they are not fully cooked all the way through and I hate that.  This was good stuff.  

I thought the service was fine, but we weren't demanding diners (and we didn't do BBQ.  I was catching up with an old friend and didn't want to waste time cooking my own food).  I think some of the waiters don't speak english well, so that may be why people say the servers aren't so friendly.  I asked a random server what kind of soju they had.  He looked around the room (i think looking for the other english speaking waiter), and said in a terse manner "only have one."  So I realized he doesn't speak english well, so I respond back in korea "could we have one bottle please."  Then he loosened up and said apologized that they didn't have options (all in korean).    Yes, service was a little slow, but we didn't really take notice b/c we were catching up (and the banchan/side dishes came out fast so we had something to munch on.
author: Minah L.

description:
My friends and I have been here several times before, but two weeks ago  was the worst. I'm not a big yelp reviewer, and I tried to let it go, but I just can't. 

Two weeks ago, my friends and I were here around 6, and the restaurant was half-empty.  A man in a blue sweater at the door asked us which table we want, but we weren't sure if we want BBQ it ourselves or just order  at the time, my friends and I were talking in Chinese trying to decide, and he rudely asked us to step back by the bar. 

After the waiter took the order, it's impossible to get the waiter's attention for some service. We were waving our hands, yelling excuse me to try to get the attention of a waitress/ waiter. But it seems the table of white dudes next to us is doing just fine getting service.  Finally, the man in the blue sweater came by and said "You can't wave your hands like this, it is rude and what do you want?" We told him we were sorry, and we just want some water and he left. He went back to the bar and talked to his fellow colleagues about our "rude waving," I know that because the entire time he and his colleagues were staring at us.  

The restaurant is not even full, and we're not asking something crazy, we just want some service. But your waiters are too lazy to service us, so we waved our hands. Even if our waving offend you in some way you can tell us politely and not talk bad with your colleagues about your customers in front of the customers you're talking about.  I would give a zero star for the service, but food is not that bad.
author: Shirley Z.

description:
I arrived a little after 7pm. When I saw a three tour buses, I was scared, scared that I would have to wait for a long time. Fortunately, two of those buses left, whew. 

This was our first time, so we weren't sure of what to expect. We got the stone pot bi bim bap, which was really hot, so don't go touching it out of curiosity. It was good with the right amount of sauce. Since we didn't finish it and there was about 3/4 of it left, they gave us the biggest take out box I have ever seen. 

We shared the seafood pancake, it was alright, but I would have liked it to be more crispier. The seafood pancake had some octopus bits and some shrimps in them. 

I like that their tofu soup was not too spicy, so I am able to enjoy it. =)
author: Mandy D.

description:
My Direct Boss wanted to take me to this Korean Joint that he loves.

I may like this place more than Arang now.

**Click pictures below**

You get all this food for $20!!

I agree w/ Jonas T. "Great food, but service could use some work."

Jonas T.
http://www.yelp.com/user_details?userid=NK-zIxHMuTnLRU0RhoZWqw

All this food
http://static1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/k_SlvK-XRAmxzz-E5BiitA/l

Korean BBQ Chicken & Short Rib
http://static1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/OfLqn92nxAbwEO6GjSbtMg/l

(Thursday, May 6, 2010)
author: Kenny C.

description: One of my favorite korean restaurants in San Francisco because the Bon Chon is the largest pieces I get in anywhere in San Francisco. We ordered the gal-by, hot tofu soup, combination appetizer, and the jap-chae. Everything came out quick, and the food was delicious. The gal-by was my favorite because it was tender and juicy. I'll definitely come back again.
author: Jason L.

description:
This is my favorite place for korean BBQ.  
The meat here is good, especially their chicken which I just love.  While I'm not a fan of kimchi, I really like their kimchi pancakes.
They give muultiple complimentary side dishes plus tofu soup plus mini pancakes.
author: Karen L.

description: A LOT of food they served including complimentary 10 side dishes, boiling eggs on the house and free rice wine at the end of the meal!
author: Jeannie Y.

description: Disgusting! Gross! Never eating here again. Ever! We got take out. When my husband was eating the pancake, he found a rubber band inside of it. The rubber band was fried right inside the pancake and he almost ingested!  How disgusting is that? To have a rubber band show up in your food is intolerable. Someone should call the health department and report this place!  When I called them to let them know about it, the woman on the phone just said, "oh I'm sorry."  No offer of a refund. When I asked for a refund , she told me to come right away and bring all the food back with me!  Well, most of the food was already eaten. The rubber band wasn't discovered until the meal was almost over. So no, why should I be inconvenienced to drive all the way back to this restaurant at 7:15PM in order to get a refund? I offered to email/text a pic of the rubber band pancake, but the woman on the phone said she doesn't want a picture of it. So I'm posting the picture on Yelp.  Do not eat here. I never will again. Unless of course you want rubber band poisoning. YUCK! Please save yourself!
author: Mary P.

description:
This joint was one of the better Korean BBQ restaurants I've had in the City.  I came here on a Saturday night with 6 others and enjoyed their BBQ.  We were worried about the wait especially with the big tour bus they had parked outside.  In the end, we waited about 30 mins which wasn't terrible.  Talk about being super busy!

We ordered: Kalbi, Spicy Bulgogi, Pork Belly, Bi Bim Bab, and sauteed squid.  Everyone at the table loved the Kalbi and Spicy Bulgogi (talk about tasty!).  The restaurant provides either tofu soup or steamed egg with your meal (I'd suggest the tofo soup although they sometimes throw in the steamed egg anyway).

The service wasn't great.  It's not that they were rude, but they didn't have enough staff on hand. We couldn't get menus until 10 mins in (they don't have enough to cover the whole restaurant), but once we ordered things our orders came out at a good pace.  Overall, the staff was nice.

Bottom line, come here for the food.
author: Sunny W.

description: Probably the best korean food I have ever had in SF. Everything was delicious. I ate till I felt regretful and then ate some more. yum yum yum. This place is very often frequented by korean tour bus groups. Try to go before the bus arrives otherwise you'll get stuck watching the entire 50+ bus group eat their awesome dinner before you get seated. Unfortunately, this happened to the group I was with. Fortunately, we weren't in a hurry so we ordered some bottles of Mak Gul Li to share and enjoyed those before sitting down to our epic feast.
author: Alice H.

description: Great customer service! Good variety of ban chan and they were constantly refilled. Workers were very attentive and service was fast. Well-marinated and high quality meats. Galbi chim (braised short ribs) was not up to par though..too salty. Prices are reasonable. The wait can be long so make reservations.
author: Angela F.

description:
Ate here for dinner a while back with three other people.  It was regular Korean food and we had some nice memories so I came back on a recent Sunday for lunch with just one friend.  

Warning:
- They have two kinds of tables.  The ones you can cook at and the ones you just sit at.  If you pick the one you cook at there's a minimum you have to buy/cook.  You need to know this fact before going in or you might be treated like a tard for not knowing...like I was.
- As far as I could tell from the menu...the meat dishes are what you'll cook and they are at least $20 each.  So lunch at the cooking tables will cost you at least $40.

I suggest only sitting at the cooking tables if you're a group of 3-4 so you can do two meats and some other thing.  I might be wrong about the minimum but the wait staff wasn't very helpful.  We ended up leaving after the tea arrived because I'm ghetto like that.
author: STEVE L.

description: Decent korean food with plenty of options.  Hits the spot if you're craving variety of korean food.  Our order: mul-nengmyun, dohl-soyt-bibimbap, soon-doo-boo chigae, oxtail soup and galbi.  Everything was decent but the oxtail soup.  The oxtail meat was not cooked for long enough so I couldn't eat it - which is the whole point of ordering oxtail soup!  The banchan is decent.  It's pretty good for San Francisco but no comparison to K-Town in LA.
author: Ivy L.

description:
This restaurant is somewhat hidden away on a small residential street and so you won't easily discover it. This and the fact that there are many tables might explain why I never had to wait for a table. 
The menu is the same for both lunch and dinner aside from several lunch specials available on weekdays. 
This review is for the prepped food and not the Korean self BBQ. They start you off with a good variety of banchan and a pot of steamed egg regardless of what you order. We ordered a variety of items but the only dishes I particularly liked were the bulgogi and the marinated chicken. The casserole stews and japchae were no more than average.
To sum it up, this is a homey neighborhood korean restaurant that serves decent food but does nothing to make me want to go back.
author: Alfred L.

description: Great for groups if you make a reservation.  I haven't had REALLY good Korean food in SF until I went here.  If you're with 6+ people definitely opt for the fixed meals, it'll be more than enough and it'll take the stress out of trying to order from their very diverse menu.  Unless there's something in particular that you really want, which you can always add on.  I wanted to substitute the spicy pork for pork belly but they don't allow it.  We had so many left overs we're still eating them 2 days later.  It's a great place and the staff was pretty good once they got the food serving.  4.1 stars :)
author: Kyle I.

description: This is my favorite Korean restaurant in the city. The banchan are always really tasty and you get a lot of variety. Everything is really good. I've had the bbq, spicy tofu soup, bi bim bap, and bulgogi.
author: Jessie L.

description: Love this place. The soups and hot pot dishes are excellent. My wife loves the oxtail soup, with it's milky consistency. Once in a while we will have the Korean barbecue, which you grill right on the table. The banchan selection is great. The service can be on the slow side but is tolerable. As for the tourists in the buses, they get seated in the back and they have a fixed menu. I am always there early to beat the lunch crowd, and never had bad service.
author: Frank B.

description: The wait was about ~40 minutes (on a Friday night), but it was well worth it. The side dishes were amazing, as were the drinks and the food (in particular the stone-pot Bibimbap). Would highly recommend, but probably when it's less crowded.
author: Daniel K.

description: Consistently awesome. I have yet to find a better Korean place in SF. (My Korean buddies have shown me better in LA, but that is not overly useful)
author: Donald C.

description: Tried Han IL Kwan's lunch special. Ordered the lunch Galbi. Of course, the lunch portion is smaller than dinner. Really good value for lunch. You get the banchans (including a little Korean pancake) with the Galbi (cooked in kitchen). Also got a complimentary Tofu Soup. Quite a lot for $13.95.
author: Ronald C.

description: This is the worse dinning experience ever!  A bunch of old grandmas provide service or should I say NO SERVICE.  They are grumpy and have no smiles on their face.  We were constantly flag them down to ask/beg for stuff .  They rushed us out after 30 minutes of dinning. The food was ok and not that fantastic.  TRUST ME AVOID THIS PLACE!!!!!
author: Scott N.

description: Favorite Korean restaurant!!! Ever since we discovered this place 3 years ago, it's been my family's go-to Korean restaurant. I love their wide variety of banchans (side dishes) and bulgogi. I also love the kimchi jjigae and the rice drink that they give as as services. They also have good customer service and atmosphere. However, sometimes they might be crowded or reserved for tourist groups so make sure to call beforehand. Also Keep in mind that this place might be on the pricey side for Korean BBQ. In conclusion, I LOVE IT!
author: Maggie W.

description: Tour bus takes precedent even if you come before them so try avoiding them or call in ahead
author: Sam Sooin L.

description:
Best Korean BBQ I've been to so far, and I've been to a few (Brothers, Wooden Charcoal, Korea House, To Hyang, etc). The overall quality of the food was really good. Not quite LA K-town good, but pretty darn close. I don't want to hype this place up, but it's by far the best Korean BBQ you're going to find in the city. The inside was very clean and had a nice Korean ambience to it. Definitely good for groups. 

I don't know what the other yelpers are complaining about in terms of service. Our server was awesome. Parking was no problem either although we went for lunch.  Balboa does get packed at night so I imagine parking could be a pain. 

All in all you if you are craving Korean BBQ this is place to go hands down.
author: Richard K.

description:
Got takeout bibimbap. It was really busy but my order went through pretty quickly. They give you sides, rice, and soup with your order. Big portions that are proportional to how much you pay ($15 for stone pot bibimbap). The dishes were good but they were sparse on the meat. 

It seems like a good place to share dishes with a group because of their portions.
author: Deanna L.

description:
I have to give them the extra star just because this place holds a special place in my heart and I met a special someone here for the first time. :)

Now onto the food. I've only come here twice and both times was for lunch. Why? Because their lunch menu is VERY affordable, great portions, and just as delicious.
Their lunch menu comes with rice, entree, and the banchan. 

Banchan is my faaave part of any korean meal! Standard banchan choices of jelly with seasoned soy sauce, kimchi, bean sprouts, pickled cucumbers, fishcake, and a few others I forgot. They also give complimentary tofu soup and these little pancakes made of beans. Yummy! 

Now for my meal I always tend to get their BBQ chicken. Since it is the lunch menu, it does come cooked to the table, which I have no problem with especially since I'm not particularly fond of smelling like BBQ. 
I've also enjoyed the bulgogi (bf tends to order this) which is delicious here as well.
They also give this delicious dessert drink of sweet malted rice(?). Cold and refreshing after a hot meal. Mmmm.

Service is by far one of the friendlier Korean establishments I've been too, and we all know Korean waitresses can just be as bad as Chinese waitresses. They don't make a stink when you ask for refills on the banchan, which is definitely a plus. And they always keep my glass of water filled and my teapot.

Location and parking is alright...If you come on a weekday during the lunch time it's easier to find parking.

Overall, definitely be back when I want some great Korean BBQ for lunch!
author: Jenna H.

description: This is very good and authentic Korean food.  The customer service is awesome too.  My husband knows Korean food and he absolutely approved of Han II Kwan!  I highly recommend you try them if you are looking for authentic Korean food.  They give very good size portions and lots of sides!  Everything was delicious.
author: Tia C.

description:
Overall, I like this place and would definitely go back. 

Service - as long as you don't come during tour bus hours (5-7), the service is actually decent and attentive. Also, try to make a reservation beforehand. It helps and will minimize your wait time (but yes, you still have to wait a bit). 

Food - We had a table of 18 and the dishes were very tasty and came out fairly quickly.

Ambiance - I like that this place isn't super smokey with the smell of cooking meat at each table. Still has it, but not that bad. 

We had ALOT of food:
Panchan - good, but they no longer had those small fish or the seaweed dish. Boo.
Japchae - great dish
bulgogi - good solid dish
short ribs - good, but can be fatty
chicken - a bit dry
Pork belly - solid dish. Comes with a salt/pepper/oil dip that was good. 
tofu soup - spicy, salty and good amount of tofu and meat
seafood pancake - was meh. A bit too many green onions and a bit doughy.  

Be prepared to drinks LOTS of water after this meal.
author: Linda L.

description:
My wife and I went to this restaurant and saw people waiting to get in.  We thought this was a good harbinger since this neighborhood restaurant must be good to attract so many customers.  It turns out those are Korean tour members who were brought there by a tour bus.  This turns out to be a cautionary sign since the tour restaurants we had been brought to when we traveled had mostly been mediocre.

The waitress brought out several dishes of banchan.  The portions of the banchan were large, much larger than all other Korean restaurants we had been to.  We liked that.

We ordered marinated eye rib and rib soup.  The eye rib was extremely disappointing.  While the portion was large, it was flavorless.  The iconic Korean marination flavor was completely lacking.  There was no saltiness, sweetness, soy flavor, spices, nothing.  The beef was very plain.  It tasted like what a school kid in home economics class would cook.  We added soy sauce to the beef and it only added saltiness.  The beef remained tasteless.  We left half the beef on the plate.

The rib soup was like plain water.  The good Korean restaurants I liked had flavorful soup apparently made from hours of simmering the beef and bones.  This restaurant's soup was flavorless, like it was hastily slapped together after I ordered it.  The beef rib chunks in the soup was tender and nice flavored, and this is a redeeming touch.

We were very disappointed.  I left on the table the business card I picked up earlier at the cashier counter.  We will not be going back.
author: Robert W.

description:
Pho Kim Son!

Pho Kim Long!! 

Pho kim Gu!!!

These were some of the places i saw headed over here... 
I sorta knew that we had something good in store for us... The menu is a little misleading.... it didn't seem as cheap as it would be...but it actually is!
The food's great!  They put so much food on our table it's like they didn't want us to leave alive.....

my conclusion is... GO!!
author: John R.

description: Yummy BBQ! The banchan is spot on. It's all the goodness you'd expect from a korean joint. It's quite lively and busy though. I always end up going in during the weekend in the evening and it's usually a long wait. I'm also a fan of BBQ my own goods, so I think this makes the wait a bit longer, but well worth it.
author: Charlene F.

description: Some of the best Korean BBQ this side of Seoul. Absolutely delicious with great service. I especially liked the tteokeokki, which was a great accompaniment with the BBQ. Highly recommend.
author: Matt G.

description:
This was one of the best Korean places i have been too. Previously my favorite place was in Berlin, Germany which had only BBQs, here they have the entire range. We got there pretty early around 12.00 for lunch during a weekend and it was not crowded and we were seated and served almost immediately. We ordered plenty of food but the spicy pork bbq was the best. It was my girl friends first time at a Korean restaurant and she was dying to have some good korean food and she simply feel in love with it,  I have never seen her smile so much...
I will surely would go back if i am in the area.
author: Arun S.

description: Can be CRAZY busy.  Food is AMAZING.  So much food for not a whole lotta dough.  Can be difficult to get in and the service can be a little slow, but definitely worth it for Korean BBQ.
author: Max J.

description:
I came here for lunch and it was great! Well, the food was at least...

One of our teacups had lipstick on it so we asked for a new one. Our server just took a really long time and never brought it out so we asked the other server. She just put her hand up to stop us from talking and then walked away--that was a little odd and rude. When our server finally came by, we reminded her about the teacup and she eventually brought it out. We also asked for more kimchi and she didn't bring it out until we were already done eating. Unfortunately, she took so long and we were so hungry that we just kept eating with no kimchi :(

Despite the bad service, I'd probably still come back because the food was good. I'm hoping this bad service experience is just a one time thing. I'd give it another shot! :)
author: Hwan L.

description:
Fellow Yelper Shirley L. and I came here to get our Korean food fix. The first time we were here, we came during lunch (M-F until 4pm) and completely failed with eating our meal. We were able to pack up our japchae and spicy pork, which filled up the entire to-go box they gave us. It was really delicious. Lunch is extremely reasonable where all dishes are ~$10 with banchan and a little complimentary tofu soup.

Came here for lunch today at 2:30pm and mind you, Shirl and I love our food spicy! Our banchan came and the guy endlessly put little dishes on our table. We ordered the spicy tofu soup this time and boy, it was spicy alright! We were a little confused as the guy asked us "you want it extra spicy?" and I said "spicier than medium" as he responded with "extra spicy." We also ordered the daeji bulgogi (spicy pork). 

The tofu soup came on its own and we waited for our rice to come. We asked the nice server and she got us two bowls of rice immediately along with our ice water. The tofu soup was much spicier than My Tofu House's spice level and the red chili flakes were not so fine. Still tasty! The spicy pork is dryer than other places, which caused the spicy marinade to stick onto the pork. The flavor was good and smokey (Idk why, but I thought of jerky when I ate it). 

**Parking was easy since the white zone for tour buses in front is free to park in from 2-5pm everyday!

Han Il Kwan was definitely good for our Korean fix, as we try to alternate between this place and My Tofu House (closed on Saturdays til 5pm). This time, we dominated our food and showed it who's boss!
author: Ada T.

description:
Made reservations the day of for a party of 7 for 6:30pm but they didn't have anything available till 7.30pm. 

So the reason for the 7.30 reservation was because there was a bus tour of Koreans eating there. I wonder why you would eat Korean if you are Korean visiting America. Makes no sense.

Anyway, it was pretty hectic when we first went into the place because all of them tour people were leaving. I guess if you come after the tour you don't even need a reservation.

We actually had a party of 6. They gave us a table by the window. We then decided what to order. We got
boolgogi- thinly sliced spicy beef. I can't really handle spicy but this was good.
tofu soup- pretty good
2 bim bam bop- best I have had but I am not a huge Korean expert 
korean beef- it was extremely chewy! take your time eating this or you'll choke!
seafood pancake- not bad if u dip it in the soy sauce they provide. i think it would be disgusting if you eat it when its cold
bbq chicken- absolutely nothing special about this at all. just regular bbq chicken

they have a lot of side dishes to offer and tasty! They provide lettuce for you make your own wraps with the meat and the side dishes. YUM!

Complementary egg thing at the beginning yum. Complementary water egg. Goes well with the soy sauce. You get a bowl of rice for every item you order without rice in it. 

We didn't bbq our own meat but it was cool. I don't want my hair to smell.

One bathroom for women and one bathroom for men. One stall for the female while other ladies can wash their hands and check themselves out in the mirror while waiting. The stall is cramped and don't have hangers. 

Overall best Korean experience I have had. BUT I have only been to 3 other "authentic" Korean places.
author: Sarah C.

description:
Went here after my friend who lives nearby recommended it.

Upon sitting the waiter was extremely rude to us, grabbed our things and moved us to the next table without really asking us to.

When we asked for water he said "just wait".

All of us felt variably offended, enough so that we walked out.
author: Thanh T.

description: Definitely one of the better Korean restaurants I've tried in the Bay Area. We went for lunch and it was very busy (I've heard evenings are insane). It looks like they have tourist buses bring people so it can get packed quickly. Anyway,  had the bi him bop and it was well prepared. I like it when they get the rice nice and crunchy, and that was the was it was here. A good complimentary tofu soup and lots of tasty ban chan (sp?) kibbles came with the meal. Reasonably priced and clean, with nice but unfussy decor. Service slow but efficient and friendly. Lots of variety on the menu and at table BBQ available.
author: David H.

description: You can't go wrong with this authentic korean food. Food is amazing! Good price for generous portion.
author: Iris C.

description:
This place SUCKS! I went there at 12:40 in the afternoon and there were flies EVERYWHERE so disgusting. Not only that but my boyfriend and I waiting 10 minutes just to be seated when the place was obviously empty.

After we were seated and ordered (3 lunch specials) the tour bus came and flocks of people came into the restaurant. Not only did they get all their little appetizer dishes before us they also got their main entrees as well! How rude! 

When our food finally came out there was only one bowl of tofu soup! It says on the menu that it comes with tofu soup per order, I would have been okay if they brought out two tofu soups because we have two people but just one tiny bowl! Jeez cheap much?  

The food was so-so same as my tofu house on geary, but a little pricier.

I will NOT be coming back!
author: Jenny N.

description: One of my favorite Korean restaurants in the city. I really like their banchan, kalbijjim, kalbitang, and seafood pancake! YUM!!
author: Bo Y.

description:
You know a Korean restaurant is good when it's in the outer Richmond yet tour buses still drop off their passengers here.

I've been to Han Il Kwan several times now, and they never fail to disappoint.  We've even had the back room once, closed off to the rest of the world, where we could be as loud and stupid as we wanted to.

The last time I was there with my bff, we ordered enough food to feed a village.  Then they gave us free dish upon free dish, so we could have fed two villages and had some left over for lunch the next day.

Parking can be a pain, but oh so sweet once you nab a spot.

FYI, 12 oz of beer is $3, 20 oz is $6.  You do the math.
author: Jenny L.

description: Very, very solid performer for traditional Korean food.  They serve everything from korean BBQ (all types) to tofu stews.  A great place to do family style and share everything.  The taste of everything blew me away.  This place definitely rivals some of the Korean places in Los Angeles!  Naturally, they also bombard you with a wide variety of Korean side dishes.  I can definitely recommend the bbq beef spareribs.  What are you waiting for?  Come try it!
author: David C.

description: This review its basically for the service. The food average it's good. However, the waiter does not speak fluent English for that I can understand. BUT...do not take off my plate so quick;y while I am still eating and still have both beef bone soup and tofu soup in the pot. It's about 1/3 of the pot. We came today and no one was waiting in line since it's a weekday night. We would like to eat slowly with our friends from out of town. They simply walked by and put the meat back on the grill for us while we still have cooked meat pile up on our plate. What's so hurry for them? I have no idea. Finally, he asked may I clean up your table. We said yes. He even took away ALL the tea cups and tea pot while we are still drinking our tea. IT"S REALLY RUDE!!! I will not pay tips for this kind of service!
author: Jenny C.

description:
Came and ate here with my sisters the day before Thanksgiving. The place was bustling, and there were very few servers available, so the wait was quite a while.

They have late ending lunch special, and the portions are large, delicious, and worth the price and wait. We ordered spicy squid, spicy pork, spicy tofu soup, beef, and jap chae. Meal comes with rice and an assortment of cold Korean side dishes. To drink, we ordered their hot tea, iced water, and raspberry wine.

All in all, my experience was quite nice. Attentive service, despite the lack of staffing. Food was good, and filling. Nice place to come with family and dine casually.
author: Nancy F.

description:
It must be good if it's a stop on the Korean students Tour of the U.S. I was a little worried when we first arrived that it would be super long and our food would take forever but, they were in and out in 17 minutes flat (2 large tour buses worth of kids +)

We ordered one of their family style meals that they prepared for us and everything was tasty.  Great spice on the spicy items and plenty of food and super cheap per person.

Service isn't really the greatest, but once you flag them down, they get you what you need.

We'd go back.

Parking in the area is a pain.
author: Mabelle A.

description: The food here is absolutely delicious. However, the service is not the best. The waitress's are no attentive and kind of just throw the dishes down on the table in a rush. But all in all, a great restaurant minus the service.
author: Meghan C.

description:
So first of all, I give you a wanring that not all tables are set up for BBQ, we were hungry and I wanted to get food in my stomach, so if you really want to fry some meat make sure to request that table and prepare for a decent wait. 

The Banchan was the best variety of banchan I've ever gotten at a restaurant. Kimchi, cucumbers, a few things I've never tried before and the usual selection of fish cakes and etc. They even give you an steamed egg! It was damn good.

I thought I was paying a ridiculous amount of money for the plate and it proved to be GIGANTIC, holy shit that bowl was huge. Don't get appetizers, seriously, the Bim m Bop and Tofu Soup was so much that I couldn't even finish them. Don't even try to get appetizers unless you're splitting stuff. 

I would say, the prices for the BBQ meat though are ridiculous. I was kinda shocked by the cost since I've gotten more for a lot cheaper than that, but whatever they are actually really nice here, the service is good, you get unlimited refills, and they offer a wide variety of banchan and sides.
author: Rohan D.

description:
So this is the place where you will almost always see Korean tour buses parked in front over the weekends for dinner and at those times it can get SUPER busy. But that's also a good indicator that this place served authentic Korean food.

My friend and I dropped by around 6:30pm to find that the Korean tour buses just got there. The staff inside was really busy setting up to feed probably around 100 Korean tourists so even though the main dining room was pretty empty, they were rushing to prepare the back dining room for the large party. We had to wait around 15 minutes, which isn't too bad. Since it was just two of us, we decided not to go for BBQ and just order from the regular menu. 

We ordered the seafood bibimbap in the stone clay bowl and a beef short rib stew called kalbijim that has a little sweetness in the broth. Both dishes were really good and filled us up. When the kalbijim came out, the waitress helped us to separate the meat from the bones before she let us eat it. Good service :)

I'll definitely be back when I need my Korean food fixing.
author: Julia K.

description:
A great place for a group dinner pigout. I took my friend here for his surprise bday dinner and it turned out really well.

Great kbbq (kalbi, bulgogi, spicy pork, mixed seafood), side dishes, seafood pancake, tofu soup, spare rib soup, bibimbap, basically everything was super tasty.

Price were very reasonable and service was good. We stayed pretty late and they didn't once hint for us to leave as they started to clean up the other tables and begin closing down.
author: Kenny J.

description:
A year and a half later, I'm still convinced Han Il Kwan is the best Korean restaurant in the city. You get the best value here with very reasonable prices (most non-barbecue dishes average around $8.95-$10.95) and generous portions.

Granted, I haven't tried the barbecue here yet, but Han Il Kwan doesn't emphasize this aspect of their food fare as much. The Korean tour groups who come here usually order the non-barbecue dishes, and they always seem to leave very satisfied.

What can I add to this update? Well...

* Lots and lots of banchan served with complimentary tofu soup or steamed (savory) egg custard
* Rice comes with every entree, even if you order noodles
* Delicious entrees: Dok Bok Ki, Bibimpap, Cold noodles, Fried Kimchi/Mung Bean Cakes, etc.
* Great prices (most Korean restaurants average at $15.95 per entree; Han Il Kwan averages $8.95 - $10.95 for the same portions)
* Decent service

If you go on a summer weekend night, be prepared to either wait or be surrounded by the tour groups. They fill up the restaurant pretty fast, but they also leave relatively quickly since the cooks/servers make sure the groups are accommodated for quickly.

Very satisfying place for Korean food. Must try for all!
author: Helene K.

description:
Grubbed here a couple weeks ago. Very much enjoyed. 

Kalbi + Marinated Pork + Bi Bim Bop was way more than enough food for 3 hungry folks. Banchan were visually impressive, and well seasoned.

Keep in mind there's a minimum of two meat/seafood dishes for a group at one of the grilling tables. I prefer this policy to Brothers Restaurant which tacks on a $5 surcharge to anyone in your party who doesn't order a plate of protein.

Definitely would return here with a group.
author: Anthony R.

description: Ordered Galbijim but didn't come in time and we were all full from the small dishes and tofu soup. The only memorable part was the steam eggs. I will have to come back again to taste their meat and that elusive galbijim.
author: George L.

description:
Although I love The Brother's I wasn't in the mood for smelling like a BBQ Pit afterwards, so we decided to head to Han II Kwan for an early Saturday dinner since it normally gets packed.

FOOD:
*Tofu Soup: Well seasoned and spiced. Tofu was very soft and had the texture of silken tofu.
*Buchujeon: We were given free veggie pancakes and it was just ok. It was kinda too thick for my liking and doughy.
*Kalbi: We opted to have them cook it for us. It was ok. The kalbi was lacking the char marks, so the meat was a bit chewy. 
*Dae Ji Bool Gogi: The BEST I've ever had. I'm a huge fan of spicy pork and most places have it swimming in sauce which makes the dish heavily salted. Not here, the pork had just the right amount of sauce, so you can actually taste the meat. The pork was perfectly cooked. It was tender, well-seasoned, and had some burnt ends from the brown sugar in the marinade--YUM! 
*Jap Chae: It was ok. The noodles were cooked well (al-dente), beef, and veggies were seasoned well. What I didn't like about the dish is it had some broth in it and I prefer my noodles dry.

Can't have a Korean meal without Sikhye (rice beverage). Han's Sikhye was sweet and had a slight silky texture. A great ending to a spicy meal!

SERVICE: My rating would have been 3 stars for the food itself. But the service made up for it. The entire staff was very super friendly, prompt, and attentive. Our waiter was super cute which didn't hurt!

I'll definitely be back for the Dae Ji Bool Gogi! Yum! :P
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
This place was PACKED with Koreans. 

That's an under-statement. Let me explain:
My friends from Jersey came to visit and wanted to contend their east coast Korean dining experience with that of San Francisco. Took them here because yelp thought this place might be a good idea.

The place wasn't so full - there were about three tables. Wait time? One and a half hours. We told them about the three tables that were free, but they said those tables were unavailable. We stood there, dumbfounded. After spending a few minutes trying to figure out where else to go, they seated us. Very weird... but that isn't even the worst of it.

As we sat there, Hoards of Koreans came through to eat. Where were they coming from? Tour buses! 

PLEASE don't eat here on a Saturday. PLEASE. If you know what's good for you.

This is literally a stop on the tour. They unload about 40-50 people into the restaurant at a time. Once they've finished, the next bus pulls up and they switch out. Pretty efficient. They must make a lot of money. But you know what? The people who are in tiny groups that aren't part of the all-star tour -- you do NOT get noticed. Even with your arms waving in the air and all you need is some water. 

Service SUCKED because of this. I'm sure the tour bus people had a better experience. Maybe because they were Korean? LOL Who knows. 

The food was bland, mediocre, and definitely not worth the price. Disappointed friends got compensated with Mitchell's Ice Cream. Thank goodness for that.
author: Rosavida C.

description: This place is awesome! The food is good, especially the soups. One of my Fav is soft tofu soup. Also, the complimentary appetizers are always fresh and tasty. Service is good, the place is always clean and nice. When I think Korean, I think Han II Kwan:)
author: Aya J.

description:
I'm Korean so that means I'm an expert in Korean food.  That also means I have to do the talking at all Korean restaurants so my friends and I can get discounts and free food.  Being Korean, I can also drink as much as I want without getting drunk, I can sing karaoke well, and I beat my wife.  I love stereotypes, don't you?! 

That being said, Han Il Kwan was okay, but nothing to write home to um-ma about.  They definitely fill you up with tons of side dishes and freebies like the steamed egg, but the entrees are uneventful.  I got the oxtail soup and my friend got the jap chae and kimchee pancakes.  All 3 were just okay. The soup was too watery and I feel like I ate it all just to finish it, without really enjoying it that much. 

All in all, I'd go here again if I had a craving for Korean food on a Monday night, since Um Ma Son is closed on Mondays.
author: James C.

description:
So when I was a kid, I used to go to Kumon down the street and everytime I'd be coming or going, I'll always remember how AWESOME it smelled... and this was the restaurant it was coming from. 

Finally got a chance to eat here and it was really tasty. I liked all the banchan it came with. For the three of us, we got two main dishes - tofu soup and kalbi. We barely finished our food at all! Totally worth the trip.

The service is spotty but it's ok... they do drop off your side dishes early and I see it as them leaving me alone to enjoy my food. And yes, there is a spot for a tour bus to park there. Parking is a pain to look for though. Mainly residential and nearby the strip of Japanese restaurants on Geary where everyone there is looking for parking too. 

I'll be back for sure!
author: Jeannie L.

description: Great food, great apps, great prices. We randomly walked in after a stroll around the city. The beef soup was great. So were the appetizers.
author: Maryam M.

description: Food was good and they give you more comped dishes than the usual ban chan. BUT beware of the multiple Korean tour companies that come in and out during dinner time. You'll end up waiting an hour for a table and if you even dare ask how much longer you need to wait, the host will just yell at you to stand to the side and get out of the way...
author: Patty K.

description:
Amazing food. Subpar service. 

I was raised on korean food; having a traditional korean mom meant eating rice and kimchi at practically every meal until moving away for college. That being said, the food here is as close to authentic (and delicious) as any other place you'd find in SF and the peninsula. Seriously damn good. 

Unfortunately, the same cannot be said of the service here. You often have to flag down a waitress for more water even when it isn't busy. We were also turned away on several occasions due to large tour buses filling up the place to max capacity. These tour buses seem to come often on weekends so be sure to call in advance!
author: Eugene C.

description:
Q: Why is there a Korean tour bus parked in the middle of this sleep residential neighborhood? 

A: Oh, because they're all going to Han Il Kwan for dinner. 

Ya heard that right. Korean tourists. They go to Han Il Kwan for dinner. If that's not enough of an endorsement of this place, I don't know what is. Be warned, though, if you do happen to come here when the tour group is in the house, you'll be waiting for awhile. They tend to take up the majority of the restaurant.

Quite a few times I've been here, I've seen a few couples that look like they're on a date. I'm not sure that's such a wise choice. Unless you find the smell of smoky bbq meat a turn on. This place is a great place to get together with friends, though. The place is pretty big and there is ample room for large groups. The service staff here have always been exceedingly friendly, although sometimes you'll have to ask a few times for something. 

The food is some of the best Korean food I've had in the city. The kalbi meat is good quality, good marbling, very tender when it's cooked on the grill. The mung bean cakes are ok, a little dense, IMO, and you only get 4 fairly small ones. The dol sot bibimpap is very good, lots of vegetables and meat in the stone pot. The galbi jim (braised short rib stew) is really good, though. There are big ol' chunks of tender braised beef in a stewpot with potatoes and carrots. The jap chae tastes good, but a little heavy on the veggies, not enough noodles. They usually comp you something like tofu stew  or steamed egg, which is awesome.
author: Saunders C.

description:
Thank you Chris for taking me to this spot! I haven't enjoyed a great Korean restaurant in SF until....well, two years later and I'm NOW reviewing this place! Yikes!

Since it's a short walk from where he lives, we've been here several times. They never fail to disappoint me each time I've ordered their choice of kalbi or bulgogi, dak gui, japchae, soon dobu soup, banchan or something random. They also serve their small side dishes as well, so be careful upon ordering entrees. You'll fill up quick before the actual dishes come out!

Parking is never a breeze here, so the distance from his place and the restaurant is never a problem. However, you'll have to make it a trip if you plan to eat some hands-down, yummy Korean food. If you notice Korean tourists walking inside here, then you'll know you've walked into the right restaurant! Service is top-notch, so friendly staff and great quality of food that come hand in hand? Hallelujah!

Don't be fooled by the outside appearance, because it's really nice inside. Not too shabby. Prices aren't on the expensive side, so it won't leave a hole in your wallet. Lots of food to share!

In short note, I'll come back again and again if I'm ever nearby!
author: Fraulein C.

description:
Plus:
Crazy good spicy pork. All the pickled sides are amazing! Let them cook it for you once the novelty of cooking for yourself wears off b/c they know how to BBQ. Also tried the Mackerel, another epic dish.

Minus:
Long lines.
author: Sean D.

description:
My favorite dish here is the bibim map in a hot stone bowl. The food is very authentic Korean, it's not an American version of a Korean restaurant with mild food.

Sometimes there are hoards of Korean tour bus people clogging the back room which can slow service, but generally not too long a wait.

Negative stars due to the slow and unfriendly service. If you go to Korean restaurants in SF you will experienve similarly icy service
author: Spoon G.

description:
This place would've gotten 5 stars if they had better service.

By better service, I mean, let my friends and I sit together. I know we're a large party of 10 or 11, but really....it doesn't make sense for us to not sit together. We were about to leave since they refused to let us sit at one table/joined tables and then they agreed. Should've just said yes in the first place if we were gonna arrive at the same conclusion.

The food is good. You can choose to grill the meat yourself or have them do it for you. I love the massive amounts of side dishes and serving sizes - pretty good deal! 

Parking is seriously hard. I doubt I would come again because of the "bad" service and parking - otherwise, it's a good place and is one of the better korean bbq places I've been to.
author: Amy T.

description:
I had a craving for my grandma's cooking and this was pretty darn close.

It is better to come here with more than two people because the portions are large and you get all the extra pickled goodies.   Two dishes is perfect to share between three people.  When my friend and I come here just the two of us we usually end up eating way too much (but we can't stop - it is so yummy...)

Try to get here earlier rather than later in the evenings.  It seems totally random but huge tour buses will pull up here and the restaurant will be packed full for two hours.
author: Kristine K.

description: Usually like this place but food and service tonight was just mediocre. Kalbi didn't have much flavor and was tough! And waitress would just arrive and push everything over to place more food down but things looked like they would topple over. Not once did she do this, not twice but three times! They were not very friendly at all and it wasn't like they were busy or anything....they just wanted us to order, give us our food and get the eff out...id rather eat at Pine for Korean on Noriega. Hole in the wall but at least their kalbi is good.
author: Linda L.

description: Good food and somewhat friendly service. It's a good meal. The pancakes were too dense. The kalbi was super tender. The tofu soup was tasty. The veggie and beef soup tasted very similar to the tofu soup but only spicier. Good meal but there are cheaper and tastier Korean places on that side of the park.
author: Eve C.

description:
3.5

After visiting last week, Han II Kwan is now on my rotation of possible Korean BBQ destinations when in the City.  

First off, as you walk towards the restaurant, you are enveloped by the delicious aroma of K-bbq.  Why?  Because they have amazing ventilation inside that pipes the smoke outside.  Most of the time, when you eat Korean BBQ, you reek until you scrub yourself raw in the shower but after we left Han II Kwan, it wasn't so bad.  We even decided to go to a movie and didn't offend the rest of the theater.  LoL

That being said... they get props because they let me special order my favorite dish (which wasn't on the menu) - squid with rice cakes in spicy sauce - and it was actually really tasty.  The rice cakes were very soft - like clouds and the sauce and squidy were also good.  We ordered Galbi and though it wasn't 'quite' as good as our Oakland favorite, it was still delicious, more reasonably priced and had a decent quantity of meat.  I can't remember much about the panchan but I remember thinking it was pretty good while eating it.  They also give the free tofu soup... nomnom.

Negative things... parking was a biatch.  Also, we had to ask for water 3 times.  All the servers seemed to be too busy with the larger groups... ah well.

We'll probably check it out again... hope to bump the star up from 3.5 to 4.

See ya there!
author: Susan D.

description: I like this place because it's close to my house and they give you a lot of side dishes but they really need to work on their phone etiquette.  I always call in before walking over to make sure there isn't too long of a wait, but the guy who picks up always hangs up before I even finish my sentence.  Be warned tho, they won't put your name down for you even if you call from standing outside.
author: Tina L.

description:
Honestly, the food is above average. 3/5 maybe?  
However, the service there is really, really terrible.

No need to wait, if no table? Just leave. Not worth it, on the other hand, 3 of the waiters there are extremely not in good manner and bad services...... 

Let me say this story. I just make it simple to let you know the reason. 

I and 2 of my friends want to go there to have a regular dinner. We arrive there at like 5:57... We are told that.. ummm, just wait 20 more minutes.. And my name is just on the white paper... They are so busy serving those large group of koreans who have reserved the table, well, I understand. But what I am not understanding is that they are really happy and smile to those ''native people''... But for us, just.. impatient faces......Actually, there is a BBQ table for 2-4, but they just ignore and say no no no, you guys want the regular one, furthermore, they just don't talk to us.. We ask how is everything and how long.. They just apparently don't listen on purpose, just say wait if we ask to many time... 

Well, general speaking, I am a person who can wait, but the idea is that waiting in a restaurant is not like that... I have experience great restaurant that when you wait, waiter will come and talk to you about how long, and smile and say apologize.. I don't expect to see any apologizes.. But just nicely answer our  question, giving everybody how long to wait is fine. 

Even more, one thing makes me mad is that they say the name on the list is not correct, everybody waiting in the store at the time seems arrive same time.. Ok, then we say WHAT!!!! By the time, we have waited for 45+mins, is 6:43 something.... Even though there are people say we are the first, they still give the table to someone who personally say they have reserves.. (Apparently they have 8 people and we have 3.. You know what is going on..) 

The end is that, we leave... This is just one time waiting, next time, need to wait, we will leave...

I have been there for more than 10 times... Not one time make me satisfied... Always like waiting, not only for table, also for food, especially  services... You want some water, need to wait, guys... 

Sad, really disappointed.. 
Just one word... There are still some good korean restaurant, if need to wait, don't go this one, nothing special...
author: Q C.

description:
Han Il Kwan is definitely one of the best Korean restaurants in SF.. I usually pay around $20 during dinner, which is a little high for me, but the quality of their food and service make it well worth the price. 

First, the banchan. I love how they rotate the banchan...you never know what your going to get. And I can never get over how there's so many choices and how we can get as many servings as we like. This time around my favorites were the fish cake (always a favorite) and the chilled cucumbers. The fish cake here is a little spicy, but it's not overwhelming at all. The cucumbers were nice to eat whenever I needed a break from our some of our spicy entrees.

During my last trip, my friends and I shared the rice cakes in red sauce, an order of kalbi, and # 30. Can't remember the name right now, but it was these different types of seafood with rice and an egg on top...kind of like bibimbap but without the vegetables. The latter was my favorite dish of the night. It's great for seafood lovers, and while it was spicy, I still could taste all the other flavors. Plus the crunchy rice at the bottom of the bowl is always a plus! Kalbi was standard- the meat was a little too chewy at times, but I liked how the marinade wasn't too sweet. Spicy rice cakes were some of the hottest I've ever had, but I managed to endure and really enjoyed them. The rice cakes were perfectly cooked.

Service here is really nice and helpful, and the restaurant is pretty spacious so I never feel crammed in. Parking can be hard to come by in this neighborhood, but don't let that hinder you from eating here. I still haven't had lunch here, but their lunch specials seem like a really great deal! Definitely will stop by here for lunch next time!
author: Amanda K.

description:
We love HAN ILKWAN, food is tasty and waiters and waitresses are very 
nice.
author: Kyo C.

description:
I seriously don't think there is anything special about this place. First of all the parking is HORRENDOUS. The dishes are just so-so.  The ba-chans (little plates) that everyone is raving about are no better than any typical Korean restaurants.  Seriously.

We made reservations for 7pm fo 11 people and didn't get seated until maybe 7:30 because some tour group was late coming from Vancouver so we had to wait until they finish.  The owner did comp us free 1st round of drinks, including beer.  When we finally got seated, you would think that because of the wait, they would tend on our table immediately. But nope - as most people say, if you get seated inside those "private" rooms, be prepared to wait.  We waited and tried to wave someone down.  We even walked outside of the room to get the waiter's attention. He acknowledged us and said he'll be coming, but nope. Another 10 mins passed.  We were all starving.  It's about 8pm already - 1hr after our initial 7pm reservation.  We finally ate around 8:15.  It's ridiculous.

The food, once again, was mediocre.  We ordered the Dinner B special for $145, and I don't think it's worth it at all.  We ordered a chop-jae and a seafood pancake on the side.  Do not order the seafood pancake.  It sucks.  

I would not come back to this place again.  I would rather go to Shin Toe Bu Yi on Taraval.

Review #129
author: Jannie Q.

description:
Have been to this restaurant some times ago around February 2012... We were a table of 4 persons, and I have to say we all enjoy the food here. We came for the meat and we got the meat ! Come here with a good appetite otherwise you'll waste your money.

Place is clean service is good, and food is very Korean BBQ so 4 stars.
author: Renaud P.

description:
Can someone please explain to me how you order Korean BBQ for dinner, why is everything like $22????

Anyways, this review is for lunch.

Once upon a time, 3 of my friends and I came to this place under the pretense that it was named Kim Jon Il. Like really. We ordered two different meats and with all the other unlimited sides that came with it, we all filled up on delicious KBBQ for like $6 a person. YES. $6 a person. We must've done the math like 12 times before we agreed that the bill was correct. And then they gave us weird Korean rice shots for dessert. They were good and we were very pleased with our almost-free feast. 

Fast forward 6 months and I found out this place is called Han Il Kwan.
author: Glenda L.

description: Gal bi jim is good here! I always order take out. I like their rice too. Service is punctual.
author: Clemencia S.

description:
I LOVE korean food and this place totally delivers!!! 

The free appetizer dishes rock my world!!! I recommend getting a seafood pancake, the rice rolls, and the bi bim bop (I'm pretty sure I'm saying it wrong...) Don't get tofu soup because it's one of the FREE appetizers! :) 

I almost didn't want to review this place and give is such good ratings because I want to hoard this place for myself.....but I'll be a generous person and share my amazing findings with the rest of the world...
author: Amiee H.

description: Love this place, the food is solid, and they occasionally give you complimentary dishes, so far ive gotten something 9 out of 10 times ive been here. The sauteed octopus is good and best part is making your own lettuce wraps with your grilled meats.
author: Will L.

description:
This place has the best panchan! (side dishes)
I came here for a late lunch and the place was still 1/2 full despite being between lunch and dinner. Great spot to bring a group of friends and those friends that want good korean food and not in a place that looks "hole in the wall". This place has a trendy and clean open feel. 

First they come out with like TEN pan chan dishes. It was just me and I got all 10! Panchan included:
- fresh kimchee
- cucumber pickles
-bean sprouts
- kimchee cubes ( not sure what it's called, but the sauce was SO fresh)
- cucumber with red sauce - ate all of this!
- dried fish
 - a veggie pancake that was tasty
- some sort of peanuts in a sauce ..mmm
- white jello with soy sauce

AND, along with my main dish I was also given a bowl of steamed egg - mmm mmm! I can't believe how much  "free stuff" you get and the quality.

I wanted to order seafood tofu stew (ha mul soonduboo) but i couldn't find it on the menu for some reason. Maybe I should have just told them I wanted that and they'd bring it out. Instead, I stuck to the menu and ordered their vegetable tofu stew of which i regretted. It was healthy tasting and the veggies/tofu were good, but this was a VERY bland stew. Darn, I'll need to order better next time on the mains.

Definitely want to come back here for my next panchan craving and order the right main dishes!
author: Cecilia T.

description:
"A-Wop-Bop-A-Loo-Bop-A-Bi-Bim-Bop! " 

Most Big Asian restaurants have a same problem.
They want the all tables are always taken and keep people busy in and out.
Or,..... you have to have a connection with travel agencies to get a large bus with a full of people from the origin country.

The place gets those buses sometimes parking right front of the street and you'll see that full of Koreans from Korea sitting inside.

When you see the large bus, parking front, do not even think to go in there.

If you don't see the large bus, you can go, it's a time, the time, only time, for you to go inside getting decent service.

People here are very polite, I was by myself but the service was very nice.
I had a BBB, Bi Bim Bup, cold version with banchan was $10.65 include tax.
I think this is a lot better deal than BBB lunch with out banchan, $8.50.
Great banchan.
Love the small pan-cake thing tasted like Okonomi-Yaki.
I WANTED TO HAVE MORE OF THOSE!!!!

I was loving it.

Cat C said, "The kbbq is good but its an even longer wait for a table with a grill!."

When I was there, it was around 3 pm. 
Who wants BBB at 3 pm ?
Me!
I will be in the BBB-mood anytime.
author: Nobu K.

description:
I'm from LA, so you know I'm crazy picky about my Korean food. 
Not going to lie tho, the food was pretty legit. Almost as good as my mother's home cooking. 

Gets UBER busy and cramped. There were 9 of us, got seated at a round table smack in the middle of the room. Some dude kept bumping into me EVERY SINGLE TIME HE GOT UP for something (must've been a fob, never apologized for nothin).

THERE IS NO PARKING ANYWHERE!!!
author: So H.

description:
This is one of my favorite Korean BBQ restaurants!  Not all of their tables have the grill, so you have to request it when you make your reservation.  Reservations aren't always a guarantee, I've had to wait there before even with a reservation made in advance.  

I love all the side dishes that come out, and they are good about restocking whatever you get low on.  They also come over and take over the grill for us if the meat-turner stops paying attention. :)

I'm not sure what the sauce is that they soak the beef in, but it is OUT OF THIS WORLD.  Especially wrapped in the lettuce food.

One thing that's tricky about this restaurant is they have a lot of bus tour groups come through, so timing is really important.  I went there once thinking because it was early we were going to beat the Saturday night dinner rush.  Imagine my surprise when we got  there and the place was packed and they said it would be an hour wait.  So it's best to call ahead.

This has nothing to do with anything, but I can only remember the restaurant name when I first think of The Wrath of Khan.

:)
author: Gabrielle L.

description:
I like this place almost as much as I like Brother's. 

This is a nice clean and well ventilated Korean BBQ house. The service is really good and the food is yummy.

I've eaten here a few times and enjoy them cooking my food for me because I don't like smelling like BBQ after i'm done eating.

Kalbi, Bulgogi, Chicken, Fish, Ban Chan.. it's all good.
author: J-nine I.

description:
This place is amazing. Before this place I found Korean food to be quite dull, but this place easily changed my mind. The workers are always so kind and will gladly give you a little more kimchi if you ask. I never do the grilling because the times I go here it's for small celebrations. Don't get scared of the prices though. The dishes, plus free kimchi, plus the rice tea, will definitely give you food coma. Practically everything I've tried here is well-seasoned and I always fall in love with Korean food more and more when I order different things on their menu.

Now lemme also say that I spent one month in South Korea last summer, yknow taking in the sights and eating the variety of food and stocking up on some kpop merch. I compared this place to the food I ate in South Korea. Equally delicious (but Han Il Kwan does not have a certain noodle dish I loved very much in Korea). And what surprised me was that my friend (who went to Korea with me) and I compared the Kalbi from Han Il Kwan to the Kalbi we had in Korea. We both agreed that Han Il Kwan's kalbi was much more flavorful and more tender. So trying this place's kalbi is A MUST!
 For you spicy lovers, order their marinated pork. I'm a huge lover of spicy foods and their marinated pork has become my favorite dish here. But if you're feeling particularly lazy, get the Bi Bim Bop. Most of their food is delicious.

Note: Certain tourist seasons, this place is PACKED! Beware of Han Il Kwan being too crowded. I sat there eating lunch with my friend and noticed 2 couples waiting 1 hour for a seat, so my friend and I were kind enough to ask to take our food home so they could sit.
author: Cathy V.

description:
I've past by Han II Kwan numerous times over the years and I finally came here the other night for dinner and I'm glad we did.  Prices are a bit pricy, but it's pretty good.  Staff are great, but once it gets busy, they can slip and forget to get you the stuff you need.  They defintely need to get more staff for the weekends.  

We ordered the family set dinner for 8 and order additinal dishes.  

Defintely will be back, hopefully they won't be as busy.
author: Shana W.

description:
Went for a good friend's birthday and we sat in one of the paneled off back rooms.

First off the staff was polite and helpful. We ordered tofu soup, kimchee pancakes, some other cake-like item, bul gogi, kal bi, pepper glass noodles, someone ordered bip bom bop and another  soup and of course it came with all the sides and two stone pots of steamed egg.

$17 each, including paying for the bday girl.

The food was excellent and served in a timely fashion. The kimchee and kimchee pancakes were especially notable. I would recommend this place. 

On a side note, a sweet rice drink is served as the end, I guess as palate cleanser? It did cleanse my palate. The inside is utilitarian, but clean.
author: Lily G.

description:
I think this is my new favorite KBBQ spot in SF! It's much cleaner than Brothers too, cause I am not welcomed by a cloud of smoke as I enter. They have more banchan dishes than a lot of other places. Price is about average for your typical korean bbq joint and the tofu soup was good with an ample serving of tofu. My friends didn't want that much tofu, so more for me.. yay! We only order the spicy pork and bulgogi and that got us three quite full!

I always see Korean tourists come here to eat, so if the tour guide companies think it's suitable for their clients.. best believe this place is legit.
author: Helen Z.

description:
Because of the Yelp reviews, I've always been wanting to try this place. This place may be better for those who come for BBQ, but for other dishes, they are really disappointing. We came here for a weekend lunch. The place was almost empty.There was only one server. Though he was friendly, and gave us a complementary steamed egg dish, the service was undeniably slow. 

For the food, the banchan came in 7-8 varieties, all of which, including the supposedly spicy kimchi, tasted rather bland. The seaweed salad, one of the banchan dishes, was my all-time favorite, but it delivered a weird smell at this place. Maybe it's just for that day, but the food didn't seem to be all that fresh. Most of other dishes we ordered, including kimchi pancake, bibimbap, tofu soup, ox tail bone soup, were disappointing taste-wise. I had to add more sauces to the bibimbap but the sauce still did not help. The bill came out around $20 per person after tips. It's not cheap, and the food wasn't that impressive. I don't think I will go back.  Unfortunately, this is one of the few times that Yelp reviews disappointed me.
author: Elle W.

description:
Food isn't bad but WORST service ever.

All they care about is the TOUR BUS that takes all the Korean tourist there but NONE other customers matter.
author: Moto B.

description:
I was craving some Korean food last night, and my friend suggested that we try something new...well, new for me.  Its not hard to find, just look for the tour bus parking right in front of the restaurant.  My first thought was....why is there tour bus parking in front???  I got my answer when a Korean tour bus pulled up and unloaded the passengers into the restaurant.  This all happened as we were walking up to the restaurant, so we hauled @ss because we thought they would take up the whole restaurant.  No worries...there's a back room to accommodate them....phew!

My friend and I always over-order because we want to try different things.  We ordered the kalbi( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/xglU8roSVbgd2RyYSmalQQ/l ), fried dumplings( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/ZKFLNTMv5rzuK3jFoQmaJw/l ), and the seafood pancake( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/801hbsT7qYcnAaZge3Ew3g/l ).  We probably should have only ordered 2 dishes because you fill up on the panchan( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/bUlY06XB2Q33rqjeIcaD-w/l ) and the complementary tofu stew( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/jfp_OxRBoHfZrs6S9679vg/l ).

The kalbi was excellent.  The meat was very tasty and not chewy like some other places.  The dumplings were good, but they would have been better if they were a bit more crispy on the outside.  The seafood pancake was meh.  It was too mushy as if wasn't fried long enough.  I really liked their tofu stew.  It wasn't too spicy and warmed up my belly.  Bi Bim Bap seemed to be a very popular dish, so I'll have to try that next time.  

Service is really good here, and the food comes out pretty fast.  Its very hard to find a Korean restaurant where you don't come out smelling like you took a bath in a BBQ.  This place seems to have good ventilation because I didn't need to drench myself in Febreeze when I got home.  There's still a hint of BBQ, but its not that bad.

Parking's a bit of a pain.  Make sure you give yourself extra time to drive around and snag a spot.
author: Patra I.

description:
Hands down my favorite Korean Restaurant in SF. The banchan is delicious and abundant, the service is kind, and the food is delicious. 

HIGHLY RECOMMEND!
author: Esther K.

description: Hands down the best Korean BBQ in S.F.  Reasonable price for such quality and quantity.  I'm not really a big fan of rice, but for some reasons, their complimentary rice comes with the BBQ meat order just SOOO good and on point (always tempted to ask for another bowl lol).  The free dessert rice drink they give you at the end is very delicious too.  The only downside is the wait... make reservation every time you go!
author: Kho M.

description:
After our yummy Korean food experience in New Zealand, we were craving some Korean food here in the city and Han II Kwan got tons of positive reviews so we opted to give it a try. 

A 3.5 sold review for this restaurant (again wish there were 1/2 stars!) 
To come here a couple of things should be noted: 

1) parking is really hard to find. it's located in a residential neighborhood and open spots are few and far between. Luckily this lady couldn't fit her large suv in this tight parallel parking spot and we got a spot in less than 5 minutes. When we went into the restaurant, this Korean lady patron told us "you are very very lucky it is hard to find a spot here". Her husband didn't get into the restaurant until 10-15 minutes later (who knows how long she came before us) 

2) wear your dingiest clothes, no clothes that need dry cleaning, not your favorite sweater. after you eat here, you will smell and it is not an aphrodisiac. 

That said, the restaurant is an all around Korean restaurant serving many noodle, rice, soup dishes but also table side kbq meat grilling for those who want that experience.
