Everything on the menu looked really good. Try to come with a group if possible so you can try more dishes! We ordered the spicy bulgogi, chop chae, and stone pot bim bim bop. 

Let me be clear, you will walk away from this place stuffed. They give you so many different banchan dishes. The stone pot egg omelet is not something you see too often and it was soo good. You can get full from eating all the side dishes before the food comes! 

All of the dishes were good. The spicy bulgogi took some getting used to be but the bim bim bop was flavorful as was the chop chae. We definitely had enough left over for dinner the following night!
author: Betty C.

description: I've driven past this joint sooo many times and saw a lot of Korean tour buses parked outside. I thought it's just a tourist trap.  One day my Korean friend told me about this place and said it's good price and generous servings.  He ain't kidding! Good Korean food too. Been going here a few times now. Not yet disappointed.
author: Troy V.

description:
One of the reasons I don't like dining in the City is because of the parking.  I know it may sound trivial, but I hate looking of an open space when I'm hungry.  What usually happens is after searching for half an hour frustration and famine forces me to settle for a chain place like Jack in the Box.

Imagine my delight when I happen to be driving on Balboa Street and saw Han Il Kwan: good looking Korean restaurant in a quiet neighborhood where you can still find an open spot or two.

We recently took some out of town guests here and tried the set Dinner Special A because it came with Bulgogi and Spicy Pork Bulgogi and we didn't know what else to get.
I cannot begin to tell you how many plates they brought out.  At one point, I suggested we invite the couple sitting next to us since we had so much food.  The other three convinced me otherwise.

The only downer about dinner was the flame for our grill kept going out.  In the end, it didn't really matter since we were trying to finish the other hot food and forgot about all the uncooked beef and pork.  

This place serves some solid solid food and some tasty sides.
The tofu soup was watery but still satisfying.

Overall, Han Il Kwan is one of the better Korean places I've tried and its location garners an extra star.
author: Dan B.

description:
Sooo many banchan!! I think every time I've come, I've gotten 9 of the delicious complimentary sides including a soodobu, or soft tofu soup, and a sweet dessert drink at the end of your meal. 
I have come here a couple times to split a lunch special dish with either my sister or my mom cause there are so many banchan, two people can get totally full while only ordering only one entree and wasting food is bad!!!

BUT it seems the management has caught on to us because last time I went, we were informed that we must ALL order one dish. Which kinda sucked cause we had 6 people with us this time and six dishes is ALOT to be ordering at lunch!!! It felt really excessive since we ate everything family style. 

The food quality is plentiful, authentic and fresh but service is slow, mostly because they don't hire more people at peak hours! On the holiday Monday we went, only one man was working the cash register, waiting tables and bussing them! It took FOREVER to get in and out which was stressful because we had a slight time crunch. 

I used to look forward to coming here but now I might try another Korean place for my kimchi cravings.
author: Rayna L.

description:
food: 4/5
service: 3/5
atmosphere.decor: 5/5

Will come here again.

Han II Kwan is a large restaurant with nice decoration and furniture inside. There are two seating areas. The nicer one on the outer side, and the inner one for big parties. This is also a popular stop for Korean bus tours, so the inner room is mostly for large tourist groups and not really customers (at least that is how it is during the day time). The prices are average for a korean restaurant (~$20+ for meat dishes, ~$15 for soups rice and veggie dishes). Everything is family style and the portions are fairly large for the price. This is one point that will keep me from comming back. And at least 8 banchan!
The older waitress ladies are nice. They are not that attentive, but had a great attitude when we tried to get their attention. Typical of an asian place. After your meal, they have a sweet rice dessert cup.
author: Cecile S.

description: Solid food quality, great portions, hard working group staff. Best Korean in ST IMHO. Only lacking menu item so far had been the bul go gi but I always get Kal Bi anyways...
author: Collin L.

description:
First got introduced to this place by high school friends. We had a birthday party where we did a private room and got a grill to BBQ our own food. Super fun, great tasting food. Recently I got  the broiled mackerel with rice and waited a bit longer than I thought it would have taken, but when my food came it was totally worth it. I thought I was only going to get half a fish like most places, but it was the whole thing, not to mention they added an appitizer and soup for free. I even forgot about the assortment of kimchi that they packed in a neat container for me. 

The service isn't the best, but the food more than makes up for it. Also, parking sucks around here but that isn't the restaurant's fault blame over population.
author: Brian J.

description: I've been here and I guess the service is alright, but its so busy I can understand why the service is kinda weird
author: Erin K.

description:
Tasty, cheap, and free gimmes.

I am left a happy girl!

This is not my favorite Korean joint (since Shin Toe Bul Yi has stolen my heart), but it's definitely in the running when I'm trying to pick a Korean joint in the Richmond.

Sad that on a rainy Monday, we couldn't get a table to bbq- that was a downer.  But being greeted by tons of ban chan (was there actually little panjeon that was given???  hooray!) and a free cooked egg dish left me pretty happy.

Tofu soup was good.  
Bi Bim Bap could be skipped next time.
Oyster panjeon- YUMMMM AND GENEROUS PORTIONS!

Slighty cheaper than some of the other Korean joints and very generous portions.  Parking is not great in the area, but if you luck out then it's definitely worthy to wander over.
author: Christine K.

description:
Lets just say if you're going to go for dinner with a party bigger than 4, show up early or have the underdog go wait in line. For a party of 8 girls on a friday night, the wait was approximately 1.5 hrs.
The meal comes with a generous amount of side dishes, bowl of rice,  "decaf tea", and a rice dessert drink (at the end of your meal). Actually, EVERYTHING came in pretty generous amount, so even though you may WANT to order everything, I'd suggest holding off til the food actually arrives.
We weren't able to be seated with the grills on the table so the kitchen cooked all the meat for us. The beef and chicken were definitely not steaming hot and a bit dry. So I'd definitely recommend asking to be seated on a table with a grill.
However, the seafood pancake, spicy squid, and tofu soup was absolutely amazing, must try!
author: Ada C.

description: I would give 0 stars if that were possible. This place has continually gotten worse over the years and my tolerance has given out. I've gotten yelled at by one of the waitresses to please order in English, ironically, through her broken English. Keep in mind, not only did I say kimchi jeon (kimchi pancake) in Korean, I made sure to repeat it in english and point at the menu, because who enjoys getting their orders misunderstood?  (She heard kimchi jeongol, how she managed to hear an extra syllable is beyond me). The people I was with can all confirm that they heard me order it in both Korean and English. My mistake that she didn't follow my finger to the menu, or pay attention long enough to hear me repeat the item in English. To top it off, when another one of the waitresses was placing the ban chan (side dishes) on the table, one of the guests I was with was moving things down in anticipation of the many items we ordered and the waitress snaps at her, asking her not to touch them because she was placing them specifically for color. Excuse me, but none of us really care if you create a rainbow of side dishes on our table; it wasn't our first time at a Korean restaurant and we all have our preferences for which dishes we like to eat, and we're only trying to be considerate when they came with the main courses and would eventually need to move the side dishes to make room anyway. I swore never to return to their restaurant, but today I was asked to place a reservation for 8 people here to which a woman who kept cutting me off mid sentence to chit chat with another woman in the background informed me they didn't have tables for 8 people. I've been here enough times to know they can accommodate large parties. I don't know what happened over the years for all the ladies who work here to become so bitter, nasty, and especially rude. I know my review won't keep people from coming here, and this isn't to say ALL the ladies are rude, but a few of them are very snappy and short tempered and if they hated interacting with people, God knows why they became waitresses. Good luck for those who still wish to dine here, I know I won't.
author: Eunice K.

description:
Okay, this is a wonderful, wonderful place.

Of course, you've read all the newspaper articles and reviews here about how busloads of Korean tourists stop here to get a taste of home. That's a sign that this is as close to the real deal as it gets.

I came with Angeline P. (read her review, too). Basically, we got three plates of meat and japchae (glass noodles), 5 small beers ($3 apiece!) and the total was $105 after tax/tip. That's incredible, considering that the small plates were many and varied (we had lots of trouble fitting everything on our table) AND they even comped us a big bowl of tofu soup!

I attribute this to my dashing Korean features (Everyone thinks I'm Korean.. but I'm Chinese. Sob.)

Oh yeah, and don't forget to wear something where you won't mind if it smells like BBQ for the rest of the week. In similar restaurants in Korea, they will literally spray you with Febreze on your way out to counteract this. I'm both happy and sad that they don't do this here in the States.
author: Josh K.

description:
AWWW YEAH, delicious KBBQ and getting my lightweight friend drunk. It's a win-win guys. 

I wish the sides were a little bit better. Most of them were amazingg though. I would have loved some cold tofu and sesame oil seasoned with the broccoli. The seafood pancake was truly very good. The octopus was not overcooked for once. The only other time I've had good octopus was when it was sous vide at Spruce, k. It's not easy to make a super crispy pancake without overcooking octopus.  

You need two plates of BBQ to cook at the tables. The BBQ is definitely really good. Really good quality meat and really good seasoning.
author: Margaret S.

description:
Pretty good overall - service was attentive, and food wasn't bad. 

For two we ordered the fish roe soup, kimchi pancakes (blah), and jap chae. Everything was good except the pancakes were kinda bland and oily. They gave us an egg as service which was nice. The banchan was good as well. 

I would come back if I were in the area, but parking was a pain.
author: Leily P.

description:
O, Northern Virginia Korean BBQ how I miss thee!  I am in search for a comparable place in the city.  So fam din din was at Han Il Kwan.  I called in for reservation a week ahead of time.  Some of the relatives arrived there early, and servers said we didn't have a reservation.  After double-checking the calendar, there was my name, but it was not transferred to the waiting list.  O well, I wasn't too worried.  However, some of my relatives are way more temperamental, particularly since they said it would be 45 min. (prior to finding out we had a reservation).  They then changed it to 15-20, but let the next available table go to someone else.  So, after assertive negotiation (from relative), we got a table.  Again, I wasn't too upset b/c the server came by and apologized and offered 30% off our entire order!  

We ordered Dinner A  even though we had 7 people, it says "up to 6 people..." Server said it was plenty of food.  We added another plate of kalbi at the end.  Dinner A included Jap chae, boiled egg, tofu soup, spicy squid, tempura zucchini, oysters, shrimp, pancake, and for meat we chose kalbi and spicy pork.  All were enjoyable.  The best dishes were the jap chae (a lot of flavor), kalbi, and boiled egg (soft and fluffy).  We ended up saving $46 when receiving the bill...not bad for waiting (I must say).  If I had never savored the flavorful meats (e.g., kalbi, bulgogi) in Northern VA on the regular, I think, I too would rate this place higher.
author: Steph W.

description:
Came here for a friend's birthday. We ordered a lot of food. I liked the tofu soup, the steamed egg, salted fish, spicy rice cake, and kalbi. I thought the spicy pork was a little dry, the little seafood pancake was on the oily side,  and the pickled cucumbers were too salty. 

I liked that they brought out everything just as they cooked it. I think its a litlte on the more expensive side that I would have liked. Also, we had a really hard time trying to find parking.
author: Caroline C.

description:
For maybe 8 or 9 years, this has been my go-to place when I'm in the city. Generally, the food is excellent. The last couple visits were less than spectacular. On one visit the bulgogi was almost flavorless. 

On another visit, the Oxtail soup was terrible. There were literally 3 pieces of oxtail in that $11 or so soup. The actual bad part about it was that the broth was completely flavorless - it was basically just water. Added some salt, which helped but not by much. You don't serve water as soup to a Korean, because I will notice! 

Usually the food is very good, especially the banchan, but it's been hit or miss for me lately.
author: Jen K.

description:
The best Korean BBQ I've ever eaten.  Consistently offers sizzling iron platters of grilled meats along with a rainbow of ban chan (sp?) side dishes to pick apart.
Very popular with native Koreans and tourists, this authentic restaurant offers all the Korean favorites.  The prices are OK for the quality and the service.
If you want to eat some top notch Korean BBQ, come to Han IL Kwan!
author: Pablo R.

description: I use to love this place, i use to always bring friends and family here. The food is always consistent and great. And most of the people are really friendly and nice, but  there this skinny waitress with short hair, beady eyes, and with way too much makeup, that is extremely a rude. Her makeup looks like it was done by a mortician.  She has a huge attitude and constantly has a bitch face. She looks like she wakes up everyday hating her job and her life. Every time we ask for anything she ignores us, and when we do get her attention and ask for something, she never brings it. I have seen her do it to other customers. Maybe its me, my friends, or my fam, but whatever the case is, this place has definitely lost a few customers because of that waitress.
author: R S.

description:
Often times, I associate dining at Korean restaurants with rude service, a less than charming ambiance, ...but in to my surprise, there is a tiny gem in the Richmond district that gave me a glimpse of light.

Just as the monstrous tour bus reaches a complete halt, a flock of eager Korean tourist like marching penguins walk into Han Il Kwan for authentic Korean food.  

Blue interior shingles and wooden partitioned booths add to the casual family ambiance.  With a pleasant smile, our waiter Tina took our order.  

A few minutes latter, a vibrant fleet of side dishes call "ban chan" excites the appetite.  Notable ban chans include pillowy mung bean cake, steamed egg custard, and kimchi - with a combination of sweet and spicy tones.  

In Korea, there are many varieties of kimchi and each taste is unique to its region.  Because of it proximity to the ocean, the kimchi in the northwest of Korea is seasoned with fish and oyster.  While low in calories but high in dietary fiber, one serving of kimchi can provide a high amount of Vitamin C and Carotene.  

Other healthy ingredients often used in kimchi recipes include chili and garlic. Before the times of refrigeration, many types of kimchi were prepared in early winter and stored in the ground using large kitchen pots.

Arriving in a small stone pot, the hot tofu ($8.95) features a dark red soup simmering with silky tofu.  The spicy flavors from the chilli stimulated my appetite further more.  

Topped with a golden sunny side egg, the dol sop beem bi beem bap ($11.95) served in a large clay pot displayed multiple flavors.  With a few squeeze of their house sweet chilli sauce, the medley of vegetables combined with the creminess from the eggs and savory bbq beef pieces created a good comfort food dish.  The highlights were the nutty flavors from over cooked rice sizzling from the heated clay pot.  

Riding along the flavor train, Jap Cha (sautéed vegetables with beef and vermicelli-$11.95) is a great peppery noodle dish that compliments the bowl of rice.  

Skip the cold noodle served with beef and raddish ($10.95).  The addition of mustard and chili paste did not rescue the cold soup base from its lack of character and flavor.  Quickly, I reached for cubes of raddish marinated in chilli sauce to thrill my palate.  

Korean food is unique from other Asian cuisines in that it gives the diner control in terms of flavor, temperature and texture instantly.  If a dinner's palate has been over infused with spicy flavors, a quick nibble from cooling cucumbers or sprout amongst the pan chan army does the trick.      

For a table of four, the total was $60 including tips.
author: Rayfil W.

description: First trip for Korean BBQ and the food was very good. Loved the spicy pork and all the pickled appetisers. Thought the service was a bit raw but I believe this is customary to these types of restaurant. Would visit again when in the area.
author: Brian L.

description:
This place was great but with me comparing LA all you can eat KBBQ, it just doesn't. The meat wasn't all that great but nonetheless, it was good decent food. I would come back to just eat their little dishes. I do feel it might be a slightly over price but not too much. It is KBBQ in San Francisco. 

I like this place but it just didn't fill me up as much as I would hope to be. It was my friends birthday so it's not like it was a time for me to pig out. I have to act a little more lady like even though I remember that night, my boyfriend and I ended up grabbing a full on meal from somewhere. The boyfriend and I are fatties. 


The service and staff was great, very accommodating to storing my cake and other things. They were really nice. Next time, I want to go and try their soup and what not!
author: Hei Ming C.

description:
I've been here three times now... each time... progressively worse than the last. The service anyways. The food here is definitely pretty good!

The first experience was pretty amazing. The food was great, if not a bit pricey, but I came with one other person and they were extremely generous! Lots of stuff on the house: steamed egg, chap chae... I think there were at least 4-5 things that we didn't order that came for free (not counting the ban-chan of course). 

The second time I went there with two other people. Portions were pretty good (not the best I've had, especially for what they give you), but it was still good fun. This time we used the special cooking table for the BBQ meats, which was a blast with a good group of people. Service was considerably less satisfactory this time around... our ban-chan was never refilled, tea/water never replenished... our group was pretty much ignored the whole time we were there, despite having ordered quite a bit of food... which was very disappointing. It was a bit busy though, so I figured they just didn't have enough help...

The third time is what puts me on the fence about this place. We had reservations for a table (for 5 people), but when we got there, it still took them 15-20 minutes to seat us. It seemed as if they had forgotten about us for a bit, and we were left waiting around. Even after we were seated, ordering was difficult (took forever to get a waiter's attention). We ordered quite a bit of food this time around (oddly enough, when we tried to order just the fried tofu... the waiter gave us a funny look and told us it was not a good dish... so we avoided that one):

1. Chap Chae - pretty tasty; one of my favorite dishes to get here
2. Tofu Soup - decent... probably wouldn't order again
3. Mackerel - first time I've had it, very crispy and flavorful
4. Seafood Pancake - average, have had better, it was a bit thick... and there were very little ingredients
5. Dak Gul - definitely would order again, marinated perfectly, juicy and oh so tasty :)

There were 9 ban-chan dishes (I think the most I've ever had at a Korean place): fishcake, cucumber (yummy), kimchi, eggplant, beef something (pretty good), beansprouts, the gelatin stuff, radish, and pickled something. The ban-chan was definitely awesome... the service was not... The entire time we were there, we didn't get a single refill of tea/water, getting any service whatsoever was difficult, even when it was just to get the check! To top it off, the place was maybe only half full at the time...

So in conclusion... pretty great food (some of the best Korean I've had, ever)... but if you're looking for service... look waaaaaaaaay elsewhere :/
author: Denise C.

description:
love love love love love love love!!!
the best banchan in the city
open 7 days a week
that steamed egg in the stone pot blew my mind
i love the sweet rice dessert!! happy ending!! 
xoxoxoo
author: Libra J.

description: This was one of the worst dining experiences of my life. It started off with a wait and then even though there was an available table we were told to wait for them to clear a different table. We waited 20 min for our banchan and so I finally said something. People who came in after we did got their food first. 3/4 of our main dishes came out after forever and then the last persons food came out 10 min after everyone else's. Our appetizer came out last, basically by the time we were done eating. Also the food was really quite bad - below average at best. Service was terrible. We had one terrible waitress but the other ones were okay but the restaurant was severely unstaffed. Again, I really wanted to like this place based off other reviews and since we are Korean and love Korean food but it was really so terrible. Not only that, I had a migraine and indigestion for the rest of the afternoon. Never would I ever recommend this place even to my worst enemy. 0 stars if I could.
author: Elle P.

description: I thought it was average. The space was outdated - pretty so-so. I mainly liked how they were open to three ordering for two - and giving tea, rice, soup, and pancakes for three for free. I felt a little ignored at times (when the meat was burning). But overall, it was so-so -- no chosun galbee.
author: Andrew K.

description:
I am NOT COMING BACK EVER!!! 
Neither are my friends, in fact, you won't catch us within a three block radius of this horrible place. 

First of all, their SERVICE definitely is AWEFUL! (I will explain towards the end....)

Second, this restaurant is expensive $$$ including myself, I went with a party of 5. I understood that we had to order two dishes to be seated at the table with the grill. When we walked in, the waiter guy just sat us at the regular table without asking us where we wanted to be seated. To be in the service industry, hun, you have to have decent english abilities (or whatever the dominant language is in.) We constant had to repeat what we were saying twice, and when the waiter spoke back he had to repeat twice as well because we could not understand his english.
Okay back to the point of their EXPENSIVENESS, so we ordered two of the grilling ourselves dishes which were ~$20 each. The waiter tells us that we have to order one dish per person at least. So we order three lunch specials which were ~$10 each. 

Thirdly, the food was OKAY. The dishes we cooked ourselves were good but the other lunch specials were dry. 

So this is where the real shit happened. We get the bill and the bolded price is with an 18% tip already calculated into the tab. The ACTUAL TOTAL was  ~$16 per person (tip not included) in our group of 5. We flag him down and waited for him to bring us back our change, so then we'll give the tip. The waiter never came back. We saw him around and we were tired of waiting (we were also waiting for the rice drink at the end of the meal, which never came) so we left the tip on the table. Admittedly, our tip was not much. We left a 5% tip... 

As we were walking down the block, the waiter runs after us and gives us back our tip and says "IF YOU CAN'T AFFORD THE FOOD NEXT TIME, JUST GET TAKE-OUT" and something about a not big enough tip....

Of course I'm defensive. It's not like we skipped out on the bill and a tip is something we think of their service. 

So bottom line, do NOT come here if you don't plan to spend some BIG DOLLARS on MEDIOCRE FOOD. If you do go there, then you might want to calculate that apparently REQUIRED 18% TIP!!!!
author: Nina D.

description:
Momma C. hooked me up with some suh-weet Korean slang the other day.  "Dulri mokdaga hana jewkohdo morewgehtda."  Literally this means:  "Two people eating, one dies, the other doesn't notice."  Colloquially this means:  "This food is da effing BOMB!"  

I definitely could've used this info when I was stuffing my face at Han Il Kwan.  

My friend suggested that we get one of the set dinners.  For $105.50.  For "4-5 people."  I looked at the long list of what was included in the dinner.  Then looked at my 3 friends.  Then back at the list.  I had my doubts.  

"It'll be fine.  HE'S here," she said tilting her head towards our friend aka the Garbage Disposal.  The Garbage Disposal nodded reassuringly.  

Who was *I* to get in the way of a Korean food fest?  

Message to you "hip" small plates restaurants, do as the Koreans do.  Have about 10 small plates (aka ban chan) as part of the meal for free and refill any and all of them.  We had a good assortment including kimchee (of course!), cucumbers, anchovies, and bean sprouts.  We also got a couple complimentary items including some pajun that was tasty.

For our Korean food fest we got:  kalbi, chicken, ojing o bok kum (squid and veggies in hot sauce), mo dum jun (egg coated and pan fried shrimps, oysters, fish and zucchini), chap chae (noodle dish), marinated fish, and dubu chigae (tofu soup).

Everything was really good!  My faves were the chicken that had a great marinade on it and was cooked perfectly.  The chap chae was also tasty.

Despite our valiant efforts, even the Garbage Disposal couldn't handle all the food that covered every inch of our table.  Defeated, we raised the white flag and asked for to go boxes.  Aigu!
author: Amy C.

description:
I went here a couple years ago with my dragon boat team and they gave us the entire backroom which is a major plus.  The food was great, very authentic Korean food.  I would definitely come back here again for their sizzling dishes!  

Extra plus that they were considerate and took our RSVP of 20+ people!
author: Morris C.

description: Lots of banchan, really yummy fried squid casserole, and super nice service will lead me back here.  I didn't try the bulgogi but the variety of banchan was good and they gave me a complimentary soon doobu soup!  Service was slow but it was a busy night.  I like this neighborhood because most times you can find parking if you don't mind walking 2-4 blocks and it's a quiet and safe area.
author: Lalu B.

description:
So delicious!

I've had Korean food but the food here is just so much better. 
The flavors are all there. Everything tastes so fresh. 

Boyfriend and I had the Japchae, Seafood Pancake, and Kimchi Bibimbop.
It came with free tofu soup, 8 dishes of banchan, and 2 fried fritter thingies (so yummy)!

We didn't have to wait and the people were so nice. 

I will definitely come back. 

P.S. We have enough leftovers for 2 more meals.
author: Melissa T.

description:
I came here last Thursday with some coworkers for lunch.  We were probably seated for almost 15 minutes before someone took our order and then forever passed before they brought out our banchan.  Two lifetimes later, we finally got our food (we all ordered from the lunch specials menu which were all less than $10).

I had the kimchee bibimbap and the stone pot was really overheated...to the point that the rice at the bottom was black!  I also tried some one of my coworker's bulgogi (BBQ beef) and it was overcooked and dry (taste-wise, it was okay).  The tofu soup was okay...nothing special.  The banchan was good though!

I've had way better Korean food and experienced better service at other restaurants so I probably won't be coming back, especially with Muguboka not far away.  Sorry, Han Il Kwan, but you probably won't be seeing me again.
author: Katelynn L.

description:
Lately, I've been tasting the rainbow of many Korean restaurants in SF.
You could say Han Il Kwan is one of the more modern Korean restaurants I've been to. 

First of all, be sure to prepare a wee bit of time to look for parking. This place is on a corner in an area of mainly houses so there aren't many spots.

When you arrive you have the choice of choosing a regular table or a table with a BBQ grill to self cook your goodies. I didn't want any BBQ cologne at the time so I just got a regular table. My friend and I both got the Dol Sot Bi Bim Bap which is Hot Stone pot Bi Bim Bap on the menu. If you're going to get bibimbap, I recommend you get it in the hot stone pot because you get different textures of rice when the stone pot crisps up the rice. The bottle of sauce they provide for my dish was a good mix of salty and spicy; very good. My bibimpbap seemed to be endless though; I ate and I ate for at least over an hour to conquer it because I do not let food defeat me.

I liked:
+My Dol Sot Bi Bim Bap was good. Accompanied with the sauce they provided made it better
+Huge variety of baanchaan(side dishes); green onion pancake was especially good.
+Free tofu soup served in a hot stone pot
+Free sweet rice drink at the end of the meal to cleanse the palette.

There was something that didn't irritate me, but I definitely noticed throughout the meal. The two employees tended to the other 3 or 4 tables a majority of the time and we were forgotten after our food was received up until I had to ask for the check. I like not being rushed, however, I do not like to be forgotten.
author: Benson T.

description: I've been here a two times. Both times the food was amazing. Both times they were able to easily accommodate our large group for dinner. The first time we went early around 5pm and lucked out getting a table when we walked in. The second time I made a reservation and was seated with 20 mins of my reservation time and they kept us updated on the wait time. Overall had a good experience both times. The service has gotten better lately so that is a plus. And the food, well it speaks for itself. Will always recommend this place for a jump start into loving Korean food.
author: Leah C.

description:
Food: 4 stars
Service: 3 stars

FYI: Parking is hard here unless you park around on Geary

My friends and I originally had a party of 9 and they seated us reluctantly in one of the round tables. When we wanted to add a 10th person, they said we all couldn't sit in one table and said we had to split up. So we asked if they could join two tables together so we could sit together, but they said no we had to split. When we decided to leave and go elsewhere, THEN they agreed to pull up a side table to the big round table.

Besides that, everything else went pretty okay. We ordered the meats and BBQed them ourselves. We got the chicken, the three layered pork, and ribs. We also got bibimbap and jap chae, some type of fish plate, kimchi tofu soup, a pancake, and one other dish that I can't remember the name anymore. They gave us two steamed egg dishes on the house.

I love the amount of side dishes that we were given. There was a big variety and it was all so delicious. For the three layered pork they gave us small dishes with salt and pepper and oil to dip it in and lettuce to make wraps. The meats were all good, but the chicken was the best to me, probably because it was already marinated whereas the other pork ones weren't. The bibimbap was decent and the jap chae was good. The fish was probably one of my most favorites in the whole night. The pancake was a little burnt though. It would have been nice if the fume hood above us really worked...

Overall the food and the bbq is good. Its nice to know that they can bbq the food for us instead of us bqq-ing it ourselves. It'd go back, but definitely with several people because the portions are pretty decent sized.
author: Jay L.

description:
Pretty amazing. We ordered kalbi, bulgogi, and sam gyup sal, as well as japchae and small Hite beers for the five of us. Total came out to $105 including tip. Not bad, considering we got stuffed beyond comprehension. This would be a four star review but...

Bonus points for soondubu sabisu! I love getting stuff free, and I definitely miss that in Korean restaurants here. When the ajuma brought out the soondubu and told us it was on the house, I could hardly believe my luck. Totally worth the trip out to the Richmond. 

I brought the smell of the barbecue home with me, just like any good Korean barbecue place. I regret that I wasn't spritzed with Febreeze and made to stand in front of a giant fan like my favorite barbecue place in Seoul, but I am content to come here over and over again, and bring friends.
author: Angeline P.

description:
This place was recommended to me by a friend, who happens to be S. Korean. She said it was the best Korean restaurant in the city. It did NOT disappoint! They place was great!

The food was fresh. The number of side dishes was extensive. My only complaint was the the beer menu was not great. I guess that is to be expected though. You don't go to a Korean restaurant for the "great" Korean beer... I highly recommend this place to anyone! It's a bit of a schlep to get to but well worth it.
author: Cheyenne C.

description:
Get the lunch specials.
I've come only during lunch.
Quality bargain.

Banchan (side dishes):
Fish pancake, sweet beans, kimchi
Just to name a few

Seafood bibimbop,
Or any pork or beef dish. 
These I've tried before.

Ending your meal:
Small sweet fermented rice drink
Enough palate cleanse.
author: Jeanne L.

description:
Let me just say this will be MY FIRST AND LAST TIME COMING HERE. I don't even yelp but because the service I received today was SO AWFUL, I need to share with other yelpers. I've always heard good things about this place but now I'm curious how they even got passed two stars. Upon arrival, my family and I were ignored. A Korean family came after us and was greeted and then got seated right away. My family and I decided to have Korean BBQ as a snack and wanted to order Kalbi. Since this place has a two plate minimum for bbq, we decided to order the Kalbi and Marinated Spicy Pork which came out to be almost $50. 

The chubby waitress with short hair took our order and gave us extreme attitude because we only wanted to order two entrees for four people. I asked her if there was a minimum to order at the restaurant and she said "no, but you have four people". First off, we were not really hungry and just wanted a snack so why would we order more if we know we can't finish everything, not to mention the side dishes. So she decided to yell at me and gave me attitude by asking how much rice I wanted. I said we don't need much and before I finished, she said you get two rice bowls only and walked away. She didn't even ask us if we wanted the complimentary soup or steamed egg but whatever. Then, after our food was served, I saw the same waitress glare at our table and start gossiping to her coworker while pointing fingers at me. I stared back at them and she looked away. 

Our bbq grill was also defected. Flames flared up on our grill at random times and it came up to the level of our faces. When we told the waiter about the issue, he claimed that the fire went off because we put "too much meat on top" (there was only six small pieces of meat). He came back a second time to check on the grill and realized the flame was still off with two pieces of meat. He decided to just light up the grill and walked away and never came back. Our flame never came back on and they didn't bother to change our burnt bbq top. Next, I noticed the same chubby waitress was gossiping about us again but this time with a female coworker. They were both blatantly staring at us. When we called that female coworker over, she straight up threw the "no" hand signal at us and made a #2 hand signal (stereotype Chinese sign) to her other coworker while laughing. All we wanted was the check too. 

This is by far the WORST KOREAN PLACE EVER!!! I love trying new places and this is definitely a place I WOULD NEVER RECOMMEND. TRUST ME, I eat out a lot and will definitely spread the word about my negative experience here. If you want good Korean food, I promise MY TOFU HOUSE IS 10X BETTER THAN THIS PLACE!!! MY TOFU HOUSE HAS WAY BETTER SERVICE, DELICOUS MEAT (not plain like Han II Kwan), AND QUALITY FOOD! For self-serve BBQ, go to BROTHERS ON GEARY OR JP for all you can eat. This place is NOT WORTH THE MONEY! ZERO STARS IF IT WAS POSSIBLE ON YELP! Also, before I forget, the Korean workers were truly discriminating against other races, not only because of the RACIST hand sign, but because they ONLY SERVED KOREANS with immediate service and ignored everyone else.
author: Monica C.

description:
After reading Yelp reviews, Han Il Kwan was our choice for Korean food when our New Orleans friends visited last week.  We went for a late lunch so the restaurant was nearly empty.  That being said, parking was still absolutely beyond frustration!!!  But the wonderful meal that awaited us soon made us forget fifteen minutes of circling the local neighborhood beforehand.

Han Il Kwan was impeccably clean and service was excellent as one would expect with only two groups of diners.  We were amazed at the large spread of banchan arrayed before us - about ten dishes, and an excellent soup.  We shared bulgogi and chap chae and a mixed seafood dish that was absolutely spectacular with calamari, mussels, shrimp, scallops and other tidbits.  Outstanding!!
author: Carmen H.

description: Family was in town and decided to make a pitstop for some korean food before heading to Napa for a wedding.  They had trouble finding parking so the guy who worked there suggested parking around the corner- which they did.  They all went in to eat and came back out in 30 minutes to find that their car window was smashed and all the belongings were stolen (outer richmond area is ghetto).  Obviously, its not the restaurant's fault BUT what was uncalled for was that they told my family (who were out of towners),that it was their own fault for leaving bags in the car. Who says that?? AND they were extremely unhelpful and rude throughout it all.  horrible customer service.
author: Christine M.

description:
I've heard great things about this place so it could be just a bad day

Pros: The side dishes that come with a Korean meal are noticebly larger than typical Korean restaurants, which is a plus since we always have to ask for more.

The food was good and the price is what you'd expect from a Korean restaurant, which is ~$10 or more per dish.

Cons: Residential parking could be hard to find. We parked about two blocks away and it wasn't even busy here.

The biggest turnoff was that we we had to wait 15 minutes for a table when the place was only half full. It was probably because all the smaller tables were full, but we didn't even get offered a seat at the larger tables. I guess it's reserved for large groups but still, it's just not right to make us wait when there's about 8 open larger tables available. 

I don't know if someone called out sick or what, but they just had one guy doing all the front end work, so we had to wait even longer for menus and service. 

Summary: Even though it was filling and tasted good, I will probably not go back. Hard to find parking and unnecessarily making us wait was a turn off. Add in insufficient staffing and I'm no longer interested.
author: Johnny D.

description:
In a city full of mediocre korean food, Han il Kwan probably ranks as one of the top 5 for me, which you can throw up there with My Tofu House and Doobu. And I'm korean, so take it for what it is.

I've been looking for any decent sullungtang all over the city, which is the korean version of a hangover cure and I wasn't disappointed with what I got here. The kimchi-jeon is amazing too!

Price is going to be on the higher end of korean restaurants in the city, but the place is well decorated and cleanly maintained.

Definitely coming back if I'm in the area.
author: Noah P.

description:
Well.......I give their food four stars especially the meat and the seafood bibimbap. BUT!!!!!!The service there really pissed me off. I've been there several times, and they rarely smile to the customers. They always pretend they are busy and dont listen to you. U have to be EXTREMELY patient to wait until they want to serve you. Also, BE SURE TO CHECK YOUR BILL!! They wont tell you the bill has included tips or not. Last time, we only had four people and they included the tips and didnt tell us, so we paid double tips for that poor service.....
TIPS: You HAVE to wait for a LONG LONG TIME...! 
           Korean groups(visitors) always have higher priority. If you get ignored, relax, it's their style of serving people who are not Korean. 
        Dont go there around 5-7pm. You will be srewed by the endless waiting...
       If you can have a spot once you walk into that place. Luck you!!!!! Go buy the lottery!!! OTHERWISE, just LEAVE. Get a ride on 38 to JP town. There are much more better korean food waiting for you!!!!
author: MemeJes W.

description: The food was great but service no so good. We went on a Sunday afternoon with friends that were visiting from San Diego. After they took our order we kept waiting for the side dishes to come, seeing that minutes later they didn't come out we had to ask one of the waiters for them. Our main dishes came before the appetizers so that was not good. In general the food was great! Awesome indeed but the service could be better.
author: Elizabeth D.

description:
The wait is long, unless it's a school night. I came here the other days with friends and it was AMAZING. We ordered two types of meat and a clay pot which rounded up to about $50. Considerably worth your money because along with the appetizers, the meat, and rice, my appetite was easily satisfied.

All in all, I would recommend the here if you're looking for a KBBQ place. It's worth it for a party of 5+! If less, it may be a little too pricey.
author: Roger Q.

description: It was not my first time at this restaurant but today I got the worse service ever. We waited 15 min before got seated which is ok to us, we shared a long table with 2 other parties which was ok too. One of the waitress took everyone orders then left and came back with the beverages, after that they started bringing out the side dishes for the 2 parties beside me, i thought well one of them got seated before us and the other one came with kids so we were ok to wait for our turn. But then they start bring out food for everyone else around us but not us, my cousin got to stop one of the waitress to ask how come we did not get our food yet because we ordered first, she yelled back at us "hold on", 10 min later she came back with food but for another table that got seated like half an hour after us and just ordered their food like 15 min ago, we were so pissed that we left right away. I barely post review on yelp, especially bad review like this but this restaurant thinks that they are so popular so they do not care about customer service anymore.
author: Hai Yen H.

description:
My friend and fellow Yelper, Tiffany C. and I decided to stop by because we have been hearing amazing things about this place from different people!

We came at 2 pm on a Saturday afternoon and were able to park in the tour bus only parking spot hahaha.

Tiff and I ordered WAY too much food than we could handle. We got the spicy pork dish, korean clear noodles dish, ALL the side dishes were fantastic and absolutely mouth-watering, tofu soup, and pancake. This was way too much food for two girls and lunch so we had plenty to bring home.

Spicy pork dish- Large portion, delicious in flavor and very tender meat. 

Clear noodles- Hmm, these noodles were only OK. Tiff and I agreed that it would be much better if they were warmer and not so soupey like. We had already ordered the non-soup noodles too.

Side dishes- Fishies, kimchi, seaweed salad, spicy pickle, etc. Out of all the side dishes, our favorite was the pancake. I wish I ordered it separately too but it was so crunchy, fresh and yummy! 

Tofu soup- The tofu was plentiful and the soup was actually really good and I am not usually a fan of tofu-soup. I'd actually order it here again! 

I plan to come back soon and bring my boyfriend to try this place!
author: Vikki K.

description:
Good food. I wasn't a big fan of the seafood pancake (in my opinion they put too much leek), but the tofu soup and all the ban chans were awesome! 

Service was very friendly and quick. 

Price was reasonable. A little cheaper than most Korean restaurant .

Oh and at the end of our meals, they gave us this sweet rice drink that was absolutely mind blowing! Great way to end the meal. 

Recommended!
author: Christina L.

description:
When I'm craving Korean BBQ, I go here.  Hands down.  My favorite dishes are the sweet marinated beef, spicy marinated pork!, and the japchae (silver noodles with veggies & assorted meats).  I shared these dishes with two other friends and there was PLENTY of food to go around.  We all left with happy tummies :D

Parking has never been a problem for me in this area which is always a great start for any hungry soul.  The interior atmosphere is like any comfortable Korean restaurant (some tables with burners and others without).  It's a great spot for both small and large groups.  The service was fair and food comes out pretty damn fast which is always appreciated :D  The price is excellent for the amount and quality of food.
author: Lynnie T.

description:
I have to say, of all the Korean restaurants I've eaten at in SF, this place has the best sides. They give you a free soup or steamed eggs, and pancakes.

Most of the dishes are good, just don't order the bu-go-gi (it's overcooked and dried the few times I've tried). I don't usually opt for the bbqing yourself on the table, it gets you smelling like bbq. The chef cooks it better anyway.
author: Loi L.

description:
I blame Yelp for this!!

I searched "tofu soup" and this place popped up. This place is NOT a tofu house -- I ordered what she said was tofu soup with vegetables and meat, the bibambap and bf had the seafood udon noodle soup.

First of all, we took a cab from SoMa for this!! It was like $15 to get here since we didn't feel like driving because we knew parking was a pain. When we got there, we were worried about our way back -- no cab in sight. This little restaurant was tucked away in a neighborhood area.

The cute thing was, there was a Korean Tour Bus in front of it -- looks like this place was legit!! So we got a nice booth, equipped with a grill in the middle and a fan above to suck of all the smoke -- too bad we were not going to grill.

One of the great things about this place is all the freebies/side dishes that you get!! They initially gave us a little pancake with a vinegar sauce. I liked it a lot! Then out came out the side dishes: kimchi, cucumbers with sesame seeds, pickled daikon, picked sliced radish, seaweed, little anchovies, bean sprouts and this tapioca square thingie. Quite honestly, I've tried better side dishes than this place.

Then our food came out. The bibambap was good, probably my favorite one. A nice hot clay pot of yummy gooeyness when mixed with their spicy sauce -- yummy!! But, the tofu soup had no flavor, barely any meat and was very thin. Not my favorite. My bf had the seafood udon noodle soup which came with this egg soup too. They put a lot of squid in the udon soup!! Just alright tasting food for above average prices. Not good.

The service was quick and efficient but they didn't come over to ask us if the food was okay. Maybe there was a language barrier? At the end, when she gave us the check, she gave us these little glasses of some sort of rice dessert. I was not particularly fond of it but my bf loved it. Took them both like shots of alcohol!!

I think this place is probably best for their grilling entrees, not tofu soups (or lackthereof). I'll probably be back to try it...

PS. Their bathroom is super weird and cramped!! But the decor is really cute!

PPS. Geary Blvd is a few blocks around the corner so you can find a cab along that street!
author: T L.

description:
Items Ordered:

Min. 2 bbg dishes
Chicken bbq
Bul bbq

Kimchi pancake 

Bbq came with banchan 

banchan so delicious. I love the way they make the radishes and kimchee. It's much sweeter than other restaurants. The portions are also bigger. 

I enjoyed everything about my meal. The service was great. It's good that we came before the tour bus came. The tour bus comes every 30 min with more people. I guess the restaurant has a contract with the bus comapny.
author: Lai P.

description:
Previous Yelpers Forewarned: SEE TOUR BUSES, GOOD LUCK!

3 Tour Buses?!!!  This was on a Tuesday night at 6 PM!!!  
The guy who said no availability at all,  recommended another place (said it's better than Brothers), so off we went ... 

Seriously 3 Tour Buses?!!!  Couldn't you have a little section of the restaurant for local/regulars (my friends who brought me here)? so sad. 

but Bookmarked Still "TO TRY" !!!  So Still Hoping!
author: Stel D.

description: Best Korean BBQ we've found so far in SF. Not quite the variety of banchan we get at our #1 rated Chung Kiwa in LA, but the quality of everything is really good here. The constant stream of Korean tourists bused in here is an indication of the quality.
author: Anthony B.

description:
Mmmmm, Korean BBQ. The only downside is that I really did leave smelling like I BBQ'd my jacket on the table stove.

Had the preset menu for 6-7 people and it was about $22/person (including bill, tax, + tip!) including all the food (kalbi and chicken on the grill, squid stuff, oyster/clam fried stuff, japchae, soon du boo, TONS of side dishes, mung bean pancake, rice) and some Soju and Hite beer.  

Their soju was kind of just ok for me, and Hite is, well, it's Hite.  You come here for the food.

There were more side dishes than one could want - different types of kim chi, steamed egg, bean sprouts, macaroni salad, tofu skin, little fish, and so much more.

There's only a few tables available so make reservations so you don't have to wait in the smoke of other people's food.

Parking is HORRIBLE in the area - it's street parking only.  It's in a pretty residential are of the Inner Richmond, but on weekend, no one is really leaving, so spaces are hard to come by.

Come hungry, leave smelling like meat and BBQ smoke.  Mmmmmm.
author: Traci H.

description: Han Il Kwan is one of the better Korean restaurants in SF. I came here for lunch and came away with an alright mean and decent service. They actually have the grills built into some of their tables but I didn't have any galbi on this occassion. I ordered the dolsot bibimbop and the seafood soondubu. It's hard to screw up bibimbop so that came out fine but the soondubu was awful. I don't hold the awful soondubu against them because there just isn't a good place for soondubu in SF. Otherwise they give you plenty of banchan and the prices are decent. The service wasn't great, but the restaurant itself has a real authentic Korean vibe to it. There are lots of tour buses parked outside on the weekends so keep that in mind. Otherwise, this is a good Korean joint by SF' standards but not in the grand scheme of things.
author: Ken C.

description:
The parking situation = sucky
The food = Decent
The service = Failure

The wife and I went here because we were craving some Korean BBQ and the place had a good rating. Joke's on us!

The beef soup bowl I ordered had about 2 tea-spoon sized portions of beef in it and a lot of cabbage and tofu. Now don't get me wrong, I love me some cabbage and tofu, but when you order a beef soup you expect beef to be the main attraction.

The scallop and vegetable plate was pretty good, though.

Maybe I just went on a bad night because it seemed like there was one server taking care of about 25 people. But all together I'd give this place two stars for the food, service, and parking.
author: Robert B.

description:
Best Korean lunch bargain and quality hands down.

Their lunch specials are easily under 12 bucks and they come with banchan (7 side dishes!), rice, two mini pancakes, TOFU SOUP or steam egg, and little rice dessert to drink at the end. You save so much on the free tofu soup itself and the portions and quality are no compromise. Service is great and plenty of seating. Definitely adding this place to my Top 10 best bang for your buck hidden jewels list!

Quick tip: lunch is Monday-Friday ends at 4pm. credit cards accepted.
author: Johanna P.

description: Service is not the best, but the food is worth the wait! Everything is delicious, generous portions ... come hungry!!
author: Amy W.

description:
My experience korean bbq friend took me here and it was my first time at a Korean BBQ so I was definitely the student and he was the teacher. 

We sat at the BBQ table and ordered the normal beef and pork belly. All of a sudden a bunch of appetizers come flying over and I was like whaaat? But I mixed stuff together and I really like the marinate on the meat.. If you've never had pork belly its a lot like bacon but fattier. They give you so much that I had to take it to go!

Overall it was a great experience and a very family style cuisine. I will definitely be exploring more korean bbq!

Thanks Mike for taking me there! :)
author: Lana K.

description:
My new favorite Korean place in San Francisco. Really good Korean food, lots of panchan (even 2 special panchan on the house), friendly service, and nice atmosphere inside.

The dolsot bi bim bap (in hot stone pot) was some of the best we've had. It came with a generous portion and the stone pot was so hot that the rice was still sizzling, creating an awesome rice crust for us to enjoy. Other places don't serve dolsot bbm with as hot of a pot and there isn't as much of a crust. And the red hot sauce I added was so good as I love a spicy Korean sauce.  The other dish we ordered - a tofu and veggie one - was also perfectly hot and spicy. 

We got all the panchan mentioned by others (and shown in the picture) as well as two extra hot side dishes that they gave us totally complimentary on the house - one was a small plate with two yummy Korean egg pancake-like things with ingredients mixed in it and the other was a mini-pot of tasty and fluffy steamed egg. That was super cool and definitely earned them some brownie points.

What was also impressive is their service efficiency. When we first approached this place, we were so worried about the wait given the 2 huge tour buses that stopped right in front and unloaded at least 90 people into the restaurant right as we were walking down the block toward the restaurant. I thought we would have to wait at least an hour with the madhouse of people. But I guess they handle large tour groups all the time and these 90 people sat down, were served their set menu, ate, were done, and out the door in about 45 minutes. So impressive. And we still received decent service at the same time. 

Only minor thing I didn't like was that you couldn't just order 1 portion of bulgogi (korean marinated grilled beef) - you had to order at minimum the portion for 2 for something like $40 that you bbq at your table. Also parking sucks since this is more of a residential neighborhood - we had to circle around 6 times around the surrounding blocks to find a spot.

Bottom line: Really good Korean with efficient service and good side dishes (and extra complimentary ones if you've been nice). Just get some good parking karma before you head over there.
author: Jim C.

description:
If Korean tour buses drop off Korean tourists to eat here, I'd think it's a pretty good indication that the place serves pretty good Korean food. And I feel exactly that way. 

Generally when I come here, it's for a party of 10+ people. They are really accommodating, don't charge extra for us using the rooms in the back, and never rush us to finish. Last Saturday, I ordered Bibimbap with seafood. It was so flavorful and absolutely delicious! It was so hot that it was crackling for half the time I was eating it! Make sure you keep stirring the food in the stone pot so you don't end up with dry rice. 

They always give us something on the house. This time, it was pancakes, steamed egg and a tofu stew. They are so nice. And the ban chan...yummy I tell ya! 

I found a small loophole in their beer pricing. Get two 12 oz bottles of beer and it'll cost the same as if you ordered one 20 oz bottle. Enjoy!
author: Diana C.

description:
Dear diary,

Last Sunday night after I lost track of the time due to unrelenting debauchery, I went on www.yelp.com (real people AND real reviews) to look for a nearby Korean restaurant. While other places on Yelp said they closed at 9:30 or not open on Sundays, a phone call to this place confirmed that it closed at 10 on Sundays. Although it was several miles away through local traffic along winding and roller coaster-like roads, I decided to depend on the 4 stars average (which this restaurant brags about via sign near the exit!) produced by Yelp's real people.

Han Il Kwan was on the corner of Balboa and 19th almost camouflaged among residential houses (which all look the same in San Francisco) were it not for the shining beacon that was the sign for the restaurant. Parking was difficult to find that late, but I did not have to walk more than a block.

Good thing it opens that late because there were two other groups eating with us, also seated along the window for the world to see how great the place was. The servers seemed quite attentive: I made eye contact with one, and she took our order. They regularly came by to check on us, and I was able to get more banchan and napkins without having to ask. They also seemed well versed in both Korean and English.

The banchan came in three waves (without counting the steamed egg "on the house"). Good Lord, I should not have ordered three items for two people. But I felt like I might as well be baller after driving a grueling 7 miles in the city, damn. Banchan was delicious, food was delicious, and even the egg was delicious (I usually do not like egg). By the way I ordered the "thick beef soup" (sullung tang), "pan fried pollack" and "fried meat dumplings." I kept the receipt in my pocket for 3 days solely to report to the Yelp community. Please make me an elite one day. 

One thing I would noted was the relatively steep price on certain items. Others were decently priced for the area. The exit also smelled like newspaper drenched in urine.

I would like to return here for the lunch special, but I forget if it is available during weekends. I would not call myself a fan, but I am giving it 4 stars for its excellent food and especially excellent service (these are the people who actually deserve tips).

Good night diary,
Brian

Update: I can consider myself a fan or at least a supporter because I find often myself referring to this place when I talk about Korean food.
author: Brian H.

description: This is my absolute favorite KBBQ in San Francisco. It's quite well known, which means you will often get lines. The restaurant also regularly has tour buses come in adding to the wait. Even so, when you come at the right time or decide to wait, you won't be disappointed. There are a good number of delicious ban chans (my favorite is the bean sprout one. I can eat three plates on my own). The complimentary soft tofu soup is decent. I always choose to cook at the table and my absolute favorite meats are bulgogi, kalbi, and samgyeopsal (pork belly). If I had to complain about the food, it would be that the samgyeopsal isn't fresh but frozen (samgyeopsal is hard to find raw, in my experience). Overlooking that, the marinade is delicious for all meats. I like the food enough to look over this one waiter who is a bit standoffish. I've brought many different friends and they've all had a great experience, leaving with satisfied bellies.
author: Valerie Z.

description:
=Han II Kawn=

Korean BBQ! We had to wait awhile for a friend to arrive. In the meantime, we ordered Chap Chae to start with. Out came the tiny little yummy side dishes. We probably went through 4 sweet cucumbers, those little tofu slices, and beansprouts. lolz. I almost got stuffed off those! We didn't grill things ourselves, just ordered prepared food to come out.

The Chap Chae is perfectly cooked! Mmmm mmm good is all I'm going to say. It comes with beef too mixed all up in there.

Ordered the marinated grilled beef and it didn't taste like it was marinated enough :(. More on the dry side. 

The house soup had the balance of spicyness and lots of tofu! Yummy. Well balanced IMHO.

Out came Chicken and Vegetables. I have to say that it looks like it's drenched in spicy flavored sauce, but it had a dash of tangyness and a little jolt of sweetness in the sauce which tasted really good. The chicken was not too salty like most chicken would be, and the veggies were nice and fresh. Give this a try :)

We then ordered the squid. Not sure what was the dish name, but it had a lot of hotsauce all over it with onions and vegetables. I'm not  a squid eater, but I tried one little piece and it was really well cooked! Not rubbery overcooked, just right. I was sure not to eat any with sucker feet on it. haha

The air in here was nice and cooled and well ventilated so you don't smell like BBQ when you leave. Spacious tables and very very friendly waiters.

The house tea - wow it's addicting. It has a rice flavor to it with the perfect taste. I drink I drank over 20 little tea cups.. lol

If you're looking for a good and friendly korean restaurant, come by here and dig your chopsticks into some yummy goodness!
author: Christopher J.

description:
Talk about getting a lot for a little. 

I'm a new Richmond resident and, after walking by Han Il Kwan every day, I decided to give it a try. I stopped in for an appetizer and ended up getting more than enough for a whole meal! 

The Kim Chee pancake (which was the only thing I actually ordered) was coupled with about 8 free, small dishes, as well as free tea and a rice drink at the end of the meal. Everything was fresh and delicious, and they even take credit cards. 

Of the 8,734,242 restaurants of Korean/Chinese/Vietnamese descent in the Richmond, I think I've found a solid one.
author: Tom A.

description:
You're immediately greeted with a nice pot of barley tea, pretty much as you sit down.

Dolsot Bi Bim Bap is awesome here.
I'm careful not to disturb the sizzling and crackling rice on the bottom of the stone pot. This way, I get to enjoy the crunchy goodness later.

You also get about 8 small dishes of assorted snacks... perfect for some beer.... my favorite, crunchy anchovy.

House soup, tofu based and desert, a sweet rice drink are also comped.

Parking here is scarce.... the Balboa 31? from the Ferry Building stops right in front of here.
author: Geordie E.

description:
EDIT:  2/6/07

I went again a couple of days and and again was comped this delicious steamed egg with green onion dish that made me think of my mommy.  Anything that makes me think of my mommy gets an extra star. 

Our meal for 3 people with PLENTY of leftovers was only around 35 bucks.  I think I've found a SF favorite Korean place.

The best Korean dining can be found in Santa Clara, bar none.  However, this place a close second.  For around $22 a person, we had an ample amount of food and tried many yummy things.

Our dinner consisted of:

- Kal Bi
- Kim Chee Bi Bim Bap
- Fried Kim Chee Cake 
- Cold soba noodles
- FREE tofu soup

I found the kal bi to be mediocre - a little under cooked, imo.  However, it could be that I'm more accustomed to bul gol gee & it was cooked by the kitchen.  The little dishes were AWESOME - worthwhile going just for them!

My favorites were the soup (comped because of our wait...which wasn't that long, but much appreciated) and the bi bim bap.  This is the BEST bi bim bap I've had, in fact.  I'm not a fan of cold noodle, but my friend seemed to enjoy it.  The kim chee cakes were okay - a bit bland, but eh.  I much prefer the fried seafood cakes that are part of the little dishes.  

Overally, I think the prices are decent, the service is good and heck, if Korean tourists are dropped off there ... this place MUST be quite exceptional.
author: Helen F.

description: Food was really good, but the soup would have been better if it was less saltier. Service was okay.
author: Jazzlynn L.

description:
As soon as we arrived at Han Il Kwan, I saw a tour bus drive up, and we found ourselves in the midst of a crowd as we walked into the restaurant.  The hostess was nowhere to be found, and after waiting, waiting ... and waiting, I asked one of the waitstaff whether there was a table available for 3.  He didn't even bother to look up and stoically exclaimed, "no!"  

With a first experience like that, I won't be going back to Han Il Kwan no matter how good the food may be, as there are PLENTY of Korean restaurant, literally within 1-2 mile diameter, that actually welcome patrons who do not arrive on a tour bus.
author: S. I.

description:
I came here with my friend and we ordered so much food for just 2 people. We ordered the Chapchae, BBQ Pork, BiBimBap, & Kimchi Pancake. It was way too much. Everything was so good though!! The side dishes were amazinnggg! 

I would definitely return to this place and try the BBQ since I came for lunch last time.
author: Polly L.

description:
If the Richmond weren't so far away I would come more often...it seems every time I do I always enjoy it!

Two of us ordered two barbecue meats: bulgogi and pork belly, mmm.  What we got was an incredible amount of food:
- two large platters of meat
- ten (!!) different appetizer dishes (I was a very big fan of the kimchee)
- two bowls of rice
- soon tofu (I noticed the lack of raw egg, very practical in light of all that salmonella)
- lettuce (try wrapping meat with kimchee, sprouts, and cucumber.  or just play around!) (watch out it gets really drippy and messy)
- fried egg pancakes
-and to end, a sweet rice dessert drink.  It was very refreshing!

Of course, my hair and clothes smelled like smoke, but it was totally worth it...
author: Cathy Y.

description:
I live a block from here, so I pretty much HAVE to write a review.

My Richmond neighbors - there is parking, i repeat, PARKING in front of this establishment after 11 pm and before 10 am (i think)!! As long as you move your car so the tour bus full of other korean ahjumas and ajushis can park, you're good.

Food here is pretty good compared to the rest of San Francisco. I don't actually like their soon dubu, but the bimbimbap is decent. Side dishes are good too. Service is a hit or miss depending on who is in the restaurant; my friends have had a pretty bad experience (see Thanh T.'s review). There have been times where I've been mistaken for a Korean and gotten extra dishes on the side. Free food is always good to me. 

I wish I could be able to make smaller orders, but all their sizes are the same. so you end up having either 1) no variety with 1 HUGE order of jap chae or you get 2) variety but wayyy too much food with 3 HUGE orders of jap chae, dukbokki, and seafood pancake.

I'll be moving out of the Richmond soon... and HIK, I'll miss you!
author: A Y.

description: Wow.....I've passed this place many times, but was always turned-off by the tourist buses parked outside.  I was off on a Friday, so decided to give it go. Great decision!  I went for the lunch special and it was not disappointing.  Generous portions for a value price (got the spicy pork - $8.50).  The lunch specials also come with many side dishes and tofu soup.  In and out with a full belly and change left my pocket.  Will definitely return!!
author: J J.

description: Foods are really good.but the rice cake is not as good as the other Korean restaurants.They really should take care of the customers and tour people at the same time.That Korean woman should stop acting so rude.#25 is definitely recommend:)
author: Xi P.

description:
I was really excited to try this place. I read the reviews and was undaunted by the thought of the tour busses. After all, I think its great that local businesses benefit from the tourism to San Francisco.

This evening we decided to go there for dinner. We found parking and as we were locking the car we saw a tour bus coming up the street. We looked at each other and hustled ourselves in the door. 

The was barely anyone in the restaurant. There were tables that were obviously reserved and set up for the large tour bus party. There were also small tables that were empty. It would appear that there was enough room to accommodate the large party arriving AND us, a party of 2. 

But no, we were told the wait would be 45 minutes...and so we left. The women didn't even seem sorry to turn us away. 

We wont be going back even if it is this highly rated for the food on yelp. I'd rather give my money to somewhere that ALSO appreciates its LOCAL business.
author: julia h.

description: Not the worst, but not the best either.  Very full restaurant, we had a hard time getting a seat even though there were open tables.  A tour bus apparently stops in here with regularity, it got really busy half way through.  The Tofu Soup was a delight.  The BiBimBop was very dry without flavor or any kind of liquid beyond the egg.
author: Ann M.

description:
first time here. even tho i live 3 blocks away. lol 

always drove past this place and see that huge Korean tour bus parked right at the front filled with about 50 passengers. I dont recall the exact names of what we ordered but we had the kim chee pancake, grilled chicken, and some other dishes.

The kim chee pancake was okay. Pretty bland in flavor but i am no fan of kim chee.

The grilled chicken was good and my favorite dish. The portion sizes were good. This was enough to feed 4 people with big appetites.

I thought the service could be much better. Seems to me they treat certain groups of people better than others.
author: Jeff C.

description: kbbq was overpriced by a lot, and most were burnt as well. Definitely not worth $30, but the service and others were alright.
author: Josh Y.

description: Great food.  I love the ban chan.  Their sweet rice dessert drink is delicious.  The servers aren't quite culturally adapted to their San Francisco clients.  There are always buses full of Korean tourists lining along 21st.  A good sign for sure.
author: Elico C.

description:
Came here to celebrate a friend's birthday on a Sunday night.  We made a reservation on the same day and when we go there, they seated us promptly.  For such a large party like ours (table of 11), we were seated in the back in one of "four" rooms.  Their "four" rooms are all divided by your old school accordion room dividers and can open up to seat larger parties such as 20 or more.  

This is by far one of the better Korean restaurants in SF AND very comparable to the Korean food in K-town in LA.  The only thing they are missing is the noodle wrap that goes with you meats. *Sigh*.. just thinking about the noodle wrap is making me want to drive to LA for some awesome Korean food. Well at least I found this place to hold me over until I can get down to LA.  

Ok now to the food!  I ordered a Bi Bi Pap for myself and shared the Short Ribs and Kimichi Pancake with my friends. OMG the Kimichi Pancake was the BEST I've ever had.  It was so flavorful and you could actually taste the Kimchi.  Most places I've had it always made it too bland and you couldn't really taste the Kimchi.  The Short Ribs were marinated just right and the flavor really came through after being barbecued.  The Bi Bi Pap is pretty much like your typical Bi Bi Pap...hot. LOL.  Make sure you eat this slowly as the dish is kept warm by the hot stone pot it is served in.  The best part of the meal is the FREE little appetizers they give you to go with your meal.  They're mostly cold vegetable dishes to help balance the meat and hot dishes you're about eat. Also as a freebie, they give you Spicy Soft Tofu Soup, which tasted AMAZING.  There was an extra kick that is left in your mouth after slurping this magnificent soup. Then finally for dessert, they give you a malted sweet rice drink that was DE-LISH. I kept asking for more =D. 

This is my new go to Korean place when I'm in the mood for Korean.  Sorry, My Tofu House.
author: Bertie Y.

description:
NOTE: Takeout only

My sis was craving for tofu soup so I Yelped and found that this was the closest to her house and that it had good reviews. 

We ordered a lot of food, most of them I forgot the names...but of course, I didn't forget my order! I had the bul go gi and it was plain tasting. Nothing special...

Overall, we received a ton of side dishes and everyone seemed to like their food. Hopefully we'll be able to try it out again for dine-in...
author: Cath M.

description: One of the better Korean BBQ restaurants in the city, and more reasonable than the others on Geary.  The kimchi side dishes are top notch and they'll refill them.  The gal-bi. bulgogi. and pork are really good, and the lunch prices are very reasonable.  Parking is a hassle though.  It's not the best I've had, compared to Woo Lae Oak in LA or some in Santa Clara, but it's up there and it's reasonably priced.  And yes, the service is not friendly, but as a foodie, I don't care that much.
author: Gregory N.

description:
I came in here with my boyfriend for some Korean lunch. Unfortunately, the restaurant was bogged down with 2 huge reservations back to back, so we came in at a bad time.

It took 10 minutes for anyone to even notice us, it took another 10 minutes to get seated, it took another 10 minutes to get menus, and it took another 10 minutes to get tea and eating utensils, and then another 20 minutes to get our food. It was just way too long. I understood that it was not ideal circumstances, but I work at a restaurant too and that was just ridiculous. The side dishes didn't even come out until right before our food, which by then, we were starving.

The food was good, but it wasn't the most fabulous Korean food I've ever had. I ordered jigae and my boyfriend got the bibimbap. We tried to order the lunch specials, but they wouldn't let us even though according to the menu, we should've still been allowed to. The one good thing was that they use real stone pots so it stays warm for a real long time, not those fake ones.

Anyway, I should try to give this place one more chance because the circumstances weren't really their fault, but nothing really impressed me enough to want to go again.
author: Momo C.

description:
Definitely a fan!

This place is fantastic. I live only a few blocks away from Han II Kwan and finally had the chance to try it with my best friend! We didn't have to wait too long at all. There was only one waiter when we went, but he was great! Super nice, gave us everything we needed, etc. 

They give you THEE most side dishes for a Korean restaurant I've ever seen. The waiter was so nice, he refilled our "oh-deng" (that's how you say it, I'm not sure how to spell it) for free, even though they usually don't give refills during lunch time! Everything was there, the fish cakes, the kimchi, the cucumbers ... even the kim chi pancakes! They give you mini ones! 

I had the chicken bulgogi and it was super yummy. I love Korean restaurants where I don't have to cook myself (: 

Han II Kwan is rather reasonable, too. I thought this place had a reputation of being more on the expensive side, but for what you get, it's definitely not! They're raising the prices as of Dec. 1 2010 about 5-10%, so go there ASAP! 

Of course I'll go again anyways; such a great setting and environment. Who knew we'd find a jewel in the middle of a residential area! (:
author: Chrisy Y.

description: After eating at all you can eat kbbq places LAs koreatown, this place is a joke. Overpriced, small portions, and not all you can eat.  $20-$30 for each small plate of meat.  The only thing bringing me back here is my yellow fever.  Looking forward to my next trip to LA for proper kbbq
author: Jordan s.

description:
I usually plan my Korean BBQ outfit and after-dinner activities carefully: cotton-only garments, nothing that requires dry cleaning, no activities in close proximity to strangers (i.e. no choice but to go to a Noraebang) and immediate shower as soon as I get home. Han Il Kwan has great ventilation, so none of those things were really necessary. (but we did them anyway)

As for the food, if you have never had Korean in SoCal, it's pretty good. I'd say about as good as some of the better places in NYC or Queens. Of the 5 meats we ordered (seasoned and unseasoned Kalbi , Bulgogi, Spicy Pork, Pork Belly), I'd say the meat and marinade quality were average, but they are definitely not stingy with quantity. Don't expect much from the service, you'll be cutting and grilling all your own meat, but thats all part of the fun right? While their Soondooboo Jigae was totally bland and watery, the banchan was pretty good and they had a decent number (8 or so). However, if you are expecting SoCal level Korean, just stay home, there is no point.

One thing though, this place is in a totally sleepy residential part of town. In other words parking is a complete and total b*tch. And I mean TOTAL biatch!! The up side to the 1 mile walk back to your car is that it will help undo some of the damage from the whole cow sitting in your stomach at the end of the night.
author: Snuffles B.

description: Great Korean BBQ. Get your patience when going there, you'll need a 20-min waiting to get seated. But that's well worth it once on the table. Yummy.
author: Victor G.

description:
They made us wait 20 minutes when 4 empty tables were available...Im hope the food is everything its hyped up to be.

update:
The food was good. I wouldn't say it was spectacular like most people say, but good nonetheless. But we did get a LOT of food which was awesome. Service was nonexistent. even picking up the bill took a long time.
