Overall good food and good helpings. Slow service and a bit pricey.
author: Brian T.

description:
2 stars on yelp = "meh. i've experienced better" and i definitely think this is an accurate description of my experience here. 

i have to say, i'm quite disappointed with korean food in sf, except for My Tofu House, which has AMAZING tofu soup. 

came here on a sunday night and it got pretty crowded by about 7 or 8pm. we got here, quite hungry and ready to feast. We ordered 
*tofu soup - probably one of the worst i've had because it literally tasted like they just added some water, spicy seasoning, and tofu in the soup. it barely looked like it was well cooked. they also didn't give the egg to crack into the tofu soup
*bi bim bap - my friends got the bi bim bap in the clay pot and they didn't seem to enjoy it too much. and, they didn't give the egg!
*korean beef broth soup - it was meh not too flavorful. 

on the up side, they do give lots of banchans. we got the regular side dishes, korean pancakes, and steamed egg. however, i'd rather get good food then a bunch of side dishes.
author: Joyce B.

description: Good thing the reviews for this place were great; we really had a good time there. I mean the side dishes were all fantastic and the service was awesome and the seafood pancake wad delish!!! I'd definitely be taking my sister back here to try since she's tried a few korean bbq places in socal but this one topped my list. We weren't seated right away because we wanted to bbq but nonetheless, the staff was great and the wait wasn't too bad. Plus once your seated, they are very quick in getting what you need. We did the bul go gi and the spicy pork and they were both marinated well and plentiful. Not only that but they were very good at making sure they change the grill so the meat doesn't get charred. Definitely will be coming back.
author: Vanessa P.

description: I am in love with this place!  I love the Kalbi here!  I miss it just thinking about it.  I often come here and ask to bbq the meat myself even though my friends and I have no idea what we're doing.  It's just more fun that way.  Thank God one of the waiters was very helpful!  The first time he cooked the entire 3 orders of meat for us whenever he was free to help.  This past time he took time to teach us and was very patient with us!  We know how to bbq by ourselves now!  He also taught us how to fun combinations to eat our food!  Great service but come early.  I usually come around 5:30-6:30pm and can get a table easily.  I usually come on weeknights though so don't take my word on it for the weekends.  ENJOY!
author: Anita L.

description: Last Saturday was the last time my partner and I will return here. We have been regulars for the past 3 years, but are tired of the horrible service and deteriorating food quality. The spicy pork has slowly gone from one of our favorite entrees, to something borderline inedible. The servers at this restaurant also blatantly prioritize the customers from the tour buses and scoff at you for simple requests like "May I please have the check?" or "May I have water?" I can understand being understaffed, but being openly rude is unacceptable.
author: Darius M.

description: Group of three on a busy Thursday night.  We had to wait a good 25 minutes for a BBQ table but it was worth it.  We had the usual Korean fare in America. All WAY above average, including the banchan. Swift and nice service.
author: Patale M.

description: Lunch prices are a reasonable price (less than $10 before tax for the most part).  Good portions, anything you order comes with tofu soup and unlimited small dish things.  Tastes pretty good.
author: Javier G.

description:
After reading a few reviews, I felt nervous as I walked towards the restaurant.... with a tour bus parked outside. However, there were free tables and we were seated immediately. The service was quick but after we were served our food, it was pretty hard to catch one of the waiters or maybe it's just because of where we sat. The banchan was really good. I liked pretty much each and every one of the dishes except for that gelatin-ish stuff. None of us could figure out what it was and it pretty much had no taste. Tell me if you know! The free tofu soup and mung bean pancakes were good as well. Grilling the meats was pretty fun.. until you're done and the sugars just burn and burn. There was plenty left over and we all left stuffed. Yum yum. I don't know if it's just me but I really liked their water. It just tasted so crisp and fresh. 

What was that rice drink thing that they give at the end? It was tasted interesting... but kinda good at the same time. 

Also... parking didn't suck! Maybe I was just lucky but I got a good spot right by the restaurant. There were a few other open spots as well. =)
author: Katherine C.

description:
Disclosures: 
- I'm not Korean. 
- I have had Korean BBQ in the bay area 3 times and all at Ohgane in Oakland. 
- I live very close to this place so I decided to support my local neighborhood by trying more eateries in the Richmond area

OMG, the best Pork Bul Go-Ki ever!
Yes, even better then Ohgane in Oakville. The flavor and portions are very good in this smokey joint. 

The pros:
- Flavor of the Pork Bul Go-Ki and every dish coming out to fellow patrons looked amazing
- Good but not great soft tofu soup

The cons
- Service was disappointing at best
- We were seating promptly, placed our orders promptly 
- We unfortunately waited 40 minutes for our basic orders (one order of Pork Bul Go-Ki and two tofu soups)
- We watched while two other tables who came in 15 - 20 minutes after us (one table of 2 and one table of 4) were served there dishes within minutes of ordering
- It was truly sad to watch all these dishes flying by and none of them were ours
- I flagged down a different server and they came and set something on our table that we didn't order, it went to the table that came in way after us. 
- The place is too smoky if you want to us the restroom you will stand outside the line of the kitchen which is basically blowing BBQ smoke all over your clothes 
- The smoke was so bad at one point my eyes started to water and I needed to get our check bad!

Advise to the owners: 
- Your local non-Korean patrons are important too
- I would do something more then add egg soup or our order when you realized you screwed up
- I would start handing out wet wipes to avoid a long line at the bathroom when many people are likely just trying to wash there hands

Advise to future patrons who love Korean BBQ: 
- Order take out!
- Have your Korean speaking friend order take out on your behalf
author: Kristina A.

description:
We arrived at the restaurant just a bit after 8pm. The service was great. The food was awesome and the spice was perfect. I highly recommend this restaurant to everyone who is willing to have dinner after 7pm.

Cons: Tour buses have priority seating until 7pm, then the restaurant welcomes the public.
author: Mscee M.

description:
We came here just in the nick of time because there were two large tour buses stopping in for dinner.

The dot sol bi bimbap was good because there was enough "crispy" rice on the bottom of the stone pot.  The panchan were pretty good.  

They gave a free "tofu soup" (which is a bit softer and better than the soondubu per my last review).

Japchae was pretty good as well. 

Service was prompt when asked for something (even if they were running on a 3 person waitstaff when the restaurant was FULL)
author: Jboogie L.

description: My friends took me here several times. We had korean foods of course such as beef, chicken, rice bowl, and other small side dishes. They were served hot and warm, and some of them were still boiling when it arrived on the table. We all enjoyed our meals here.
author: Serena Z.

description:
This place is a little far from everywhere else I go in my life except for my girlfriend's hair salon. So after picking her up from there, we headed over here to give it a try. A big part of this motivation was the picture of green bean pancakes on Yelp, actually.

Located in a nondescript area that seems a bit shady, we found parking within a block and made our way over. The restaurant itself is actually quite nice, and nicer still once inside. Also, after we ordered our food, a tour bus full of Korean tourists showed up and took half the restaurant, which we took as a good sign. It didn't seem to slow down service by too much, either, as they had everything prepared.

Banchan were of higher quality than I am used to, which was nice. Green bean pancakes are indeed a very good value, as we got a giant plate for less than $10. The chap-chae (japchae?) was excellent as well. I could run through every item we got, but I'll just say that pretty much everything here seems to be a cut above all the Korean restaurants I frequent.

Now if only I had more reason to be in the area, I could come here more often.
author: David H.

description:
Thanks to Yelpers, I decided to give it a try for my son's 15th birthday. My daughter wanted to cook the food herself, so regardless the high price. For grilling your food on the table, 2 orders are minimum. We had the beef rib eye and chicken with all those side dishes, soup and rice. It was actually enough for the 3 of us, but since it was my son's birthday, I allowed him to pick 2 more dishes. So, we got Mackerel and pan fried tofu. 
The meat was pretty well marinated, just about right. We enjoyed the grill. Fun for the kids. It is pricey, but the food was great. I wouldnt come back for dinner, but maybe lunch. Overall, its a nice place. We were lucky, soon after we came in, a tour bus arrived with a crowd. If you wanna get a space to park, come early as we did (5pm). There were already 2 tables when we got there. One bad thing, there's only one waiter. We had to wait quite some time before he noticed me (for the check).
author: The Black Cat C.

description:
3 1/2 stars.  Despite having passed by this place thousands of times, I have only eaten at Han Il Kwan once, and it was pretty recent.  I went there for lunch with several relatives, and much food was ordered.   The kal-bi beef and bbq pork were good.  So was the spicy tofu bowl, although I wish it would have come with an egg.  My one major criticism is with the seafood dish we ordered.  The squid was really tough and rubbery. 

Overall, I liked Han Il Kwan, and will definitely consider eating there again whenever I'm in the City visiting relatives.
author: Rogelio H.

description:
We like going to this place for some easy (not the parking!!) good, fulfilling Korean food. Granted that Korean isn't the cheapest dining option out there, I still crave it now and then. I guess the "free" banchan is rolled into the price, but hey, just keep getting refills then!
This place works out great for large group dining, they have a room in the back that can accomodate, but just make sure to call in advance, especially on the weekends.

I almost always have to get the Bi Bim Bab here and/or Jap Chae; their fishcake is good and I don't even normally eat fish! Mmm most everything we've had here is pretty good and meant to be shared. You can opt to not cook at the table, so that you don't end up smelling like bbq...unless you do want to. 

Our most recent visit, we were stuffed like no tomorrow and wished we had back up lol. Service on weeknight was superb. It wasn't one of their busy nights, but still a decent amount of patrons. We didn't need to annoyingly wait around and hope to flag down our waiter, which are sometimes MIA at other establishments on non-busy nights. Food came out fast, our side dishes were replenished even though we didn't ask for it; our bill and boxes were brought to us when we were ready, no need to even ask. 

Now only if SF can get an all-you-can-eat Korean bbq in the city....  :)
author: Ly T.

description:
If I could, I would name this place Kim Jong Il b/c this place just DOMINATES all other korean places.   Like all half starved north koreans who cry at the very sound of his name, I cry just a little hearing Han Il Kwan's name.  Oh my GAWD this place is the bestest.

So I'm not a N. Korean...or hell I wouldn't have access to the internet to write this review.  I'm not even Korean.  But I'm a NYC transplant who spent more than a few night partying at 3rd floor Cafe or Kamel.  

My favs - kimchi jigae, octopussy stir fried goodness and the white-ies favorite-- kalbi.  yeah i can marinate it at home w/ some pear juice for 1/4 the price, but i'm lazy and want my kalbi NOW!
author: Jae H.

description: Delicious BBQ and sides! Only downside is the wait staff. Terribly short-handed staff for the dinner rush. In addition, the waitresses walk around but look right through you when you try to signal them over! The waitresses treat you like idiots and only comes over to take over the grilling you're doing if they see that you are not grilling the 'proper' way! How rude! They love butting in when they aren't needed. It was annoying to the point where we had to put the tongs out of their reach so they would leave us alone! They're condescending and rude most of the time, especially the older waitresses...
author: Jackie C.

description: I called in today and made reservations for a large group at 6:30pm. My family and I ended up getting there early around 5:50pm but the rude gentleman with the mustache told us to come back at 6:30pm as they did not have any tables ready yet. That was fine (even though the restaurant was half empty) but his attitude was not. My cousin asked politely if we could be seated a bit sooner as we had 3 older family members with us but he curtly said no and walked away. After waiting a while, we decided to take our business elsewhere but he told us the table would be ready in 5 minutes. After some back and forth and him telling me to "calm down" and rolling his eyes at my cousin, we finally left and found a place nearby that was able to seat is right away. The lesson of the story is to always treat your customers with respect and this guy definitely did not. I work in the service industry and this was just a complete disappointment. Needless to say I definitely won't be coming back here.
author: Annie N.

description: Probably the best korean bbq in this area. However, I lived in Los Angeles so unfortunately, this doesn't compare to anything that they serve in K-town. Coming from LA, the meat quality wasn't as good and the price was almost 1.5 times higher.I went with my buddy and we ordered two plates of kalbi + egg soup + bean soup and it came out to $45-46/per person including tip. Great service but I wouldn't wait 1hr for this restarauant again.
author: Ricky M.

description: Nice food, a bit pricey though. Great ambience inside, good for family, easy parking, Great bbq, overall it's great
author: Darren G.

description:
My honest opinion- this would be 3 1/2 to 4 stars.

Firstly, what a trip to eat here around dinner time and see bus-loads of people come in, eat in the back room, then leave after 20 minutes only to see it all over again with another bus-load of people!  They must do a lot of business with several Korean tour groups.

Anyway, this place is a bit of fresh air for not having much to choose from in terms of decent Korean food in the city.  Oddly enough, I discovered this place when I was applying for my current residence because my property management office is located right next door.   The restaurant is  located in a mostly residential neighborhood so it is a bit strange to see this place here.  Parking is possible (it being away from downtown and other high-traffic areas) but Balboa St./Inner Richmond can be challenging some times.

Food- This is four-star worthy for sure for SF.  I've been here many times and have had pretty much the staple dishes. They don't specialize in anything particular, but if you stick to the popular dishes (grills/barbeque,  chigaes), you're good. I did order galbi-chim once and was disappointed that the beef didn't fall off the bone (it tasted like they boiled the beef and then put it in the stew instead of having it slow-cooked).  But props for what they give you- I asked for lettuce for ssam (wrap) and they gave me plenty.  Banchan amount was decent.  I also like how this is one of the few places that actually serves Kimchee jun, so props.
author: I love t.

description:
I've lived across the street from Han Il Kwan for almost 3 years and I'm embarrassed to say I'd never eaten there.  My craving for Korean BBQ is somewhat rare and typically satisfied by a trip to Brothers on Geary.   

The timing was right on Friday night when MCM and I were sipping homemade pineapple martinis and contemplating the spaghetti dinner we'd planned to make when the smell of BBQ wafted in the window.  We had one of those "Are you thinking what I am thinking?" moments and made for the door  in hopes of getting a table in between the bus loads of tourists.  (I kid you not there are at least 3-4 bus loads of Korean tourists there a day - they even have special bus parking in front.)

We got a table right away (thanks to good timing) and had the most delicious meal.  We grilled thin slices of spicy rib eye and marinated chicken at our table and had fun pairing bites of meat with the many side dishes.  MCM didn't much like the sizzling tofu soup but I thought it was fabulous.  We had enough food leftover to have a sizable lunch next day.  We're going back again for sure but with a bigger group so we can sample an even larger variety of dishes. 

This place is worth the search for parking.  Try Cabrillo Ave. or offer to buy me dinner and you can park in my driveway. :)
author: Julienne G.

description:
Okay, tell me why I didn't know that Korean food was my soulmate until last month? Now I have 24+ years to catch-up on. 

How do I love thee? Let me count the ways...

1. Bibimbap. Alone, reason enough for me to declare my undying love for Koreans. Rice, vegetables, beef, and egg in one bowl...MEANT to be mixed all together. As someone who prefers to have all her food placed in one dish, eaten with a spoon, and mixed together (I like to have ALL flavors in my mouth at once!), bibimbap is my new Jesus.  

2. Panchan. FREE assorted little dishes of pickled goodness; kimchis galore. They literally covered the table.

3. Mung bean pancakes. Heaven when dipped in that side of sesame sauce...and FREE.

4. Tofu soup. Best tofu soup I've ever had. FREE.

5. Sikhye. Sweet rice drink served after your meal, as a dessert. Yummy, and yes, you guessed it--FREE.

7. Great service. The guys that work here are really sweet and happy to answer any questions you might have about their menu.

Now we just got to rally up all these Korean restaurants out of the Richmond into downtown. Me no likey traveling to the end of the earth for your amazing food, but you know that I will.
author: Kristine W.

description:
I really don't understand what's the BFD about this place. It was alright....

I've had better Korean food. I just remember another regular tofu soup, nothing really special about it.

Lots and lots of korean tourists taking up the seats! So be prepared to wait if needed.

On the plus side, free side dishes!
author: Tammy S.

description:
I thought the banchan were deeeeeeeeeliciouso. Like so omnomnom good. For realz.

I enjoyed my tofu soup a lot as well.
author: Dina G.

description: The service here is great. The people help you replace the grill almost immediately. They also help you or teach you how to grill. When something wrong happens, then they try to solve the problem. The sweet rice drink at the end is good. I also like how the tea here is very different from other teas that i have ever tasted. It has a rice taste to it. Also, the rice that they give is also pretty good. It is very clean here too. However, I would say that the sauces of the food is not entirely to my taste, but it still tastes amazing.
author: Suki L.

description:
Mah-shee-soy-yoh. That's Korean for, "damn, that tastes good." And everything I've ever had at Han Il Kwan tastes good. Granted, I'm a vegetarian, so I'm sure I'm missing out on the finest they have to offer. My brood swears by the bulgogi and kalbi. They can't bring it out fast enough, and they offer the option of letting them cook it, or grilling it at the table. But what's truly amazing is that, in this environment, my kids will eat all manner of ban chan without batting an eye. 

The dishes are prepared by two ahjumahs that never leave the kitchen. These women are for serious. Service is mostly great, especially when someone in your group speaks Korean. In fact, this will almost guarantee you some free kim chi chiggae or pan dhuk. They lose a star, however, because of their occasional inability to seat customers AT ALL EVER due to a massive influx of Korean tourists. This spot is a routine dinner destination for the Big White Korean Tourbus circuit. I have seen three buses pull up, disengorge hungry passengers, and swamp the place. So be sure to call ahead to make sure no tours are scheduled, or to confirm some availability despite them. 

I generally order the be bim bap (vegetarian) or the kim chee dul sot (also vegetarian.) The latter is one of the most flavorful, savory, and irresistible things I have ever eaten. It comes in a scalding clay pot with a raw egg cracked over the top, that cooks as you stir the pot. While you eat, the bottom layer of rice forms into a crisp, creating a worthy reward for members of the Clean Your Plate club.  

Pair this with an ice-cold Hite, and we're in business. As is typical of Korean restaurants, there is no dessert to speak of, though they do bring the sweet rice drink that is a traditional closure to the meal. 

Oh, one other thing...Han Il Kwan will donate 20% of your dining tab to my sons' PUBLIC school. That's right, PUBLIC school. San Francisco offers one of only two Korean Immersion Public school programs in the United States, and this restaurant supports the program with these donations, which we need now more than ever. It costs you nothing. So if you're so inclined, here's the link to the donation voucher. 

http://www.clairelilienthal.org/KIP/Han-Il-Kwon-KIP.pdf

Either way, you will enjoy your meal at Han Il Kwan.
author: Bonnie J.

description:
Technically, I'm Korean but I can think from a white person's perspective on Korean food since I don't really speak my own language...but at the same time, I was raised on this stuff. As far as the various Korean restaurants I've been to in the city, this is probably one of the best ones if you're looking for an all-around menu for typical Korean dishes. 

Also, the rumors are true about Korean tour buses stopping by this place so their tourists can eat here. Right when I got to this place, I saw a bus. Again, further validation that the food is pretty legit. The Coke was pretty delicious too.

Want even more validation? My white friend cleaned house at the end of the meal, eating all the leftovers. So there!
author: Tery L.

description: Pretty standard Korean BBQ place. The meat was good though and the sides were too. They give you soup and some potato appetizers which was nice. Staff was friendly, the place was open but not overwhelming and didn't feel like a cafeteria or anything. Nice decor. Also has a wheelchair ramp and door so kudos for that!
author: Kat M.

description:
Just got back from dinner !!!!! 
 Really good food and great price for what you get. Really enjoyed the options of banchan- and the complimentary tofu soup is good not amazing but good. the spicy pork was awesome!! 
of course the bulgogi was good and the squid also good. 
I would recomend calling before heading over to the restaurant though. We called and they informed us of a tour group that was at the restaurant and so it would be crowded for the next hour, so we decided to wait a bit at home before heading over. They seem to get a lot of tour groups they said and the tours take up most of the resturant while they are there. We made a reservation and were seated within 5 minutes of our reservation. 
Overall great restaurant, awesome food, good prices - would totally recommend to try if you like korean food.
author: Nicole S.

description:
so sad that my fave korean place in SF was a huge FAIL last night.

- we got the private room, maybe this was our mistake
- they completely ignored us, practically ran away from us mid-sentence whenever we flagged them down or asked for anything.
-they skimped on the panchan (no free veggie pancakes and no smelt or egg soup)
-bulgogi was really bland, they didn't cook it enough to get that nice bbq flavor.
-when it was time to refill the romain lettuce basket, the server picked up the empty basket and spilled water all over my friend's head!

total for 9 people was $25 a person, which included 3 bottles of beer.

i'll forgive them this one time because i really love:
-the kalbi
-their chap chae
-there is nowhere else decent in SF to get korean food and LA is too far

parking is pretty much a nightmare fyi.
author: Josie M.

description:
i parked right in front but there was a big old pot hole in the spot.  right when we walked in the waiter handed me an open beer.  what service!    well actually we were late to dinner and our large group was waiting for the room which had not cleared out past our reservation time.  which means free beer for everyone!!

it felt a little bit chilly when i walked in but by the time we started eating, the temp felt ok.  i dont know if it was just because i was super hungry but i thought everything was pretty good.  the banchan was good.  the steamed egg.  jap chae. etc.  we had ordered a set dinner too.
author: claudia y.

description: I went into this restaurant and nobody's at the front desk, when I was writing down my name on the waiting list, the waiter was like:"hey what are u doing here, I'm the one who can write on this sheet." then he crossed all my info out, and asked me about my info and writed them down again. After that, even tho there're several empty table and all guests in front of me had a seat, they're not calling me. There's no more weird place than this. Food is good, but the service there sucks. U deserve better, trust me.
author: Yuan F.

description:
I came here on a Thursday night after soccer practice with six other people. It's surprising that this restaurant is nestled in such a foggy neighborhood. 

What we ordered: 

Meat's favorite was the beef rib eye but several others at the table loved the spicy beef rib eye. All of the meats were well marinaded. 

Beef short ribs 
Beef rib eye 
Spicy beef rib eye 

Kim-chee Pancake-- was the best kim-chee pancake I've eaten ever. 

Dolsot Bibimbap--this was what you would expect for Bibimbap. 

Spicy Beef Soup--nothing special here 

Egg Custard--compliments of the house. Smooth and creamy like silken tofu 

Rice Drink--everyone gets one of these. Cleanses the palette. 

The service was awesome. They knew just when to help with the grill and offered useful advice on a few occasions. 

The bill came and we were very pleased. It costs much less than Brothers and you get more food. Would it be nice to have some Korean BBQ tonight. Hmm...
author: Thang H.

description:
Really bad Korean food.  Garlbi was fatty - most of it ended in my napkin.  Very similiar experience to Brothers - Both highly rated on Yelp, but end up being really REALLY horrible.  I have some credibility for saying this...been to korea many times and have had real korean food for about 11 years.

I won't be back to this place.
author: Jon G.

description: A truly awesome Korean cuisine. They were catering a large group upon our arrival without reservation and it took awhile for them to serve us. Once they did, our food came quick. Friend had an Udon noodle soup with meat that was savory and delicious. I had Chicken Bulgogi platter. Side dishes were delicious of course. Rice was great and had sticky consistency. Food went down so easy here. Love it and will definitely come back. Seems to be a great place for a group outing int he future as well!
author: Austin P.

description: Great service, great food, great banchan.  I am a huge fan of their seafood pancake which has just the right amount of crispness and dough to seafood ratio.  Their jap-chae is good too.  The noodles being nice and bouncy- not too chewy nor too soft and has a lot of flavor. The mix of noodles to veggies and meat is good too.  Best part of the meal is the sweet rice drink at the end to cleanse your palate.  It is a little pricey, but I would definitely come back for another round when I'm in the mood for excellent tasting dishes and service to compliment.
author: Kristy L.

description: This is currently my go to Korean BBQ spot in the city. I love the variety of banchan and their kalbi.  Sometimes there can be a long wait for the cook top tables but lately we've been lazy so we just have them cook our meat and bring it out to us.
author: Julie F.

description: We have been going to this restaurant for years as a family.  Recently my husband has been on a kick to try new Korean restaurants.  I still believe the Korean food served here is solid.  The eel with vegetables was fantastic grilled.  The spicy pork just tasted spicy and the kal bi tasted sweet but didn't have the flavor that has brought us back here.  The soup and banchans were great.  I would still come back here as it is 3.5 stars but it is not as good as I remember.
author: Mary H.

description:
Driving around SF with my boyfriend and got hungry.  We passed by this place and yelped it and saw that it had a good rating and lots of raving reviews, so we decided to stop in.  We didn't expect to wait over 30 minutes in a nearly empty restaurant, but this place always has Korean tourists coming in to eat, so the tables were reserved for those groups.  

We were starving, but boyfriend wanted to try this place out, so we stayed and waited for a table.  The servers were busy running around serving us and the tourists, but sometimes it was hard to get their attention, so minus 1 star.  Otherwise food is tasty and they were really nice.  You get either tofu soup or steamed egg with your meal.  We didn't know when we ordered, but after we asked for the steamed egg, but they brought us tofu soup.  I was sad, so I made my boyfriend ask for the steamed eggs and at first they were hesitant, but he said since we waited patiently for our table, he'd give us the steamed eggs too.  I think I enjoyed the banchan and steamed egg more than the meal, but that's usually how it is for me at korean restaurants.  

Anyway, if you're in the area, or not, I'd say to definitely give this place a try because it's pretty legit for a korean restaurant, especially if Korean tourists hit up this place when they visit SF.
author: Jae W.

description:
If you've ever been to Han II Kwan, you've have at least experienced it once where you have been denied seating or asked to come back in 3-4 hours, because of the tour buses.  Well, it has happened to us many times, and I'm sick and tired of it.  Between 5 pm and 9 pm on Saturday nights, they serve tourists only.

I get it that they make tons of money off of the tour buses, and kudos to them.  I am applaud them for their business acumen.  However, they are located in the Richmond district.  This is a neighborhood restaurant, and they should at least allocate some prime time to serve their patrons.  I don't appreciate them telling me at 5 pm that they cannot serve me until 9 pm.

This place belongs in Union Square or Pier 39, not in our neighborhood.

I am not coming to this restaurant anymore - not worth the wait.
author: Helen C.

description:
The clouds parted, angels sang, and out fell "Special Dinner B" from the Han II Kwan menu. Complete with BBQ short ribs and delicious noodles we all dove into the food like it was our last meal on earth. 

This place is great for groups. They have private rooms in the back which are private, though you are cut off from other diners so you don't get the full experience. You do however leave without your hair reeking of smoke from the BBQs. 

The $6 beers are big and cheap while the $12 Soju cold and refreshing. If the Korean tour buses come here you know they are doing something right! YUM!
author: Natalie N.

description:
This place is 4 blocks from our apartment and we didn't know!  Thank you YELP.  This review is less about the food, which was excellent, and more about the service.  It seems that they cater to tour bus folks - indeed, there is tour bus specific parking located right in front of the restaurant - and that means that the service was so-so.  More specifically, it was tough to get our waiter's attention and when we did it was that -- oh, you MUST be a tourist that I'll never see again kinda 'tude. 

So just be prepared: food is good; service is ok.  Wear clothes that you'll want to wash immediately after dinner because you're going to take the bbq smell with you.
author: John B.

description:
Sometimes I like to judge restaurants by the bathroom trip immediately afterward. This just somehow works out and makes sense.

If it comes out nice: I had a good meal, and I should definitely go back.
If it doesn't come out so nice: It wasn't so great of a meal (or they overdosed me on msg or something) and I probably shouldn't be going back.

Let's just say it came out nice. Real nice.
author: Jeffrey Z.

description:
Came for a friend's birthday with a 7:30pm reservation for a large party of 20 in the private room. We waited FOREVER for them to bring the small dishes and water. We had to flag someone down to get anything. No one was coming to take our order so I had to walk up to the waiters and ask them to come. We finally ordered with them at 8:30pm; the food came a little after 9. The food was decent but since the service was literally sooo painfully slow, by the time the food came, I was suffering from acid indigestion and I couldn't eat much. (I get this when I don't eat "on time.")

I may come back someday but NOT with a big group of friends and definitely NOT in those private rooms!
author: Tina T.

description:
This is my favorite korean restaurant in San Francisco :)

Their food is tasty. fresh, and they have lots to choose from on the menu. They give you complimentary little side dishes which includes a pot of tofu soup. These small dishes alone are good enough to fill anyone up so be careful, don't order too much!

I like having the option of cooking your Korean BBQ at the table -- it's just fun and adds to the experience. But I do notice that the meat tastes better when the kitchen cooks it themselves :P

When it comes to korean food, I LOVE LOVE LOVE bibimbap but this place does not have "the best" bibimbap I've ever tasted :(
author: Jennie S.

description:
great place for small families or large groups. we got a big bbq table so we were able to indulge in all-round korean feast. i think we received free mini seafood or kimchi pancakes since a big group like us, we ordered a lot dishes. overall food quality was applaudable. premium customer service. our bbq fire went out for a couple times so we had to keep bugging them to turn it back on for us xVx.....the waiter would bbq the meats for us, so that's definitely a thumb up!

simply delicious and will definitely come back!
author: Eva J.

description: I could eat here for breakfast, lunch, and dinner everyday! Just can't get enough of the amazing goodness at this place!
author: Marwa A.

description: The food tasted great all around.  The BBQ short ribs was the best.  Beware of the late afternoon tour bus rush.  If you see tour buses parked in front of restaurant, come back another time.
author: Benny A.

description:
First of all, I would say parking spot is hard to get around the restaurant, but it ain't stopped me from trying out this new restaurant.

Few dishes we ordered:

1: Seafood Pancake, a little bit disappointed, it is not really a pan-cake but pre-cut pieces of pancakes. Taste okay but I would recommend go to other Korean restaurants to get your seafood pancake.

2: Soft Tofu Soup, very plain, no surprise but the tofu does taste good. We try to ask for an egg so we can mix the egg in the tofu soup but the waiter said they don't serve egg here like other places, I guess I am not a Korean so I don't really know when should I add or not add an egg to the tofu soup, lol. I really hope the restaurant can offer what the customers want so we don't really get disappointed.

3:Steamed Short Rib: this is the only dish that made me give this restaurant a 4 star rating, because it tastes super wonderful. Even with its pricy price $19.95, I would still recommend this dish to anyone. I can't really tell what sauce they use to cook the dish but it just tastes exceptionally delicious. And they make it just right.

Come try out the steamed short rib, and you won't be disappointed by this dish, for other regular dishes, other Korean restaurants offer better choices.
author: Jay J.

description: I've been looking for an authentic Korean food in SF and this place has been the best so far. You can tell what the food will be like from the banchan restaurants serve and I was pleased with all of them. They tasted clean, like they were freshly made and the variety was good, from the sprouts, fishcakes, marinated cucumber to acorn jelly and a couple different kinds of kimchi etc. My Ground Bean Soup was seasoned perfectly and they even brought out some complimentary veggie pancakes. They were really busy during lunch hour but the wait staff was quick and friendly. I'll definitely be coming back for more.
author: SL K.

description:
For my birthday recently, I decided to hit this place again.  I had gone for the first time back in November of 2010 and enjoyed it.  This time around, my friends and I ordered a set dinner instead of picking individual dishes since there was a large number of us.  

Overall, the meal was quite good.  While I don't remember every individual dish we had (there was egg, soup, plenty of meat), everyone had a great time.   It was better than the usual choice of Chinese or Sushi. 

If there is a negative, the wait was longer than expected even though we had a reservation.  Apparently, there was large parties there so we had to wait until they cleared out and that took about 45 minutes.  

However, I do recommend this place if you want some good Korean food.
author: Donald L.

description: Worst Korean restaurant ever! We went there 535pm on 2/14/16. We put our names on the list and were told the wait would be 45 mins or so. During our wait, we saw groups of Korean tourists coming in the restaurant out of tourist buses. It was clear that the tourist groups have some business relationship with the restaurant so they were seated immediately after they came in. At first place, we felt this might not have to do with our wait and we just ignored it. Then the worst part happened after we waited there for 1 hour at 630pm or so. We went to a lady looking like store manager and asked why the waiting list was not moving and how long would we have to wait any longer. She replied it would be another hour wait. We were like this is insane. What she replied was even crazier. You guys can order now and wait so you don't have to order when you are seated. Of course we left immediately. This manager kept letting the people coming in with no wait and let us stand there for one good hour and did not give us any heads-up? It seems they cherish the tourist groups which I think very likely they have a very strong business relationship more than the local bay area residents like us who might come here every week. Surely I will never go back there wasting my time and felt frustrated with this kind of treatment.
author: David K.

description:
All the dishes were flavorful and the service was great.

We ordered and the food started coming within 10 minutes. First they gave us the banchan which I love and they didn't mind at all when we asked for refills for some of the dishes. I'm not a lover of kimchee, but I am now! It was marinated perfectly. 

We had the chicken and spicy beef to be cooked at the table. The chicken had great flavor. The beef was really good too. Meat was really tender.

We also had the sauteed vegetables and squid. It was good, but not my personal favorite. I'm just not a huge cooked squid fan. 

I was so full by now, and totally forgot that we also ordered the seafood and scallion pancake. This was soft but still had great texture and very fragrant. One of my favorites of the night.

And lastly, the japchae came as our last dish. I was stuffing my face now just to eat some. Well worth it.

Wonderful food. Great service. Just a little hard to find parking, but well worth the search.
author: Heidi L.

description:
The food was good, but the service was SO slow. They had a kimchi bibimbap (sans meat) so I tried it, but I would rather ordered a regular bibimbap with meat on the side. The kimchi bibimbap didn't have anything but rice, kimchi and egg. I missed out on the bean sprouts, spinach, and whatever else comes with a regular bibimbap. It was still tasty, though, and not too spicy for me. 

In any case, we kept asking for more banchan, and they never refilled it until we were done with our dinner. They weren't mean, but they weren't very attentive. Can't speak for the quality of the meats here, but I'm sure it was good, since there was nothing left on the grill.
author: Aiko L.

description: Been here now a couple of times. Quality very stable, service also always the same.  Good food for a reasonable price. Portions are on the larger side. The spicy rice sticks are pretty good, as are the spicy porc and egg variations.
author: C S.

description: Fantastic food! The spices and execution are always top notch. Our server was Dennis. Very friendly and very professional.
author: Chris L.

description: Really love this place over YakiniQ or other famous Korean BBQ places in SF. The service here is pretty solid, and the waits aren't bad. I had a birthday party here a few weeks ago, and they even catered to a reservation! We had plenty of soju and the waitresses were all pretty great. The food is excellent - the galbi was enjoyed by everyone who went and tried it for the first time. The bulgogi and shrimp are always big hits, but the service is top-notch as far Korean restaurants go! The only negative is that there is a limited amount of do-it-yourself grills, and if you have a larger group you need to wait a bit. So, if you've got 6 or more, plan to eat early or late to avoid the line. When we want Korean, we go to Han il Kwan!
author: Tighe B.

description: It is such a terrible service in the restaurant. I asked how long we had to wait, and then the waiter told me to wait 40 mins. When we waited more than 40 mins and asked the waiter again, he told me to wait another 40 mins impolitely. And there is open no waiting list for the guest to see and they just wrote down the name by Korean. It is totally discrimination. Although some guests came later, they would eat first because they are Korean. I would never comeback for this Fucking restaurant. The waiter such a jerk!!!
author: Yanni Z.

description:
Last night was my first time dinning to this restaurant. I would say for what you pay it's worthy.  

The place is big enough if you coming as a big group, I would recommended to come here as a group because they serves a big portion and it's fun fighting foods with them :)

I enjoyed my meals here last night, i also like how they gave me a lot of side dishes, as well as free hot tea and the end a rice drink.
author: Sasitorn O.

description:
This is always the place we go to for the BF's best friend's birthday dinner.  We usually have a large group and so will always be in the backroom. 

I don't remember what we ordered but we ordered a lot and it was ALL DELICIOUS. The waitress was nice and knew what she was doing as she brought in platters and platters of MEAT. 

Of course there were veggies but all were in tiny little dishes, refills on any of them were greeted with a "sure! :D".

Also, soju was on hand...or in bottles for a few rounds of "Happy Birthday!" or "Drink up, Birthday Boy!" or "Birthday Boy's gotta catch up! C'mon, CHEERS!"

Anyways, this place is awesome, the parking around it suuuuuucks, and we'll be back here soon enough for a few rounds of soju and some tasty bulgogi.
author: Julia W.

description: I went here last week with my friends, and we had to wait in line around 20 mins. The  Korean style BBQ are really delicious. wroth to wait!
author: Sharon-Xiaoying H.

description:
Came to San Francisco for a 2 week vacation.  We were in LA a year and a half ago and had such a great Korean bbq experience that we thought we should also try to find something in San Francisco.

Boy was that a big mistake.

I've been lucky to experience some great Korean barbecue in Seoul and I've never been able to find anything as good until my trip to LA.  My wife and I prefer the non-marinated beef especially with the sesame oil and salt.  We love it when they provide for different kinds of beef and you really get a chance to experience a good meat taste and texture.  You never really get good quality beef when it is marinated in our experience.

We ordered the kalbi and rib eye...  mediocre beef.  Only good thing is that they provide good size portions.  We ordered the raw beef.  It's the largest raw beef dish I've ever had but doesn't do any good when the meet is still frozen.  Bim bim bab...  very bland.  Only the sweet hot sauce saved it.  The kimchee pancake was the only acceptable dish.

Service was also mediocre.  Once we started the burner, it started dripping water under the table.  We asked the waiter and his response was, "oh don't worry, it'll stop".  We put a couple of paper towels so that the dripping wouldn't splatter so much.  Thank goodness we did as the water was grayish black.

After this experience, there's no need to try Korean bbq in San Francisco.  For those who have ate in Seoul and LA, don't waste your stomachs.  I would've gave them 1 star but they had large portions so I thought that deserved another star.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Great food!!  Ordered the squid dish, kalbi, and pork bulgogi.  The small dishes were also really good!

Call ahead to find out when the last tour bus is leaving, then plan to arrive right around then.
author: Cy C.

description:
there is a huge debate as to which place has the best korean food in SF. 

alot of people would say brothers, or any restaurant on geary. i beg to differ. brothers is disgusting and overpriced. i have had no luck finding good korean food in SF, period. all the good places are in oakland, in case you were wondering.

that is, until i discovered han il kwan. 

came here with Paul M to go out for a nice dinner [it's been awhile].i haven't had korean food in a long time and i was hoping it would hit the spot. 

and it did. oh god, it did.

we ordered kalbi, yook gae jang, and the broiled king fish. we also ordered the boiled potstickers. yes, we are gluttons. don't judge us. i was delighted that the steamed egg came with the food, not just in a tiny sidedish, but a whole freaking pot of it! the kalbi was actually very tasty and the meat was much better quality than the kind i had at brothers. the fish was also delicious, and the banchan was honestly in the top 5 range. the filling in the potstickers was delicious as well. 

my only gripe is that the yook gae jang was hardly spicy, but then again i'm a korean and we apparently have warped taste buds. paul said it was making him sniffle, so i guess the soups here are tweaked for weak american tongues, mwahaha. but it did make me a little sad, because i absolutely love yook gae jang. i read through some other reviews and apparently their soon dubu is also mild. i guess us koreans have to specify we want it the normal way =P 

but overall, we got a shit ton of delicious food for $57, and the service was actually NICE. trust, you don't find that at alot of korean joints. next time i'm craving korean in the city, i'll be back. =]
author: Angela L.

description:
First Impressions. We read about them all the time and how they're a good indicator of what you can expect. I knew this place was going to be good right off the bat based on the panchan (typical side dishes you get at Korean restaurants) they hooked us up with shortly after we sat down. The vegetables retained that crisp and snappy quality that you find in only the freshest ingredients. Also, I've they served us some panchan that I haven't gotten at any other Korean joints I've been to such as a boiled egg soufflé and octopus salad. 

So when the main courses arrived, I was not surprised at all to find that the meat and soup we ordered was delicious (I highly recommend the spicy bulgo ki and kim chee chi ge).

Post-meal, they even serve this sweet rice drink where the grains of rice kind of dissolve and have this fabricky texture. Kind of weird but very pleasant at the same time.

A big plus for me is the after dinner mints they have there. They look like peppermint candy but they are the softer, buttery mints. What normally would've been a 4 star review was bumped to a 5 star one, solely on this.

Overall, it's my favorite Korean place that I've come across so far.
author: Jeffrey J.

description: I heard that Han Il Kwan is one of two (the other being Brothers) authentic (and good) Korean restaurants in SF--this is not accurate.  Han Il Kwan is much better than Brothers.  Food was excellent and the portions are actually larger than expected.  Street parking (virtually non-existent when we went) was the only issue we had.  We had pretty good service but we were there early before the crowds so not sure how it is when it gets super busy.
author: Platform Universe S.

description:
I do love me some good Korean BBQ, though I rarely go, probably because I've never known of a good place in the city.  Well, thanks to Cathy Y. for introducing me to Han Il Kwan last week.

Unfortunately, there was so much of a crowd on a Tuesday night that we weren't able to get a table where we could cook the meat ourselves.  Our hunger and desire for immediate food overcame our love of the self-cooking novelty.  

But that just meant the heaping plates of meat came out sooner and once the food hit the table, we were never at a loss for something to eat.  Between four of us we shared 3 plates of meat and a bibimbob, which even for our ravenous appetites turned out to be too much.  The sides and accoutrements just kept coming and there were so many taste/flavor options!

I'm a big fan of lots of food, and this place was very reasonably priced for the amount of plates they served us.  I will definitely be back, and hopefully next time we can get a table with a grill.
author: Anne Marie B.

description:
This place is good, really good, seriously good, hella good!

Everytime we go here, we have to wait an hour or so for a table. The meats are marinated to great taste. We usually order two stone-bowl rice, some fish, some beef, some pork, and some chicken. The portions are pretty generous, and can fill up four people with left-overs easily. The price is also reasonable. The best thing, they take AMEX (3% cash-back FTW)

One down side -- parking sucks, though.
author: Chi T.

description: This place has horrible service. The food is so-so, I have nothing bad to say about the meat... Spicy Tofu soup was the worst I've ever had and I go to alot of Korean spots. My advice if you really want great Korean, go over to Oakland.
author: Alicia J.

description:
The best Korean restaurant in SF. Their Gal-bi is delicious and the ban-chan (side items) are some of the best I have ever tasted. I would seriously go there just to eat the ban-chan. It's that good. The cucumbers are simple yet so fresh and flavourful. The radish cubes are tasty without being too spicy. The service is great and I have never left wanting for anything.

Become a regular and the service becomes even better. I could eat here at least 3 times a week during a recession and 5 times a week during good times. Plenty of seating and never had to wait for a table.

My only complaint is that parking can sometimes be a bitch. Because they do not have their own parking lot and the only parking is on the street. May be smarter to take a cab or mass transit.
author: Earl Y.

description:
An Awesome find! I went to this Korean restaurant on Labor Day weekend! Boy were they busy! I had their dwen jang chi gae, burlgogi and rice. Yummies! If I ever moved to SF, I'd be there EVERY DAY! :)

CONS: Street Parking Only!
author: Jay Y.

description:
I always think Mom's food is the best, so most Korean restaurants don't quite measure up.  Since Mom's not here, Han Il Kwan definitely feeds the need.  This place will have you asking, "Brother, who?" 

Everything is mouth-watering delish, but my favorite is the Kalbi-jeem.  This is braised beef, sweet and tender.  Just order it!! You won't regret it.  

Make reservations, especially on Friday and Saturday nights.  Trust me...you'll be glad you did.

Party tip - If you ever want to cater, they do that too!  Just stop by and order off the menu, but don't expect any discounts.  This place does too well to apply Costco bulk price cuts to your party order!
author: Stella K.

description:
Came here for a birthday dinner with 11 of us. It came out to being
$13 each person for 7 dishes and TONS of banchan (we got 3 sets of each item). That's super cheap for Korean food! We were in a private room in the back but we waited forever before we were acknowledged.

We ordered kalbi, spicy pork, jap chae, 2 tofu soups, bi bim bap, and the seafood pancake. The food was pretty good...my faves were the spicy pork and seafood pancake. I've had better tofu soups (wasn't even spicy) and bi bim baps. I liked how they cut the pancake into separate pieces too.

Service was a little slow but the food came out fast and was affordable!
author: Karen Y.

description: definitely a good place to eat Korean food.  Service is decent and food is great.   Full variety yummy dishes for your choice in its menu.  Love it!
author: tomcat f.

description:
Best Korean I've had. Parking is near to impossible on Sat night, but it's worth the walk from Geary/Fulton. Food is fresh, service is spot on. Flavors and spices are traditional and totally balanced. 
All around good stuff. I didn't foot the bill but I think it's worth at least $20 per person. 
Yeya. Good date spot, great for large parties. I hear lunch is good, too.
author: Jordan S.

description:
OK. Need to up this place two more stars. Like other Asian restaurants, if you speak the native language, service improves exponentially.  The ahjummah is very nice and the side dishes are great.  

Kimchi or Doenjang jjigae, spicy bulgogi, and the complimentary ban chan have to be among this place's best.

Now, this place feels like home :D.
author: Jennifer Y.

description: Came for lunch on a Saturday.  Made reservations for seven.  The banchan were all yummy...kinda filling too.  We had #23. Kim-Chee Casserole* with seafood, vegetables and noodle and #25. Long-Boiled Beef Short Ribs with potatoes and carrots.  #25 was sooo good I might come back just for that.  Service was a bit disappointing.  They really didnt come by our table and we seemed to always had to flag someone down...to order...get more tea...the check.  Oooh and this was before the tour bus even got there.  Wondering if its really a hit or miss on service with this place.
author: she q.

description:
I find it interesting that this out-of-nowhere Korean restaurant is the destination of busloads after busloads of Korean tourists, no matter what time of the day it is. 

Don't get me wrong - the food is amazing.  It's just that it's not exactly in a place that a tourist would find very interesting - the RIchmond district.  But I guess if I were a tourist in SF I would rather be feasting on good food in a rather inconvenient location as opposed to dining at the usual Fisherman's Wharf tourist traps. 

The dolsot bibimbap (mixed rice in stone pot) was tasty, the portion was generous and they were generous with the toppings (including the meat).  Love love love.

The gal bee (beef ribs) weren't at the same level as some of the Sunnyvale / Santa Clara Korean establishments, but it was still flavorful AND the price wasn't too outrageous.  

The banchan could've been better (where's my free japchae????), but the sweet rice drink at the end was a nice little touch and was effective as a palate cleanser!
author: Ange L.

description:
wow, soooo much food as others have commented. $16.50 for a huge lunch (bulgoggi, and a beer...with plenty of leftovers... service was efficient, and unlike alot of korean rest. i've been to in LA/NY, they spoke good english. they gave a complimentary soup with the banchan, a complimentary drink and tea..the banchan were okay, there was a lot, not the best i've had but not the worst...but a lot of food!

bulgoggi was flavored and cooked right. could have used some onions as it it was served plain.

i wouldn't think it would be worth it for dinner, more of a lunch special place tho...but that's just me. the rest. was on the quieter side despite being somewhat busy on a rainy day.
author: Jonathan A.

description: Came here for lunch one day because of the Yelp reviews.  I was very disappointed.  The spicy pork was very fatty and grizzly.  The side dishes were just so so.  Cheap low-quality food with large portions, no wonder the Korean tour buses come here.
author: TopCat W.

description: This place is one of my favorite korean restaurants. They give you tons of side dishes with every order during lunch or dinner. The service is great!  I usually order the bulgogi, short ribs and the chapche, all really delicious!! AND at the end of your lunch or dinner they give you this rice drink that's also really good. I would recommend coming here during lunch time on the weekdays because of the lunch specials they have, which are cheaper then coming on weekends or for dinner, which can get pretty expensive. Parking maybe harder to find because the restaurant is kind of in the middle of a residential area and they don't have their own parking lot.
author: Connie Y.

description:
The food is pretty good, we usually get the Pork with spicy sauce or Beef Kalbi barbecue.  I also like the Tofu in spicy soy sauce.  A friend says the raw beef dish is delicious, and so I plan to try that some time soon.

They have the best ban chan I've had in SF -- with those little pancakes and also a fluffy egg soup.  I also like that they give you the fermented sweet rice drink after the meal.  

One order of barbecue is enough for me and my husband because they are so generous with sides, so we try to make up with a bigger than usual tip.

The best deal here is the lunch special (we order for pick up).  They always pack a container of ban chan and some tofu soup and the meat is really enough for 2 people (not American sized servings, just regular servings for 2).  And today we ordered some tofu and the lady at the restaurant gave us an extra serving of rice, ban chan, and soup.  Nice!

We live close to the restaurant and find it a bit of a hoot to see the tourist buses filled with Korean tourists unloading customers every day.
author: Mia G.

description:
This is probably the first place I've had really good korean food. The place is tucked away in a residential area in the Richmond District so it's a little tough to find if you haven't been there. A friend of mine took a group of us here.

The food was great with everything having just the right amount of flavor and spice. I had the Bibimbap with chicken  (first time) along with the various sides and loved it.
author: Ajay K.

description:
This is my favorite Korean joint in the Richmond district.  Beats Brothers by far.  Huge variety on the banchan - my fave is the pickled radish.  I always get the bim bim bap and the kalbi.  

Really, a 4.5 rating.  Reasons for the markdown:
1.  There is no music in the daytime.  No korean pop music.  No traditional Korean music.  It's quiet and you can hear conversations from loud, annoying people.  
2.  Parking is pretty tough.
3.  This place is really popular with Korean tour companies. There are times where there are tour buses of folks filling up the restaurant.  It takes a while to get a table when that happens.  I usually call or drive past beforehand to see how long the wait is.

The above should not take away from the food itself.  The food is awesome.
author: David M.

description: Party of 4 went there for some authentic Korean bbq for dinner since where we're from doesn't have real korean food. Ordered Kalbi, spicy pork, pork belly fat, and kimchee jiggae. Overall it was pretty good but would've been 5-star great if they have more choice of banchans. The skinny korean man who served was awesome. I'm guessing he is the manager. He has the golden customer service voice that man. We came to this place because of other raving reviews of this place being the best in SF and was not disappointed.
author: Jeff K.

description: Yummy!  We love to go here whenever we can.  We think it is the best Korean restaurant in the Bay Area!  We love the variety of the little dishes and the free egg custard!  No other places have same ones. It is very special.
author: Sarah K.

description:
After reading numerous reviews on Han Il Kwan and the popularity of this place for Korean tourists, I have always been skeptical.  However, I finally found my way over for lunch and it was somewhat good timing.  From experience, lunch is usually a good time to eat especially when the restaurant is consistently popular and busy during dinner.

My experience however, was a little bit different.  While we beat the bus loads of Korean tourists, we had to wait a huge long time during.  There were only about 3-4 tables of two to four people...and only 1 waiter.  *Sigh*

The thing that I LOVE and HATE about Korean restaurants is the Ban Chan (Side dishes).  Great especially when you are super hungry, but not so when you only have one waiter slowly having to take orders, get drinks, preparing and serving all the ban chan,  bring out entee's and bussing tables full of small plates and hot iron plates.  All this while checking up on the tables making sure everything is well, and cashing out, and doing credit card transactions. This ONE poor waiter was rushing  to get everything done.  

Loved the 8+ side dishes--great variety...but by the time they arrived, so had our entree's. 

And this I believe is the disadvantage of coming to eat at less busy hours: the lack of sufficient staffing!  

Aside from the extremely slow service from the poor waiter who I completely sympathize with, the food was good.  Ordered the lunch Bul Go Gi, meat was tender, and flavorfully sweet. Also ordered Jap Chae...*Eh*  Huge portion and very flavorful, but the noodles were thicker and chewier that I expected--became hard to chew at certain times, definitely wasn't soft and slippery as I enjoy.  

Overall, food was good. Hopefully I can come back next time for BBQ table grilling...but I just hope that the next time is fully staffed to where patrons don't have to wait 10 minutes for service for every little thing. A big huge turn off. 

3.5 Stars.
author: Cass J.

description: I also have to add every single time I go I have to wait about 30-45 mins which is really annoying.
author: Pamela I.

description:
First off, if you want to try authentic Korean food, COME HEREEEE. 

This place is pretty big and there's plenty of street parking. If you go at the right time, you can park right outside the white zone reserved for mini tour buses. I went to this place a couple of times for lunch and there are always tourists coming in. The owner here is super nice. Oh and did I mention, FREE FOOD? 1) Free Korean pancakes, 2) Free banchan (aka side dishes) & they are REFILLABLE 3) Free Tofu Soup, 4) Sweet Rice Drink! The food here gets two thumbs up for taste and reasonable price.

Food to try: 

[[ Bi Bim Bap ]] Very traditional, freshly made & comes in a BIG stone pot.

[[ Bulgogi Marinated Beef ]] Yummy! Goes great with rice and all the assorted side dishes.

[[ Chap Chae ]] Crystal noodles with veggies and beef. Pretty good if you're up for noodles.

[[ Cold Noodle w/ Beef & Veggies ]] Yes, cold noodles. If you want to try something out of the ordinary, try this. It's noodles in cold broth. (Owner said Koreans eat this on hot days to cool down.) Doesn't hurt to try. It's kind of interesting and...cold. ^^

This place is a MUST TRY. *thumbs up*
author: Janice M.

description: I haven't had LA Korean BBQ, so I can't compare, but this place has great korean BBQ and soft tofu soup.
author: Caroline D.

description:
Love this place! My family and I have been going here since I was a kid.  I must say I've always been impressed with the high quality food and good service. I also like that you have the option to cook at your table...a fun activity with friends and family.

We always order the bulgogi and sometimes the BBQ chicken or kalbi. The meat is tender and flavorful. And their tofu soup and side dishes (especially the pancakes) are delicious. 

If you want authentic Korean food that is both high quality and delicious, you must try Han Il Kwan. I go whenever I'm in San Francisco and it's one of the best Korean restaurants I've tried. Hope to return soon!
author: Mira F.

description:
I found this place on Yelp when I decided to research Korean BBQ restaurants.  I wanted to find an alternative to Brothers.  Now, I do love me some Brothers #1 on Geary, but you always, ALWAYS end up smelling like you spent the entire day standing in a pit oven.  

The food at Han was comparable to Brothers.  Some of the ban chan dishes were better, like the steamed scrambled egg thing that reminded me of chawanmushi.  Damn, that was good.  On par with most Korean restaurants, we got the free pot of tofu soup and the sweet rice drink at the end of the meal.  We ordered the Kalbi and Bulgogi to bbq at the table and also ordered the battered zucchini.  The meat was ok, not the best I've ever had.  The zucchini was good and lived up to my expectations.  Nothing will ever compare to homemade korean food so it's difficult for me not to be overly picky.  Service was also comparable to Brothers, a bit spotty and abrupt.  Yes, parking really is a bitch as every other review has mentioned.

What really made Han II Kwan stand out for me was the cleanliness and the super efficient ventilation system.  The table was clean, the plates and silverware were sparkling, and even while we were cooking our kalbi and bulgogi at the table, there wasn't much smoke.  Granted, they use gas fire here instead of charcoal so that helps.   

In short, the food, service, and atmosphere earns this place an easy 3 stars from me.  But they get another additional star simply because my clothes and hair passed the smell test!  I got home and I don't smell like smoke AT ALL.  I could eat here on a date!  You will walk out of here without smelling like a slab of barbecued marinated beef!  That, my darlings, is the best reason ever to include this place high in your list of Korean dining options.
author: Courtney Y.

description:
They gave you so many side dishes!!!  And they all tasted good!
I love the beef stew we ordered.  The dessert rice drink was my favorite!  I'll come back!
author: Elena L.

description:
Easily the best korean restaurant I've been to in San Francisco. They're generous with side dishes and provide complimentary items regardless of the size of your order.

Everything I've ordered so far has tasted fantastic and definitely satisfies the Korean NOMNOM's. 

I've grown up on Korean food and have visited quite a few Korean establishments including those in Korea and Han Il Kwan definitely delivers. 

Oddly though the only disappointment so far has been the Soon Do Bu which is ok because they usually provide it for free during meals.

Otherwise service is great, food tastes great, and is a great little spot to fill those Korean cravings in the city.

***Follow-up: Still keeping my starts at a 5 rating but wanted to toss out an important warning for would-be patrons. I strongly recommend trying to avoid their tour bus hours. Not only is it immensely difficult to get seats, their quality of service deteriorates significantly as they tend to prioritize their tour bus customers over their walk-ins. 

They seem to have a contract with a Korean touring company and if you happen to come by during those hours, you'll see endless mobs of tourists coming in and out of the fairly small restaurant.
author: Aaron H.

description:
We used to love this restaurant! Nice folks working, great food, good prices. But suddenly they can;t be bothered to seat us when the entire restaurant is empty - even tell us to come back in two hours and they will be able to serve us! And yes, the restaurant is *open*! Apparently they would rather hold tables for tour buses than have local Richmond District residents eat here. 

Definitely off the list.
author: DasLael D.

description: So much food! The workers are very nice and the service was pretty decent. The meat was very well marinated especially the short ribs. The short ribs is a must have. Also the kim-chi pancake was pretty good too. And not to mention its good price and you get all the side dishes. AMAZING!
author: Kevin Q.

description:
Free side dishes and hmmm delicious chapjae!

Con: parking. 
took me about 10 minutes to find one. 

regardless. this place is good.
author: Viola C.

description:
I live in the Mission, which has every kind of cuisine in the universe, but for Han Il Kwan, I make the hike out to the the Richmond. Most people I know are pretty unfamiliar with real Korean food past kimchi, so this is a great place to take them for their first experience of it -- they are invariably impressed.

The key to eating here is understanding that you should order one dish -- usually just meat; I recommend the marinated ribs, the pork belly a close second -- per two people. No matter what you order you will get literally a dozen small appetizers with it, plus rice and soup, which are enough to fill up an ordinary person all by themselves. There is no chance you will leave here anything but stuffed.

They will also do the cook-at-your-table system here. This is a lot of fun (fire!) but actually less tasty, since the chefs are professionals at cooking this stuff and you, as an amateur, will tend to get it wrong and burn stuff. So I recommend letting them cook it for you.

On to the rating! My in-no-way-patented 5-star system:

Location: the Richmond. OMG, far away. You have to drive, and then there's no parking. NONE. No star.
Atmosphere: clean, bright, friendly, not too loud, and full of Koreans. 1 star.
Service: rapid, attentive, friendly, generous, perfect. 1 star.
Food: DELICIOUS. Varied, interesting, fresh, and flavourful. 1 star.
Prices: you can feed two people for $25 including tip. Super-great. 1 star.

So four stars, only because it is so very far away.
author: Laurie V.

description: This is the best Korean restaurant/BBQ place in SF. It's authentic, fresh, and plentiful. Watch out for the tour buses which crowds the place on weekdays from 6 to 7pm usually, so call ahead. The BBQ can be cooked at your table or they will prepare it in the back. It's a gas grill on the tables, so it doesn't get as smoky which is good for your clothes. They have great Dol Sot Bibim Bop (Hot Stone Mixed Rives with Vegetables) and Duk Mandu Goook (Rice Cake Dumpling Soup). If you bring a dog less than 20lbs, they will also serve it up for you at the table. WoofWoof.
author: Mike C.

description:
I like the decoration over there, and it is so Korean, and comfortable.

They offer two kinds of tables: one with bbq pot or the other without.

Their menus have a good variety of traditional korean food to choose from. My table got 3 orders of bbq set (#1, ribs, #6 pork belly and # 8 seafood) plus oyster pancakes.

ALL YUMMY!! Their portion of food is larger, comparing to the famous bbq korean restaurant even though the prices are slightly higher.

The staff was friendly, and willing to take questions.

Remember to reserve a bbq table and save time to eat rather than wait! Definitely take a look at the menu before u go.

the sides dish and sauces are delicious, and I will go back to eat.
author: Sue S.

description:
Service was ehhh... we had a big group, 14, got squeeze into the back room, being a big group, people tend to be loud. The food was good, I thought the service was not so good. We literally walked out three times to ask for the check before the person brought i in, and we asked for boxes in which, it was not provided, in the end, we didn't have enough boxes, and walked out to get some more... 
Oh, yes, and parking... was a beeeeeach...
author: Monika T.

description: I've had better Korean BBQ. The food was okay and the service was slightly above average. The Kalbi was decently marinated and the portion size was pretty good. Side dishes were okay but I guess the fish wasn't included. I'd give this place another try perhaps. But it's hard to justify paying 25 dollars when you can just go to an AYCE place for a few more dollars.
author: Chris T.

description:
I was half impressed, while wary about the sanitation...

On the plus side, Han Il Kwan has much better side dishes than most Korean restaurants that I've been to.

On the lesser side, Han Il Kwan's 'entree' dishes were tasteless and dull. I've ended up eating more of the side dishes than the actual entree order.

On the worst side, Han Il Kwan has a huge sanitation problem (at least when I went there last Saturday) - I've counted about a dozen flies around the area where I sat, and yes, they've made their way to the dishes.
author: Ming S.

description:
meat! bonk bonk! This place is a block away from where I have a safehouse out in San Fran so walking distance this can't be beat. 

this is not for the faint of appatite or single eaters, I thought I could tank this mess by myself.. wrong! the banchan selection and quality is excellent.  You need to order two meat dishes to be able to cook for yourself at the center table. I orderd the spicy beef (rib eye meat) the flavor and quality was excellent.  Prices are fair and I had more than enough leftovers for my little funsized self!
author: Chris M.

description:
This place is only a block or so away from where my husband and I live. We always see people inside and giant Korean tour buses with a bunch of Koreans going in. Must be good if the Koreans are eating there so my husband and I decided to try it one day.

This place was pretty good. I got the dol sot bi bim bap and my husband got the tofu soup. While we waited they gave us some onion pancake like thing to try - it was ok but kinda greasy for my taste. Then came the banchan - the stuff that I especially love about Korean food. Came with a lot of the stuff I love - pickled bean sprouts, cucumber, kimchi, radishes, fish cake, and a few others. Sadly, they didn't have the chap chae (my favorite) or the potatoes (my husband's favorite). 
But they were nice to refill our banchan when we were low so I am happy. 

My bi bim bap came out sizzling and smelling wonderful. I enjoyed my dish and it's so filling, I couldn't even finish it. I had a taste of my husband's tofu soup and it's a little different from the ones we usually get but it was still delicious. Although, I got the beef bi bim bap, there wasn't that much beef in it so next time, I would rather get the veggie bi bim bap and save some money. Not that prices here are expensive and unreasonable. It's actually pretty cheap for bi bim bap - I've had ones where they cost much more and were not as good. 

Since we live near-by, we were able to walk. However, this place is mainly surrounded by residential housing so parking may suck and you'll probably need to park on Geary and walk over. Service was good, despite the busy night, we were still attended to by the two waiters.
author: Lang T.

description: Sigh...I have to take a star off.  I really didn't want to but I got a pretty bad MSG reaction last time I was here from their spicy stew dishes and some of the side dishes.  The reason I am not taking off more is because aside from that, it would have been perfect. Tasty (& I have a feeling they could do a pretty good job of that even without the msg), reasonably priced, and they give you LOTS of side dishes -- even mini pancakes -- and aren't shy about refilling them (except for the pancakes.)
author: David A.

description: Popular with tour groups. Good Korean food and you can BBQ if you want, or have it done for you. Kal bi is $22.95. They have lots of small plates and threw in a few extra freebies. I also like how they give your table a bottle of water. Korean food always makes me thirsty!
author: Natalie S.

description:
After going to probably 50 or so similar places to this one in various other states and countries, I'd rank it in the bottom half. The kalbi and bulgogi(pork) was lower quality than what I've seen at most other places for the same price. The sides for lack of a better description didn't seem very fresh or flavorful. I was there around 6pm on a week night and the place was almost empty. It might be coincidence, but most of the other Korean bbq joints have much more attentive waiters that will cut up the meat so you don't have to hassle with it. Not the case here.

There are a half a dozen similar places on Geary that you should check out before wandering over to Balboa.
author: Nate S.

description:
I enjoyed my meals here although it may be a little on the expensive side. Come with friends! Always more fun to fight over the last bits of chan!! 
I once spent over twenty bucks spoiling myself for lunch here. I've never eaten lunch at a restaurant by myself before, but that day I was alone and no one wanted to join me..so I bused here and had the meal of a lifetime! I was so full, I could barely stand up and had a hard time walking outta there! Hahaha! 
The food was pretty good! Apparently, the Korean tour bus stops here and if you're lucky, you get to eat with Korean tourists! 
I like that they serve a little sweet rice water after the meal! That was my favorite part, and probably the reason why  I get so bloaty like a blowfish afterwards b/c I always finish everything, every last grain!!! I practically lick the bowls. Hahaha, not a healthy thing to do, btw.
 
Now, if only it were a little cheaper, or if only I were a really rich girl (though I'd prefer the latter much)...i'd eat here all the time!
author: Tu L.

description:
Han Il Kwan is a block away from my compound and has always been an object of curiosity for me.  Everyday, around 2-6, tour buses park right in front and unload a horde of Korean tourists.  This could mean one of three things: 1.  Han Il Kwan sponsors these Korean tour buses 2.  This place is that damn good or 3.  Han Il Kwan is a training camp for Korean militants...North or South, of this I am unsure.

Planning a most glorious forth of july evening for kvu that included no plan, we walked from my compound to 28th, turned around and back all the way to arguello to pick a random restaurant.  Unfortunately, everything was closed; I was disappointed because behind the veil of spontaneity, I really wanted to go to Sanmi.
