However, we did have a delightful chinwag that she could not enjoy properly due to a wounded food.  Finally, we decided on Han Il Kwan because we were so close to my house.  It was pretty late when we arrived, about 9 yet the restaurant was still bustling.  There seemed to be a native Korean client base which means that the food was authentic, too authentic for casual eaters and non Koreans.  I was a little worried that I could not handle this.  We were asked what our preference was, bbq table or regular table.  I picked the table with the bbq just because it was a booth and looked more comfortable.  When we opened the menu, we learned that upon sitting here, you had to order 2 bbq items which were priced at about 20 bucks each.  As a result, I called my new roommate from Minnesota who galloped over in 30 seconds time and we ordered bulgogi, spicy pork and some jup chai? (sesame noodles) .  The bulgogi was tasty, however, for 20 bucks, the portions were not that generous.  We should have opted for them to cook it for us as my chef skills left some of the meat charred.  As a result, I put it on my roommate's plate.  The spicy pork was okay.  It was a bit spicy for me however, I won't use my shameful taste buds as an excuse to lower the rating.  I felt that the spice wasn't marinated as well as it should be.  It was a coating on the exterior of the pork, however, did not have time to meld with the meat.  I don't know if they marinated it on the spot or what.  The jup chai? was probably the best item out of those three.  It was sesame noodles with assorted vegetables and beef.

If Han Il Kwan is super authentic, then I guess I am not a fan.  All I really want when I eat Korean food is some cheese corn, tofu soup and unlimited bulgogi.  I am impartial to kalbi...i hate removing the bones.  As a result, I think I am more suited for AYCE aka Bob Sang.  Their ban chan was pretty exotic, highlighted by these jelly blocks.  All I ate was the pickled cucumbers.  My girlfriend had a higher opinion of the food than I did, echoing my sentiment for the sesame noodles.  The food was pretty expensive given the amount they gave you.  As a result, I have concluded that the "tourists" that come here aren't here for the food.  This place is a top-secret militant training camp.
author: Brian V.

description:
Tasty flavors all around.

I'd like to weigh in as a Korean food first-timer.  I absolutely love trying new cuisine.  I absolutely hate when you go to a restaurant and every dish is seasoned from the same pot.  Lucky for me, Kristin P. took me to Hall Il Kwan. 

Each of the little plates was bursting with unique flavors, and I'm still salivating over that hot pot.  We also had the pork ribs and a delicious egg dish.  

The service wasn't overly friendly, but was efficient enough and the price was right on!  We weren't drinking, but we got out of there for under $20/each.  I'd say it's a great place to go with friends - but not a great date atmosphere (the lights are super bright and it's not cozy furniture or decor).
author: Gretchen S.

description:
Can we order three bi bim bop, 2 without bean sprouts, 1 bulgoki, and 1 pork.

The three bi bim bops came and all three had bean sprouts.  We asked that we didn't want the bean sprouts because my friend was allergic to it.  She goes............those aren't bean sprouts and that they are soy sprouts.  I go wth?  Ok..........then show me how the bean sprouts look like on the one that had the bean sprouts.  All three orders looked exactly the same.  She couldn't explain.  Go figure!!!  The other two orders weren't any better.  The kim chee and the other 7 condiments were great but the bi bim bop was below average.  Got the free spicy tofu soup.  It was ok.  

I remember back in college where this place used to be called charcoal korean bbq woodhouse.........or something like that.  It was good back then...........now it's just ok. 

Total price 42.00
author: jason g.

description:
The wait is an hour long. so make sure u go one hour before u want to eat.
im not korean so im going to describe what i ate
We had the 

beef with potatoes dish - super YUM. beef was so tender, the sauce was AWESOME. Never had this before 5/5!
shredded beef soup - stable korean food 5/5!
complimentary egg stone pot - 5/5! yum
pork dish (semi spicy)- SO GOOD 5/5! the sauce was diff from the usual korean red sauce.. it was delicious
seafood pancake - 0/5 - it sucked. dont get it . i dont know why it tastes so horrible.
the complimentary rice water dessert - dont like it, its weird. but its free
rice cake - my friends like it, im not a rice cake person so i didnt eat it. i dunno if its good. cant rate.
lots of side dishes

this is the new korean place im gonna go to from now on.
this place is LEGIT!

btw, dont wear nice clothes there, it will smell. haha
author: Cindy L.

description:
3.5 stars.

We waited forty minutes, rather than the estimated twenty, to get seated at a BBQ table on a Saturday night. Waiting sucks! I was considering leaving so that I could redeem my free birthday lip gloss trio from Sephora (before it closed), but Jon W. made a puppy dog face, and how could I say "No" to that?

The restaurant was full of authentic Koreans, probably in part due to the Korean tour bus outside. I never understood why Koreans come to America to eat Korean food, but maybe it's really good here. Who knows. When I went to the bathroom, a bunch of older Korean ladies were brushing their teeth at the sinks and saying things to me in Korean, which I did not understand.

When we were finally seated, I was starving. The four of us ordered BBQ beef, BBQ chicken, and a bimbambop. The meal came with complimentary tea, spicy tofu soup (I don't do spicy), a rice drink dessert (not my thing really), rice, lettuce, and several plates of small dishes. I really loved the pancakes!

The BBQ beef was pretty good, but the chicken is where it's really at. It was soooo tender and delicious, bursting with flavor! It was also my first time utilizing a "cook-it-yourself" table. The boys did the cooking, but it was fun to watch!

The Bimbambop was so-so.There was an excess of veggies that are brown and look kind of like beef, but not enough actual beef. 

So definitely, the highlight of the night was the chicken. Price came out to be perhaps around $15 per person, reasonable. It was a really busy night when we came and the service was pretty good. Ironically, it's supposed to be the opposite on laid-back nights. According to my friends, on slow nights waiters/waitresses take care to treat their customers worse if they are not Korean. How sad!
author: K W.

description:
Jang Soo used to be our go-to restaurant for Korean food. But sometimes you want to switch things up and sometimes the often empty Jang Soo has fifty rowdy 20 year olds having some sort of party inside on a random Tuesday night. So you drive to Han II Kwan, a Korean restaurant located in another part of Richmond district that is equally difficult to find parking. 

Now, Han II Kwan caters to Korean tourists on most nights. And I don't mean a family on vacation in SF suddenly felt nostalgic and came in looking for authentic homemade food. I mean, there is a parking space outside designated for tour buses. Whenever we see one of those parked outside, we know our chance of getting a table is slim ( even if we do get a table the waitstaff will be too swamped to offer fast service). However now it seems like they put all the bus tourists in the inner room and people like us can still get a table in the outside room. Fantastic! 

Food is wonderful at Han II Kwan. Their chicken bulgogi is so flavorful and tender and not dry at all. Their little dishes are abundant and delicious. And like most Korean restaurants, they also throw in the freebies like pancakes and tofu stew. One of our favorite dishes to order is the spicy rice cakes. The texture of the ricecakes is really chewy but not tough. 

Service is fast and efficient. Space is fairly large and open and comfortable. And price is reasonable.
author: Candice B.

description:
I eat here after a stroll in Golden Gate Park.
Maybe its because of my heightened appetite but,
When its not overcrowded with busloads of Korean tourists, its wonderful wonderful food.
they give you spicy soft tofu soup free of charge.
They also give you sweet rice drinks for desert.

I got the kimchi and pork stir fry. It was pretty good.
Spicy pork BBQ is enjoyable as well.

Can't complain about the soon doo boo (soft tofu soup) since it doesn't cost extra.

Better side dishes than most places.
The mini pancakes they serve are pretty good w/ the spicy soy sauce.

Only prob is that I turn into a skeleton after years of decay when tourist groups are dining in.
It takes FOREVER to get seated when that happens,
so I keep my fingers crossed before I go in that there are no busloads of Korean tourists dining in there.
author: Cadence C.

description:
Just got back from dinner here.
The extent of my Korean authenticity starts and ends at the fact that I am one-quarter by blood.  I do not know the language.  I do not know much of Korean history.
What I do know is why there is a City Ordinance sign out front that  says "No idling of tour buses."
Now please excuse me.
It's elastic-waist pants time.
author: Barry A.

description:
Great food, but service could use some work.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description: Han Il Kwan is probably the best Korean restaurant in the city that being said...  Korean food isn't well represented in the city.  This is place to go for a nice sit down dinner.
author: Suz L.

description:
i am so stuffed from not being able to keep my chopsticks down and picking and picking even after i was "full", but still can't wait to go back here and get everything else on the menu. the next warm day, i've gotta  go back and get their Be Bim Neung Myun- looks soo good. 

between my chingu and me, the Kim Chi Ji Gae and Kim Chi Pancakes were waay more than we could handle, what with all the panchan- fresh and yummy panchan. seriously, super fresh ingredients, presented beautifully, appropriately priced and portioned, pleasant-pleasant service,..: Bomb Dig Korean Food = Han Il Kwan.
author: eVa J.

description:
This was my first Korean meal and it was amazing!  My friend and I had a table where we cooked the meat ourselves.  It was really really really good.  The side dishes were amazing as well.  
My only complaint is the super-bright lighting, but perhaps the light is there to show how clean the place is.
author: Irving B.

description:
Had an impromptu lunch her with a girlfriend and we were both so pleasantly surprised! The server was helping about 5 to 6 tables with grace. What a find for lunch....specials pretty much, under $10. Lots of sides, tofu soup and a pancake to try. We will definitely be back!

Loved the beef ribs, but the spicy pork wasn't as good as the beef. I will definitely be back to find some more fav's.
author: M M.

description:
all-around pretty solid. no one item really stood out, but we got a pretty wide variety of stuff, and nothing was bad either. 

for bbq, it's certainly better than brother's down the street (i don't get the hype about that place), but not as good as yakiniq. 

regardless, coming from the mission, it'd be shorter to bart to rockridge and go to ohgane in oakland's mini-koreatown, another place that also doesnt' really do any one thing particularly well, but is also all around pretty solid and just a notch above this place.
author: Mark A.

description: Pretty decent Korean food!  The ban chan was plentiful and the service was fast!  I only had the jap chae for lunch ... But I will have to return to try kbbq one day!  Let's see if it can match the caliber of the restaurants in LA ;)
author: Janice M.

description:
Usually come here with a large group for dinner because of the private rooms they have.  Food has always been good and a good selection.  

Came here for lunch the first time.  Ordered the lunch specials and wasn't bad.  Nothing really special during lunch.  The rating is really for dinner.  I think with the large selection of food, it is great to come with a large group and order a lot of different dishes.  

They do the tour bus crowd every now and then, there is reserved bus parking in front of the place.  Parking during the day is easy.  Get's harder at night  but if you don't mind walking a little - not a problem.
author: Ray Y.

description:
Yesssssssssss finally a place to go when you are FEELING for that korean food. We ordered 2 beef thingys and one pork (you can have them cook it inside or outside) I love all the little sides cept they dont have that rice cke thing (evidently a so-cal thing?) The service is pretty polite and fast. 

I love the rice drink at the end.  good thing my sister has a bunch of it in her room! 

Parking sucks we had to search for 20 min. and we ended up parking 5 blocks away!
author: Amy S.

description:
Decent Korean food.  The service kind of slow, and we had to ask to get the ban chan refill...

There were 2 bus full of Korean tourist there having dinner.  I was glad my friends had the insight to go early, so we beat the crowd.    So on weekend, try to go before 6pm!
author: Coco L.

description: I feel I've found my lost heritage, my Korean family .  My wonderful family who makes wonderful kimchi.  Just try to come before the tour bus comes.  I love this place.  Let me repeat, I love this neighborhood place.  They are generous with the banchan.  We counted 9 little big plates, enought to feed four people.  Lucky for us, there were just two of us.  Barley tea-they actually bring you a teapot.  Most Korean restaurants give you a tiny teacup; then you have to depend on them to refill it. We can actually drink our fill!  They started us with a little pancake.  The bibampap was good.  The Jap Chee had lots of mushrooms and spinach.  We even got a little tofu soup.  Aw, our tummies were filled!  On major holidays, no lunch specials.  I just have to play hooky one day from work and go there for their lunch specials.  There's at least 7 options to choose from.  To end our lunch, they have us a small sweet drink, just to clean our palates (I made that up).  Strangely, our cell phones didn't work inside the restaurant.  I wonder if they have a force field around this place?
author: Helen L.

description: We frequent this place at least once a month. Option to cook at the table or by the pros. Meats are savory and flavorful. Environment is not too smokey, if any. Favorite dish = raw beef with raw eggs and apples!! YUMMY! So much better than My Tofu House... which is on my "Banned" list.
author: Stephen Y.

description: Pretty authentic Korean dishes. They have one of the best spicy rice cake and beef stew in SF. However, the wait and service are definitely holding me back from giving them a 4 star. Never picked up the phone for reservations and the wait for dinner was 40min+, not to mention all the loud tourist groups. Though most of their dishes are decent and plentiful, I would only recommend this place to people with much patience and at least a party of 4.
author: Nawei C.

description:
Hooray, I've found my favorite Korean restaurant in the city!  Now if only it wasn't so far away!

Everything we ordered was fantastic - the bibimbap, rice noodles, tofu soup, BBQ pork, and pancake.  I'm looking forward to returning and trying even more dishes.
author: Corey C.

description: This is a good Korean restaurant, so good in fact that it attracts tour buses of Korean tourists.  You know that means it's good.  Downside is that you can have a wait and the service felt lackluster.  We were a bunch of suburban moms coming in for a meal, and perhaps that doesn't get the wait staff excited.  Little did they know we had a sleeper agent with us; one of the group had a Korean boyfriend in college and therefore speaks fluent Korean.  So, when she busted out some Korean, the wait staff paid attention and our service improved.  Anyway, all the food was excellent, and my only beef (beyond the complaint about the initial service) was that one of the wait staff picked up raw chicken to put on the grill and lifted it over some lettuce & other sides, dripping raw chicken juice along the way.  We all saw it and avoided the potentially salmonella-tainted food, but they really should know better!
author: Pamela D.

description:
My bro is working as a chef in a cool gastropub in the Haight.  So of course since I'm from out of town, I say let's go check out your new restaurant.  Nooooooooooo.  The fucker wants to eat Korean instead.  And that's why I'm writing yet another Asian food review instead of trippy free love gastropub review from the Haight.  And it looks like this place has already been yelped enough.  But I'll yelp it for my LA and NY friends anyway.  

The food is good... and the portions are generous.  OMG - there's a lot of food.  No recession going on in there. But for me, what makes it stand out is the novelty of seeing authentic dishes on the menu that I've never seen before.  

They have dishes like non-marinated kalbi.  I dunno what the real name is, but I've never seen that on a Korean menu before.  It's tasty... but given a choice between marinated and non-marinated kalbi... choose the marinated kalbi.  It's got more flavor.  I kicked myself after having some of my brother's.

And seriously, go easy on the portions.
author: David F.

description:
This was only the second Korean restaurant that I have eaten at, but I still think that it was pretty good. We had a lunch special so, the prices were pretty low, I think that it was like $30 plus tip. The chicken and beef were very delicious, but then again its kinda hard to mess that up. We also had the Bi Bim Bop. I thought that it was much better here, than it was at the previous place I tried it. All of the side dishes were good.
The only down side to the experience was the fact that there was only one guy working in the front, so he was serving everyone and also working the register. Even with that the food still came relatively quickly.
author: Josh S.

description:
I have been here several times now, and it was only until I tried to write a review that I realized I had no idea what the name of the restaurant was. This place fulfills my Korean cravings so dutifully that I have never taken the time -- no, no. . I've never taken the second to look up at the name of this place. All I know is that it's delicious and hurriedly walk straight in. I mean, c'mon. . . that's gotta make their food sound great if i have complete tunnel vision when I come to Balboa and 19th. To be honest, I couldn't even tell you where on Balboa this place is, i had to look it up. . I suppose whenever I do go there, I'm magnetically drawn to it rather than needing to look for an address of follow directions. Hm, that's kinda funny.

Alright, enought rambling. I haven't been here for yakiniku as I am fully satisfied with the plates alone. Reasonably priced at below $10 for a plate, you just can't go wrong. Side dishes are usually enough to fill anyone up. I barely touch my main dish when I come here for lunch. I usually look at my server with pleading, "I swear I'm not anorexic" eyes, and I'm sure she understands. 

Also, the last time I was there, a giant bus of tourists from Korea unloaded to eat at this restaurant. If a giant bus of Korean tourists come to eat here, you know it's gotta be good.
author: Irene C.

description:
We ate and ate, took a break, and ate some more. The tofu soup was good, the seafood soup was rich, the kalbi was great, the banchan was excellent. Two tour buses outside kept a constant supply of Koreans from LA who ate quickly and with their jackets on to fill the tables causing us to have to wait 20 minutes or so to be seated. But watching LA koreans eat in rotation efficiently and happily made me confident that the food would be good. It was. Its no BCD tofu house, but it is good enough. After attempting Korean in London, I am just happy the banchan is like its supposed to be...free. 

Will continue the search for korean food in SF but I will likely end up back here.
author: Octavia L.

description:
I studied abroad in Korea for a year so I'm quite picky with my  Korean Cuisine. My friend and I were craving Korean BBQ so we ordered  Pork strips and  Spicy Beef. The side dishes were alright but the meat was delicious. It came with soup on the house and we ate it with loads of Miso paste for meat and washed it down with a OB beer.

Over all the food was delicious, very clean environment and service is really good. I would definitely come here again. Korean BBQ was a little on the expensive side, we spent with drinks around $28 a person but it was well worth it.
author: Sara B.

description:
Han Il Kwan was totally worth:

-putting on an extra layer of clothing to brave the thick Richmond fog
-driving 25 minutes to travel 3.1 miles (thanks Google Maps!)
-driving another 10 minutes to find a parking spot in the land of driveways and people who don't dare to move their cars on a Friday night.

But despite all that, I'd go back!  The food was excellent.  As good a Korean restaurant as I've been to.  Nice atmosphere-- a little bright, but it'd be great for a group.  The little plates are the stand out star, bites of pickled goodness that you don't even pay for!  The Kimchi soup was really tasty, not too spicy.  The bulgogi was very flavorful, if only a little fatty.  The Tteokbokki was better than I've had it other places, the sauce was less sweet more tangy.  Three of us, three dishes, $16 a person.  Can't beat that!
author: Kristin P.

description:
The good: Their side dishes (bahn-chan) and wonton soup (thuck mandoo) were decent. Nice assortment of side dishes and they were fresh and flavorful. The wonton soup was hearty without being too greasy.

The bad: Their galbi was just average. Not much flavor to the meat. Their thuckbokgee (rice cake logs in red bean paste sauce) had a funny taste to it, almost like they used anchovy-based seasoning on it. Odd. Even a Korean market thuckbokgee is better than the one at Han Il Kwan.

The ugly: Service was ATROCIOUS, even for a Korean restaurant. We waited about 40 minutes to get seated and then it took another 15 minutes to get our bahnchan.

I initially told the waiter I was just going to have soup and no barbecue. When I arrived, I told him we changed our mind and we would also barbecue at the table. Once we got seated, he tried to MAKE US MOVE TO A NON BARBECUE TABLE because some customer who CAME IN AFTER US complained about it.  Apparently, he had promised them the barbecue table. Instead of telling them that the customers who came in BEFORE THEM had changed their minds and had the barbecue table, he had the BALLS to try to make me change tables. F*** YOU!

Also, the old Korean ajima who "took care" of us, and I use the term loosely, only came by when she had something to bring. Otherwise, she didn't stop BY ONCE to see if we needed more bahnchan, water, or anything else.  And she didn't change our grill even once, a pretty standard procedure in Korean restaurants that know what they're doing.

Why is it so difficult to find a decent Korean restaurant in SF???  If you want decent Korean food, I'd suggest going to Ohgane in Oakland. Worth the extra 10 minute drive.

Avoid this place like the plague.  I got crappy service and I'm Korean and I SPOKE Korean with them. Imagine the kind of service YOU'RE going to get.
author: Baxter L.

description: One of my favorite Korean restaurants in the City.  Flavors are great, meat is quality.  Its gotta be legit when Korean tour groups stop there to eat.  Can be a little pricey for dinner but what K-spot isnt?  Lunch is super reasonable as we go to this place all the time when my fiance lived across the street. Only thing that would make i better if it was an AYCE spot.
author: Kevin A.

description:
Checked this place out with some buddies on a Saturday night. After reading up reviews on Yelp, I have to agree with everything. Service is bad. We waited probably 15 minutes for a table when there were plenty of empty tables. When a table did "open up," we were put in a corner where the waiter couldn't see you. Nevertheless, we persevered and ordered a ton of food

 (Pardon any spelling errors as I don't speak Korean.) 

Had the spicy pork chabchaei (noodles), and rice clay pot with beef. All the dishes were excellent but what was really really good were the side dishes! Very fresh vegetables and top notch sauces and flavoring. 

If you can handle the service, I highly recommend this place. Food is wonderful.
author: Jonathan L.

description: Pretty yummy Korean food. I can't say that there was one thing that stood out, but the seafood pancake was good and so was the bulgogi. The tofu soup was just okay. Its a good place for a large group because the restaurant can seat a lot of people.
author: Gwenn G.

description: Came here the other night and was definitely impressed with the bbq. We ordered the marinated rib eye and spicy pork. Side dishes were super tasty (kimchee was delicious and tangy). The spicy pork was so tender and had just the right amount of spice. We were brought a complimentary tofu soup that was really delicious. My boyfriend would make a special trip out to the Richmond for this soup alone.  We also had ordered the kimchee pancake but our waitress had forgot to put that order in. She was really apologetic and we had ordered plenty of food as it was so no biggy. Not every table has grills so depending on the night, you might have to wait a bit (we only waited maybe 10 minutes) or you can sit at a regular table and have the bbq cooked for you by the kitchen. We'll definitely be back!
author: Heather U.

description:
Love the side dishes. Price is reasonable. Food variety is decent. Service is slow tho

Korean pancake is great! The spicy soup is okay
author: Cliff T.

description:
The best Korean restaurant in the city along with one of the most affordable! And lets just say that I've had a LOT of Korean food in my lifetime. Possibly too much. But I loooove me some Korean food, no lie! 
Every time I've gone to Han Il Kwan I've had a wonderful time. It's a very comfortable atmosphere, where you can choose either a BBQ table or regular table. I prefer the BBQ tables by the window even if we are not BBQing, because it's exceptionally cozy and nice when you're accompanied by friends or family. 

The food is really delicious, seasoned well and very fresh. The only mishap I've had is the spicy squid dish (can't remember the exact name) where it was a little gummy for my taste. Squid is not necessarily the easiest texture to deal with though. Everything else I've had is always on point and tasty. My boyfriend and I frequent this restaurant as much as possible as it's one of our favorite spots, and we always get the same friendly service with great food. Our favorites to order are the chap chae, bulgogi and kimchi jigae. All the panchan are always fresh and compliment our meals to the tee. Plus the free sides never dissapoint and we love to receive the little surprise to our meal.

Love this place! You can't really go wrong, seeing that even Korean tourists come to this place on the regular. ;)
author: Tay R.

description:
the main dining room is basically 2 concentric circles with 9 booths having hoods in the outer circle. the inner circle  has 4  hoodless tables. there is a private banquet room in the back. there is a dual lighting system, making this place very bright.

after i ordered the oxtail stew soup(10.95),  a pot of barley tea was  quickly followed by 9 banchan items. they were all fresh and served at room temperature.  

the oxtail stew soup  came with soy sauce and a cup of salt which was helpful in flavoring the bland, milky white broth which had some strands of  yam threads in it.  the waitress also brought a steamed egg side dish "on the house". 

the five pieces of oxtail was tender but tasteless. adding soy made it tastier. the banchan was plentiful and good but not outstanding. a  sikhye(sweet korean rice beverage) was given  for dessert. .

4 stars for efficient service, fair value. i didn't find the food outstanding but ok 
ymmv.
author: Victor G.

description: The bimbibap was just ok here. I don't remember now, but i remember it missing several key ingredients that most korean restaurants usually put into it. This place is alright. Can't say I had the greatest experience here or the most fun. Mayybe I'll come back to give it another shot seeing that most people do enjoy eating here.
author: Sylvester N.

description:
I'm going to go out on a limb and say this is the best Korean restaurant in the city of SF.  Fresh, varied sides, really good stews / soups / noodles and super sweet service.  Of note: spicy beef soup, rice cake soup, cold noodle soup, dol sot bibim bap, kim chee chigae, pah jan (green onion pancake), etc.  They'll also throw in complimentary items ("on the house") like steamed egg and mackerel, just because they're super nice.  If you're really really lucky, you'll visit when the Korean tour bus is parked outside, and the Koreans are partaking in the back room.  Wherever you go, there the Koreans are. This place is also clean.

EAT HERE!!!!
author: Natasha S.

description:
I must say, for something I've only eaten a few times in my life, Korean is rapidly overtaking Chinese and Japanese as my favorite of the east asian cuisines.  Maybe it's the dedication to serving everything at scalding temperatures, like bi bim bap in a sizzling stone pot that stays hot for hours, or the grills built into the tables (which Han Il Kwan has a few of).  Maybe it's the generous use of egg in everything (dig that batter on the pan-fried shrimp).  Maybe it's those orgasmic, crispy-n-chewy veggie "pancakes" (or those squishy-n-sticky rice ball banchan--I could eat a million of those).  Maybe it's all the free goodies you get (banchan, of course, but they even threw in a huge bowl of tofu soup here).

Anyway, I can't quite give Han Il Kwan it the same 5 stars as Toyose's or Shin Toe Bul Yi, if for no other reason than the grotesquely bright fluorescent lights (a real shame because the decor's actually not bad).  But it's a worthy entry in the genre nonetheless, and in an off-the-beaten-path location that always makes you feel like more of a local.
author: Wes M.

description: So I'm guessing there aren't too many good korean places in the city, which is somewhat a disappointment since I'm from Philly. This place was recommended by my friends and even though I was craving for Korean food, it really didn't satisfy or satiate me. We got the tofu soup (assuming it's suppose to be soondubu) as a compliment along with the side dishes with our korean bbq consisting of kalbi, pork belly, and spicy pork. Each meat was ok, not super flavorful. The tofu soup was also just ok. It didn't give me the wet dreams I've had of soondubu on a cold night warming me with it's spiciness and the heat from the soup containing soft tofu that slides right down your throat. As everyone has claimed, the bebimbap was pretty good. We just got the classic one to share. The rice is pretty soft and mixed well with all the other vegetable ingredients. i doused mine with hot sauce too!
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
I love Korean food.  I love the flavors, I love the smells.

The day after Thanksgiving, we had reunion #2, missing a couple of people, again.  I called earlier that day to make reservations for 8 at 8pm (we ended up with 9 people but that didn't seem to matter much).  We slowly began arriving starting around 8, I didn't get there until 8:30..parking sucks!  The guys all came shortly after I did.

We decided on a set menu for 6-7 people + dduk bok ki!  We had 2 sets of ban chan which made me super happy :)

The set menu included
- choice of kalbi or bulgoki (we ordered kalbi)
- choice of dak gui or spicy pork (we ordered spicy pork)
- pancake
- japchae
- soon dobu soup - kinda on the salty side
- spicy squid & octopus
- 2 fried fish
- deep fried egg&shrimp, and zucchini
*complementary steamed egg (which is piping hot...a few of us burned our mouths, including me...)

The dduk bok ki was really over cooked, rather than being chewy, it was really soggy and fell apart.  Everything else was wonderful though!  The ahjuma's that work here are all pretty nice, I've been coming here for about 6 years and I haven't had a bad/bitchy experience.  My Korean is rusty, so I don't dare use it!  

We all had a great meal.  No complaints..nobody said anything tasted funny, with the exception of some of the banchan (to this day, there are a few dishes I won't touch).  Our meal ended with sweet rice water, yummy!  

In the end, it came out to be $16/person, including tip, which is REALLY cheap considering how much food we had.  There were tons of left overs!
author: Steph D.

description:
My last two experiences with Korean food did not work out so well and so I was reluctant when my Korean friend suggested/demanded we go to this place.  I have never had Korean BBQ before, mostly because I don't eat beef or pork but I was assured that there would be enough for me to eat.  Well, not only was there enough food for me, there was (as my friend put it) "enough food to feed the entire country of Ethiopia".  I let my Korean friend do the ordering and so was not aware of the sheer magnitude of what was about to hit us.  The next hour and a half would go down forever as the most epic eating experience of my life.

At first I was skeptical of the concept; when I go out to eat, the last thing I want to do is to have to cook my own food.  But this place really reminded me of how little we have evolved as a species; if you have a group of 5 hungry men, throwing a pile of raw meat in front of them with an open flame is still the best way to appease them.  The food was pretty fantastic, despite the fact that the only meat I eat is chicken and some seafood.  I don't have a good frame of reference when it comes to Korean food, but pretty much everything I ate was delicious.  

Despite being completely overwhelmed and defeated by the inordinate amount of food we received , the waiting staff must have felt we had not suffered enough because they also brought out a complimentary steamed egg dish and a shot of sweet rice milk(?) for dessert. By the end of the meal, I probably increased my likelihood of developing heart disease and will possibly get struck by lightning for the number animals that were harmed during the preparation of our meal.  Gotta love the food chain...    

Pros:
- Now I can hibernate
- Good service; my friend would yell out what sounded like angry demands for water or a new grill plate in Korean, and the waitresses would happily oblige, sometimes while bringing back more plates of food.
- Vegetarian friendly
- There were a good mix of people eating at the restaurant, so I was not as intimidated as I usually am when I go to most other authentic Asian restaurants...even though I was still embarrassed to order water

Cons:
- The chicken could have had a bit more flavor too it
- Would have liked the spice level a little higher in general
- My clothes will smell like Korean BBQ for weeks

After a couple of weeks of recovery and a few more months of training, I think I'll be ready for Round 2...
author: Satyan P.

description:
this might be the best korean food ive had in SF.  i loved ALL the side dishes- lots of veggies that were flavorful but really refreshing and all the spicy stuff was a good amount of spicy but still tasty.  we had the spicy pork bbq and the chap chae for dinner and they were both solid- the pork was flavorful and not overcooked (we didn't do bbq at the table) and the chap chae was tasty and had lots of delicious veggies and meat mixed in.  i also loved that you get hot tofu soup to start as part of your meal.

prices were good, service was excellent, and food was solid.  i will definitely be coming back here.
author: Lisa C.

description:
Remember when you were a kid and tried to feed your goldfish a little bit of food but ended up doing an 8 year-old's version of the Exxon Valdez oil spill?  After the initial shock and panic, what would you do?  If you were like me, you'd leave it and hope your parents wouldn't see it.  But what happens?  You come back and find that your goldfish has exploded from overeating.

I act like a goldfish when I'm here.
author: Tommy O.

description:
4.50 stars!

I've came here many times, mostly with a very large group (15+). The staff (family-run I believe) was very friendly and accommodating. They have separate rooms in the back that they can rearrange (using curtains) to accommodate big groups. They always give some dishes on-the-house, which is a very nice thing for them to do. Those dishes are delicious too. I usually get the stone-pot rice. One time, a smaller group of us (4-5) came here for a Korean BBQ, and we had a blast (with soju) and a full stomach afterwards.
author: Sam W.

description:
Very near my house so I've been dying to try it. It's very intimidating since it's a major draw for Korean tour buses. I feel like maybe I'm a little too white to go in sometimes.

Was feeling adventurous so I dragged some friends with me. We ordered a few things to share but didn't think we went overboard on ordering. Man were we wrong! They bring out so much food "on the house" that we were incredibly full by the end (and only $54 for 3 people!). Some of the small plates they brought were a little too "Fear Factor" for my white self, but I made sure to try everything. Let's just say fried guppies aren't really my thing.

Other than the few surprises, I can safely say that I enjoy authentic Korean food. I had had only bbq before, so we stuck mainly to the non-bbq side of the menu. Will be adding their take out menu to the drawer - late night kim chee bean curd pancakes? Yes please
author: Sarah P.

description:
Looking for a good Korean restaurant in the City is the Holy Grail of restaurant searches (well, at least for me).  It's the Holy Grail in many respects because at its core is the question of whether it really exists.  Is it real or just the result of someones overactive imagination?

Assuming it does exist, I'm hoping to God that my first sip of Dae Gu Mae-Un Tang (hot cod fish stew) will give me eternal life.  Considering all the money I've wasted at bad Korean restaurants around here, I gotta deserve at least that right?  Indiana Jones had it easier.

Alas, Han Il Kwan is not the Holy Grail.  In fact, it's not even the Styrofoam cup you can find in your office breakfast nook.  Instead of eternal life, I think I just lopped off a few years.  Might as well speed up the process with a little soju (SKOAL!)

The fish in the Dae Gu Tang was just horrid....like it was dried and was not given enough time to hydrate.  It's was like bacalhau still in its mummified, salt preserved state.  Awful.

The Galbi was not marinated in the right way, and when you cooked it up, instead of turning a caramelized deep brown color from the sugars in the marinade, it turned lighter in color, like it was steamed.  The flavor showed it.  Not good.  I also prefer real charcoal grills, which Han Il Kwan did not have.  But if you are going to use gas grills at least have a real grill on top.  We were given a perforated round metal plate that was way too thin and thus caused the beef to burn too easily (no, it wasn't a So Duuk Gong grill top....not shaped right, too thin, and a real So Duuk Gong doesn't have perforations).

The only saving grace was Sam Gyup Sal which was cut thick the way I like it.  But heck, that wasn't really the skills of the restaurant showing was it?  And we had to cook it ourselves....so no mercy points there.

Anyway, my faith in things religious has been put into question for many a years now.  Experiences like these aren't helping.
author: James K.

description:
[words of advice]  if you see a tour bus or a huge crowd of people both inside and outside, just WALK AWAY from the restaurant.  i guess this is a hit place for tourists to stop and eat, but it is definitely a NO-NO for local patrons. :O

[when]  tuesday, 08/04/09 @ 5:15PM
[service]  not so good. my friends & i had to keep asking for everything. all the waiters and waitresses were too busy serving the tourist. 
[food]  SPICY TOFU SOUP:  not bad, but had better. 
            COLD NOODLES:  just so-so. 
[perks] side dishes galore, like 10 of them!   they give you a nice cold sweet rice drink after your meal. 
[price]  the food is somewhat on the pricey side. 
[things to remember] don't come here between 5-6:30PM or when you see bunch of tour buses. 

if i go there next time, hopefully, it will be better.
author: Deborah C.

description:
Another regular spot for my family, our go-to Korean restaurant in the city.  We love coming here for lunch to take advantage of their incredible deals!  To be fair, I have eaten my share of Korean foods and have definitely developed my own personal taste, but it's not anywhere near what the authentic standard should be. 

They recently changed their prices abit, but it's still great.  We normally go for 2 of the meats: bulgogi ($8.95), kalbi (9.95), pork bulgogi and chicken ($7.50).  And sometimes either bimbimbap or japchae as well.  With each entree, it comes with rice, tofu soup or steamed egg, and some dessert sweet water.  They also have a good variety of appetizers.  The meat is on par with other good restaurants in my opinion.  

The service and staff is always very nice and generous about giving the extra stuff.  They do serve Korean tour groups during lunch time often, so service can be a bit slow during those times, but it's never bothered us before!
author: Christina D.

description: long wait to get a table but man was it worth it! They said that you can make a reservation if you call 2 hours in advance so maybe give that a try. Food was amazing, service was great, and the extras that come with any korean meal just takes it over the top! Can't wait to come back.
author: Venatius P.

description:
So basically in my opinion..this is the best korean restaurant in the city.  You can, however, call me biased since I did basically grow up off of the food of this restaurant.  But you can trust my word since I cam very Korean and I have tried many other Korean restaurants in the city and this is one of the top ones!

Their kalbi is usually very tasty, they have the best and most plentiful and replenishable side dishes, they give free eggs and tofu soup and bean cakes, and their service is usually good for us..since us koreans r super assertive.  All in all, I love this place...I can call it home
author: Jane K.

description: i give it 2 stars because of 4 areas. The first area is the food. I think the food is OK but not the best I have tried in a while. The beef was too chewy and I couldn't swallow it. The second area is the service. I personally think the service was TERRIBLE. For example, the appetizer came last. The point is, the service was really slow. The third area is the price. This KBBQ place is a little pricey. The beef was $26! The last area was the setting. It was a good setting and it was a beautiful part of San Francisco. That is why I rate this KBBQ place 2 stars.
author: Michael T.

description: Awesome korean bbq.  The short ribs were fantastic.  Also a big fan of the pancakes.  We went with six friends and it came out to $19/person with tip (and everyone was pretty stuffed).  They also threw in an egg custard on the house!
author: Sean L.

description:
Ok. 

For the record, just because you are 240 lbs of snarky white guy, have eaten the 72 oz steak at the Big Texan in Amarillo, and have a Korean cousin as well as a half-Korean god-daughter is NO REASON to talk smack to the ridiculous amount of BBQ that Han II Kwan has waiting for you.

14 small side dishes, a quart of beer, and 5 pounds of perfectly marinated BBQ on a freezing cold summer night in the Richmond. I'm talking Thanksgiving meat-sweats level of full, here, children.

Bring a posse, and make sure your posse got velocity. Han II Kwan will defeat you, and you will feel shame.
author: Brock D.

description:
Came here with a group of friends on a Sunday night around 7ish. Looking for parking took so much longer than the actual wait time for a table! There were a lot of open tables still by the time we walked into the restaurant. The friends had all been here in the past and claimed it was delicious, it was my first time here. 

Their menu offered your usual choice of Korean dishes- we went with jap chae, spare ribs, chicken, and bulgogi. They offer free tofu soup with the dishes so that was something different that you do not find often in other Korean restaurants. Their side dishes were pretty typical, bean sprouts, anchovies, kim chee, etc. The star of the side dishes i must say were these delicious fish cakes that had me asking for more one after another! I couldn't get enough of them! As a dessert for when you are done with your meal they serve the sweet rice drink that you can ask for refills on!

The reason this place is getting only 3 stars is because their service is just horridly slow. It definitely was not a busy night but the waiter/ess just did not seem to want to move!! We had a party of 7 and they gave us only one pair of tongs to cook all our meat. We had asked them for another pair and the nice man said "okay", but he just walked away and completely forgot about us. We asked again but with someone different this time, and the nice lady said "okay", but she too seemed to have forgotten. Finally my friend got up herself and went to the back to grab us some tongs. Same thing happened when we asked for a refill of the side dishes and tea. You have to ask multiple times over and over till you sound like a broken record till you actually get what you are asking for. Again it was NOT a busy night so we didn't understand why the service was so bad and slow. We never got our tea refilled btw, because they either just simply forgot or didn't want to refill it. 

Overall the food was tasty and the jap chae was one of the better ones I've had, but the service was not that great.
author: Virginia L.

description:
Got together here tonight with my college sorority sisters.  We make it a point to get together every other month to catch up wtih each other's lives--  who's married, who's dating whom, latest gossip, etc...  anyhow, we chose to try the pre fixe meal with the choice of cooking it yourself or having it done in their kitchen (we chose the latter so that we'd have more time to chat). For 4-5 people and for $105, we got the fried mackeral, deep fried vegetables and oysters, calimari, kalbi, bbq chicken, spicy tofu soup, and all the other tasty side dishes that come with Korean meals (my favorite!)--  lots of food, very tasty, service is cordial and non intrusive, but available when you need something.  

I would recommend this place to others, though there are also a lot of other good Korean restaurants to choose from in the city.
author: Vickie Y.

description:
I came here for lunch on a weekday.

The food:

Pros: I loved the wide variety of authentic korean dishes offered on the menu compared to other korean establishments in the city. Food included bbq, tofu soup, chop chae, seafood pancakes etc etc. We ordered a tofu soup and bbq beef short rib (kal bi). The tofu soup was just average compared My Tofu House on Geary. There was only one type of tofu soup offered and it was lacking the hot spice and overall flavor i was accustomed to in most tofu soups. On the BRIGHTER side, however, i must say that the kal-bi was excellent. It was perfectly cooked, consisted of the right portion of meat and fattiness, and very very flavorful. I could not stop eating the kal-bi. Furthermore, like most korean restaurants, han il kwan offered a number of small dish appetizers (ban chan). They offered an extended variety of appetizer dishes in larger portions when compared to My Tofu House. They offered fried pancakes w/ dipping sauce, steamed egg custard, kim chee, cucumber, etc etc. 

The service + price:

I think price-wise, it is comparable to most korean restaurants, maybe slightly cheaper for some items. The service was eh. The waiter seemed a little too strict with certain rules and acted like he didn't want to be bothered. For example, i witnessed a party of 6 come in for lunch and they approached the big round tables (there was no one but us in this restaurant). Before they seated themselves, the waiter quickly added that round tables were only for "big parties." The party of 6 reiterated that they had 6 people, yet the waiter didn't want to hear anymore of it and simply gestured them to a smaller table and put the menus down. Those big round tables only had 8 chairs, two more than their party size. This, in addition to the glaring fact that there were no other people in this restaurant, reflects very poorly on the staff and management of the restaurant. 

Overall, i liked the food, variety, and price of this korean restaurant. The service was so-so and has potential for being worse than that, though i have not personally experienced anything unbearable just yet. Would i go here again? Probably and really only because there are few korean cuisine choices in the city and I would like some variety in my korean choices.
author: Nathan T.

description:
A review in haiku:

Food is pretty good.
Parking is kind of a pain.
But clothing won't reek.
author: Jenny K.

description:
This is the worst Korean Restaurant I ever went to! I heard so many good things about this place so me and my husband decided to go there and give it a try.  Yes, I have to say that the portion  is huge but seriously lacking some flavors. Price is the same as most Korean restaurant.Service was horrible! When we got there , there was so many empty tables so we were a bit surprise when the waiter told us to wait 10 minutes. Well, 25 minutes has pass and the waiter just keep walking pass us as if we don't even exist.  Finally, he gave us a table that was empty in the very beginning. Then he gave us our menu, took him another 15 minutes to come back and take our order.  This will be my first and last time going there. 

FYI , don't even bother going inside if you see tourist bus parked outside. All they care about is the tourist people, they don't give a crab about the locals. If you happen to get a table and tourist ppl start coming in, prepare for the long wait  for the waiter to even come to you table to take your order. 

I sure hope the owner of this restaurant read this and make some improvements.
author: tina l.

description: great mom and pop. there are sooo many side dishes including soon du bu, so it doesn't get better than that.  i always go to get the beef tartar bi bim bap and its delicious!
author: Sharon C.

description: Had driven by here so many times in the past 6 years I have no idea why I never walked the 3 blocks from my house to eat here.  Probably because there are so many other options.  I could also be the fear invoked by the tour bus parked out front 40% of the time I have driven by.  So we set out on a Sunday at 6 pm to check it out and as we turned the corner sure enough... there was that tour bus.  I wanted to bail but my wife insisted.  I'm glad she did because we thoroughly enjoyed this place.  The wait wasn't more than 10min and there was an extra room in the back for large groups.  We had kids with us so opted to have the kitchen bbq our meat (which they charged us to do annoyingly).  It was good.  Hot pot good.  Soup good.  The copious number of small side dishes thrown in were awesome.   I can't wait to go back and do this again. .
author: jd h.

description: Came here starving and freezing one weekend evening and had to wait a good while for a table that had a working grill. Luckily once we were seated, everything came out super fast. And luckily bf is an amazing kbbq-er and prepared our food perfectly. I loved many of the banchans and enjoyed the complimentary tofu soup that totally hit the spot on such a cold night. I highly enjoyed the chicken bulgolgi and of course the beef is always fantastic. Two orders of meat can probably feed a family of four. I could barely move after the meal, I was so satiated and blissful. So many tour buses come here that there is a special parking space for tour buses during the day. If it's good enough for Korean tourists... it must be good.
author: Lydia W.

description:
Definitely one of my tops for Korean BBQ. To be blunt, I'm a bit of a rookie when it comes to Korean BBQ, but I could "bulgogi" with the best of 'em I tell ya! I'd prefer cooking at the table since it looks like I know what I'm doing - and plus, I like the beef as rare as possible. The place does get loud, especially when big families and Korean tourists are bus loaded in there (yes, I kid you not...bussed in there). 

But when it's only a handful of people inside, it's worth it. And the staff is helpful as well when it isn't as crowded...so you won't look like such a rookie.
author: Ted P.

description: Hadn't eaten here in years. So I didn't know what to expect. BUT, it was great. We went with a group of our colleagues and it was a feast! I think we all had to roll outta there when we were done. Yummy..
author: Mashimaro M.

description:
Ever since moving to new work and working with an office full of Koreans, my vocabulary of Korean foods has expanded tremendously.  I'm still no pro to Korean food, but I can say with confidence that my tolerance for spicy food is a lot higher than it used to be.

One of the great things I generally find about Korean food is that it's typically good. I've never had a bulgogi or galbi that I didn't like, although sometimes kimchi jjigae can be hit or miss depending where you go.  Nevertheless, to my beginner's K-palette, Han Il Kwan serves up a delicious meal.

My girlfriend and I came here for some take out.  The interior is interesting to say the least, they've got an inside-outside motif going with a faux roof decorated in blue ceramic singles facing the interior of the dining room.  It's cozy and makes you feel like you're somewhere other than Balboa Street.

We had some of the basics--panjun, galbi, jap chae, and kimchi jjigae--enough food to last us a couple days.  We both stuffed ourselves silly and passed out.  Mission accomplished.
author: Tony L.

description:
This place is really a hit or miss. Depending on if there is a tour bus parked in their designated spot.

Luckily we came just as the Korean/Chinese tourists were finishing up and leaving, so we didn't have to wait long. However, people continued to pour in so I suppose that's why the food was a bit lacking.

The two of us ordered the soon doo boo to share, figuring it would be enough considering the side dishes. We immediately changed our minds and called the waiter back to order a kimchi jun. When the side dishes came, and then the soup, we knew we ordered too much. Reason: the side dishes are plentiful and are (almost) always spot on. The tofu soup, however, had little to no spices in it. My Korean boyfriend was extremely disappointed! Kimchi jun was really doughy, and we couldn't really eat more than 1-2 pieces each. This trip was no good, but I've gone other times (when the place is emptier) and the food is yum.

Oddly enough, we felt fairly satisfied after our meal. Although i do think this has something to do with coming back from a 15-mile bike ride. Stars for the one friendly/always smiley waiter, though.
author: Cynthia T.

description: This place tastes amazing. I went here when I was on vacation, and it makes Korean food in Houston look like crap. They have the best little side dishes. The price is very reasonable for the quality and the amount of food they give you.
author: Nancy K.

description:
5 Stars, have I gotten soft? nope, but for soft tofu soup, generous helpings of banchans (side dishes), and mountain high portions.. I think so. 

Being a closeted korean foodie, I've been around. It's no lie when I say that I finally found a reason to stop my korean crawl. Han II Kwan is by far one of the few better korean restaurants in the city.

Food:

Side Dishes: soo yummy, and fresh! They also give each guest a korean pancake on the hizzhouse! steal.

Marinated Chicken: Very moist, juicy, and well seasoned. You can taste the sweet and savory combo of the marinate well after the BBQ. This is mouth watering good.

Chap Chae: I usually hate this dish cause' typically, it's tough, chewy and hard to digest.. usually ending in a very painful #2 (TMI, i know. but i want you guys to get the full picture :D. your welcome). Contrary to my bad experiences, HIK serves up very digestible and delicious chap chae loaded with mushroom and other veggies. yummm.

Rice Noodle Cakes in Red Sauce: Nothing spectacular, but definitely delicious. Chewy&Spicy. Great app.

Soft Tofu Soup: DON'T ORDER IT, cause' it's generally on the HIZZHOUSE. Very delicious! Well seasoned, perfect amount of savory and spicy! Def. the best I've tasted so far!

Kim Chi Pancakes: Again, nothing spectacular, but great appetizer! Very tasty and comes in a large portion.

Diggs&Service:

It gets busy here for dinner.. Not cheesecake factory busy on a satuday night in DT SF, but still a wait. With Korean Tour Buses dropping off bus loads of guests every 2 hours, I would suggest you  get there early or make a reservation. Parking also sucks... -___-

While jam-packed with guest, the staff still manages to hold everything together. Very organized and efficient style of serving.

Decor looks very traditional korean restaurant. HIK appears very clean and spacious.

SO here's the dirty dirty... I've been turned away from here a couple of times because it was so busy. My generally reaction would be"F U HIK, I can go else where"... So the fact that i return like a good lil' bitch, suggests a lot. and NO i am not getting soft. 

HIGHLY RECOMMENDED to ALL.

TIP: come here for lunch for even better prices! literally half off! Have you ever paid 8.50 for delicious kal bi? HIK's lunch specials are NO JOKE!

i heart thee.
author: Alex C.

description: I have given only two stars. This Saturday I had lunch here. Service was poor.  Nothing especial about the food.  One can ger similar food at other Korean restaurants but a bit cheaper. The only good thing about it was that the sorroundings were better.
author: roger j.

description:
Jan 1, 2009 12PM
Me: Hello, are you open?
Korean lady: Yes
Me: Do you have dduk gook?
Korean lady: Yes

Done and done, thank you Yelp for saving my New Years!
author: Allen S.

description:
Dining at this restaurant makes me question everything I know about Korean BBQ. I've been in this city for less than a year, so I realize my options are still pretty vast, and I've tried a few, but none of them even remotely resembled my experience at this place. 

Under normal circumstances, I prefer chicken over beef 7 days of the week. However, when the lunch menu here didn't include any chicken options, I went ahead and reluctantly ordered the beef bibimbop. My routine would probably involve taking a bite or two of the beef to try it before pushing the rest of it off to the side of the bowl so I could focus my attention on the vegetables instead. Yeah, not a huge beef fan I guess.

As is customary with most Korean BBQ experiences, a sampling of great Korean starters appeared before us including soup, kim chee, bean sprouts, tofu, broccoli, and more. All of it was pretty decent. 

Then the bibimbop came a sizzling down before me. The rice was the perfect golden crunchy brown on the bottom and fluffy on top, the vegetables, flavorful.

 I ate every piece of juicy, perfectly-marinated beef in my bowl. In fact, while I did really enjoy everything else in my bibimbop, they could have served me a dish of just the beef and I would have left satisfied.

At the end of our meal, the waitress brought us some kind of sweet rice water and I dipped my fingers in it while my boyfriend fearfully took a sip. Neither of us had any idea what to do with it and left before the waitress caught us looking like idiots. (*If anybody knows what this is called, I'd really like to know, by the way.)
author: Kat E.

description:
korean girl from los angeles with a strong familiarity of ktown..

han il kwan gets about a 3.5 star in my book.  it wasn't bad but i wasn't raving over it.  a good friend and i went for dinner on a weekday, so the place wasn't that crowded.  it seemed like they cater to large groups well so that's always a plus. 

i did love their banchan/ side dishes.  it's always a strong sign of a good korean restaurant when their side dishes rock.  they had a lot of the basics and the plus for having pajun ~ fried korean pancake.  i had the dolsot bibimbap (stone bowl mixed rice) and my friend had the yukgehjang (spicy noodle soup).  both were about average.  nothing super spectacular.  

service was pretty good.  a mark down for having bleh chinese restaurant tea. compensated by having good shikheh (sweet rice water dessert drink).  prices were reasonable (especially considering their quality of banchan), but i think it would have been way more pricey if we had meat dishes.

first korean restaurant to try in the richmond district but it wasn't anything to go crazy over.  would maybe try it again but not a huge fan.
author: Kimmy C.

description:
I live down the block so the SMELL is always intoxicating! and im one of those variety people, so the side dishes are a plus here! TONS of side dishes + free stuff! like mung bean cakes and tofu soup! so dont order TOO much, even though i know its hard to not.

sometimes u want korean BBQ without the smell, and this is the place! i prefer to have to pro's handle the cooking.

i LOVE their #10  tripe intestine in spicy sauce! most places dont make this so I always order it! *note it is a dish for those more open to weird dishes, im chinese.. so its normal for me!
author: Deanna T.

description: Found this place since we were basically kicked out of dim sum place. Besides being a typical Korean BBQ/restaurant place I think the thing to rave about is the amount of side dishes you get for the BBQ! Oh dear god.. you can probably just order 1 plate of meat to bbq and you can fill up on the side dishes which includes rice and tofu pot (complementary). In addition to a rice wine at the end of the meal... just awesome.
author: Angela W.

description:
Wow, my recent fave general Korean restaurant. The food is pretty decent--not GREAT by Korean mainland standards--but certainly good by mediocre U.S. standards. 

The interior is pleasant to eat in, not divey at all. The wait can be quite long, especially if you have a large group. The staff don't like to be hollered at old-school Korean school ("Yeo-gi yo! Gong-gi bab hana jushilae-yo!?"), so take that into account if you don't want to risk them using your dol sot as a spittoon!

The best part is that they're still into giving some freebies once in a while. They'll throw in bin-dae dduk (a mungbean [I think] pancake), or some other tasty hot banchan as "service" (free). Maybe they only did this to us because the wait was a bit long, but still, it's a good indicator. 

The real test is how good this place remains over a longer period of time. If it stays at this level forever, it's a keeper. (And a REAL rarity in Korean food in the States.)
author: Kevvy K.

description: My regular, good Korean place. Sometimes, it could be a long wait, even if you have a reservation, but the food is always good. They also often offer some freebies if you order enough. Our regular order: Kalbi, Kalbi jim, chap chae sometimes, fried kimchi or some other pancake, tofu soup ...
author: Alton Y.

description:
I eat here practically everytime I'm back in town.  That means I probably eat my bodyweight annually in BBQ, kinda gross.  

This place doesn't really compare to LA-Koreatown food, but no place in SF does.  Now that we've got that out of the way, here's what you can expect:

All the food es muy delicioso. 
BYOB option - no corkage!
Tofu soup included, no charge. 
Tasty banchan (side dishes). 
Good service, no attitude. 
Very good ventilation (your clothes will still smell, but you won't feel like you're in a smoker, ahem, brothers, charcoal bbq?)

Note - If you've been to LA - koreatown, you should know that good service and proper ventilation are essential to a great K-BBQ place. 

Four guys can stuff their faces here for $60, tip included.  That folks, is a GOOD DEAL.  Try it out, you won't be dissapointed!
author: Eddy L.

description:
So I thought that I would hold off on writing a review for this place until I had gone there more then once. In my experience you really need to visit a place a couple time to get a feel for it. So with that being what did I think of this place??

Well I liked it, I thought there selection of banchan was good here. It was a nice selection, more then I have seen at other korean places. I thought that there kimchi was good here along with a few other sides dishes. It was also a nice touch that they give you a kind egg soup dish included in your meal.

So to the next part, the actually food here. It is good, The two times I have been there I order kimchi jigae and yukkaejang both dishes were good but not spicy enough for me. The staff there was friendly but I would say it was a little hard to get my tea refilled a couple times. The first time I did go with my friend who is korean, we got pretty good service.

Overall a good place for korean and I will be going back here for more in the future.
author: Andre L.

description:
My favorite Korean place in the city. 

The food is decently priced and the service is great. Just came here yesterday with the whole family and ordered Dinner Set A. For about $100, it fed all 5 of us and was a GREAT combination of our favorite Korean dishes. Plus we had left overs. 

HIGHLY recommended.
author: Tina S.

description: very solid korean food. Not sure why people told me that SF doesn't have any good korean food. Worth the drive from anywhere around the city. Kalbi Jim is $20, but it's enough to feed two.
author: Robert C.

description:
This place is a steal considering they throw in tofu soup, egg pancakes, and many more Korean panchan (side dishes) than other establishments. The yummy food tastes clean and fresh. There was definitely love poured into making every dish scrum-dilly-yum-tious. 

The place is great for large groups as they have several private back rooms and large circular family style dining tables. The wait staff is very attentive and never gives attitude to non-Korean folk. Although there is not much of a wait, the parking in the residential neighborhood alone is a time sucker in itself. The trick is to pull up front right when the tour bus parking expires around 9PM. Yeah, they have a tour bus permitted parking spot to bus Korean tourists here for some authentic dishes. Koreans from the homeland vouching for this Korean restaurant. Take that!
author: Cathy H.

description:
They bring tourists by the busloads here.  However, don't let that fool you.  This place is a staple in the Richmond.

The spicy pork is solid.  And the panchan is top-notch.  You even get a sampling of the Korean pancake, which is a nice surprise.

The tofu soup did seem a bit bland, but we think it was a matter of taste preference.  After all, every other dish was spectacular.

Parking in the Richmond is still frustrating, so we recommend that you either walk to carpool.  The residential street parking is extremely rare, so unless you ride a scooter, be prepared for at least a 5-10 circle about the Richmond.
author: Kel S.

description:
I've probably only had Korean BBQ 10-15 times in my life, but I'm a bubba from Texas so I sure can appreciate good BBQ.  Their marinated pork and beef dishes were seriously good - even for this Texan!

Yes, parking was a bit of a pain... but well worth the trouble!
author: Alex S.

description:
Okay this review is going to be incomplete until I can go back and try their Kalbi---I only had the Kalbi Tang (soup) when I was there and I have to say it was pretty bland.  The people were nice though. Seems like everyone else really likes this place so all I can say is just don't order the Kalbi Tang and you should be alright hahah.

UPDATE: Okay..went back to try the Kalbi....ehhhhh nothing home to write about and the service was so so.
author: Ed C.

description:
The bi bim bap is amazing and for some strange reason, every time I come here, they hook it up with free food ya'll!  The first time, it was an egg-custard like soup thingy, the next time, it was kimchi jigae, and the time after that, it was jap chae.  Fo sho they know how to hook a brotha up!

There are also lots of requisite posters of Lee Hyori holding soju bottles and winking so you really can't go wrong with Han Il Kwan.

I would definitely recommend this place to a friend or a coworker.
author: Peter L.

description:
FINALLY! I'm so psyched I found a korean place that satisfies my boyfriend, wallet and I! I've gone from place to place and each time, I'm reminded why I don't frequent korean restaurants. I realized that A) I am ordering all the wrong items and B) the dish is good but way too pricey for the quantity given.

This place just so happens to be around the area I was in and after much tugging and pulling, I got to come here with the bf. For those who don't know, Thankfully the restaurant was not too full  when I came on a friday afternoon, PLUS! I decided to order bibimbop and marinated chicken. Han II Kwan serves either soft tofu soup or steam egg, bowl of a rice, and ban chan with the meals that is marked as such. Both our marinated chicken and bibimbop was marked under the category but we were only given one bowl of rice and a small stonepot of soup to share. MINUS ONE. I looked around and noticed other customers also sharing one rice bowl and soup too :( Our food came out and I soon forgot about it, plus there's rice in the bibimbop! We enjoyed our food, the bibimbop was perfectly cooked and the rice was crispy on the bottom just as I like it. The chicken was good too, with lots of meat. Both lunch specials were about $8. The owner then came out with a complimentary pancake, PLUS AGAIN! 

The food was overall tasty and price was on point! We filled up our tummies and left with a doggy bag too. I only wish that they have kim chee fried rice here, that would just be magical!
author: Connie C.

description:
Two things about this place that are AMAZING:  
1.  BBQ Eel
2.  Bul Go Ki

And a story:
The first time I went to Han II Kwan we arrived early on a saturday evening.  It seemed slow, but came highly recommended.  Just after we ordered a full tour bus stopped in front of the restaurant and unloaded a bus full of Korean tourist.  It was Awesome!  I love this place and am utterly delighted to have found it.  
Ps.  they take reservations.
author: jessica o.

description: Not worth the long wait... Especially after tour bus after tour bus after tour bus... Drop off everyone here to eat dinner and all me and friends want to do is eat... Not worth my time
author: Calvin Y.

description: My favorite Korean BBQ place! There are so many different choices for food and honestly, everything I have tried so far was great. The staff is very polite and attentive to your needs. I come here all the time for birthday celebrations with family or friends and regular dinners. I never leave dissatisfied.
author: Tiffany P.

description: first time having that beef stew with potatoes. it was absolutely delicious! food came really fast and the service was great! i would definitely go back!
author: Louis O.

description: That was my first experience there. Their side dishes were better then many other Korean places. I had soft tofu soup, kimche pancake, and "Bibimbap". They both were better than Tofu house. The pancake was just ok.
author: V L.

description: Delicious!! Cooked our own Bul Go-ki and marinated chicken. 3 of us and we were stuffed before we had all meat cooked. A real treat!
author: Kendra K.

description:
When you see a tour bus full of Korean tourists pull up in front of a Korean restaurant to dine there, it must be damn good and authentic.  This has to be my favorite Korean (cook at your table) spot.  They have friendly service, good vegetables and condiments to go with your meal, tasty tofu soup and cold sweet rice soup that I can't help but ask for more.  The prices are pretty typical of these types of Korean restaurants where you can choose to cook your own food ($15-$18).  The meats and seafood that they prepare for you are full of flavor.  If you don't see value in going out to cook and smell, they can cook the dishes for you.  For the alcoholics, they do a Korean version of a Sake bomb with Jinro and Obe Beer.  

This is San Francisco's best kept Korean restaurant secret from the masses!  I can't believe I'm sharing this with you yelpers!
author: Jason A.

description: One of my fav Korean restaurants but the wait is always long especially if you like a bbq table. They need to expand the place a little bit. Love their complimentary side dish.
author: Lovetoeat A.

description:
Ive gone here a few times now and its been consistently good.  Both service and food.

I really like their lunch specials which gives you a fantastic deal on great Korean bbq.

Their tofu soup is good, their bbq meat is good and all the sides are there.  I also like their tempura.

Not much else to say really....typical Korean bbq stuff you'd come to expect.  Havent tried bibimbap here.
author: Gilbert C.

description: Had a reservation and we still had to wait forever bc a tour bus filled the entire resturant. The people were nice and the food is decent. They also gave us complimentary soup. But I wish they had the small fish that MY TOFU HOUSE has. We ordered Kal bi, Bulgogi, spicey pork, chap che, and rice.
author: Sheenie L.

description:
When it comes to Korean food, I always have to have my banchan...and this place does not disappoint! Ok, the cucumbers were more salted than pickled, but they have the fish cakes that I looooove!

A group of my friends and I decided to get the family style meal for up to 6 people for around $150 including tax plus an order of seafood pancakes. We got spicy tofu soup, poached egg, herring, marinated ribs and chicken, japchae, stir fried squid and vegetables, tempura veggies, and and and..I don't even remember, our table was so covered with dishes and banchan it was a tad ridiculous. The seafood pancakes comes in a smaller portion than most restaurants and has very little seafood inside, but it was still tasty. I would recommend ordering this meal if you want to try a bit of everything, but not if you just wanted Korean bbq. We did not finish a lot of our food, but we did wish we had ordered more meat to cook on the grill. At the end, we got our shots of sikhye (sweet malt and rice drink) and our waiter was kind enough to split our bill between five credit cards. Even though we had 7 people at our table, they did not charge us gratuity!

Make sure to tip well!
author: Jenny W.

description: Good stuff! Food is fresh and tasty, their servers are always friendly and on it. The price is decent... I ordered a Bibimbap for take out and I got banchan (sides) and hot tofu soup with it.. all for 11bucks!... can't beat that... they take card and also serve beer.
author: Frank T.

description:
I came here for the first time yesterday. Parking is difficult cause it's a pretty residential area. I had reservations and they were good about setting it up for me especially since I only called the day before. We sat down for about 15 minutes and they gave us the menus. Pretty pricey for the small portions that you get, which is pretty disappointing.15 minutes later a guy took some of our orders and didn't bother with the rest of the party. He was pretty friendly though. He came back about every 10 minutes to take other people's orders which made no sense to me but whatever. 10 minutes later the ban chan came for the people who ordered first. It was pretty good, fresh, except for the pancake things (sorry I don't know what it's really called). It might just be because I've had better. Nonetheless the ban chan was good. 

Our orders finally came and it came out sizzling, how I like it! For the $20 I'd say it wasn't worth the tiny plate we got, but regardless the meat was well seasoned and NOT over cooked. Also the vermicelli was amazingly delicious! Highly recommend that. 10 minutes after we got our mean, awoman came to give us rice and didn't give my mom one. When she came back my mom asked for rice and all she said was "again?" SO RUDE! She never came back to give us the rice either. Yeah I don't really know what to say about that haha.

So let's see. For the for the food I'd give it 4 stars. For the service I'd give it 2 because it was unnecessarily slow and rude. I might be back here, but it has to be a day when I have lots of time to spare.
author: Rose D.

description: The best Korean Food I've had I've had in San Francisco
author: Charles T.

description: Came here at dinner time. Their Korean meats are so Dam good and delicious. Prices are reasonable. Overall clean place, and good food!
author: Calvin L.

description: Ok we made reservation.   We got there half an hour early to find parking.    after searching for half an hour we had to call to cancel the reservation.   They do not care if you cancel  because they have no room for parking or inside for people.   My daughter's birthday was ruined.   Thanks a lot  if you are not taking a taxi don't bother showing up.
author: Marg P.

description:
I came here a couple of times. One of my favorite Korean restaurants by far. I live a few blocks down so it's very convenient for me to just walk here. Parking is hard to find here, day AND night. 

This restaurant gives a LOT of side dishes. I really like the seafood pancake and the anchovies I believe? Or whatever those little fishies were =p The tofu soup is tasty also. The portions they give here for the bbq are pretty decent. Gets me full everytime. The service here is friendly and helpful. I always see tour buses when I pass by the restaurant. It must be that good..
author: Vivian L.

description:
Just had a raucous good time last night saying goodbye to our own Major Dentist who is leaving for three months overseas to serve our country well by fixing the teeth of our boys and girls in the military. 

We took over the back room and our Major Dentist, who is Korean himself, ordered up food and while I have no idea exactly WHAT I ate I know I liked it and will go back for more. Our servers were kept hopping bringing back bottle after bottle of Soju and beer, we feasted on meat and more meat and these jelly-like noodles for hours, and when it was all done the tab came to $30 each -- and somehow there was money left over when it was all counted up. Amazingly cheap for the amount of good food we ate up.

I will definitely venture out here again!
author: Phoebe H.

description:
Everytime I'm craving Korean food, I go to Han II Kwan. They give out the little plates of food to start out with, and they're alway fresh and yummy. They also give you the pancakes (which I LOVE) and tofu soup on the house. The tofu soup is a little bland and not spicy enough though.
