I normally order the kaibi, spicy rice cakes, pan fried oysters and the jap chai (the vermacelli dish). And for dessert they give you this sweet rice drink. Mmm Mmm Mmm!

They have rooms with long tables so it's a great place for a big group or party. The staff are very friendly. The only thing about this place is parking, but it's not THAT horrible.
author: Gina P.

description:
Very delicious Korean BBQ.

Price: Average for Korean restaurants, $20-$30 for order of Kalbi.

Ambiance: Nice and charming. Extremely quiet on a weekday night. Nothing fancy.

Food: Delicious and generous portions. We got the table top BBQ kalbi, pork, and seafood which had great marinade. 

Service: Great, the waitress is very caring and extremely helpful when I burnt the food. Very friendly and amicable.

Other: Parking is impossible to find in this area in the evening. It's located in a residential area so be prepared to walk a few blocks if you're lucky to find a parking spot.

Recommendation: YES, when you just want solid, no-frills Korean food.
author: David Z.

description:
From reading previous Yelp reviews, I made reservations for dinner for 4 at 6:30pm on a weekday thinking that I wanted to beat the busload of people that roll through here.  To my surprise, when we arrived, the bus  was still there, but there was no one in the restaurant!  I guess they come really early.  More people came later as we left.

They have booths where you can cook the meat yourself.  What's nice is that they change out the grill when it gets black and really smoky.  We got the spicy pork and bulgolgi, which were both really good.  The pork is more flavorful than other places in that it's really spicy! =P  We also got some kind of seafood soup, which was ok... I probably wouldn't get it again.  They give you LOTS of side dishes, which are all really good.  We asked for numerous refills.  They give you more side dishes than a lot of other korean restaurants.  We probably had like 8 other side dishes.  They even give you this egg soup.  

Overall, the service was good and the place was well ventilated so you don't end up smelling like smoke.  The food was reallllly good and decently priced.  I would definitely come back here again.
author: Diane L.

description: I was very impressed with the quality of the BBQ. Even though it was my first visit, i could tell by looking at all the other customer's plates that everything is good. :) This is my favorite Korean BBQ for now.
author: yelp j.

description: Hands down, my favorite Korean restaurant in the city. (Brothers just isn't as good as I remember.) The mung cake is crispy and cooked just the way I like it. Their banchan is delicious. I especially love the seasoned black beans, fried zucchini, and steamed egg. I usually order the yook gae jang (or spicy beef soup), but I've also had their dolsot bibimbap and one of their fish dishes -- all equally amazing. I brought my dad and sister here, and they both loved it as well. Only downside is parking is a pain.
author: Sophia B.

description:
Solid Korean food.  
A little bit out of the way, and with the typical boring atomosphere, but the food is legit.
author: shaun l.

description:
GREAT food, decent prices (probably cuz you're not paying for their rent on Geary st. or whatever).  

Great for larger parties.  Lots of seating.  Smells kinda funny though.  

I'm sure there's a reason why lots of Korean tourist groups come here.

Sucky parking.
author: Dong T.

description:
My brother always wants to go to the restaurant that is packed full because he figures that the place has got to be good, and damn him, he's usually right. Even if we have to wait.

Walking up to this place, my friend and I notice a tour bus full of Koreans piling into the restaurant. That's when we knew it had to be good. I really think we were the only two people in the whole place that weren't Korean.

The meat is lean, the atmosphere is nice, not too crowded, and the service was excellent. They were very quick and helpful. And there was so much food! We had plenty to take home. 

I think this is my favorite Korean BBQ restaurant in the city! Though, I am biased since I live so close by. JUST GO.
author: Anna H.

description:
HIK is so good for Korean bbq.  Unlike Korea House in Japantown, they still serve complimentary soup and pachanga (veggie pancake) and the service is better. 

The one downside is the hellish parking situation.

Return Visit = Definitely
author: Jeannie C.

description:
I really like their banchan here.  Delicious!  I love the fish cake and the anchovies!

The lunch special is great! I wish they had it during the weekends though.   For about 10 bucks you can get tofu soup, rice, pancake, banchan, and kalbi.  so much food for one person!  

Their meat have a lot of flavor!  It's sweet, salty and soo good.  Their dinner items are a little pricey and I really like how Brothers uses wood for BBQ so for the diy bbq...i like going there.

Han Il Kwan
author: LiveToEat F.

description:
The dead giveaway about this place?  They take bus loads of Korean tourists here.  

I'm pretty certain tourists from HK don't get sent to PF Changs.

Caveat!  Don't go when a tour group is inside.  Service slows to a snail's pace.  Quality dips a bit too.
author: Tan H.

description:
there's some ins and outs and what have yous.

we wanted some delicious bip im bap, so we went to my tofu house.  and the line turned us right around and out the door, to han il kwan.

the food was ok, and the service too. i can't say anything really bad nor good about the place.

there were plenty of panchans! :) that's always a good thing!
author: Ameer N.

description:
Ate here for a friend's birthday dinner. I ordered a bi bim bap(?) It wasn't anything out of the ordinary. A bit overpriced. 

Oh, the waitress isn't very nice. She complained about individual ordering as to group adjusted orders. Waited well over 30 minutes and she had forgotten two of my friend's orders. They ended up canceling it.
author: Tina C.

description:
Hands down, the best korean in the city.  Trust me, I'm from LA (where the korean food is sometimes better than the motherland).

Good luck trying to find parking, I sugguest you drive a golf or a fit or some other small-ass car.

YUM
author: systems e.

description:
Cham mashi sa sehyo! Hey. My Korean sucks! Han il Kwan rocks!
Besides the name sounding like one of the lesser-known Korean characters from Star Wars, this place is one of the best all-around Korean restaurants in the Bay Area.
Food quality, quantities and price are by far the best. While the bbq-at-your-table is gas grilled, as opposed to Brothers, which is wood burning, the quality of the meat and fish is far superior. Plus, gas is more sustainable...right?
We grilled pork and mixed seafood. It was tasty and had just the right amount of spice. The soon du bu chigae, soft tofu soup, was equal to that of My Tofu House, but about $4 less a serving. The pan chan were top notch!
The only down side, if you want to go, better start walking from wherever you are now-because parking's a total female Korean dog.
author: Mr. S.

description:
Friends in the East Bay have taken me to some "hot" Korean places over there, but I didn't know any over here. Han II Kwan's pork with special sauce (number 34 or 35, I think) was some of the best pork I've had, of any cuisine. The beef (33 or 34?) and clay pot seafood (55) were also great. But the pork was hands down the best, and worth the entire price of my meal alone. 
Both people I was with were similarly floored - one was a foodie who had never had Korean food. Suffice it to say, he couldn't stop raving about this place.
Korean food definitely doesn't get the attention it deserves from Western palates. I will be bringing many a friend here in the future.
author: Max M.

description:
Mmm...
I got my Korean food fix here the other night and it made me really happy.  With two people, we ordered a Bi bim bop in the clay pot and the spicy pork.  It was plenty of food because they serve a LOT of panchan.  They have the mung bean pancakes and soondubu (soft tofu soup).  And last time i went with a large group, they gave steamed/claypot egg instead of the soondubu.

They are friendly, and the food comes out promptly.

I guess I think this place is so good because their bi bim bop is so good.  I remembered it from the last time I went and I think that is saying something.  I was especially happy because I also got to bring home leftovers.

My suggestions are to go with a group of 3-6, but they also accomodate much larger groups because they have a back room.  The last time I went with a really large group of about 20 and they were so friendly, which i thought was especially 5-star-ish because it's so easy to hate large groups.

Can't wait to go again!
author: Sareen L.

description:
While not the BEST Korean food around, Han Il Kwan serves par Korean food, which is to say it's pretty darn good, because I like Korean food.

We used to go to some nasty place for family dinners (which will remain unnamed), but now we come here.  It's a big improvement that I'm happy about (^-^)

Great for groups.  If it were cheaper I'd come here more often.
author: Jin D.

description:
Good service
Little smoky inside the restaurant
Not too busy
Easy Parking
Mediocre Food -- Kalbi was quite dry and jeongol was quite bland.
Conclusion:
Yet, another so so korean place in SF...... ;-(
author: jung S.

description: Okay. I've been there twice and multiple take outs. I don't know why I'm still eating their food. There are a couple of the rudest, nastiest, and bitter waitpersons I've ever come across who hold court there. They must be related to the owners or caught the owners is some illegal activities. Otherwise they would be in the very crowded unemployment line. The problem is the food is tasty and cheap. I just realized why they're still there, they don't get paid, only fed but only left overs from patrons and so they take out their misfortune on the diners. Anyway, the food is indeed tasty, especially the Korean bbq beef and all the banchan appetizer/freebies. The place is a bit rundown but relatively clean. Roomy dining area and a private room in the back is available. I haven't taken the cook-the-damn-food-yourself-and-smell-like-a-campfire option since I'd rather someone cook for me especially if I'm doing the paying. I know what you're thinking, why only two stars if the food is that good. They'd get 4 stars from me but I'm taking back two just because I'm afraid that everytime I go there I get that nasty attitude and I'm too chicken sh*t to say anything because I don't want spit in my food. Yes that's done in restaurants just like in the movie "The Help" cause just maybe someone I know just maybe used to do that maybe in a restaurant that maybe this person that I know was maybe working at while he was maybe attending a college in Stockton and was treated poorly by some overweight rude and irritating self styled food critic hics maybe way back then. Just maybe.
author: bongo c.

description:
Brothers to me is still the best in SF.  Which doesn't really compare to some places in the south bay and SoCal.  But is still money!!

Han II Kwan... All I need to say is by the end of the meal, i had a pile of fat on an extra plate I had.  The Bul gol gi was super fatty, about 24%.  The Kal Bi was super chewy and we ended leaving half the plate there. The free tofu soup(which you get at every Korean rest.) was watery. 

Overall-
Food- Fatty and Chewy.  
Mung cake-Oily and dry(bad combo)
Great Panchan!!  Very fresh. 
Bi Bin Bop- Was pretty good

Service-we were there at 4pm, not the best time to go, there were only 3 tables of people, and they checked on us once.  Poor and lazy.  

Decor, was nice, no complaints.  

We had them grill the food for us, bc we had some where to go after and didn't want to stank! Would try again just to give them one more chance.
author: Chase F.

description:
Read Phoebe's review below.  She sums it up!

It's also my other Korean and/or foodie friends' fave Korean food in the city...  Note the Tour Bus Loading Zone directly in front!

Loved the mung bean cakes (like green scallion pancakes except not) and the glass noodles with veggies!  And endless OB beer and Soju wasn't too shabby either.

Very fresh all around.
author: Melanie C.

description:
Aw hells yeah.  

A group of us went for a friend's birthday- and might I say, DAMN F-ing GOOD.  The decor ain't pretty, and Korean food ain't cheap, but fir gut splitting joy, n lip smacking BBQ, I do believe Han II Kwan is the reasonable choice.   

We ordered half the menu, all the BBQ meat items (our party was 11 large so we had the cooks grill it, instead of grilling at the table ourselves), the tofu soup, the bi bim bop, meat dumplings, sea food cakes and clear noodles were all delicious!

FYI - loads of families come here, so for an intimate first date experience, try somewhere else romantic.  As I waited for our table, a hoard of 6 children bum rushed me- squealing about some other kid who had "cooties."  

FYI II - if you have a big party, I noticed 2 private rooms in the back that looked accommodating, sadly we didn't get it, but maybe you can (request it).
author: Carolyn H.

description:
We had been duly warned by other Yelpers: "Beware the Ides of March!" (Didn't you know Shakespear was referring to parking near Balboa?)

But young and foolish, the bf and I ignored the wisdom of our elders (or betters), so hungry were we for good Korean food after a scenic ride on the Sawyer Camp Trail. After 20 mintues of endlessly circling blocks and cursing the gods above, we finally found a parking spot mere steps away from the restaurant. Victory was ours, and it was sweet!

Sweeter still was the food. We shared a spicy cold noodle dish (bibim naeng myun), a spicy octopus stiry-fry, and a spicy rice cake dish (duk boki). The cold noodles were bouncy to the bite; the octopus was tender and tasty; and the rice cake was chewy enough to earn it a place in my heart and tummy. All three dishes were delicious, if a bit spicier than expected for our non-Korean (but nonetheless Asian) tastebuds. The portions were so large we ended up taking home roughly half of it. 

The wait staff were all helpful and friendly. As indicated in previous reviews, they give you a few appetizer samples for free. We got 2 small green onion pancakes and a steamed egg custard type dish. The only slight downside to the meal was that they were understaffed, so it was difficult to get the server's attention for water/tea refills. 

All in all, this place was well worth the hassle of parking!
author: Lillian L.

description:
I live down the street. I'm very annoyed by the tour buses that zoom by my street heading toward Han Il Kwan cause they are LOUD... the bus, not the tourist. 

I luckily always miss the tour crowd so better service. I like that they give free soup, but I prefer the tofu soup at My Tofu House. I like their bi bim bap and their sweet rice water thing at the end, yummy. I have to find the rice to make that stuff.  But over all good, but puts a hurting on my wallet.
author: Kimberly S.

description: i love coming here for korean food. i am never disapointed with teh seafood or beef bimbap. also i love the soft tofu soup here its so delicious!!! and sometimes they give out free korean pancakes which are so yummy. i drool thinking about the food here! =)
author: Stella J.

description:
4 stars for food, minus 1 star for service. 

Came here for a birthday party. The group was pretty large so they gave us a room. We opted not to bbq ourselves so the kitchen cooked for us. 

Everything wasn't too bad. Kal bi was tender and flavorful, as was the chicken. 

Kal bi jiim was a bit too sweet but the flavors were great. Mung bean pancakes were like dry little hockey pucks so I'd stay clear of those but the kim chee pancake was awesome! 

Service was lousy and they didn't even refill our teapot once.
author: Derrick L.

description:
This was my first experience with Korean food.

We ordered two huge soups, bi bim bap,  and the Bul Go Gi & mixed seafood as the two do-it-yourself table BBQ items for dinner. The space is quite large and was nearly empty on a Monday night.

The bi bim bap was a little too heavy on the rice for me but the meat was great. 

The BBQ items were both fun to grill and absolutely delicious and came with a multitude of side dishes including yummy spongy vegetables, tangy tiny fish staring at us with their little eyes, and many unidentifiable but tasty objects.

The service was basic and brisk. I wish she's taken a couple of minutes to tell us what we were eating but the sometimes mysterious sides were good anyway.

I'd definitely go for the BBQ again.

At $25 a head (including tip) we were stuffed to the gills and had leftovers for the next day.
author: Sharand N.

description:
One word: BOMB SAUCE! Best Korean restaurant in town. From the great tasting beef, chicken, and pork...this place also has great side dishes.
I have been going here for a long time, and nothing touches it.
author: flash f.

description:
With regard to weekday lunchtime, it is a breeze to get in. The lunch special prices are very reasonable. I've been twice in the past three weeks. 

First they start you out with tea and a tasty scallion mini-pancake for each person. I have ordered the seafood bibimbap each time I've been (sorry I'm a creature of habit) and I have not been disappointed. It is sizzling hot which results in that bottom crispy crust on the rice that I like. 

The only thing that I will try to change with my bibimbap next time is to see if they'll put a raw egg on top instead of a sunny-side-up egg, hopefully they will be able to accomodate my request.

Add in the plentiful side dishes of various pickled, spicy items, this all makes for a lot of food. It's a bit much for me as I never quite can finish my main dish.
author: Jen A.

description: Good authentic Korean BBQ and food. The side dishes (banchan) are generous and fresh. Sometimes there big groups from Korean tour buses so call to confirm availability if you want to get a private booth with a grill and will be eating around 6pm.
author: Sun K.

description:
I first noticed this place driving by because there were two huge tour buses parked right outside with Korean tourists filing back onto the buses. "Intriguing!" So after we saw that the restaurant we wanted to hit was closed on Tuesday (what?!), we 360ed it towards this place. 

YUM. Great little side dishes and more of them than I'm used to. The seafood pajeon, bulgogi and bbq chicken were tasty as well. 

Definitely coming back.. with more people.
author: tessie n.

description: Only have been here for lunches. There is a lot of seating. Nice and clean atmosphere. Banchan is soooo good here. They give a nice variety and large portions of banchan. I love the complimentary pancake and tofu soup. The soup is so tasty, lots of flavor. A lot of the times I crave just the soup! Their food comes out quick and delicious. It's very addicting!
author: SF R.

description:
The reviews sounded good, but I wasn't a big fan.  I also figured it'd be good since a Korean tour bus had just left the place. Not so much.

Service was dreadful. The main course wasn't all that good.  They give a good amount of side dishes. I'd call this place mediocre.
author: Brendan L.

description: I hate this place. The waiters are the rudest people. I went there at 5:00 p.m. on a saturday night and there were plenty of tables free. The waiters said that they could not seat me with no explanation. They couldn't and wouldn't give me a reason why. I can't believe that all the tables were reserved. If they were reserving the tables for the bus full of tourist, this means that they do not want business from the locals. I won't ever go back- I hate this place. One star is being generous.
author: E. L.

description:
Best Korean food in SF. I've eaten at Brothers a few times as well, which is also pretty good. However for traditional Korean food Han Il Kwan is the best. The service was very attentive and the waitresses very friendly. Lots of food for cheap. 

They even brought me out complimentary Sundubu! yay!

The only thing that sucks is the parking. There is no parking anywhere.
author: Kyle K.

description:
Nothing can beat my favorite korean restaurants down in Los Angeles, but i must say, Han Il Kwan is right up there with LA food. Unfortunately they didn't have a lot of my favorite soups...but it's ok! 

I had their mul nehngmyun. yummy on a hot summer day! I must say it was muy delicioso! it reminded me of the times i spent at a noodle house with my grandma. I loved that they gave free soon dubu soup and shikae after the meal. My mother would love this place. 

Can't wait to go back and try the bibimbap!!!
author: Suzan L.

description: Me and my two good buddies eat here at least once a month if not more. We come here because they really know how to marinate their meats and the fact that u get a really good portion for a cheap price. Plus u get to cook ur own food, tat is bomb. There was one nite that My gf , me and my two buddies went here and we were very hungry so we ended up ordering beef, pork, chicken,eel and some other dishes. We finished everything. The funny thing is majority of the time we stay until they close and we are still eating. The only thing is the service is not that good, sometimes its hard to get the attention of one of the waitresses. We go on Fridays usually so u never noe if u will see me there. But yea for sure I would come back considering it is a short walk here. :D
author: Jonathan W.

description: Really great Korean food! And the price is right. The restaurant itself is pretty nicely decked out and clean. The fact that it is out of the way may seem appealing, but parking is going to be tough and that's not their fault. Despite the pluses, the service knocks off 1 star: the wait staff was pretty inattentive. Make no mistake, the food here is top notch, but between time lost on parking and the service, don't be too ambitious with after-dinner plans. The next time I go - and there will be a next time - I'll make my plans for the rest of the day pretty light.
author: Sandeep C.

description: without argument, the best Korean restaurant in the city of San Francisco. Great barbeque, with option to barbeque OR not (the table you sit at will change accordingly). Where do I begin? Awesome kimchi (no one in the city comes close, not even), awesome banchan (hearty servings and quick service, too), and one time we asked for steamed egg custard thinking that like many LA Korean restaurants it was free; they gave it to us for free anyway; awesome Binddaedduk (almost impossible to find bindaedduk of this quality unless you're at a place that specializes in it), and plenty of other delicious things including soups, stews, and pancakes. Made with a chef's sensitivity to delicate flavors and star ingredients with homemade goodness and a skilled consistency. This place is like the San Tung of Korean restaurants.
author: Y K.

description: The best Korean restaurant in San Francisco the Banchan is fresh, savory and just the right spice. The overall dishes are comparable in price to other Korean restaurants and the cleanliness is notable. I had the beef kalbi and bean paste stew both very good.
author: N A.

description:
I actually read a couple of the reviews beforehand, so I wasn't surprised to see a tour bus parked outside. Luckily, as soon as we walked in, the owners(?) walked in with us so we were seated and waited on immediately. So it wasn't at all overwhelming that the restaurant was packed with kids straight from Korea... all decked out in school uniforms. interesting. 

The place was clean. I didn't see flies everywhere like some people said. My friend and I were seated at a comfortable booth by the window, and I swear, the both of us could've sat there all night long (no, the food coma had nothing to do with this) 

The food was good! the bulgogi was really nice and fun to bbq. the banchan was good too. i just wish there was more kimchi... but they do give free tofu soup! cool. 
The one thing though, is that you won't carry the appetizing aroma of bbqed meat after you walk out since they have a great vent system and they use a gas grill (i still like it the old skool way tho!) ..so feel free to come all decked out in your dry clean onlys. 

And by the way, my friend had never had kbbq before this, and she enjoyed her first time experience.
author: MB M.

description:
Han Il Kwan is one of our favorite Korean restaurants, and it's right in our 'hood.  The food, service and atmosphere are all good.  And they've got plenty of room for big parties.

Street parking is somewhat limited--I recommend arriving in a tour bus (they have an enormous parking stop for them out front).
author: Chris L.

description:
The best korean food I've had in SF. And I've gone trekkin' all over these hills trying all sorts of Korean places, most I've been sorely disappointed by, others I was kinda "eh" on, and a few where I've been pleasantly surprised and very happy with.

One day when we had just arrived here for lunch, my friend and I saw a huge busload of Korean tourists unload outside and knew that it was going to be GOOD. Seriously, there is a bus stop in front of this restaurant which regularly seems to be unloading large tour buses of Korean moms and pops. You know they *should know good Korean food, and you know that this bus came all the way to Outer Richmond to get here. Yes, it was gonna be so GOOD. And we were not disappointed! I don't think the busloads of people were either. The restaurant, which had been mostly empty at that time in the day, filled up to the brim with large round tables of piping hot food. I know how they get so much business now!

I came here the very first time as part of a large birthday group. I think perhaps the super large group was so distracting that I didn't properly enjoy the food. Since it's not far from home, I started coming more and more. I mean, you just know.. when it's good. I'm from LA and the K-town there, though incomparable, at least gave me some point of reference. This. is. good. Korean. food.

I've had their kalbi, bulgogi, bi bim bap, kalbi tang, gom tang, etc etc. Flavorful soups, juicy and well marinated meat, fresh ingredients are all things that come to mind. Also, I love their side dishes - the best I've had in any SF Korean restaurant. Fairly larger plates than other places and they will gladly refill them for you. Good service. I also LOVE the steamed egg that comes with the dishes occasionally (depending on what you order). It is my absolute favorite side dish :)

Hope I didn't raise the bar too high but I don't think you will be disappointed.
author: Nebula H.

description:
Good, not overly expensive Korean food housed in a 1980s kitsch mall-like atmosphere. All that was missing were fake hanging plants. Service is practically nonexistent, so make sure you order everything you need for the entire night the moment they take your order.

It's pretty solid food though, with plenty of options. Apparently, there is an option to cook meat on the tables, which is good to know considering how much of my life has been spent standing outside/waiting for a table at one of the more popular Brothers restaurants. We ordered the kalbi to be cooked at our table, and it came out already cooked/sizzling on a platter. I'm not sure I understand why that happened, but it was tasty nonetheless.

If I wanted a table-cooking experience, I'd probably go back. Otherwise, so many korean restaurants, so little time.
author: Sabine S.

description:
This place wasn't as good as the reviews said.

The good: 
1. can accommodate larger parties and doesn't add 20% tip for large crowds.
2. The appetizer pancake was really good. 

The bad: 
1. All other dishes not mentioned above were watery and bland. 
2. The side dishes were bland. The bean sprouts needed a lot more sesame oil. 

The ugly:
1. The soft tofu soup was terrible. They didn't give you a raw egg to crack into the pot. The broth was bland and the regular soft tofu soup without kimchee still tasted sour.
author: Christine L.

description:
It was aight..

Yes, there were lots of little dishes, but none of my faves. One star for having soup and lettuce!

We got........Blue Go Gee, haha jk, Kalbi, and bacon.

All were alright.  Bacon tasted like nothing.

Best thing i had all night, rice! and the rice drink, which they didnt want to sell me when i wanted my own glass just to drink.
author: kim w.

description:
If you frequent Palace BBQ in Santa Clara, you will not like Han Il Kwan.  In fact, if you partake in Korean BBQ  anywhere, you will not like Han Il Kwan.

The service is not that bad...except that I had to request that our ventilated hood be turned on (before we even started) because the table next to ours was burning every piece of meat they had to a crisp.  The entire room was smoked out.  Gross.

The marinades were only ok.  Spicy pork sauce was too pasty, the kalbi was too sweet.  The worst part of it all was that the butchery of the meat was SO bad that it was impossible to cook any of it properly.  We managed, but it wasn't a very good experience at all.

I hesitate to say any more because I would prefer to say something kind.  Cannot find these words...won't be back.
author: Sandy K.

description: No parking around, the service (especially the guy in the front) was rude. He told us to wait for 40 mins, when time was up, he asked us to wait for another est. 40 mins with impolite attitudes. However, there food was okay!!!
author: Ruolin Z.

description: The food is really good.  Prices are reasonable. Wait staff were real great.
author: Michelle T.

description:
Where the tour buses full of Korean tourists congregate.  The restaurant pays for 2 tandem parking spots in front of the restaurants dedicated for the buses.  No parking EVERYDAY from 5-8 PM!  And during lunch hours.  

We arrived near 6:30 PM.  Shortly after, a tour bus pulls up into the designated parking space and a group of Korean tourists hopped off to their reserved tables for an US-Korean cooked meal.  BFF's hubby & Hubby do not like to cook their own food, citing "You go to a restaurant to have food cooked for you, not to cook your own food".   

It's been a great many years since our college days when we tried this place.  The place is still as spacious as I remembered and fairly clean.  The bathroom has a front anteroom with sink and an inner door with the toilet in fairly tight quarters. Parking is challenging in the neighborhood.  

They offer 2 dinner menu plans.  One feeds up to 5 for $116 and the other feeds up to 7 for $146.  Most entrees come with rice, soup and mutlple small side dishes.  There's plenty of food and it's a good place to come in a group of 4 or more. Choice of entrees include Korean BBQ dishes, hot pot/soup, pan fried/sauteed, pan fried/lpancake, soup, Bi-Bim Bab, broiled fish and deep fried seafood.  Prices are variable.  Soups can run $9 to $20 for "Sciaenoid" fish soup.  BBQ dishes are $10-$21 - chicken, beef, pork, eel, shrimp.  HOt Pot/soups are $16-22, etc.  Hot tea comes with the meal but they have Korean wine, sake, beer, soda.  We had 2 orders of beef short ribs (very good), $21,  BBQ chicken (very good), $17,  soft tofu soup (spicy, good) and stir-fried vermicelli with vegts/beef (OK), $13.  You can make a meal with just the side dishes alone (about 10 of them) and rice. BFF ordered a side of toasted seaweed to eat with the rice (refillable in metal bowls at NO extra charge).  

We waved to the tourists from our window seats as their tour bus pulled away, knowing both their bellies and ours were warm, happy, content and overfed.
author: Ry T.

description:
i have yet to be disappointed by anything that i have tried at this place. my friend originally invited me here for a bday dinner, and among the 6 of us and 3 entrees that we grilled, we were all beyond stuffed. 

i personally dont care to do the cooking at the table, but since someone in my party usually loves to do so, i let them have all the fun. the spicy pork is my favorite entree and the 10 or so side dishes are delicious. my faves are the seaweed, kimchi pancakes, marinated tofu and the tofu soup that comes with most entrees ordered. i usually dont indulge in spicy foods but i cant stay away from korean food. some places usually give you little 4oz dinky cups of water, but it's nice to get an 8oz glass beverage at this place. the servers are very attentive and if you run out of your fav side dish, you can def ask for more!

the only bad side is that on the wkends, they are known for accommodating korean tour buses. we are talking about at times almost a 2 hr wait before the group is cleared out. but, with one quick call, we can be sure to get a table.
author: kim p.

description:
This Korean restaurant is 'AS GOOD AS IT GETS!' because it's the most authentic around - The staff, the decor, and the food!  Can't find any other place in the city that can beat this kind of authenticity.  Every time I've went, I've always been satisfied with service and food quality.  I love the tofu soups, the mini-appetizer dishes they have out, and their dessert drink with the rice inside.  How do you make that stuff?  It's soo good...it's some kind of sugar tea water and cooked rice.  YUM...

The only thing I dislike is their schedule of tour buses that stop by.  I NEVER Know when the restaurant is going to be CLOSED because they're serving the tourists from the tour buses.  One time it happened that I went on one of the nights where there was an overload of people coming in and out of tour buses heading into the restaurant...and the restaurant was NOT taking in any walk-ins.  That was a disappointing day because I was really Craving me some tofu soup w/rice.


4.5
author: LovesToEat S.

description: Busy and slow service, but the food is worth it.  Generous portions, and highly tasty.  I'm a fan of Kimchee, so loved the Kimchee Bibimbap.
author: Andrew T.

description:
A solid 4 stars! Han Il Kwan is a pretty traditional Korean restaurant. The food and the decor looks traditional, excluding the music being played (Get Low, and I Kissed a Girl?) I know there aren't a lot of good Korean restaurants, especially in the Peninsula, but I'd say this place is up there in the ranks. 

I've tried the kal-bi (short ribs), bulgogi (marinated beef), and spicy pork (ok I admit, I don't what it's called). All were veryy tasty, with minimal fat which seems to be the ongoing trend at a lot of peninsula places. They give you all the good panchan like fish cake! My faave. Also, another amazing aspect of this restaurant is in addition to the panchan, they give you a Korean green onion pancake and tofu soup! *Drool*

I will say, it is pricey, but if you want decent Korean food that's what you have to sacrifice. Tip is to go during lunch for the lunch specials. It's a really good deal. Parking may be a b*tch in the Richmond District, but I must say.. it's worth it.
author: Jessica W.

description:
Darn good.  If you're in the neighborhood, this is the best Korean I've had in the city.  Brothers. . . oh brother.  Japantown Korean. . . c'mon, let's keep it real.

The place has solid bbq, the kalbi was well-seasoned and the side dishes came out rather tasty.  Great service for a Korean restaurant.

As for the people who say Han Il Kwan is as good as LA, uh. . . I'm from SF and I still cede that LA has the best damn Korean food in the world. . . better than the motherland herself.
author: E L.

description:
I went here last night on the recommendation of Judy and it was well worth the two buses it took to get there from my house.  I had the Kaibi ($17) and my  husband had the Bulgogi ($19), we were delighted by the pickled offerings and the food was absolutely delicious.
True enough - there was a bus tour there while we were there. But you are not going there for the ambiance, the food was fantastic, and the servers were very helpful. I am already planning when to go back!
author: kristen l.

description:
Han II Kwan is my all time favorite Korean restaurant! Parking can be a challenge and DO NOT park in the space right in front.  It is designated for the tour buses that drop off Korean tourist here.  

Han II Kwan offers great side dishes, including a very smoothe steam egg pot which is soooooo good esp. on a cold night.  Prices and portion sizes are great, service is excellent!!

Some of my fav dishes include the beef rib soup and the grilled dishes!!  
I hope Han II Kwan never changes their quality.
author: Mel S.

description:
Eh.... went here with high expectations, but came away with an overall 3.5 star experience.

Food: the food was underwhelming. Not bad, but not the best I've had. Their soondubu was tasty (if mild--but we didn't get to specify spice-level) and FREE--a Korean amuse bouche + apology for their rushed service. The banchan (sides) were all delicious and varied. and the bulgogi was okay, but pricey. I didn't order enough meat to use their gas grills, but I would've preferred the more traditional wood charcoal anyway. Tried  The chapchae (vermicelli noodles) was decent, but arrived a little cold so the noodles changed into a big tangled mess.

Service: Friendly but terribly busy. Three (yes, 3!) busloads of Korean tourists came and went, giving the staff way too much to worry about. A lot of the non-tourists relegated to the booths were often forgotten. They were quite apologetic and I suppose that explained why we got free soondubu.

Decor: an earlier review was spot-on with their description comparing it to an old-towne Korean soap opera set

Overall: can't say if this is the best in SF, but I prefer some restaurants in Oakland or Santa Clara more. Clearly, though, the bulk of their business comes from the stream of Korean tourists, and Han Il Kwan (in an arrangement with the tour bus operator) is able to monopolize on their captive patronage by charging higher prices. Can't really say that b/c loads of Korean tourists come here, that it MUST be good, but it can't be too bad either.
author: Richie K.

description: My hubby and I had fun trying the Korean dishes! Two thumbs up for their Bi bim bap!:)
author: Ella B.

description:
Came here twice, long time ago once with some family, and just went back yesterday for some take out. The first time we ordered more food than i can eat. Needless to say we got the general things like kalbi, everything was great. 

Then last night i stopped by to pick up some mandukk gukk because the last time i had some was a year ago. 

It's this soup with chewy rice cakes that is to die for. for 8.95$ it comes with the usual sides which is one of the reasons i love korean food, accompanied with a box of rice. I'd say it's pretty darn worth it. Not to mention the waitress is pretty cute. This place is a must go if you're looking for some good korean food, oh and they do have a couple tables that they can cook the kalbi, or chicken right on your table or DIY if you perfer that way.
author: Terry S.

description:
Good Korean food for SF. Personally this is my favorite korean restaurant in the city. You can't go wrong with any of the dishes here. It's almost like home cooked food. Their galbee (korean bbq short ribs) is great (the marinade is not too sweet or too salty).  My other favorite here is the tofu stew. 

Service is really good here too. The owner is very attentive to your needs.  They have a large private room in the back for larger parties. 

Parking can be a challenge but so is every other restaurant in the city.
author: Michael W.

description: My friend's fave Korean place in SF. We headed there last week for dinner and the bill for 4 came to a little over $100. There's a huge room in the back for the buses of Korean tourists who stop by nightly. Food was soo good! Loved the tofu soup, seafood pancakes and bul gul gi. Service was nice. Only drawback - it was a cold winter's night and the hood range pumping AC on us from our neighbors turned our hot tea to iced tea! Yikes! Coming back again in a parka!
author: Cheryl P.

description:
Quite possibly my new favoritist Korean place in the world.  Even better than Sa Rit Gol in LA (which I think closed), and San Soo Gab San in Chicago.  The bulgogi is ok, but the KALBI is where it's at.  Man that stuff is good.  I'm having a food orgasm just thinking about it.  My other favorite dish is Jap Chae, which is fantastic here.  The stone bowl Bi Bim Bap is great, and the seafood and scallion pancakes here are yummy.  There seems to be only one guy that takes orders, and the Korean tour buses keep him occupied.  Like most Asian restaurants you have to be kind of pushy to get his attention, and it's best to know what you want to order right away unless you speak Korean and can get his attention.

We don't BBQ ourselves so that we don't smell for days.

This is one of the cleanest Korean restaurants I've been to.

Parking isn't fun in the Richmond, bring your smallest car.

Did I mention the KALBI?!
author: J. L.

description:
This has got to be the best Korean BBQ place in San Francisco because:
1. excellent service, very attentive to your request, very happy people
2. free tofu soup
3. very tasty side dishes (my favorite were the fish cakes)
4. bbq meats had excellent flavoring
5. clean dining area and restrooms
6. excellent ventillation system (usually after korean food, I smell like korean food, but at this place feel free to wear your cashmere sweater because the huge table vents sucks out the smoke well)
7. i love the sweet rice dessert drink they give us at the end of the meal.  It taste like a sweet horchata without milk.
author: Joseph V.

description: Awesome value for your money. Each table comes with a multitude of small dishes as well as small tofu. For 2 people, you really only need to order one meat dish and you'll be plenty stuffed. Kalbi BBQ (ribs) was delicious with the lettuce wraps, rice and sauce. Came with generous portion size as well. Tofu soup was ok but it was free. I imagine the actual tofu soup that cost money are better. Definitely recommended spot. More people you bring the better.
author: Jason L.

description: So good.  I live like 2 blocks away, lucky me.  As everyon says the "banchan" are amazing.  Some kind of pancake thing came with our meal for free.  And they gave us a soup on the house the other night.  Ridiculous.  The little rice water desert (also free) it phenomenal.  Order the bulgogi and there absolutely /no/ reason to pay extra for the bbq table, but it's a nice touch if you have the dough.
author: Charles W.

description:
Was really disappointed when I went there on a Friday nite after work. Got there at 5:30 and they told me there wouldn't be any tables available until after 7pm. There were 3 tour buses there & they filled up the whole place. There were other people who came in here at the same time as me who got really upset saying they should post a sign on the door to let customers know about this.
Otherwise, I have always enjoyed their food & they have a good selection of banchan.
author: T T.

description: Yum!!!! A lot of Yelpers mention slow service but I didnt experience any of that...maybe because it was around noon on a Monday..? Food was delicious, side dishes were tasty and my dwen jang jji gae (Korean Miso Soup) was AMAZING! may just be back in the City this weekend for more! ;)
author: Thomas C.

description: My best friend and I were looking for a new Korean place to try, so we decided to try our luck here on Balboa. It wasn't till we arrived that she finally remembered she had already been here and couldn't recall if it had been good or not. I think that should have been the first indicator that this restaurant was just alright, and not very memorable. The side dishes are GREAT, but everything else was mehhhhh. I was craving tofu soup, but they only offered one type, and didn't even let us pick the level of spiciness. We also had a stewed beef dish, but the meat was a bit on the salty side. Service was slow, but the staff was nice. However, I think we'll try our luck somewhere else next time. I can't just come here to eat the side dishes alone!
author: Kristen C.

description: I am very impressed and happy that when I searched for Korean food I chose this restaurant. They really do give you many side dishes and unlimited refills. I order the beef tofu soup, and it came with a free steamed egg dish. My boyfriend order a spicy fried squid dish and everything was mouth watering. We couldn't stop picking and eating from every dish on the table. By the end of the meal we were so full but still kept eating because we didn't want the good food to go to waste. This is a great place for lunch because they have specials and prices are cheaper too. Once you try you will  want to keep coming back to try different dishes.
author: Minnie H.

description: Last night, I came here with 5 other friends for dinner. Although we had made reservations in advance for 6:30 PM, there was still a 20-minute wait because the restaurant was filled with 2 bus loads of tourists. When we finally got sat down at our table, the host had a very snappy, rude attitude. One of my friends was on the phone and wasn't listening when our group name was called, so the host bluntly lectured her that she should get off the phone and pay attention because he didn't have time to chase people around. Wow! This was appalling because the rest of us were paying attention--she was the only one trailing behind, but once she had realized, she immediately put her phone away. Nonetheless, the host's snappy attitude continued throughout the night. He was very impatient in taking our orders, spotty when it came to refilling our tea/water, and quick to deny our request for any banchan refills. He told us that if we wanted banchan refills, we would have to order more food. What?! Why should we have to order more food when we hadn't even finished grilling our BBQ meats or eating our other dishes yet? To be exact, we had ordered 4 BBQ meats and 3 other dishes. Plus, we had a group of 6, but he had only provided only a single serving of each banchan. Of all the Korean restaurants I have eaten at, I have never had the experience of being denied banchan refills until here. It was shocking! Perhaps the host had a stressful night, but nonetheless, his poor attitude was unacceptable. 1 star for the food; otherwise, negative 5 million stars for terrible service.
author: Emily C.

description:
I have experienced the tour bus rush.  Oh my lord.  Two tour buses full of Korean tourists empty into the restaurant, the staff goes into sprint mode, the place is hopping, and then 2 hours later the place is almost empty.  Amazing.  I can't believe that happens every day.  

In any event, it is on par with new Korea House in terms of food and comfort, AND they give you shik-hye (rice punch) to finish everything off.
author: Tim G.

description:
Thanks again, Yelpers!

My boyfriend and I were looking for a good Korean restaurant amongst the seemingly endless choices in the Richmond, for we had no idea where to start. after searching through various Yelp reviews, we decided on Han Il Kwan.

Luckily, the restaurant is within two blocks of my bf's house, so we walked on over, through the biting cold San Francisco Summer weather, to the quiet corner of Balboa and 19th.

When we arrived, we saw that a tour bus was sitting in front of the restaurant. Uh oh, are we in for a crowd? Nope! Luckily, the bus started its engine as we were entering the door. We were glad to see the group of satisfied Korean tourists piling into the bus.

They weren't able to seat us at a bbq table, but we were fine with that, since it was our first time and it was just the two of us. We both ordered a bibimbap (me beef, him seafood) and it was more than enough, considering all the wonderful side dishes and soups.

Service was a bit slow, but they were friendly and pleasant. I found it amusing that the fellow behind the counter was eating take-out from Domino's Pizza while the rest of them huddled around a table in the corner and ate restaurant food.

We felt like rolling out of the restaurant. Seriously. I coulda slept right there.

Needless to say, we'll be back. Next time, we're bringing a group of friends for some BBQ, and ordering a big bottle of that OB (Original Brewery) beer.
author: Courtney P.

description:
Hands down the best Korean restaurant in San Francisco.  So good that ever day at around 7pm, there's a huge korean tour bus that pulls up and drops about 30 Korean tourists off to enjoy their native food in a foreign city. 

The kalbi is excellent -- premium beef off the rib and marinated just right.  The side dishes are also excellent.  

Tip for insiders: ask for the wooden charcoal grill instead of the gas grill.  Gives the meat that real barbecue flavor.  Also, you can ask for the raw crab appetizer.  If you're extra adventurous, ask for the halbimbap.  You'll need to either be Korean or go with a Korean for this special treatment.
author: howie f.

description:
This place is just around the corner from my mom's house so we come here fairly often. Mom likes it too, and she's pretty picky about food. It's been around for at least 15 years, that's when we moved into that neighborhood. 

You can either choose to grill your own meat (this option is available for parties of 4 or more) or have it cooked in the kitchen. We're too lazy to grill our own stuff so we usually have them cook it. The kalbi is excellent and so are the noodle dishes. I love that they're not stingy with their little side dishes. I really haven't had anything bad here.

I marked one star down because the service can be a bit pokey. Also beware the tour buses! Most of the time it doesn't necessarily impact the wait for tables, they have a couple of larger rooms for big parties, but you never know.
author: cyndi L.

description:
Just adding my humble voice to the many satisfied customers that have come before me to this Korean diamond in the rough.  The extra dishes were awesome, the banchan amongst the best (and most numerous) I've had, service was very friendly and the food was delicious.  Definitely a place I'll go back to try out the BBQ dinner.  If only the parking situation was better, I'd go back more often.

I had been meaning to try this place so when my cousin was in town, I cajoled her to accompany me.  As a flight attendant on an international airline, she had enjoyed authentic Korean food from the motherland and even she was impressed here so two chopsticks up for my new favourite Korean location.
author: Chris C.

description:
Best f***in' Sul Long Tang I have tried in the city. Thank you!
I still haven't tried the BBQ here, but I have other go-to bbq places in the city. Han Il Kwan is where I go for my other Korean dish staples, like Sul Long Tang, Kalbi Tang, Chap chae, Mul nang myun.... 

/break/

Sorry, had to wipe the drool off my keyboard!
author: dj z.

description:
Since moving here from the east coast I've been searching for decent korean food. I'd been told that it doesn't really exist in SF (a shame really). I thought this place was really good food wise - but had a lot to be desired in terms of service as others have commented..but I'll take good food over good service anyday. I tried Brothers recently as well, well you can read my review there...

I had the galbi, bulgogi, kimchi jigae - my friends had the hot stone bibimbop. I haven't tried other stuff but will next time.
author: Bonnie K.

description:
Saw the tour buses and was afraid to go. It could either be really good or really bad. Turns out it's in between. 

Went for a late lunch and my friend and I both got the Bi Bim Bap ($11.95). For one thing - all of the vegatable side dishes were awesome. Very tasty and the tofu soup wasn't so spicy that it took out all of my taste buds before I had the main meal. 

The Bi Bim Bap was a lot...of rice. Not much meat but if I wanted lotsa meat I guess I should have gotten a soley meat dish. All in all we had a lot of food for a good price $11.95 for the Bi Bim Bap, tofu soup, and vegetable side dishes. I would like to go back to see what the BBQ dinners and/or lunch specials are like.

Good service and we didn't have problems finding parking. There are no parking limits in this area so it's even better. You just have to fight the residents for spots.
author: Wendy B.

description:
Good bbq, the best stews, good fried fish, yummy Korean-style seafood pancakes, scrumptious rice-cake and dumpling soup, make this spot a jewel in the Richmond district.

I patron here a lot and crave it often, especially when I'm driving by with my windows open and I can smell the food!
author: Susan C.

description:
I like this place i came here with my family . for my little sisters bday. and it turned out to be very good. we sat at a round table with a lot of banchans. enough for a family of 8 including my sisters bf. 

inaddition, the meats were very flavorful. and they even gave us two free dishes of a clear noodle and some fried fish cake. 

I also like how this place is designed how theres tables that are very family style and individual tables for couples to sit in thier own booths or individual tables if you do not want to cook. 

one con. is that beware you'll defiately come out smelling like food.
author: Sally Y.

description:
For this place, it is my first time follwing yelper's words to here. "sniff * sniff*" While I sniffed like my Shi Tzu to find the restaurant, I saw the perfect parking space in front of it.  OH.... it's for coaches, I hope they have no coaches tonight but anyway we parked somewhere else.

We are sort of fond of the Korean food.  Compared to Japanese food, my hunny could be stuffed with bowls of rice and lots of meat and soup.  For me, I am so excited with the small dishes of appetizers and I usually would try to finish them all.  By the way, those pickled appetizers are not cheap when I checked it out at the Korean Supermarket.

When we stood at the entrance, we are amazed that we have never noticed that grand entrance at all, or perhaps we seldom pass by Balboa Street anyway.  We got there at 7pm, and it's not crowded at all, and thank GOD, no tourist gangs!!

Although we longed for Korean BBQ, we went for dishes instead as there are 2 of us only.  We have no idea of what famous dishes are but we order the regular dishes: Beef, Sprouts, Veggie and Egg Bul-goo-bi (or whatsoever), and the Spicy Kimchi Tofu Seafood Soup with noodles, and the Kimchi Pancake.  

We receive 9 small dishes of appetizers, and also the complimentary regular bean cake and steamed egg.  the "Beef Bowl" is unbelievebly DELICIOUS! We want to finish the crispy rice remained on the sizzling stone pot, though it's burned so brown...  haha, just kidding, we didn't eat the burnt thing, but save our stomach for the remaining yum yum food.  Tofu Seafood Soup has a wonderful noodle as I can tell that the noodle is already soaked with the Kimchi Soup.  We regret to order the Kimchi Pancake as we are enough for the two small complimentary bean cake already.  We tried our best to kill them all, but finally we still have the kimchi pancake leftover.  

$40 for 2 in a lousy Korean restaurant may be too much, but this place is somewhat a worth, but I think that their BBQ may be even more outstanding.

4 yum-yum stars for them.
author: Woodspy T.

description:
Haven't had Korean food in awhile.  We went here last night to celebrate my wife's b-day a little early.

I regret eating lunch as the food choices that were picked were plentiful.  The BBQ Short ribs, tempura, steamed eggs, BBQ chicken, pan-fried oysters...and the list goes on a little longer (but I didn't eat the rest).  Simply tasty and delicious!

Their hot tea is made with barley and tasted different, but I could not stop drinking it.

Nice touch to reserve a private room for our group.

Bathroom was clean.

Enough said!
author: Mario P.

description:
This place is absolutely delicious! I love it here! 

The prices aren't bad at all, and you get so many condiments! The quality of the food they give you is great. I've only had their BBQ (to be cooked at the table), and it's delicious! The bulgogi was delicious, and the pork was so tender and lathered in good spicy sauce, and the seafood + veggies were so sweet and tender. 

If you order the BBQ, you are served a lot of condiments (several types of kimchi, several types of pickled vegetables and much more, soup, fried potato cakes or whatever they were). 

I had a great experience here and I would love to go again! =
author: Joy Q.

description: For Korean food there is only one place that I come to and it's this place!!! The service, food and the best kalbi jim I have ever had. They do a lot of Korean tourist business but don't let that stop you or the long wait on weekends. I tried most of the other Korean restaurants in the Richmond and I have to say they are the best
author: Dennis K.

description: A bit expensive, but it is pretty good! Authentic. We got a plate of food on the house. It's my first time here, but many said this place is bomb!
author: Vivian L.

description: I have lived near this place for almost 6 months and the aroma coming from this place has been enticing me the entire time! So finally I went here for dinner to try there BBQ. I was so surprised in how good everything was. The Side dishes were all really great and flavorful, it was a good mix of pickled veggies and fruits, noddles and my favorite the potato pancakes, yum!. And then we got the Bulgogi and Shrimp and Veggies. everything was really great and so filling! They give you great portion sizes and with all the side dishes just one meat BBQ item is perfect for 2. Will be back soon.
author: Sean C.

description: I had discussed with a friend that there should be  a restaurant named "the good thing you're smelling ,it's here" For we eat with not only our mouths but our eyes and nose too. Sooo like Toucan Sam I followed the delicious aroma of kal bi all the way to Han il kwan's doors and found my soon to be mommy friend waiting for me. We were a little disappointed that we didn't get charcoal for our grill. We learned later if you do want that you would have to order in advance. That however did not deter us from enjoying every single bite. A whole lotta food for a pretty reasonable price.
author: Sophia C.

description:
I like this restaurant. Dependable (when not full of a bus load of K-tourists), decent K-food, nice peeps.

Nice neighborhood restaurant on a block of Balboa that's otherwise devoid of restaurants.

Banchan selection is a good for SF, competently done.

Haven't ventured into grilling yet (my preference is wooden charcoal, not gas), but dishes from the kitchent like duk mandu gook, mul nang myon, dol sot bibimbap, and hae mul pajun have definitely hit the spot.
author: Bono B.

description: We came here despite the 'tour bus' warnings I read about.  It was late enough that the place wasn't packed.  Not wanting to eat a cow, we sat at the non-BBQ table and opted for the Bibim-bap and an order of dumplings.  The Bibim-bap was wonderful.  The skin on the dumplings was too thick.  Oh, you don't put tea into the pot after?  Oops wrong restaurant...she was so gracious and told me that they do that at Tofu House.  Yelp overload, what can I say?
author: Arlene C.

description: Good place to go to for korean food. Everytime my friends and I go here, it's packed with people. You have to park on one of the surrounding streets since they don't have their own parking lot. lot of side dishes which i love. The complimentary egg dish that they gave us was eh. The pancakes were delicious though :) One of my friends usually does all of the ordering so I don't exactly remember everything we've gotten. We always get bulgolgi and I think we got the short ribs and chapchae? We have also gotten the tofu soup which is good. Good food, nice servers. I LOVE the rice drink that they give at the end :)))
author: Jane N.

description:
Seen this place for years, but never had the opportunity to try it until someone introduced it to us as one of her favorites.  

Food: tasty, fresh, and well prepared. My husband loves spicy, so the sauteed seafood was spicy to his liking, as was the spicy pork, which was somehow less spicy than the seafood. The lunch special prices were great.  Somehow we're used to the Korea Town and other lunch box/special prices in the S. Bay and we could only wish the prices were similar to Han Il Kwan's (i.e. 8-$12 range). Their dinner bbq menu prices are akin to Santa Clara's Korea Town prices so that seemed fair.  

Korean tour groups apparently frequent this place, so it must be nice comfort food for them.  It was busy even for a weekday lunch.  Parking was ok, as expected.  Just watch out for street cleaning days/times.

Service was fine.
author: Ye W.

description: Pork bulgogi with tofu soup including tip was $11. Best lunch deal (korean food) in SF.
author: calvin c.

description: I've been going to this place for quite some time now and think it still rocks!!  Definitely not a place you will think that will have good Korean food as bus loads of Korean tourists go here...usually, like when I am in China and in a tour bus group, they take us to mediocre places...but Ham Il Kwan is not mediocre.  I usually have them cook the food inside versus BBQ'ing ourselves and they do a heck of a job.  This place is like a hidden gem in SF's Richmond district.
author: Patrick C.

description: Great beef and prawns. Good tea. This place is authentic. They give you 6-8 small bowls of random apps. Small tiny fish, cucumbers, tofu, tofu soup, cabbage are some of the apps. Only some of the tables have the option to cook at the table. Really great staff. Very busy though. The beef or cook your own entrees are between $18 for prawns and veggies and $28 for spicy beef. Easy to split just one of these between two people.
author: Rhea S.

description: Nice Korean restaurant. I came here with a group of people and food was good. Good noodle dishes. My friends seemed to enjoy the place too which can accommdate a large group when it's not too busy.
author: Leon C.

description:
I was in the mood for some Korean BBQ after not being able to eat much of anything except cut up soupy noodles and Jell-O for the past two weeks after having two of my wisdom teeth extracted.  We usually go to Korean Village (on Geary), but A said there was this place on Balboa that is pretty good and Korean tourists go there all the time, so it MUST be good.  He was telling me all about how tour buses are always stopped there and the people are, like, straight from Korea.

So we drive over there and circle around for about 5-10 minutes looking for parking.  We find a spot less than a block and a half away and walk to the restaurant.  There's only one other booth filled, so we were greeted and seated immediately.

We decided to get the kalbi and the octopus.  We have a tendency to over-order and, hence, overeat.  They brought out some mung bean pancakes on the house and their spicy soft tofu soup as well as the assortment of banchan.  I like the mung bean pancakes, but I never order them because each order always has like twelve pancakes in them and I can't finish them all.  So this was good.  The tofu soup was good - not too spicy - and good flavor.  I like the assortment of banchan.  There was one dish which was like pickled, shredded potatoes.  Definitely my favorite, hands down.  I love potatoes.  I polished that whole dish off pretty much by myself.  They do offer refills of the banchan, but, as other Yelpers have mentioned, once a tour group comes in, it's pretty impossible to get any attention from the wait staff.  And wouldn't you know it, not only did three additional parties come in to fill the booths, but a busload of Korean tourists came in too.  It's all about timing.  If you make it there before tourists arrive or after they leave, it's an awesome place service-wise.

As for food, the kalbi was pretty good.  I've had better, but it's definitely good here.  The spicy octopus with vegetables was good, but the octopus was super chewy.  I like octopus and they are chewy.  It was just still a little difficult for me to chew after the teeth extractions.  And it's not as good when you let the dish go cold.

Price is reasonable.  It cost about $40 for the two of us and we were out of there within an hour, even with the tour bus arrival.  I'd go back.
author: Kris L.

description:
My sweetie chose this place for my 24th birthday dinner. It was my first all-Korean restaurant experience, so I certainly didn't know what I was doing or have anything to compare it to, but it was pretty tasty. Quality of food is high. Navigating the menu is doable (but not fantastic) for first-timers, but we were some of the few white people in the joint. Portions are large; a major takeaway for me was how much food there was inevitably left over and thrown away at the end (all the little side dishes, etc). The sides we liked disappeared quickly, while most sat there uneaten.

They gave us a complementary bowl of boiling egg, which was deliciously light and fluffy, but we were all pretty full by that point and don't fancy eggs much, anyway.

The service was fair to poor, but the food is good.

(pssst, heads up, two 12oz beers cost less than one 20oz beer at time of review, unless that was a misprint)
author: C. S.

description:
Parking: Average. It's SF!..what else to expect?
Wait Time: 0 min. Went on a Sunday afternoon for lunch
Service: Decent, a little slow for a slow day but not complaining.
Space: pretty spacious seating (offers booths and large table and chair room)
Food Quality: SUPERB! 

Pardon me for not remembering my dish name, but on the menu it's #53. The huge bowl with beef, bean sprouts, carrots, cucumbers, other veggies and topped off with a sunny side egg on top-- bibimbop?  That portion is huge!  I stuft myself silly and still had alot left for my lunch the next day!  In additional to me feeling stuft were the 
mini appetizers in the beginning... 

(list taken from Kaye W.)

crispy fried vegetable cake
spicy tofu soup
arrowroot cakes
cabbage kim chi
pickled cucumbers
daikon kim chi
dried baby anchovies
seasoned bean sprouts
bean curd cakes
seaweed salad
sweet and salty red beans with sesame seeds

...and also a free tofu soup (on the house!)  And to cap the meal, the restaurant provides a sweet rice drink for dessert. That was a first for me, tasted like sugar water with rice at the bottom, but pretty refreshing..
author: Karen C.

description:
Alas, I've tried a restaurant as close to good tasting as Brothers!  

Service: Spectacular.  Fast.  Friendly.  They also check on you to make sure you're ok-this might be because it was slow, but I thought it was nice.

Food: Tried the Korean bacon (aka Samgyupsal).  Excellent!  The table is given a myriad of panchan, including fried pancake and cooked egg, which you hardly see anywhere else.  Alcohol is average price.  $12 for soju/ $10 for cold sake/ $6-7 hot sake. The Kim chee chi gae is brought out in a GINORMOUS pot and is cooked very well.

Price: Extremely reasonable.  Threw down $30 for everything mentioned above.  

Restaurant: Quiet during weekedays and super clean.
author: Anne K.

description:
You know what? This is a KOREAN restaurant.  What the hell do you people expect?  I like it... as far as Korean food goes... Heeelllloooo!
I go in expecting to have a Korean food experience.  It's culture man.
They are nice people.  The food tastes like "Korean" food tastes.  That's why the natives dump hot sauce all over it so they can't taste anything but hot.  But I got to say, I love the jelly sort of food things and all the little dishes they bring out in advance of the main dish, and I drink two glasses of wine and eat rice and kim chee and all is well.  It's cheap, its actually really healthy stuff, and its FUN, I love it, and the tourist buses make me laugh and the people think I'm sort of weird and they tried to show me how to eat Be-Bim-bop and I said, get out of my face I don't stir my food up in a big mess.
author: Sarah H.

description:
Being of Korean decent i am always looking for the most authentic Korean i can find.  This restaurant reminds me of sitting around the table in Korea with my relatives.  It is as good as it gets.  If you are a fan of the chic $100 a person experience this is NOT for you.  This is the kind of restaurant where you can eat until you burst and drink enough to kill a horse for only $40 a person!!  I prefer to sit at a big round table with 8-9 friends.  We share a pit in the middle and cook our own food.  They bring out MORE than enough side dishes!(I have friends that barely make it to the main course!)

It is a little off the beaten path but i have never had to wait.  Unlike Brothers that is overcrowded and overpriced.  By far my favorite Korean in the city!!
author: Reggie A.

description:
Sister recommend to come here for dinner last minute while we were driving to Go Go Cafe& Restaurant.  
Good recommendation!!
Great side dishes. 
We Ordered the set dinner A.  Wow!! it was A LOT of food for 4 people.  But it was so good...  I love our beef, and chicken bbq that we did on our own at the bbq tabletop.  It's Flavorful.  
Tofu Soup is somewhat spicy but yummy on a cold night.  
The egg batter tempura for the oysters and shrimps and cucumber was excellent.  
My sister said the chap jae was delics.  I didn't eat it b/c my stomach has no room for that....
The steam egg was smooth and tasteful.  Reminds me of my mom's steamed egg at home.  
The spicy octopus was alright but seriously, i was so full by then.  
Last but not least, the mackerel was grilled just right.  And the rice dessert drink was cooling and sweet after a huge meal.
Shit, i went to the gym earlier that day, and it just canceled out from this dinner!  Oh well, we all left feeling full but satisfied.  It hit the spot alright!
   Now back to going to the gym.  (yeah... right... ) =P
author: Selina L.

description:
Come with friends to make it easier on the wallet. WIth the 5 of us, me plus 4 really hungry guys, we ordered 2 orders of kalbi, 1 order of spicy pork bulgogi, green onion pancakes, and soondubu.

You have to wait longer for a BBQ table (we waited 45 minutes). The spicy pork bulgogi is awesome here because of all the marinated flavor, and in my opinion, better than the kalbi. One factor could have been that we had to grill everything on our own, and maybe that affected the outcome of the meat.

The soondubu had no flavor, so I probably wouldn't go back to get that again. Green onion pancakes are thick and huge, and it comes with a lot.

With the free appetizers, they also brought a huge bowl of the egg, which was ginormous and the biggest bowl I've seen served at any Korean restaurant.

Total bill was only $89 for the 5 of us. So $21 total including tax and tip. Not bad for all that food.

Oh yeah, no reservations on weekends, so get there early or wait after 9 pm.
author: Jeanne C.

description: The side dishes were underwhelming. Nothing really wow'ed me compared to other Korean restaurants I've been to.. Granted, I didn't have the Korean BBQ since it said 2 people must order and my dinner date didn't want to have BBQ. Maybe I need to come back and try BBQ to give them a better rating.
author: Wendy T.

description: I like their food. Their pre-main courses dishes are more tasty than other Korean BBQ places that I have been. Overall, I think this place is the best Korean BBQ in the city.
author: Ali E.

description:
We all know Geary Blvd. is where you go for Korean BBQ. The street is lined with restaurants- Brother's, Tofu House, etc. I've tried at least 4 other places and none of them fill my tummy with happiness and delicious food better than Han Il Kwan! 
The restaurant itself isn't anything to look at but really... who cares about that? You won't notice where you are when you start eating! They serve the usual little dishes- all of them mouth-watering delicious! The usual orders include: kal bi (beef), jap chae (vermicelli), kimchee chi gae (kimchee tofu soup) and bibimbap (rice with veggies and meat and the best sauce you've ever tasted). They will usually throw in a free dish too- a fish or pancakes. 
Of course, after stuffing your face with all that deliciousness, you get a small bowl of sweet rice soup... not sure what it's called but I know I like it! 
I really like this place but it's just so far! Prices are decent and so worth it! If you are driving, allow ample time to circle 'round! Parking is horrendous!
author: Amanda W.

description: After eating here tonight, my husband and I are both in agreement that this place deserves three stars for the food, but is seriously lacking in the service department.  The waiters are nice enough, it's just that there aren't nearly enough of them so it takes forever to get seated and get an order in.  The food and selection here are better than the overpriced Seoul Garden, but there's just no comparison to Sahn Maru (in Oakland).
author: Su H.

description: Very friendly family own restaurant! Love the service and our stomach are always satisfied the delicious food. =) Good spot for group dinner.
author: Lianna D.

description: The food is quite authentic but the service is mediocre at best. We waited a long time for the food to come. The people that came on a tour bus got food before we did. However, the staff was quite accommodating about us switching table. I like the rice drink they offered after the deal.
author: Bob C.

description:
This is my first ever Yelp review.  The service was so horrendous here, I had to write about it.  We were seated at 7pm on a Saturday night for a table of 6 in the main dining room.  It was pretty busy, but not incredibly busy, as many tables were finishing up with their meals.  For the next 35 minutes, absolutely no one came to our table.  All we had were our menus and a couple failed attempts to flag down a waiter to order.  We finally got someone to take our order of Set Menu A and an additional chicken dish.  They immediately set down 2 pots of tea.  Finally, some service!  Not really.  We sat there for another 30 minutes after ordering with absolutely no one coming by our table again.  Not even the side dishes came.  I started looking around the restaurant and people who had sat down after us were already in the middle of their meals and even people who had sat down after we ordered were being served their meals!  After a few thoughts of just getting up and leaving, we flag down a waiter and he says our food is coming.  Finally, they start serving some side dishes and main dishes.  Everything comes out except for the additional chicken order.  We notify the waiter of this in the middle of our meal and he goes to the kitchen.  Just when we were about done eating, 20 minutes later, the chicken actually shows up.

They also don't even bother refilling tea pots.  Teapot lids on our table were open for most of the night, but of course the waiters just walked by them.  At one point, I actually held both tea pots in my hand and waved it toward a waiter across the room and pointed at the tea pots.  He gave me an acknowledgment as if he was going to come over in a minute.  Of course, he never came over.  At all.  I gave up.  

You would think that after not taking the order for so long and then not bringing our food out for so long, they'd try to do something to make up for things.  Nope.  Nothing.  The service was consistently horrible, at least for us, for the entire night.  From my observation, it seemed like we were the only ones at the restaurant getting bad service though, since everyone else was getting their food ahead of us.

Food was decent, but I definitely won't be stepping foot through those doors again.
author: D T.

description:
I like it here.  I guess we've been lucky because I've always found parking and never had to wait.  I can't say the same for the Brother's on Geary Blvd.

Pretty standard Korean BBQ.  A great place to bring a group.  The fixed menu for 4 will easily feed 6, and I'm a BIG eater!
author: Collin W.

description: This place is my go-to Korean place in the city.  I always order the Spicy Beef Soup...it is soooo good. Perfect level of heat and flavors with just the right amount of beef and noodles.  The service is also great and I also enjoy all of the complimentary side dishes.
author: Maria D.

description:
Good food.  The SO loves the dol sot bi bim bap.  There is a tour bus parking up front.  I guess Koreans traveling through the San Francisco area would stop there to eat?  Anybody knows?

Being out in the outer Richmond means it is out of the way but it also means parking is easier than other parts of SF.  Well worth a track there.
author: sb T.

description: This is always my to go place for korean food. The staffs are nice and they have good food proportions. I also love how many side dishes they give you. If you haven't been to a traditional korean restaurant, you ought to try this one!
author: Forest T.

description:
everytime I come in, it smells so nice.

its so authentic. They make Kimchee soup with spice, they give big portions for the BBQ and they always bring my favorite steam eggs on the house. If I was rich, I would eat here everyday.
author: Derek Alistair J.

description: On our visit last night the staff was very friendly. My boyfriend is learning Korean in school and the staff was very happy to help him practice; they were all very friendly. The food was delicious, and the experience of cooking the meat at the table on the grill is something everyone should try. All of the side dishes were amazing, very worth the price, and an overall enjoyable experience. And the dessert water to finish was the perfect ending! :-)
author: Nicole S.

description:
First timer here with my boyfriend. The place was nice and wasn't packed during dinner time. The waiter and waitress were very friendly and nice. We wanted to have korean bbq and got seated at the grill table. That have pretty good ventilation. you won't feel the smoke or stuffiness from the grill.  We...

Ordered:
beef short ribs X1 ~ $22
pork belly X1 ~ $17
kimchi pancake X1 ~ $13
 
The short ribs was really good, tender and flavored. The pork belly was decent. They served in thin slice which became hard and dry when grilled. The kimchi pancake was not good. I've had much better kind. it was too much flour and very little amount of kimchi and vegetables. Another best part of eating here was the banchan (side dishes). They serve 10-11 small side dishes + a steam egg or tofu soup. The banchan and rice are]unlimited (free to refill).  

interior: Good
food: good
service: excellent

I would recommend to come here for the bbq. Two plates of meat can serve up to 4 ppl including the side dishes.
author: Sammi W.

description:
I went to Han Il Kwan two Sundays ago and was unpleasantly surprised by their lowered quality. I am a regular, going at least twice every month.  I ordered the Beef Rice Bowl and the Kimchee with Pork soup. The Pork soup was okay, seemed smaller than before though.

Here comes the bad part, the Rice on the Beef bowl was overcooked and  the whole bowl smelled of burnt rice.  I know that some burnt rice is to be expected, but it was just too much.
