The pluses are the free tofu soup, friendly and good service, after dinner sweet drink to kill the hot spicyness, willingness to refill all our side dishes frequently and the availability of lettuce and hot bean sauce (it's surprising how many korean places do not have this...isn't a standard?).  The meats though were just all right.  I'd still return cause it's a good value.  I wish I could give them 3.5 stars, 4 just seems too high for them.
author: Edgar C.

description: We love Korean BBQ, but living in the San Mateo we're always looking for a good place.  We heard about this place and had to try it.....and it did not disappoint.  The kalbi is our favorite so we had to get it and it was tasty, tender.....although I have had better in Hawaii, but that's about 2500 miles away.  We also had their mixed seafood, which was a nice compliment to the beef - although the octopus was a bit tough.  All the fixins are the icing on the cake and we left stuffed and satisfied.   Definitely would go back!!
author: Paul C.

description:
tucked away from the hub-bub of the main street, u might not even notice Han Il Kwan till you actually drive to the corner of balboa and 19th. being the first korean restaurant i tried out in the city, don't have much to compare it with, but i really liked it. 

we went there for dinner and were surprised to find only a few other tables occupied. it was quiet and nice though, so i'm not complaining :) 

we ordered the chicken and pork for bbq and with all the sides that we got with it, we had to bring some home! since they take a min. order of 2 portions for the bbq, we ended up having 4 portions actually, which was quite a lot!

the meat tasted really really really good! the pork in particular was terrific! and our waitresses were very helpful. there were a ton of sides (identical to what brenda's mentioned below) but not all impressed. the red beans, fried cakes and the soup (in particular) were below average. but u could get more of whatever side u wanted, so that was nice.

as for the price, umm...guess it should've been a little cheaper to make me feel completely satisfied but oh well, the bbq-ed meat was well worth it! :) 

would check out some other korean restaurants in town before coming back in a group for a korean bbq party!
author: Shradha B.

description: We went on a weeknight (Wednesday, I think) and were happy that it didn't close until 10.  My favorite part was actually not our main courses (kimchi bap and oyster dish) but the good variety of side dishes.  The kimchi is a lot milder (hardly spicy) than I'm used to, but ok.  I'm interested in going back and trying more...
author: Stacy R.

description: 4.5 Stars - For SF (I know not a high bar for Korean food), this place is great minus possible long waits esp if there is a tour bus of people here and service isn't always that attentive. That being said, I loved the sam gyup sal we had (uncured pork belly) and the kalbi (marinated). Portions were plentiful and the kimchijiggae is always good here. Not a fan of the duk bok ki. Plentiful panchans and definitely some delicious ones including the pickled radish, kimchi, octopus...etc.
author: Jeannette L.

description: Really good Korean BBQ. We had the Kal Bi and Bulgogi, along with rice and the side dishes. The kimchi was great and the mung bean pancakes were delicious. Maybe it was because it was lunch time, but we didn't get bean sprouts...But, the meat was excellent and service was good. I would definitely eat here again.
author: Theo T.

description: Appearance of the restaurant is good but food was not as great as I expected.  I have dined at many Korean resturants and some of them though not  fancy but have good food and servings. I was disppointed.
author: Noor s.

description:
Han Il Kwan has become our new go-to Korean restaurant.  It's less hectic thatn Brother's, easier to find parking, and a little cheaper.

We grew up eating Korean food and think the food is consistently good =).  The service is, well, it's a Korean restaurant, so not great, but not bad.  And as long as you're there when one of the large tour buses with Korean tourists is not, it won't be too hectic inside.

Our favorites include yuk gae jang, the various fishes, soon dubu, galbi tang, and others.  They are also great for carry out.
author: C.S. K.

description: The most authentic Korean restaurant in the San Francisco!  Love this place, and if you another place is equally as good, let me know!
author: A Z.

description: big, hearty meal out of the cold and fog. red meat extravaganza. the everpresent chill of the neighborhood is part of what makes it so satisfying.
author: Fzarond K.

description: I've been going to Han Il Kwan for over four years now and I must say that they do the best Korean food in the City. I love the fact that these guys just keep on serving good food year after year after year. I can't say that I have a favorite dish (since all of it is good) but on cold days like these, their fish roe soup is second only to a good Filipino Sinigang (a little personal bias there). Keep on trucking ladies!
author: Alex C.

description: Given that the last time I had eaten Korean food prior to coming here was in Seoul, I had extremely high expectations.  However, we really liked this place, and definitely would say it is the best Korean food we have had in S.F..  We had Kal Bi with all the extras, Bi Bim Bab, and Yuk Eh Jang (a spicy soup that was a childhood fav. of my fiance).  My only complaint was that they could have cranked up the spice factor a bit overall, as I ended up adding a lot of extra chili sauce to the Bi Bim Bab.  Otherwise, it was quite good and again, beats any other place we have tried in the city.  (Yelp is right again!)
author: Eva W.

description: Oh my God, I love this place so much. Their food just keeps getting better every time that i go here. Nice environment and prices are reasonably, plus you get all these free appetizers and delicious soup. The Korean tourists just add to the authentic touch of the restaurant. I highly recommend this place for anyone that loves food.
author: Pat T.

description: My friend and I came for Bibimbap and we were very satisfied.  Even though we didn't order any of the raw meat, we still got all of the crazy amount of side dishes and soup so it's a great place if you're really hungry.  Yum!
author: Patrick C.

description: Came here last summer with a group of friends. IIRC the middle tables were full so we were seated in a booth. Unfortunately there were 6 of us so it was a bit cramped but not unbearable. The food here is good but doesn't really distinguish itself from other Korean BBQ restaurants. It's also a tad expensive considering the average portion size, but I've seen much worse. This place looses a star for its terrible location. I was driving around and around for at least 10 minutes looking for parking. I know it's San Francisco but the experience was nonetheless quite frustrating.
author: Byron C.

description: Good quality solid cheap korean food.  Went there for lunch one day.
author: Matthew K.

description: This was my first time trying korean food that you cook at the table. OMG it was awesome trying the different side dishes with soup. My friends and i had a lot of fun taking turning cooking for one another.  Thank you Yelpers for all the great reviews!
author: Lo B.

description: I have been to HIK several time and the food is good, but the service is awful.  We are in San Francisco Bay Area...there are a lot of options out there for good (and authentic) Korean food.  You don't have to put up with rude service.  Also, this place gets bus loads of Korean tourist.  Even though their sign says "OPEN" I've been turned away 3 times because they "need to prepare" for the Korean tourist.  How about saying you are closed when there's a tour bus coming so I don't spend time looking for parking?  This happened to me when I was 8 months pregnant.  I found parking after 15 minutes of cruising the richmond dist. and waddled 5 blocks to be told that even though the signs says they are open, they are really not because they have a tour bus coming.
author: Susan H.

description: As a Korean I expect a lot out of korean restaurants. My housemates and I came here a week ago and all 8 of us left fully satisfied. There were two tour buses that rolled in, but we just beat them so we were seated in 10 minutes.  Most of us ordered the stonepot bibimbap. I've had many bibimbaps in my life and this was one of the best ones i've had from a restaurant. The wait staff was very nice and accommodating; they refilled any side dishes we needed and gave us tofu soup free of charge. There was a great variety of side dishes and the entree portions were pretty good. A tad bit expensive compared to back home in LA, but it's SF what can you do? I've found my korean restaurant in the city..I'll be back.
author: Jim Y.

description: awesome food.. service is alot better than brothers (i've only been to brothers #2 and have always gotten the rude waitress there), and in my opinion, the food is better too.   My new favorite korean place in SF (besides the place on geary by Tofu House and jackinthebox thats open till 4am ... but only at 2:30 am for the hands down best drunk food ever ).
author: Jack E.

description: Not sure what all the rave is.  It's allright.  Typical Korean BBQ prices, $15-19 per entre to cook your own food...place is filled with busloads of tourist.  Decent food.  I prefer Brothers, or even Mugu-whatever on Balboa&5th.
author: Mag K.

description: gramma kim who is the perfect gramma: soft, fat and an amazing cook went on a korean tour bus trip and their last stop was dinner at Han Il Kwan. like a good granddaughter, i met up to have din din with gramma, only to find myself being shunned to a separate table because i was not a part of the tour bus group :( so ginger and i ordered at our separate little table and watched gramma from afar. han il kwan still isn't comparable to any restaurant in la's ktown, but i may have found my surrogate in the city.
author: Jean K.

description: The food here is delicious.  A great place to bring a group of friends and grill food together.  The barley tea is damn good.
author: Dylan's Aunt E.

description: Best Korean restaurant Ive found here in San Francisco. We go here all the time and the food is always great. I especially love their side dishes.
author: Lani N.

description: very good variety of Korean dishes. and they give you a ton of small dishes! Very good marinated meat and tofu soup.
author: jen n.

description: decent korean, the doekkboki was great, the pajeon, bulgogi and tofu soup real tasty.  the chicken bulgogi was the weakest link in this equation.  ask for booth seats.
author: Teresa T.

description:
4.5 -- i'm sad to say i can't give it 5 because the meat wasn't marinated to my standards ... 

on the corner of 19th and balboa ... and yes, YES, YESSSS! i can say that han il kwan has probably topped off my korean taste bud in the city of san francisco ... korea house is just as good, but i'm talking about my overall experience ... 

i have more to explore but i was happy.. and yes, i was pleased ... so i hear that this is THE SPOT where the korean tour buses bring their tourists ... and most of the time, those places just suck, but i was actually quite surprised ... 

let's just say that after he drove about 15 minutes or so, we finally found parking on 19th, and it was more towards anza, and i shit you not when i say this, BUT... the minute we got outta the car, the galbi, the smell of korean bbq started to linger aways .. how COULD YOU RESIST? you should've seen me ... FYI, mental note: my nose is extremely sensitive and for me to actually whiff the smell of korean bbq that was a half block away means that it must be good shit .. the second i got outta the car, i literally SPRINTED to han il kwan... 

L I T E R A L L Y ...

ok ...

now, the prices are extremely fair ... totallllllllllllllly reasonable !! totally LA prices ... approx $7 and up ... they even have cool specials where you can get soondubu (tofu soup) along with your entree ...now that's a steal, totally getting 2 meals in 1 ... we came for dinner last night, and even so, you get a side of tofu soup or steamed egg in a bowl, which is totally awesome because it brings me fond memories of total homemade cooking... my ajuma (housekeeper/cook) would always make this ....  totally cool!! when requesting tofu soup, if you like it extreme~~~ly spicy like I DO, just kindly ask them, because mine was super watery and bland so i requested it as spicy as one can be .. and i was happy ... 

their bahnchans (sidedishes) were actually quite good, and i was SO in LOVE with their yellow circly mini pancakes which were SOO damn good .. right off the pan ... i even asked for 2nds ... they only give you 2 pieces so take small bites at a time ...  

i have to say that we ordered 1 serving of galbi and 1 bulgogi and they were both good, GOOD according to SF standards ... not GOOD if you compare to my mom's cooking and/or LA .. they need to marinate it a lil more, but im not complaining ... 

the service was great too, super friendly and super easygoing ... 

and they even topped it off in serving shik hae (rice punch) in the end... awesome! 

a total gem in the Richmond district ... 

SCREW all you BROTHERS lovers (http://www.yelp.com/biz/brothers-restaurant-san-francisco#hrid:zKTXacPmeiF8_7xJIFDnRg) & MUGUBOGKA (http://www.yelp.com/user_details_review_search?userid=EKdyI4jpUF29YtPkKiCtcg&q=muguboka)! read my review and see why!

if anything, check this place or not~*

and YAY, i'm definitely a fan for han il kwan ...
author: Jennifer S.

description: this is one of a few Korean restos in the city that i enjoy going! i luv their bulgogi but their combo seafood is not so generous with other type of seafood, they give you the squid tentacles only & 2 shrimps & baby scallops not worth the money i paid for! overall it's a nice place to take family/friends!  their banchans are superb & one of the best kimchees i've tasted in restos i've been to!
author: Pinkangel U.

description: This place is yummy.  We grilled meat at our table and enjoyed the delicious traditional side dishes.  We were happy and full at the end.  Oh, the tofu soup that comes with is very good too.
author: melissa W.

description: The majority of the food is pretty good except parking is really bad.  I love their rice cakes (dok bok ki) and their condiments are awesome.
author: Mary L.

description: The service was horrible.  The waiter went out of his way to avoid eye contact when I wanted to ask for a couple more napkins. It was more important for him to set up a back room than to take one minute to stop by ours.  I understand not to expect much in the way of customer service in Korean restaurants, but this was ridiculous. When the waiter brought one of the entrees, I asked for more  of a couple of the ban chan, and was told it would "cost more"  First time that has ever happened to me when paying dinner prices somewhere.  Speaking of the ban chan, it was underwhelming.  The fish cake was under seasoned.  Three of the 9 dishes were a variation on cucumber. No fresh cabbage. Nothing with much spice or heat.  The seafood stew was pretty good.  Kalbi was also pretty good,  higher quality meat than some. I couldn't understand why the kalbi was served almost 15 minutes after stew. The place was nearly empty.  Overall fair to good food, but the extremely poor, actually rude service will keep us from returning.
author: Steve N.

description: Ok their Sondubu jigae is nasty. Why the 5 stars then? Because their Min-Oh jigae is phenomenal
author: John L.

description: never had a bad dinner here ONCE!  yummy, yummy side dishes that come with the main dishes.  don't get freaked out by the barricading facade.
author: Danielle Y.

description: After eating at numerous Korean restaurants around the city, I still have yet to find one single place that satisfies all of my wants and needs. One either has the best tofu soup but not so good (or enough) sides, or their bibimbaps are everything that I've dreamed of but their bbq is only meh. That being said, Han Il Kwan is one of my favorite places to get Korean BBQ. I LOVE their pork marinated in the spicy house sauce and they always give you additional dishes that are "on the house!". I've only ever bbq'd and eaten tofu soup here so I can't speak for their other dishes but all the meat that I've ordered here were of good quality, except for the fact it's poorly sliced sometimes and you end up having to hack at huge pieces w/ a pair of scissors before you can put it on the grill...  I also thought that it was kind of strange that they asked if we wanted the meat cooked for us. Why would I go to a bbq joint and not cook it myself? It's a part of the fun! I guess some people aren't as into it... The smell of bbq tends to seep into your fingers, hair, clothes, everything - it's unavoidable even though their ventilation system here is excellent. Just be careful how you bbq though b/c my friend and I got yelled for not doing it "right". I still don't understand. We put the meat on grill, the meat was cooked thoroughly, and then we ate it. What did we do wrong? WHAT?
author: Queenie C.

description: I feel like eating korean food in korea. Good decoration and the food especially. They give side dishes and free a glass of korean drink ( I don't know what it called).. I love Spicy Beef Soup and Kimchi Pancake... Best forever.... also cheap
author: Elisabeth T.

description: So GOOD! I went to this place on my last trip to San Francisco. It was so delicious we went there 2 days in a row. They give you all the lil extras and a complimentary dish on the house. I love Korean bbq and the price was fantastic.
author: Cheese T.

description: This is probably THE Korean restaurant of my choice in SF Bay Area. It is where you can have a good Korean meal without feeling as if you are in the middle of a battle zone or in a cult society.
author: Sherwin L.

description: I wish I could give them extra star. My bf and I are big fan of Korean food and we love their Kalbi and Bulgogi with Soju (sometimes). We prefer to go there during lunch special hour which ends at 4p.m i guess Mon-Fri. Cos' when we get our favorite Kalbi and Bulgogi during lunch time (it comes with spicy tofu soup), it costs under $20 and we are totally full when we leave. but it will cost you around $40 during dinner (we ate once during dinner hour and I believe the size of the dish was same). I would say this is a must place to go for  Korean food lovers. :D
author: Alta C.

description: came here with a friend for dinner cus we're around the area. the interior looks pretty stylish. friendly services, but a guy forgot to give us an extra spoon that we asked for!! (-1 star..) we ordered their sauteed squids with vegetables, it's pretty good and sauteed chicken with vegetables, it's also pretty good. it comes with soup, a bowl of rice, some small lil pancake looking like pancake that tasted really good, lots of other random dishes that korean restaurant usually serves, they're big portions, and lastly it comes with a cup of swt drink after the delish food.
author: Valerie N.

description: I don' t have a  problem with their food, it's actully pretty tasty, but I do have an issue with the service or lack of it. We go for lunch quite often and there is only one guy who does everything! He seats people, takes orders, brings out the food, buses the tables and is the cashier as well. More than one occasion he told us to wait 10 minutes or sometimes 20 minutes in the waiting area, that only has one chair, before he can seat us even though there are tables available. Its ridiculous!! They need more people working on the lunch shift.  Just last Wednesday when there was a tour bus lucheon at the restuarant he told people who were coming in we had to wait 20 mins. before he could seat us all of us left, that's three different parties. They are loosing customers! Bottom line hire more employees!
author: Peggy L.

description: best korean restaurant i've been to in sf! they give you a lot of good small dishes to start out with... and they give you a steamed egg, which is unique and a favorite! the service is always great here too... they seat you fast, the food comes quickly, and they don't pressure you to leave! definitely one of my favorite spots to go to for dinner in the city!
author: Ryan C.

description: bout the only thing i remember about my meals here is that there is usually a very cute girl sitting somewhere distracting me from the fact that i am not cooking a tender slice of beef on the grill, but alas, preparing my left hand instead for consumption. it is not until a companion screams in horror and i look down to find my charred hand that i realize my folly. but hell, kimche on anything makes it edible.
author: Darrell L.

description: The dishes we orders was quite good:  chop chae (sp?) was very flavorful with the addition of shiitake mushrooms, kim chee bean cake was surprisingly delicious (esp. if you're looking for veg. dishes), and our fav.,  the coker (type of sea bass) w/ turnip and zucchini was simply succulent w/ a perfect blend of spice w/o overwhelming the fish.   The bul go gi the least exciting only because the other dishes we ordered were so delicious. Service was decent but slow since they had a nearly full house with only two staff members.  They redeemed their slow service with tofu soup and mung cakes on the house!  Needless to say, we were well fed!  Service Since they're located in a residential area, parking is tough esp. after 6p.m.  Lastly, ambience is nice - not too divvy.  I'm on the fences as to whether or not I'd return.  I think it depends on how optimistic I am w/ my parking karma for the day.
author: FoodJunkie S.

description: It's a nice place to eat, and the lunch specials are a great value. The staff are friendly. Nothing special about this place, really. Parking can be hard to find around here.
author: Jason T.

description: The meat was pretty good, but I kinda feel like all the meat taste the same at all places. I like BBQing it myself b/c I can have the beef as rare as I want. They were really nice to give us two free dishes (pancakes and tofu soup).  The order of the food came in all weird...first it was the appetizers, then BBQ stuff,...then when we were almost done, the rice came, then the water, then the pancakes and soup...
author: M L.

description:
I just tried Han Il Kwan for the first time and decided to post my initial impressions, though there will be more to come.

Today I tried the Oxtail soup (ggori gom tang), but I must state up front that this isn't exactly a fair review because they neglected to give me any salt (I ordered to go), but then again that itself is something consider.  

Naturally the soup was very bland, but aside from being unseasoned, the broth was not very rich and the meat was not nearly tender enough -- it was stuck to the bones.  This makes it obvious that they did not give it the time and love that a good oxtail soup requires.  They also cut the sections of oxtail into slices, bone and all, which is neither bad nor good, I suppose.  What is not good, however, is it appears that they may trim away the ligament surrounding the caps of the oxtail, stripping it of much that delicious gelatinous collagen that you suck away from the bone.  Either they trim it or just don't procure very good product.  That was quite disappointing.  The oxtail soup is fresh; I'll give them that much.

I have better things to say about the banchan; it was pretty nice.  With my take-out order they included a large 4-section piece of very good plastic-ware filled with pickled cucumber, bean sprouts, seaweed salad, a small piece of mung bean cake, and both radish and cabbage kimchee.  The cucumbers were fresh and still crisp with a nice refreshing sweet vinegary flavor that wasn't overbearing.  The bean sprouts were a little under-seasoned and I would have liked more sesame oil flavor, but they were fine.  The seaweed salad had a similar but sweeter/stronger flavor than the cucumber that was appropriate for the pungency of the seaweed.  The cabbage kimchee was pretty good and "fresh" (i.e. not from a supermarket jar or even worse, bag) but could have had a deeper, more rounded flavor (I get spoiled by my mom's); it was slightly on the milder side of fermented, but not spicy enough for a Korean.  The mungbean cake was so-so but needed some kimchee or meat because it was pretty darn plain, though I don't expect much from banchan bindae duk.  The kkakdugi radish kimchee was the best of the bunch.  Big and chunky with just the right amount of crunchiness and fermentation with the flavors running straight through to the middle of each piece --- would have been perfect for the soup if the soup had some salt!

In conclusion, my first experience here was promising enough to warrant a return visit, considering the poor competition in the Bay Area.  At $13 after all was said and done, it's not a great value, but probably par for the course in SF.

I'll have to bring some friends and eat in next time to dig into some interesting stuff.  More to come...
author: Eugene L.

description:
jap chae , bibimbap and the little plates and the little soup and the little desert  = the best korean food i have ever had, probably until i go to korea. really really really good food to die for. really.

i liked it a lot. esp the complimentary soup, so dont order a tofu soup because you get it for free!!! and the she-k (dessert) is like sugar on your snickerdoodles. 

thinking korean? go here; hands down. put your hands down!! or up!

up to swat the pesky flies flying around, bring a flame thrower and torch em for me. then i wont see them next time. thanks in advance!
author: Porkers T.

description: i got the tofu soup and it was okay. not great but not bad either. but it wasnt worth the drive over there and the parking was really hard to find. i also ordered the short rib soup and it wasnt good. the side dishes were good but overall the food was ok. the rice wasnt anything special and didnt come out in a clay pot. the server didnt give me a egg. i had to ask for one and by the time i got it and put it into the soup it didnt cook all the way. i was quite let down about this place bc based on all the good reviews i expected it to be really good. i think this place is totally overrated.
author: chloe w.

description: came here for new year's day for some dduk gook (rice cake soup) and boy did we!  you know by the banchan (small plates), if a restaurant is going to be good.  they had about 7 small plates and brought out my favorite egg custard as service.  there were 10 in our group so we had our own private dining room in the back.  we ordered beendeh dduk, dduk mandoo gook, galbi chim, kimchi jungol, kimchi dolsot bibimbap, and jaeyook bokum.  all of which were delicious!  oh, and the music rocks here!
author: Gina P.

description:
Not to be a jerk, but this place really doesn't deserve 4 stars. Sorry. Read on for why.

Some 15-20 years ago, Han Il Kwan was under different ownership and had delicious Korean food. The owners moved on and, I believe, opened up Koryo Wood Charcoal in Oakland, which is a far, far superior restaurant in every possible way (except price if you're pinching pennies).

At the risk of sounding like a condescending, arrogant snob (sorry), I can only assume that the high review scores given to this restaurant are coming from folks who are not familiar with authentic Korean food (told you I'd come off like a snob). Being Korean myself, and having frequented much better restaurants (Brothers in San Francisco, Koryo in Oakland), I can say that this place is competent, and the best thing about it is the prices, which are a bit on the low side. Some of the cheaper soup/stew dishes, for instance, clock in at just around or under $10.

The "new" Han Il Kwan's cooking and preparation are competent and the food is definitely palatable, but nothing will set your soul afire. Also, and unfortunately, if you happen to have a taste for genuinely spicy Korean food, nothing here will set your tongue on fire either, since the spicier dishes, such as the yookyejang (spicy boiled beef stew) and kimchichigae (boiled-"kimchi"-spicy-cabbage stew) aren't really all that spicy at all. Please keep in mind, however, that this review is being written by a Korean fellow who has prefers his food SPICY, so if you have trouble handling spicy stuff, you may want to avoid the spicier dishes altogether and go with something milder like gomtang (non-spicy boiled beef stew), naengmyun (cold buckwheat noodles in cold broth--NOT bibimnaengmyun, which are cold buckwheat noodles in spicy sauce), or mandugook. And yes, with that last sentence...there's that pompous snob coming out again.

Han Il Kwan apparently has some sort of deal with various Korean travel agencies; it's not uncommon to see one or more tour buses parked out in front of the restaurant around dinnertime on the weekends as Korean tourists pour out and pile into the restaurant. This is probably one of the more devious marketing maneuvers I've seen in a while, and weekend attendees at this restaurant may find themselves to be very impressed at the great number of REAL LIVE KOREAN PEOPLE who are patronizing this restaurant (much the same way that I'm patronizing anyone reading this review). Unfortunately, they're not here for the food; they're here because this is where the tour bus happened to stop. Brothers Restaurant on 6th and Geary otherwise has this place beat with fresher ingredients and flat-out tastier food. Presumably, it'd be harder to get a tour bus deal in the middle of Geary, which is, of course, the Richmond district's worst road in terms of traffic snarls.

Cons: Non-amazing food, non-amazing banchan, non-amazing spice level for soups and stews. Parking is also a serious pain in this neighborhood because it's residential, and parking spots in the Richmond district in general are laid out in a stupid manner that's extremely unfriendly to large cars. You may just want to take the 31 Balboa bus here if that's an option. It stops right in front of the restaurant.

Pros: Again, the 31 Balboa stops right in front of the restaurant, if that means anything to you. The restaurant also gives complimentary mini-bindaeduck (fried mung bean pancakes) with the purchase of every sit-down meal, and gives "banchan" side dishes that are plentiful, though they aren't amazingly fresh or flavorful. This place can also be a bit easier on your wallet, and the service is quite good, which is why I gave it the benefit of the doubt and 3 stars, rather than 2.

If you're looking for Korean food on the cheap and live nearby, Han Il Kwan is worth it for a quick, inexpensive meal with friends or family you know fairly well and don't need to impress. I realize that last part is a pretty backhanded compliment at best, but let's face it: I'm a pretty backhanded guy.
author: A P.

description:
I live around the area and was always curious why there were so many tour buses that park outside their restaurant. On one random occasion, my family and I decided to check the restaurant out. Like any other Korean restaurant they serve you with the many small appetizers. The sardines and that fish cake was mm mm good. I've tried almost everything there except for the stuff you cook at your table. I'm not a fan of that stuff because it makes your clothes smell. On a cold night, I recommend the tofu soup because it just has the right amount of spice. Sometimes the tofu soup is on the house..I guess it depends on how much you order. If you decide to drink soju there, then try the one with a white label with gold letters. I don't know what the brand name is but the soju was good enough to not get you hammered. And make sure you save some room for the dessert they serve you in a cup.
The service for here is superb. They greet you when you walk in and leave and that should be how it is for all restaurants.
author: Annie H.

description: This is my favorite Korean restaurant in SF. I only recently discovered it through my sushi chef friend who happens to be Korean - so a pre-qualified foodie - and I demanded recommendations b/c I haven't been happy with the places I've eaten and I really wanted some cooking that reminds me of Mom. Eating here made me pissed that I ate anywhere else for the past 8 years. I've only eaten here once, but the experience was sooo good, that I can't wait for my second time there. And yes, that is a tour bus stop in front, it's a popular destination on the Korean bus circuit. The atmosphere? It reminds me of being on the set of one of those period Korean soap operas as it tries to replicate an old Korean village.
author: J K.

description: the kimchee jigae was just ok.  didn't taste anything else.
author: Adela K.

description: I wasn't a big fan of Korean cuisine until I discovered this place. It has to be "discovered" because it is located in a residential area in the Avenues. I live in the Peninsula, but get my mani/pedi done across the street. I've noticed for years of waiting for my turn that there's always a stream of never ending tour buses that drop of Korean tourists on their doorstep. I figure that if tour bus operators bring authentic Koreans to this place, then the food must also be authentic. So one day I acted on my curiosity and got me and my family a table. We ordered bul go gi and short ribs. I thought at first that I must have inadvertently ordered too much food, but I realized that this place give a bountiful of portions. We love the food and the service is just right. In fact, on one of our visits, I asked the name of the tea they serve, and the waitress gave me a handful that I can brew at home. That was very kind of her, and I think it shows the kind of place this is. I believe it's a family run restaurant. It has a nice low key family atmosphere. We are not Koreans, but of the Asian persuasion, and just plain San Franciscans (or Peninsulars?), and we felt right at home. Like everyone else, we're always looking for good places to eat, and HIK will appear on our tour destination if we were tour guides. Parking is a drag, but this won't affect this reviewers experience at HIK.
author: Trish P.

description:
love this place , the food is very good , good size portion !!
and kids friendly !!
just make sure you are not there when they have a bus tour coming , better to be there after 6.30 pm !!
author: mark k.

description:
wow.. are you serious?? 
i normally don't write reviews, 
but i'm too surprised at these reviews here. 
i was born and raised in korea for half of my life, 
so i'm sure i know how authentic korean food should taste like. 
i came here with boyfriend one night, because my boyfriend loves korean food and said he found this place. 
the service was very friendly, but i constantly had to raise my hand and ask them for water refills. 
however, the food itself was terrible! 
we didn't try the meat so i won't know how they would be. 
i had seafood dol sot bibim bab, boyfriend had tofu soup, and we ordered a pancake for appetizer. 
honestly, most ive tasted was msg and i had to drink shiton of water that night. 
i couldn't even finish half of my dish.
the banchans were decent, but nothing to rave about.
i think they made a contract with a korean travel agency, because we saw a korean tour bus stopping for dinner.
god those korean tourists musta felt bad for us after tasting the food -_-
bottom line, i was very disappointed at their food, and will not go back . 
ive been to plenty of way better korean restaurants in the bay area. 
one star for their friendly service 
one star for how they can accommodate big groups
author: jamie k.

description: i read a lot of positive reviews on yelp before deciding to come here on a sunday for lunch. we were unlucky that we arrived right before a korean tour bus got there. after we ordered, we waited a good 10min before anyone bothered to give us any water or attention as they were busily handing out bowls of food to the tourists. i just kinda thought we made it easy for them since we ordered to cook our own food at the table and so it shouldn't take too long for them to just hand us some raw meat and turn on our stove.  me and my bf were also disappointed with the side dishes served.  i guess i had higher expectations cuz so many ppl on yelp raved about it, but my bf complained about how the stuff that looked spicy were not spicy at all.  i usually cannot stand spicy stuff but the tofu soup had absolutely no heat whatsoever. the chicken bulgogi was nothing special, same quality as the frozen chicken at costco. for $16.95 i also expected a little more meat because at the korean market in daly city, $6 gets you almost a pound of marinated raw chicken. the beef bulgogi was not high quality either because there were a lot of bits and small pieces.  Brothers in SF and Palace BBQ in santa clara are still my preferred korean bbq locations.
author: thb t.

description: solid good korean food. as good as you would find in sf.  i've had the soondooboo, daen jang jigae, ddak jim and the kimchi bokeum and they were all delicious.  waiters kinda suck but that's always the case at korean joints.  they give you lots of panchan which is good and there never seems to be a wait but it's still packed.  me likes.
author: shar d.

description: i lived in san francisco a few years ago, and had long given up on finding decent korean food in the city. but yesterday i was forced to admit my mistake, upon discovering han II kwan. their kalbi jim is to die for. everything else we ordered, including the seafood pancake, the pork belly, and the dolsot bibimbap was all delicious as well.
author: Rosie W.

description: i went here on a sat night at 8pm and it took forever and day to find parking.  the host said it would be 10 minutes for a table, but it was really more than thirty, so we got the party started with some libations.  obviously the place was PACKED and the service was awful at first.  we ordered DINNER A which comes with two meats, korean seafood pancake (which was substituted for fried potstickers and kimchee pancake), some squid dish (which we substituted for dolsot bibimbap --freaking good!), tofu soup, and japchae. We got the meat in a timely manner, but everything else came out after all the meat was completely eaten!  why 5 stars?  because the food was delicious sans the tofu soup!  i loved the bhanchan (sidedishes) too!  the service got better throughout the night and they even comped us all our drinks (including the alcoholic ones!)  since "we had such a long wait" but really i think it was because they brought out the rest of our food so late.  at any rate, hands down, i would go here again and you should too!
author: Christine K.

description: this is seriously one of the best korean places in the city.  the lunch special is very reasonable (~$10) and the food is gooooood.  they serve more side dishes than most other places (incl.  steamed egg, pancakes and all the other usual stuff)  and the service is always quick and friendly.  they also serve the sweet rice drink at the end of the meal.  non lunch special prices can be a little steep, but their bi bim bap isn't bad.  i wouldn't come here for dinner, but i make it here for lunch every chance i have.  come hungry.
author: Raz R.
